DOC.HEAD: Canadian Officials Hold Talks With Indian Leaders to End Standoff
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers tightened their encirclement of armed Mohawk warriors Wednesday but federal officials met with Indian leaders to try to end the confrontation. About 400 soldiers have surrounded 20 Mohawk warriors and 30 women and children in a small wooded area bordered by a highway and a lake on the Kahnesatake settlement near Oka, 18 miles west of Montreal. On Wednesday, the soldiers ringed the Mohawk stronghold with razor wire, and provincial police set up a floating barricade on the lake to prevent boats from entering or leaving the compound. In Ottawa, native leaders met with federal Indian Affairs Minister Tom Siddon and Solicitor General Pierre Cadieux. Georges Erasmus, head of the Assembly of First Nations, a major Indian group, said both the federal and Quebec governments must get involved in a new round of negotiations to resolve the dispute. Erasmus urged the army to pull back from positions surrounding a detoxification center occupied by the Mohawks. ``What we're concerned about is that an accident will happen or somebody will lose the control they have over themselves,'' Erasmus said. ``Then there will be the exchange of gunfire that nobody in this country wants.'' Quebec Premier Robert Bourassa broke off negotiations last week and ordered the army in to remove barricades set up by Mohawks near Oka and on the Mercier Bridge over the St. Lawrence River linking Montreal with its southern suburbs. On Wednesday night, the Quebec government announced that the Mercier Bridge would be reopened on Thursday morning for the first time since July 11 when Mohawks from the Kahnawake reserve put up barricades in sympathy with the Mohawks in Oka. The bridge's closure caused angry and at times violent demonstrations by local residents who were forced to make long detours to travel to Montreal. The barricades came down last week after the army reached an agreement with the Kahnawake Mohawks. But Mohawks at the Kahnesatake settlement refused to remove their barricades. The army moved in over the weekend to dismantle the barricades and the Indians retreated to the wooded area around the detoxification center. Members of the militant Mohawk Warrior's Society say they won't lay down their arms without a new policing arrangement that would curb the authority of the Quebec provincial police in the settlement. The Mohawks fear reprisals for the death of a police officer killed July 11 in a failed police attempt to remove barricades put up in a dispute over plans by Oka town officials to expand a golf course onto what the Indians say is tribal land. The clash sparked the 2-month-old armed standoff. The dispute over the golf course expansion was solved when the federal government purchased the land and said it would give it to the Indians. But the Mohawks have raised a wider range of grievances, including demands for sovereignty. Also Wednesday, the army decided it will no longer allow food or supplies such as film to reach 15 journalists still inside the Kahnesatake compound. Mohawks, however, are allowed to bring in food. The army said if the journalists decide to leave they won't be allowed back in. When asked why, army spokesman Capt. Yvon Desjardins said, ``It's for their own security. ... They would be more secure if they left.''

DOC.HEAD: Pianist Dies of Apparent Heart Attack During Performance
DOC.TEXT: Feliz Ganz, a pianist and educator in the United States and abroad, suffered an apparent heart attack and died in the middle of a performance, officials said Wednesday. He was 68. Ganz was playing the harpsicord in a two-person recital before about 200 people at Roosevelt University's Chicago Musical College when he was stricken, school officials said. ``He was right in the middle of the concert when he slumped over the keyboard,'' said Earl Schub, dean of Chicago Musical College. ``It was, as you can imagine, a very unbelievable sight and very shocking.'' He was pronounced dead at Northwestern Memorial Hospital at 2:17 p.m., a hospital administrator said. Ganz was a part-time professor of keyboard and of music history. He was born in Basel, Switzerland, and emigrated to the United States in 1947 after graduating from the University of Basel. He received a masters degree from Chicago Musical College in 1948 and a doctorate from Northwestern University in 1960. Ganz was dean of Chicago Musical College from 1970 to 1981 and served as a part-time professor and professor emeritus after his retirement in 1988. He judged musical competitions, served as a lecturer and contributed articles to music journals.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Buy Pebble Beach Company
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 2nd graf pvs, `Ben Hogan...' to UPDATE with $543 loan taken to finance purchase.
DOC.TEXT: The famed Pebble Beach Golf course and associated resorts were sold Wednesday to a Japanese-owned company, the buyer announced. Ben Hogan Properties, which is owned by Japan's Cosmo World Corp., announced it bought Pebble Beach Co., one of California's most expensive real estate holdings, with top-class golf courses and resorts on Monterey Bay. The price paid to the private partnership that owns Pebble Beach wasn't disclosed. A $543 million loan was taken out to finance the deal, according to papers filed in the county recorder's office. Pebble Beach Co. owns and operates two luxury resorts and several prestigious golf courses _ the Pebble Beach Golf Links, The Lodge at Pebble Beach and the Inn and Links at Spanish Bay. It also owns Spyglass Hill and Del Monte Golf Courses, 17-Mile Drive and substantial amounts of real estate on the Monterey Peninsula south of San Francisco. ``We are committed to operating Pebble Beach at the same high standards that everyone has come to expect of this world class property,'' David B. Hueber, president of Ben Hogan Properties, said in a news release. Company officials said they didn't expect to change the resort area's ``the management personnel or management style.''

DOC.HEAD: Gene Cloned for Brain Protein, May Help Improve Schizophrenia Drugs
DOC.TEXT: Scientists said today they had cloned a gene that helps brain cells communicate, a step that may someday help in treating schizophrenia, Parkinson's disease and other brain disorders. The gene tells brain cells how to make a structure called a dopamine receptor, which receives a chemical messenger called dopamine that brain cells send one another. Hyperactivity in this communication system may cause at least some schizophrenia symptoms, and evidence suggests the hyperactivity may result from abnormalities in dopamine receptors, commented Dr. Lewis Judd, director of the National Institute of Mental Health. The discovery will aid research into identifying receptor abnormalities and the effect they have on brain cells, Judd said. The gene is for the so-called D1 dopamine receptor. The gene for the other major kind of dopamine receptor, called D2, was cloned in 1988. The new work is reported in today's issue of the British journal Nature by three teams of scientists. The finding may someday let doctors diagnose schizophrenia and Parkinson's before symptoms appear by identifying receptor abnormalities, said Allen Dearry, a member of one of the research teams. That could allow earlier treatment with greater chance of success, he said. Parkinson's is a potentially disabling condition that can include tremors, rigidity and gradual loss of spontaneous movement. Further work may also pave the way for better drugs to treat psychosis, the loss of touch with reality seen in schizophrenia, said Dearry, of the Duke University Medical Center in Durham, N.C. Scientists may be able to distinguish variants of the receptor and design drugs to act only on those variants that affect psychosis while avoiding variants that produce side effects, he said. Most current standard anti-psychosis drugs include a risk of such side effects as tardive dyskinesia, a syndrome of involuntary movements that can affect the mouth, tongue, arms, leg or trunk. Dearry's group included scientists at Duke and the Howard Hughes Medical Institute Laboratories there. Another group reporting the gene cloning is from the Oregon Health Sciences University in Portland, and the third group is from the University of Toronto, Ontario, Canada, the National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke in Bethesda, Md., the Yale University School of Medicine, the Hospital for Sick Children in Toronto and the Addiction Research Foundation in Toronto.

DOC.HEAD: Venus Mapping to Start Even if Magellan Woes Aren't Understood
With PM-Space Shuttle, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: NASA says Magellan's $744 million mission to map the rugged surface of Venus will begin later this month even if engineers can't figure out why they twice lost radio contact with the spacecraft. ``We're not willing to wait to understand what happened,'' Magellan experiment representative Steve Wall at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory said Wednesday. Magellan went into orbit around Venus on Aug. 10 after a looping, 948-million-mile trip that began when the spacecraft was launched from the shuttle Atlantis 16 months ago. Magellan made its first pictures of Venus during an Aug. 16 test but lost touch with Earth that night for 14 hours and lost contact again for 17{ hours starting Aug. 21. Engineers will continue trying to determine the cause of the failures, but computer commands being sent to Magellan should enable engineers to restore contact quickly if it is lost again, Wall said. Magellan is designed to use radar to peer through Venus' thick clouds and make the most detailed maps and pictures yet of the planet's deformed surface. The communications trouble delayed the start of mapping last week. Officials expect to start the mapping sometime late this month, Wall said. Magellan and Venus are about 153 million miles from Earth. The spaceship's initial pictures showed long faults, other areas crisscrossed by many faults in a pattern resembling broken automobile safety glass, solidified lava flows, volcanic cinder cones, meteorite impact craters and extensive valleys and ridges.

DOC.HEAD: At Black Sea Resort, Sand Curtain Separates Elite From Soviet Masses
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: A 10-foot-high concrete barrier separates the elite from the masses on the beach of this Black Sea resort, illustrating the Soviet Union's failure to achieve a classless society. The wall starts in the water and runs over the sand to separate the Riviera, a public beach, from a vast playground reserved for those with position and influence. No one seems to know the name of the private beach or the names of those who use it. Little is known of the services provided, but the sheer size of the sanctum raises eyebrows. On an average day, 15,000 people must crowd onto a public beach only 750 yards long, while about 500 of the upper crust loll on an expanse that stretches more than half a mile. Arkady Melkonyan, a state television correspondent, cited the figures in a recent broadcast. Like Melkonyan, some citizens are indignant. Others shrug it off. ``The Martians live differently than we; why shouldn't they?'' Valery Skripnik, a 40-year-old gardener, said on the Riviera beach. He spoke between chin-ups on an exercise bar. There is increasing criticism of reserving beaches, quality medical care, luxury apartments, special planes and stores for Communist Party and government officials in a country where ordinary people live in cramped housing and stand in line for food and other necessities. Some politicians, most notably Boris Yeltsin, president of the Russian republic, have won wide popular support by attacking privilege. Dozens of country homes have been converted from private residences for the elite to public rest homes. The newspaper Rabochaya Tribuna reported Aug. 8 that the number of aircraft reserved for the privileged had been drastically reduced. Those who are more equal than others have a strong grip on Sochi, however, and few of its facilities have gone public. Melkonyan told viewers that, of the resort area's 151 beaches, only 22 were open to ordinary people. In addition to the reserved beaches, Sochi has elaborate private resort complexes, known in Russian as sanatoriums. They do not appear on maps, are generally visible only from the sea and are heavily guarded. Down the beach from the Actors' Sanatorium and Pravda Sanatorium, spas for actors and journalists, is the Dzerzhinsky Sanatorium, the summer hideaway of KGB agents named for Felix Dzerzhinsky, who founded the Soviet secret police. It begins at the seaside with a covered patio adorned with tall, ornate yellow arches and white columns. An elevator takes vacationers up a hill to a main building tucked into a thickly wooded area. Exclusive beachfront facilities nearby include a small yellow villa with white arches that was favored by Lavrenti Beria, dictator Josef Stalin's chief of secret police. Farther along the Black Sea coast are the dachas, as the villas are called, of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov and Anatoly I. Lukyanov. At least two resorts have been partly opened to the public after decades of catering to the elite. The 180-acre Green Grove resort, once reserved for Communist Party officials, received automotive workers from Gorky and steelworkers from Magnitogorsk last year, director Ludmilla Voblikova reported. Staffs of Communist Party schools, from janitors to instructors, spend vacations at the complex on a wooded hill overlooking the sea. Voblikova has run the place since 1958, when privilege was not questioned. She proclaimed allegiance to the new policy, but said: ``I think we should all work well, and the better we work, the better we should live.'' At nearby Lenin Sanitorium, the splendor formerly saved for Communist Party officials now is available to workers from collective farms. They live in a gray marble dormitory, built in 1984, that has clean, carpeted, well-furnished rooms. An older building erected in the 1950s has an ``Italian courtyard'' with colored tile, white columns and an ornate fountain. In the main dining room are glass chandeliers, white marble columns and parquet floors.

DOC.HEAD: How Hot Has The Summer Been? Well, Did You Hear The One About ...
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: So you think it's been a hot summer where you live? Pity the folks in Nebraska, where it's been so hot farmers have had to feed their chickens cracked ice to keep them from laying hard-boiled eggs. Talk about hot _ an Iowa farmer says the sun was so intense one day his cornfield exploded into fluffy white clouds of popcorn. His cattle thought it was snowing and froze solid on the spot. Sure, everyone complains about the weather, but one man has finally done something about it. Fred Pfister, an English professor at College of the Ozarks in Point Lookout, has compiled a list of tall weather tales _ he calls them ``weather windies'' _ that he's heard on his travels around the country. Pfister, a native of Missouri's Ozarks, began jotting down outrageous weather sayings ``just for kicks'' about 20 years ago. He spins the best of the 50 or 60 weather windies in his repertoire at speaking engagements around the region. ``When you're from the hills and you're out in the flatlands, the natives like to pull your leg a little bit,'' he said. ``People always exaggerate about the weather.'' Pfister's found that to be especially true in the Midwest. ``It seems as if everybody in the Midwest likes to think that their weather is unique,'' he said. ``I suppose it is, in a way. I don't think people on the East and West coasts need to worry as much about tornadoes as they do in the Midwest.'' Talking about the weather is ``always a good way to jump-start a conversation,'' Pfister said. ``I'm not sure why people like to talk about the weather,'' he said. ``Maybe it's a neutral subject. You're not going to offend anyone if you talk about the weather. You're not going to seem nosy or anything.'' Pfister says he enjoys playing the straight man for old-timers, gas station attendants, store clerks or anyone else who can add to his collection of weather windies. An Arkansan transplanted in Texas once told Pfister that comfortable summer days in Dallas are as rare as rocking-horse manure. ``I love that one,'' he said. The same Nebraskan who told Pfister the story about feeding ice to chickens complained that rivers had gotten so dry catfish were coming up to homes to beg a drink of water. A North Dakota native claimed it gets so cold in his state in winter that words freeze in people's mouths and they have to wait until spring to find out what everyone's been talking about. An Oklahoman swears that the wind blows so hard in the Sooner state that there was a calm day once and everyone fell down. And South Dakotans and Minnesotans alike gripe that their states have nine months of winter and three months of bad sledding. ``All these sayings don't do you any good, but they're kind of nice things to know at parties,'' Pfister quipped.

DOC.HEAD: Recluse Who Destroyed Her Past Leaves Fortune And 31 Claimants
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
With LaserPhoto sent Aug. 5.
DOC.TEXT: Before she died in January, Dorothea Allen destroyed family papers and letters and tore the date and place of birth from her passport. She left more than $2.8 million in cash, no traceable next of kin, no will, no birth certificate, no marriage certificate, and a growing list of claimants to her fortune. So far, 31 people have come forward, claiming to be heirs of the woman known in British newspapers as ``the vanishing lady.'' By law, claimants have 12 years to prove they are blood relatives. If they fail, the fortune goes to the state treasury. Treasury lawyers ordered the sale of her effects, including mink coats, a 1972 Rolls-Royce Corniche and a 1964 Daimler, jewelry, paintings, furniture, silver and other trappings from a glamorous past that by some accounts included a trip across the dance floor with Fred Astaire. The sale, conducted Tuesday by Sotheby's at her 300-year-old home, added $1.08 million cash to the estate. The home itself, in the village of Sutton-under-Brailes 90 miles northwest of London, is expected to fetch another $1.3 million when it is sold. According to Sotheby's, the latest claimant to come forward is Wilfried Kluber from Baden-Baden, West Germany, who says his grandmother was Mrs. Allen's sister. Kluber told Sotheby's that his grandmother's maiden name was Farquharson, and that Mrs. Allen was born in 1901. His letter has been passed along to the treasury, Sotheby's said. The Times of London said another claimant is Merilyn Horton of Cleveland, Ohio. It reported that Mrs. Horton says her great-grandfather was a Scottish immigrant named Farquharson. Chris Proudlove of Sotheby's said that after a crash in her chauffeur-driven Rolls-Royce in the early 1980s, Mrs. Allen became a recluse in her home, Sutton Brailes Manor. Her husband, Eric Allen, died in 1965. News reports said the fortune came from a corset factory they set up in 1927 in nearby Banbury. ``She deliberately tried to obliterate her past... I think she was of lowly birth, married into money but had a business head on her shoulders. I think she wanted to be remembered as the rich lady of the manor,'' Proudlove said. The Times said other reported theories were that she was a half-Belgian ex-nun, an American cabaret dancer or even Allen's sister. But The Independent said former employees and neighbors scoffed at rumors of an incestuous marriage. The Times quoted John Lee of the treasury lawyers' office as saying: ``So far we only have a passport indicating a maiden name of Farquharson, but the details of date and place of birth have been destroyed.'' Hoping to solve the mystery, Sotheby's on Aug. 24 organized a tea party on the lawn at Sutton Brailes Manor for former staff. ``She destroyed her past so successfully I don't think anybody will ever discover the real truth,'' said Leslie Stratford, 82, who was her accountant. Muriel Keyte, 73, who was also at the tea party, said Tuesday that she was Allen's only child by his first marriage. She believed his second marriage, to Dorothea, was bigamous. The Daily Telegraph on Wednesday quoted unidentified former employees as saying Mrs. Allen was a factory worker who eloped with Allen after he abandoned his wife and children. News reports said that in the 1930s, the couple enjoyed a champagne lifestyle, with luxury apartments in London, a beachfront estate in Barbados as well as Sutton Brailes Manor. Among the stories of their past _ none of them verified _ were tales of her dancing with Astaire on one of the couple's frequent visits to Paris. In her old age, servants recalled, she used to call for a cup of tea by setting off the burglar alarm.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Corporate Chiefs to Help Soviets With Fundamentals
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Lead prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: The 15 chiefs of U.S. corporations going to the Soviet Union this weekend with Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher plan to offer American know-how on such fundamental items as efficient housing and transporting goods. ``It's kind of back to the basics ... You walk up a stairway in a Soviet building and none of the steps are the same. They can't even finish a floor flat, things you and I take for granted,'' said Mark Hungerford, chairman and chief executive officer of Tanscisco Industries Inc. of San Francisco, a rail car company. ``They can get rockets to the moon, so it's not like they're incapable, but they've never focused on these things before,'' Hungerford said. He is one of 15 chief executive officers of U.S. companies scheduled to leave for Moscow on Saturday for a week-long visit to discuss what kind of ``technical assistance'' the United States can give the Soviet Union. Mosbacher and the business leaders are set to leave on the eve of President Bush's summit with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The administration said Wednesday that it would take a fresh look at economic aid for the Soviet Union in light of Moscow's ``real and very helpful support'' in the Persian Gulf. At the economic summit of industrial nations in Houston last July, the administration balked at providing the Soviet Union with cash grants or loans but agreed to provide the technical assistance. About 80 other nations receive American technical assistance, which can range from developing a fly-resistant wheat in Morocco to bringing down Bangladesh's fertility rate. The Soviets need help with improving their transportation systems and housing, said business leaders who will make the trip. Several officers of U.S. oil companies are also accompanying Mosbacher. ``Big chunks of money are not what they want. They want to have the exposure to the management techniques and construction techniques and operating techniques that we take for granted,'' Hungerford said. Hungerford's company, for example, is engaged in a joint venture with the Soviets to help them with a heating system for tank rail cars that performs well in cold climates. His firm also is helping the Soviets improve their transportation of petrochemical products. Another transportation company, Sea-Land Service Inc., of Edison, N.J. _ will be represented by its chief executive, Alex J. Mandl. Sea-Land specializes in ``global distribution networks.'' Mandl said the trip gives him a chance to help both Bush and his company. ``That part of the world is opening up. As long as the Iron Curtain was up, our distribution network did not participate in that part of the world. As that wall comes down, we have a chance to be in there,'' Mandl said. Leonard Sylk, chairman and chief executive officer of Shelter Systems Group of Hainesport, N.J., said the Soviets have been interested in his firm's expertise because it makes manufactured housing components. They are the roofs, floors and walls that large-scale builders use in putting up houses. The Soviets have voiced interest in using wood for housing, as in the United States, rather than the concrete and cinder blocks now used, Sylk said. U.S. businesses stand to gain if the Soviet economy improves, the executives said. ``It's in our interest as a nation to help them at least get into the last part of the 20th century. They say to make peace is to make prosperity, and vice versa,'' Hungerford said. Other companies to be represented on the trip are, according to government sources, are: Archer-Daniels-Midland Co. of Decatur, Ill.; Atlantic Richfield Co. of Los Angeles; Chevron Corp., of San Francisco; Dresser Industries of Dallas; Fortune Magazine of New York; Glenair International of Del Mar, Calif. Also, the Louisiana Land and Exploration Co. of New Orleans; PaineWebber of New York; Pepsico Inc. of Purchase, N.Y.; Pruet Oil Co., of El Dorado, Ark.; Texaco Inc., of White Plains N.Y.; and United Telecommunications of Westwood, Kan.

DOC.HEAD: Diplomat Turned Foreign Secretary Plays it Like An Old Hand
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMsd report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Forthright, steely and calm, Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd is playing the central role in Britain's involvement in the Persian Gulf crisis like an old hand. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who appointed Hurd less than a year ago, has been content for the most part to let him speak for the government _ a role she had usually reserved for herself. Appearing daily on British television newscasts, Hurd turns up in capitals from London to Riyadh, stylishly berating Saddam Hussein, talking of giving sanctions a chance while preparing for war, and prodding Iraq to release Western hostages. ``This is a cat-and-mouse game _ now a little mercy, now some more ruthlessness,'' Hurd said after the Iraqi president, tousling the hair of a 5-year-old British hostage, said he would let women and children go. ``And of course it's quite unacceptable.'' Hurd, 60, began his working life as a diplomat, then turned to politics and writing. He is probably the first British foreign secretary whose qualifications include fluency in Mandarin Chinese. Hurd was appointed in October, just three months after the humiliation of having his previous post as home secretary offered to others in a Cabinet shuffle. Hurd appeared a safe choice for the Foreign Office post. For him, it was the fulfillment of an ambition cherished through a long political career. Some analysts predicted trouble between the patrician-sounding Hurd and Mrs. Thatcher, who is traditionally suspicious of the Foreign Office with its upper-crust style and its instincts for compromise and conciliation. But for the first time since she led the Conservative Party back to power in 1979, Mrs. Thatcher is letting someone else is do most of the talking in a crisis. Commented the pro-conservative Daily Telegraph: ``Hurd simply conveys a strong sense of unvarnished quality which avoids slipping over into dullness.'' Hurd is an old-fashioned Tory from the paternalistic, benign, center-left wing of the party that Mrs. Thatcher overthrew in 1975. The son and grandson of Conservative members of Parliament, Hurd was educated at Eton and Cambridge, where he took a first-class honors degree in history. He joined the diplomatic service in 1952. While posted in Rome, he wrote the first of five published thrillers. At the age of 36, Hurd quit a fast-moving diplomatic career for politics. For six years he was political secretary to Edward Heath, the man Mrs. Thatcher ousted as party leader in 1975. Mrs. Thatcher gave him his first Cabinet job, as Northern Ireland Secretary, a decade later. As foreign secretary, Hurd appears to have succeeded in locking Mrs. Thatcher into a commitment to link the pound to other European currencies and to have generally oiled Britain's often prickly relations with the rest of the European Community. Only five years younger than Mrs. Thatcher, Hurd seemed to have reached his political zenith before the gulf crisis. He has talked of spending more time with his wife, Judith, his former secretary whom he married after a 1982 divorce, and their two small children. There are three adults sons by the first marriage. His name is also mentioned as a serious contender to succeed Mrs. Thatcher. The speculation does not hurt a politician who, unlike some of Mrs. Thatcher's prominent aides, manages to be loyal without appearing cowed. ``She likes an argument,'' Hurd said recently of Mrs. Thatcher. ``Some people find it difficult to argue with a woman prime minister, so they rather tend to shrivel up and feel resentful. The answer is actually to argue back. You'll find yourself being contradicted and sometimes told you don't know what you are talking about. But if you persevere .. you gain ground.''

DOC.HEAD: Diplomats: Iraq Can Survive Sanctions for One Year
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: U.N. sanctions enforced by American warships are chipping away at Iraq's war-hardened economy, but some Western analysts fear it could take a year to force any real concessions. Time could be an ally for Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, who is constantly probing for weak links that will enable him to break the embargo and the international solidarity behind it. The sanctions, imposed after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, are beginning to bite in Baghdad, however. Iraq now rations some basic foods. There are shortages and growing bread lines, some with hundreds of people waiting more than four hours. Western diplomats say Iraq can survive for months and perhaps indefinitely on its own food stockpiles and production from this year's expected bumber crop yields. ``The embargo on food is wishful thinking on the part of the West,'' said one diplomat, who like others spoke on condition of anonymity. The Iraqis, he said, are resilient people, pragmatic and accustomed to hardships after eight years of war with Iran. ``They could effectively feed themselves on a basic level indefinitely,'' the senior diplomat said. Another Western diplomat agreed, saying Iraq has enough food to ``comfortably survive for three months, perhaps more.'' The real bite of sanctions, they say, will be felt in the high-tech industry and infrastructure of this nation, which has relied on Western technology and expertise. ``It's hard to see how all these industrial items they are used to can get in,'' the senior diplomat said. ``One can imagine the whole 20th century economy of this place is collapsing or about to collapse.'' Iraq relies on imports, spare parts and components no longer available because of the sanctions. One European diplomat noted some areas have experienced brief power cuts, perhaps a sign of some technical problems in Iraqi generating capacity. ``The state-controlled media has advised people to conserve fuel. We take that as evidence of official worry about how the refineries are holding out,'' he said. Still, diplomats predict the embargo will take months to cripple the country. ``It may be a year before it hurts Saddam Hussein enough to make concessions,'' said one. Some Western diplomats also fear that Saddam will persuade poor, weaker countries to abandon the sanctions. ``He has been successful,'' a diplomat said. ``There are certain countries that are weaker, that cannot resist the situation ... the blackmail, the hostages, the promises of future deals.'' He refused to identify the countries. The diplomats said the level of the sanctions-busting is insignificant so far, and that the economic blockade will be effective if maintained. ``Export sanctions are very effective. I can't imagine them flying out planeloads of crude oil,'' the senior diplomat said. ``Iraq's creditworthiness is near zero. The money is running out.'' Private contractors said they have shut down or mothballed projects in Iraq and that many companies may be reluctant to come back. Some of their workers have been detained by the Iraqis for violating their contracts. Many foreign workers who perform menial tasks also have fled, and piles of garbage now litter some neighborhoods. One Iraqi said it was an unusual sight, caused by the exodus of Egyptian workers. Some Iraqis say they believe shortages caused by the sanctions, especially food lines, could lead to street violence. But diplomats here discount any hope that Saddam will be toppled by a popular revolt. ``Opposition is just wishful thinking,'' one said. ``There is no opposition in Iraq.'' Saddam's portrait smiles down from buildings and billboards all over the city. His name is attached to everything from monuments to the airport. Dissent is crushed ruthlessly, and the state-controlled media hails the achievements of the president, portraying him as the leader of the Arab masses who has defied the superpowers. ``The propaganda machine works perfectly in this country,'' said one Western diplomat. ``It is like the Soviet Union under Stalin in the 1930s, the people genuinely believe the propaganda.'' ``They believe it in their hearts,'' said another. Saddam, they argue, is strong, firmly in control and enjoying the genuine support of at least half the population. While desperately seeking for ways to break the sanctions, government ministries are working overtime looking for ways to increase production of essentials. The government is making loans to farmers and providing fertilizer free of charge, one diplomat said. It has instituted rationing, one said, to play up the dramatic effects of the embargo as well as to conserve food and to guarantee a constant if reduced flow of some foods. ``Rationing appeals to the soft hearts of other countries,'' the diplomat said. But the senior diplomat noted the U.N. sanctions permit the delivery of food and medicine when necessary, and he doubted they would become the biggest weapons of the embargo. ``When people start dying who will deny them food or medicine? Will President Bush be able to deny it to a dying child?'' he asked.

DOC.BYLINE: Relief Agencies Sending Food, Water, Planning Airlifts
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf-US Relief-List
DOC.TEXT: The private relief agency AmeriCares says it's sending food, water and medicine to refugees stranded in Jordan. In Washington, the American Red Cross reports it is stepping up its relief efforts in Jordan, Egypt and other countries trying to cope with exodus of people fleeing Iraq and Kuwait. Besides chartered flights carrying food and supplies, the American Red Cross has donated $75,000 to the International Red Cross to use in relief activities in Jordan and Egypt, officials said Wednesday. The Catholic Relief Services in Baltimore said it has donated $25,000 to buy tents for the thousand of evacuees stranded in Jordan. The first AmeriCares airlift, scheduled for Saturday, will take 75,000 pounds of supplies to Jordan, where hundreds of thousands of Asians fleeing Iraq and Kuwait have crowded desert camps with no food, water or money, said Steve Norman, spokesman for AmeriCares. Temperatures soar during daytime and plunge after dark. Airlifts will continue as long as necessary, Norman said. The New Canaan-based agency also might help fly the refugees home. ``We are not normally people-ferriers,'' he said. ``But if we can arrange for access to help people get out and if people think it's appropriate, I think we might extend our relief effort in that area as well.'' Asian refugees were pouring into Jordan at a rate of 10,000 a day, relief officials said Tuesday, adding the number could reach 1 million within a week or two. More than 420,000 refugees have traveled to Jordan since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, causing a massive strain on Jordan's social services. In Egypt, the Red Cross estimated 161,000 people had arrived by Monday. On Tuesday, fights broke out in one Jordan camp as Jordanian troops tried to distribute food rations of one piece of flat Arab bread, one tomato and one cucumber per person, AmeriCares said. The organization would send non-perishable food such as wafers, nutrition bars, and ``survival-type'' packaged food, Norman said. The Red Cross said over-crowding of refugees was a major concern. ``The International Red Cross has been working in Jordan for the past two weeks, and according to relief workers, the conditions for the new arrivals are deteriorating,'' said Steve Richards, executive vice president of the American Red Cross. ``It is urgent that the refugees be evacuated away from the border area as soon as possible.'' The organization said some refugees have had little water, food and shelter for periods of up to three days. The Red Cross chartered planes to fly into Amman, Jordan, carrying milk, babyfood, food for adults, family-size tents and other survival items. A flight later this week will bring the total of aid provided by the International Red Cross to Jordanian Red Crescent refugee relief programs to 350 tons, officials said. On Tuesday, Jordan's Crown Prince Hassan criticized the international community for not doing enough. ``I don't think we had any idea of how we would do it without the cooperation of the Jordanians, and I think until recently ... they really weren't communicating with anyone,'' Norman said. The international aid group Operation USA appealed Wednesday for money and bulk donations of food, medicine and shelters for the refugees, citizens of Bangladesh, India, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, the Philippines and Thailand. The effort by Los Angeles-based Operation USA came as the United Nations requested international help for the foreigners who have fled to Jordan. InterAction, an independent coalition of private, voluntary agencies which provide humanitarian assistance abroad, had several member agencies that were accepting donations of cash for the refugees. The agencies include: American Red Cross, AmeriCares Foundation, Church World Service, Direct Relief International, Lutheran World Relief, Operation USA, Save The Children, World Concern, World Relief, and World Vision.
