DOC.HEAD: Pontiff Calls For Compassion for Africa's AIDS Victims
By STEPHEN R. WILSON
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II, visiting a region ravaged by AIDS, has declared that the disease is a moral issue that calls for changes in sexual behavior. The pope, who traveled to this tiny mountainous country on the fifth day of a 10-day African trip, said AIDS is a pandemic which must not be treated solely as a medical problem. He stressed its ``implications of a moral and anthropological character.'' ``The epidemic differs from so many others that humanity has known in that specific human behavior plays a role in its spread,'' John Paul said in the speech Wednesday to Burundi's bishops. ``It is linked, directly or not, to the transmission of life and love.'' The first big landmark on the pope's drive from the airport to the city was a 90-foot-wide sign warning against the dangers of AIDS spread by permissive sex in polygamous African societies. ``The Burundi society, like many others in the world, is exposed to a grave danger,'' the pope said. ``I am talking about the pandemic of AIDS which afflicts a number of your compatriots, especially young adults, and it is painful to state it, little children.'' John Paul said AIDS, or acquired immune deficiency syndrome, poses major challenges for the church, such as informing and educating people about the disease while making sure the problem ``is not treated at the expense of the (moral) ethic.'' He said the church has a duty to assist AIDS sufferers, not only with health care but with ``psychological and spiritual assistance'' for those with an acute form of the illness and those who carry the virus. ``These people often tend to close themselves in an anguished silence,'' he said. ``They need a fraternal presence to give them the courage to accept their condition.'' It was the second time the pope has spoken about the deadly disease during his four-nation African tour. In Tanzania last week, he called for a global effort to combat the disease and reaffirmed the church's rejection of the use of condoms as a means to check the spread of AIDS. The World Health Organization estimates that 5 million Africans are infected with the virus that can cause AIDS. AIDS is most often transmitted through sexual contact. The virus attacks the body's immune system, leaving victims susceptible to a wide variety of infections and cancers. John Paul began his three-day visit to Burundi by urging forgiveness and reconciliation in this country with a long history of tribal warfare. He flew to the country on Wednesday from Tanzania. The pope, on his seventh visit to Africa, will also travel to to Rwanda and the Ivory Coast, where he will end his tour Monday by consecrating the massive basilica of Our Lady of Peace.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Crisis, Uncertain Economy Skew Budget Talks
DOC.TEXT: White House and congressional budget negotiators have agreed on almost nothing during three contentious months of bargaining. And now that they are about to resume discussions, Saddam Hussein has made the job even harder. Iraq's conquest of oil-rich Kuwait has meant higher fuel costs, and that has threatened to further slow the already sputtering U.S. economy. Dispatching American troops to Saudi Arabia has driven up Pentagon spending. Those changed economic and political circumstances will complicate efforts to shrink the federal deficit when administration officials and congressional leaders resume budget talks on Friday. In preparation, House Democrats and Republicans held separate budget sessions Wednesday and planned additional sessions today. ``We're working on a Democratic plan,'' House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., tersely told reporters when he emerged from a lengthy afternoon session. White House budget director Richard Darman met with Republican lawmakers, meantime. Darman said little about that meeting but expressed concern that the red-ink problem will be further complicated by the costs of the Persian Gulf operation and the slowing U.S. economy. The budget talks broke off five weeks ago for Congress' August recess. ``The world we left Aug. 4 is not the same as the world we'll see on Sept. 7,'' said Rep. Newt Gingrich, R-Ga., one of the negotiators. Yet the bargainers have precious little time left to work out a budget deal. The new fiscal year starts Oct. 1. Unless a pact is enacted, the Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law will trigger more than $100 billion in spending cuts to most federal programs _ a staggering amount _ that day. With that in mind, the negotiators' goal is to work out a package of tax increases and spending cuts by Monday. Their sessions _ at Andrews Air Force Base in suburban Maryland _ may be so lengthy that bargainers say they may sleep overnight at the base to give themselves more working time. ``Sometimes the will for a solution comes collectively when you know you're down to the short strokes,'' said another participant, Sen. Bob Packwood, R-Ore. Before the talks recessed, bargainers had reached a consensus on one thing: the need for a package that saves about $50 billion next year and $500 billion over five years. Now, negotiators disagree over how much savings are desirable. It is possible they will settle for a smaller plan, particularly for next year. Some lawmakers say they want to stick to the initial $50 billion-$500 billion formula. They argue that with a limp economy, there is more reason than ever to take a substantial whack at the budget gap, which could be a record $230 billion or more next year unless something is done. ``We have to make a decision about whether a deficit-reduction package is important to this country,'' said House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif. ``I still think it is.'' Others say reductions in the range of $30 billion to $40 billion may be preferable for next year because the weak economy shouldn't be shocked by even deeper cuts. ``You don't need a Ph.D. in economics to figure out if you have slow economic growth and you cut $50 billion out of the economy at that point, what you do is go right into the hole you've been slipping into,'' said William Gray of Pennsylvania, the third-ranking House Democrat. Administration officials said as recently as Tuesday that they still think $50 billion in savings is the best goal for next year, although they are willing to listen to proposals for smaller targets. Lawmakers who have spoken to White House aides say that could drop to perhaps $35 billion. The Iraqi invasion has also caused bargainers to look differently at some likely components of a deficit-cutting package. Higher oil prices will make it harder for the negotiators to agree to new energy taxes, which before August seemed a likely part of any compromise. The showdown in the gulf has also provided new ammunition to opponents of deep defense cuts. Some Republicans say the confrontation with Iraq shows that the military must remain strong, despite the waning of the Cold War. Democrats, who have been looking for Pentagon reductions in the $9 billion to $16 billion range, counter that any additional defense spending needed in the Middle East can be more than compensated for by cuts in U.S. military expenditures in Europe. Despite their divisions, bargainers say they are guardedly optimistic that they will make a deal. ``With the combination of the military and economic crisis and the budget crisis and the sequester (Gramm-Rudman spending cuts), the members of this summit are going to feel they can't just walk out _ I hope,'' said Panetta.

DOC.HEAD: Questions Asked in Sex Knowledge Survey
With PM-Sex Test, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents.
DOC.TEXT: Here are the questions about sexual knowledge asked in a new national survey designed by the Kinsey Institute. The questions were multiple choice or true-false. They are followed by the correct answer. 1. Nowadays, what do you think is the age at which the average or typical American first has sexual intercourse? Answer: 16 or 17. 2. Out of every 10 married American men, how many would you estimate have had an extramarital afair _ that is, have been sexually unfaithful to their wives? Answer: three or four. 3. Out of every 10 American women, how many would you estimate have had anal (rectal) intercourse? Answer: three or four. 4. A person can get AIDS by having anal (rectal) intercourse even if neither partner is infected with the AIDS virus. Answer: False. 5. There are over-the-counter spermicides people can buy at the drugstore that will kill the AIDS virus. Answer: True. 6. Petroleum jelly, Vaseline Intensive Care, baby oil and Nivea are not good lubricants to use with a condom or diaphragm. Answer: True. 7. More than one out of four (25 percent) of American men have had a sexual experience with another male during either their teens or adult years. Answer: True. 8. It is usually difficult to tell whether people are or are not homosexual just by their appearance or gestures. Answer: True. 9. A woman or teen-age girl can get pregnant during her menstrual flow (her ``period''). Answer: True. 10. A woman or teen-age girl can get pregnant even if the man withdraws his penis before he ejaculates (before he ``comes.'') Answer: True. 11. Unless they are having sex, women do not need to have regular gynecological examinations. Answer: False. 12. Teen-age boys should examine their testicles (``balls'') regularly just as women self-examine their breasts for lumps. Answer: True. 13. Problems with erections are most often started by a physical problem. Answer: True. 14. Almost all erection problems can be successfully treated. Answer: True. 15. Menopause, or change of life as it is often called, does not cause most women to lose interest in having sex. Answer: True. 16. Out of every 10 American women, how many would you estimate have masturbated either as children or after they were grown up? Answer: Six to eight. 17. What do you think is the average length of a man's erect penis? Answer: Five to seven inches. 18. Most women prefer a sexual partner with a larger-than-average penis. Answer: False. Note: Score one point for every correct answer. Any answer earned a point on question 5 because some people may have misinterpreted it, the poll report said. People scoring 16 or better get an ``A,'' 14 or 15 a ``B,'' 12 or 13 a ``C,'' 10 or 11 a ``D,'' and fewer points an ``F,'' according to the poll.

DOC.HEAD: Little-Known Rescuer of Hungarian Jews is Honored 45 Years Later
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: An elderly Italian man is being plucked from 45 years of obscurity to be toasted at a black-tie dinner as an unsung World War II hero who rescued thousands of Hungarian Jews from death in the Holocaust. Unlike Raoul Wallenberg, the celebrated Swedish diplomat who saved tens of thousands of Jews in wartime Budapest, retired businessman Giorgio Perlasca and his perilous exploits were virtually unknown in the United States until very recently. Tonight, all that will change. Hundreds of Italian-Americans will gather to watch Perlasca, 80, receive the Medal of Remembrance from the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Council. The council, a federal agency, is overseeing construction of a privately financed, $147 million Holocaust museum near the National Mall. Perlasca, who made his first trip to the United States from his modest home in Padua, Italy, for the occasion, will receive the medal from Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia. He is the first recipient of the award, established to honor individuals who displayed extraordinary heroism and acts of courage during the Holocaust, in which 6 million Jews were slaughtered by Nazi Germany. ``In this sea of darkness, there were flickers of light from a few people,'' said Miles Lerman, the council's chairman for international relations, who learned of Perlasca during a visit to Budapest last year. ``There weren't many who cared to step forward while other good people stood idly by and did nothing,'' Lerman said. ``But their choices made the difference between life and death. In the total darkness of cruelty and indifference, they found that goodness has a power of its own, and they became beacons of light who redeemed mankind.'' Perlasca, who dislikes publicity and dismisses any mention of his personal heroism, speaks modestly of his wartime mission of mercy. Others would have done the same, he said. ``I always say, the opportunity makes a thief,'' Perlasca said, speaking through an interpreter. ``My opportunity was there, and I took it. Maybe those who remained silent didn't have the opportunity.'' During the three months from October 1944 until Soviet troops liberated Budapest in January 1945, Perlasca masqueraded as a Spanish diplomat and arranged safe haven for an estimated 5,200 Jews who had been given phony ``letters of protection'' by the Spanish legation in the Hungarian capital. Some experts say Perlasca was responsible for saving more than 10,000 Jews, most of them women, children and the elderly, from certain death by Hungarian Nazi thugs until Soviet liberators arrived. Perlasca was the Budapest representative of an import-export company in Rome that supplied meat to the Italian army. When dictator Benito Mussolini was overthrown in 1943 and Italy abandoned its alliance with Nazi Germany, Perlasca sought protection from reprisals by obtaining a diplomatic passport from the Spanish legation. The Spanish were friendly to Perlasca because he had fought with Francisco Franco's forces in the Spanish civil war. Later, when the Spanish minister fled to Switzerland, Perlasca convinced Hungarian officials that he was the legal representative of Spain in Budapest. Perlasca, then 34, was appalled at the sight of Jews being shot, beaten and herded aboard cattle cars at the Budapest train station for deportation to German death camps. ``So much agony reinforced in me the will to do as much as possible to help those unfortunate people,'' he later told a Hungarian writer. ``The cattle loaded by my company ... were treated better than the deportees.'' Repeatedly, Perlasca harangued senior Hungarian officials to assure the safety of Jews crowded into the sanctuary of apartment houses flying the Spanish flag, and personally rescued Jews who had been arrested in violation of agreements. He spent his dwindling funds to buy scraps of meat, powdered eggs and other scarce foods, and delivered them to the starving inhabitants of his ``safe houses'' in the Spanish diplomat's black limousine. Perlasca vividly recalled snatching twin children from a throng of Jewish deportees at the Budapest train station and hustling them to safety in the Spanish limousine. ``I thought to myself, why do these two have to go to die?'' he said. When a Gestapo major tried to pull the children from the car at gunpoint, Perlasca physically barred him at the door, claiming diplomatic immunity. The confrontation escalated, with Perlasca's friend Wallenberg joining the argument along with representatives of other neutral countries, the Vatican and the International Red Cross. A German colonel intervened. The major explained the situation. ``Let them go. Their time will come, too,'' the colonel said. The Germans walked away, and Perlasca kept the twins. Perlasca asked Wallenberg who the colonel was. Wallenberg, surprised, replied that he was Adolf Eichmann. Eichmann, the Nazi engineer of the Holocaust, was captured by Israeli agents in 1960 and convicted by a Jerusalem court of crimes against humanity. He was hanged in 1962. ``His time came, too,'' Perlasca said.

DOC.HEAD: Past Conscientious Objector Status Causes Problems For Lawmaker
DOC.TEXT: For more than a year, Republicans looked forward eagerly to taking on Rep. Roy Dyson in the November general election. Now they are not so sure that the Maryland Democrat will make it that far. A recent revelation that the hawkish congressman was a conscientious objector during the Vietnam war has leaders of both political parties speculating that he might not survive the primary election next Tuesday. Dyson is still seen as the favorite. But for the first time, there is talk among political leaders in the 1st District that state legislator Barbara Kreamer, his chief Democratic opponent, has an outside chance of winning. ``If she has any money to make a major blitz on television this weekend, it's going to be a lot closer than anyone thought,'' said Joyce Terhes, state Republican chairwoman. A top Democratic official who asked not to be named said the furor over Dyson's draft status and Kreamer's pro-choice views on abortion give her an outside chance of pulling off an upset. ``The problem for the Democratic Party is if Dyson wins now, he loses in November,'' said the party leader, who considers Kreamer a stronger candidate. Not all Democrats are that pessimistic. There is agreement, however, that Republicans have a good chance of reclaiming the seat they lost to Dyson in 1980. The incumbent's problems extend beyond his draft status. They began in 1988 with the disclosures that the Federal Election Commission was investigating contributions made to him and other members of Congress by defense lobbyists. Joseph E. Hill, a consultant for Unisys Corp., later pleaded guilty to donating Unisys money to Dyson and other officials and disguising the contributions as personal donations. Dyson said he did not know the gifts came from corporate funds. Just before the May primary election in 1988, Dyson's campaign was rocked again by the suicide of his top aide, Tom Pappas. Pappas jumped to his death from a New York hotel the day The Washington Post reported that he recruited single young men for the congressman's staff and demanded that they spend off hours socializing with him and other staff members. The National Republican Congressional Committee targeted Dyson for defeat this year. The committee said its polls indicate he is one of the most vulnerable members of Congress seeking re-election. That vulnerability enticed eight Republicans and three other Democrats to enter the 1st District race this year. Just as it appeared Dyson had put his problems behind him, the story broke about his draft status. He disclosed in a news release last week that he had been a conscientious objector. The release was issued the day after The Washington Post sought an interview to discuss his draft records. ``I opposed the war in Vietnam,'' Dyson said by way of explanation. ``I was a conscientious objector because I believed it was wrong to draft young men and send them to die in the jungles of Southeast Asia.'' As a member of the House Armed Services Committee, Dyson is a strong supporter of Pentagon budget requests. He backed the Panama invasion and thinks U.S. troops should be used to fight drug wars in South America. After the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, Dyson said President Bush should ``preposition troops right in the middle of downtown Baghdad.'' His hawkish stand on defense coupled with his conscientious objector status brought charges of hypocrisy from his opponents. ``He obviously is a hypocrite in this matter, hiding from the draft ... and at the same time urging that we position our boys in the streets of Baghdad,'' said Mark Frazer, one of his Republican opponents. The disclosure provided an instant boost to Kreamer's campaign. ``There's definitely been a sea change in the last week,'' said Bob DeWeese, Kreamer's campaign manager. ``Checks are coming in that we didn't expect to get. That's going to help us get the message out on television and the radio,'' he said. No single favorite has emerged from the crowded Republican field. Seven of the eight candidates are campaigning actively for the 15,000 to 20,000 votes likely to be cast in the Republican primary. One of them, state Delegate Richard Colburn, believes Kreamer would be an easier target in the mostly conservative 1st District. ``With Roy, it would be conservative vs. conservative in November. With Barbara, you would have a liberal Democrat running against a conservative Republican,'' Colburn said.

DOC.HEAD: Frigate on Alert for Iraqi Blockade Runners
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
LaserPhoto DOD1
DOC.DATELINE: ABOARD USS TAYLOR IN THE PERSIAN GULF (AP)
DOC.TEXT: The USS Taylor was tracing its usual box-pattern patrol course in the central Persian Gulf when the tanker, heavily laden and low in the water, appeared on the horizon, outbound. ``This is an American warship. Please identify yourself, your cargo and port of origin,'' came the radio challenge. A voice identified the tanker as the Greek-registered Fortuneship L, carrying oil from Jubail, Saudi Arabia. ``Thank you,'' said the Taylor, wishing a good day to the battered vessel that once survived three Iraqi rocket attacks _ Aug. 30, Nov. 11 and Nov. 12, 1987 _ while under charter to Iran during its war with Iraq. After two sister frigates, USS Reid and USS Robert G. Bradley, fired warning shots at a pair of Iraqi tankers on Aug. 18, the Taylor was involved in shadowing one of the tankers out of the gulf. Otherwise, in a month of operating mainly in the central gulf, the Charleston, S.C.-based missile frigate has yet to encounter its first Iraqi tanker or cargo vessel. ``We have been talking with every ship that comes through our section. Every single one has been cooperative and polite,'' said the Taylor's skipper, Cmdr. Kevin P. Green of Summerville, S.C. The 3,900-ton Taylor is one of 11 U.S. warships operating in the gulf, helping to enforce the U.N.-ordered economic blockade of Baghdad. Having arrived in July for a three-month tour with the Middle East Force, the Navy's gulf-based patrol unit, it was already on station when Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. ``We were on a routine deployment. All the excitement developed after we were here,'' said Green. Even so, he said, the Iraqi invasion ``really changed very little'' for his crew. In training exercises, said Green, ``we go through just about every conceivable contingency, practice with all the weapons systems and are prepared for precisely this type of situation.'' The Taylor's patrol assignment makes it one of the first U.S. warships that would encounter Iraqi tankers or other vessels headed south from Iraq or Kuwait, Green said. It also means ships coming up the gulf have usually already been cleared by other ships before they reach the Taylor's area. ``Iraq is convinced that we mean what we say,'' Green said. ``I am sure they're convinced we know what we're doing out here.'' Although the Taylor is at ``Readiness Condition Three,'' one notch below ``Battle Stations,'' the atmosphere is relaxed. Sailors jog and work out with weights on the upper deck. Lt. Steve Davis, the Taylor's combat systems officer, acknowledged the relative comfort the ship's crew members enjoy when compared to the U.S. troops who have taken up positions in the Saudi desert. ``I really feel sympathy for those guys out there in the sand. At least we can duck inside, cool off and have a good meal,'' he said. Like other U.S. warships, the Taylor now has a small contingent of U.S. Coast Guardsmen, veterans of the U.S. government's Caribbean drug interdiction program, to assist in enforcing the U.N.-sanctioned Iraqi blockade. Each boarding party includes eight or more members, both sailors and Coast Guardsmen.

DOC.HEAD: Exhausted Airmen In `Uproar' Over Possibilty of Pay Cut
DOC.TEXT: The talk from the exhausted group huddled under the F-15 turned quickly from the intricacies of jet engines to worries about financial support for their wives and children back home. The U.S. government may cut the supplemental income soldiers received back home for living off-base because they now get their food and supplies free in Saudi Arabia. ``I just had a kid four weeks ago and that money is figured into my finances,'' Chris Jessen tells a visitor to an F-15 maintenance hanger on Wednesday, where the airmen work 12-hour shifts in sweltering heat. ``If they take it away, then in essence the government is saying, `Sergeant you're going to pay us this money so that you can go to Saudi Arabia and support the mission,'' he said. Jessen's buddies huddled under the F-15 nod their heads in agreement; all but one of the five is married, the four that are all have children. One found out the other day his wife is pregnant with their fourth child. ``As far as morale, that's the biggest problem,'' Kevin Wilde, of Sioux City, Iowa, said of the possible loss of the pay known as BAS _ Basic Allowance for Subsistence. For these men, it amounts to an extra $180 a month _ about 20 percent of their total pay. Their commanding officer interjects, saying that for now the Air Force's Tactical Air Command has kept up the payments, but that Congress will have to act to keep the money flowing if the the BAS payments are to continue throughout the U.S. deployment. The airmen complain a bit about the heat, and the long hours spent hunched under the seemingly endless line of F-15s needing maintenance. Airman Adam Bayes describes the days this way: ``You go to work for 12 hours, go home, get clean, go to bed, wake up, get clean, whatever, do your laundry if you can do that, come to work, work, go home, sleep. It's getting to be a routine.'' So much so that Wilde spent his day off this week sitting around watching his buddies work. ``I didn't know what else to do,'' he said. During a visit to the troops last week, Georgia Sen. Sam Nunn was pulled aside by Col. John McBroom, commander of the First Tactical Fighter Wing. McBroom's message: Do something to keep the extra money flowing to the families back home. There are some indications Congress might heed the advice of McBroom and other commanders in the Saudi desert. At a White House meeting Wednesday, Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, suggested that Congress and the administration agree on a pay and income tax incentive package for the troops deployed in Saudi Arabia ``to forestall a morale problem.'' The airmen interviewed Wednesday predict just such problems if the money is cut off. As the law stands now, servicemen lose the extra payments when they get free meals. ``Every serviceman here that has heard about it is in an uproar,'' said Jessen. ``They're telling us that for the opportunity to go and sweat over in Saudi Arabia you may pay me, Uncle Sam, $180 a month,'' Jessen said. ``We've got family at home depending on that money and we can't afford to lose it.''

DOC.HEAD: Judges Conclude Audition Tape Was Menuhin or Kreisler, Not Blumita Singer
DOC.TEXT: The screening committee reviewing applications to the $20,000 International Violin Competition had doubts about a Brazilian candidate, but her audition tape was so dazzling they invited her to play. But when Blumita Singer did, she was so bad that some in the audience giggled and others walked out. The panel of judges then reviewed the audition tape and soon concluded it hadn't been Singer's artistry but that of Yehudi Menuhin or Fritz Kreisler, two of this century's greatest violinists. The judges disqualified Singer from the competition, the richest in the world. ``It took just five notes for those 10 people to say, `Who's this playing? It must be Menuhin or Kreisler,' '' Thomas J. Beckiewicz, executive director of the annual contest, said Wednesday. ``When you have 10 of the most expert violinists in the world, you cannot fake anything.'' Singer, 26, was sent home to Sao Paolo, Brazil, on Tuesday. She had performed in Sunday's preliminary competition. She was the first person accused of fraud in the contest's eight-year history. Besides the $20,000 cash prize, the competition offers concert opportunities and recording contracts for the gold, silver and bronze medalists. The gold medalist also debuts at Carnegie Hall. The screening committee reviewed more than 200 candidates; Singer was among 53 who made the cut. Singer said on her application she received professional training at the Manhattan School of Music in 1983-84 and at Juilliard in 1982, and that she was taught by the late violinist Henryk Szeryng from 1984 to 1987. She also listed several competitions and awards, including first prizes in the 1983 Fritz Kreisler talent award and 1975 National Young Soloists Competition. It was not immediately known whether she had falsified any of those credentials. ``The screening committee looked at this portfolio with special care because there were doubts in their minds from the beginning,'' Beckiewicz said. He said the committee had doubts about documents accompanying the application, including recommendation letters, copies of certificates of musical education, and programs and reviews of concerts she supposedly had given. When she was confronted with the fraud allegation, she offered ``no admission, no regrets, no penitence,'' Beckiewicz said. She showed ``no indignation ... but some stress that she was unmasked.'' No further action will be taken against Singer, contest officials said. She did not return a message left on the answering machine at her home Wednesday. Singer was accepted as part of ``a very honest effort to search out those who are less known,'' Beczkiewicz said. ``I don't want to discourage the screening committee from taking a few risks.'' However, he said that to prevent cheating, future applicants may be required to submit a statement documenting the authenticity of their tapes. Wednesday was the last day of preliminaries for the competition. Beginning Friday, 16 semifinalists will perform full recitals over four days. Six finalists then will be selected, and each will perform with the Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra. Medalists will be announced Sept. 16.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Say Shortage May Come at Start of Heating Season
DOC.TEXT: Bush administration officials say they fear an oil shortage from the embargo against Iraq and Kuwait may develop just at the time Americans turn up their furnaces for winter. If so, private analysts said it could cause a repeat of the heating oil crisis last winter when the coldest December in 60 years sent prices of the fuel up by an average 45 cents a gallon on the East Coast and related propane prices up by more than a dollar. Despite commitments by other producers to make up much of the Iraqi-Kuwaiti output and record high inventories, both government and private analysts said they expect a world shortage to develop by the end of November. ``The last half of the fourth quarter gives us concern,'' Assistant Energy Secretary John J. Easton Jr. told the House Government Operations Committee on Wednesday. ``We see the potential for greater uncertainty as winter develops.'' The 21-nation International Energy Agency foresees a shortage of 500,000 barrels a day developing over the next three months. Because the winter seasonal demand for oil is expected to increase by several million barrels a day, private analysts said the shortage could be much larger, particularly if it is unusually cold. Edward N. Krapels, president of Energy Security Analysis Inc. of Washington, said the shortfall ``could easily'' reach 2 million barrels a day, possibly sending oil prices above $40 a barrel. ``We are convinced that useable commercial crude oil stocks will be depleted by the end of October,'' he said. ``Anticipation of the shortage will result in a run-up of crude oil prices that will be translated into higher heating oil prices as the winter develops.'' Krapels, whose firm closely monitors world oil supplies, said the government could pre-empt a spiraling of home heating oil prices by immediately drafting a contingency plan to begin drawing down the nation's 590-million-barrel Strategic Petroleum Reserve in November. ``A reasonable, organized, modest drawdown will send a signal not only to the oil industry and to consumers but also to the financial markets that the winter will be a difficult one, but not an economy-breaking one,'' he said. The administration has said it will dip into the reserve only when a real shortage occurs and not as a ``price mechanism.'' Compounding the threat of heating oil shortages is the worldwide lack of refining capacity. Now boycotted refineries in Kuwait and Iraq accounted for about 1.2 percent of world's gasoline, jet and diesel fuel and heating oil production. Meanwhile, the U.S. petroleum industry, in the face of high operating costs and environmental opposition, has shut down more than 100 refineries without building a single one in the past decade. Calvin Kent, director of the government's Energy Information Administration, said refineries already were operating at more than 90 percent capacity _ an all-time high _ to meet the summer demand for gasoline and to build heating oil stockpiles when Iraq invaded Kuwait last month. The cold snap last winter and related fires and explosions from trying to continue production during it forced some refineries to close and others to cut their output, an event that officials fear could happen again. ``There's no question that an accident would cause a severe impact'' on supply and prices, Kent said.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Praises the Secretary and Crosses its Fingers
LaserPhoto WX8
DOC.TEXT: The Democratic congressman from Connecticut told Secretary of State James A. Baker III that everyone was ``thrilled'' with the administration's handling of the Persian Gulf crisis. ``You've done a terrific job,'' said Rep. Sam Gejdenson. The chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee said America was solidly behind President Bush's policies. Not since the Cuban missile crisis, said Sen. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., had he seen ``as much pulling together as there is now.'' ``Superb,'' said the senator from New York. ``You have made an impression on the world, and that doesn't happen to many people many times,'' Democrat Daniel Patrick Moynihan told Baker. Baker's testimony Tuesday and Wednesday marked the first administration appearance before congressional committees since Bush committed U.S. force in response to after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. But with all the praise, there was an undertone of misgiving. Lawmakers wanted to know where the exit was. They wanted to know what the United States would do about Saddam Hussein and his country's nuclear and chemical weapons capabilities even if he withdraws Kuwait. The questions betraying uneasiness were sandwiched between the barrages of praise for the way Bush and Baker had won worldwide cooperation and support. ``A brilliant job so far,'' said Sen. Joseph Biden, D-Del., but ``I need more explanations of where it's going to go from here, what your plans are.'' Baker's replies were often vague. He spoke of a regional security arrangement _ some sort of Mideast NATO _ to check Saddam. He spoke of a long-term American sea or land presence. And he called for American patience. ``That is what we ask most of the American people,'' he said. ``Stand firm, be patient and remain united so that together we can show that aggression does not pay.'' Sen. Paul Sarbanes, D-Md., said that even if Bush's goals are met, ``we are left with an Iraq to deal with afterwards.'' Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., wanted to know if Baker could not provide some sort of ``international United Way campaign'' donor chart, listing which countries were providing troops, which were sending money, and how much. Biden wanted to know why Bush insists on returning the Kuwaiti emir to power rather than taking the opportunity to encourage the democratic selection of the country's leaders. Rep. James Leach, R-Iowa, making the same point, said an emirate ``is a little bit difficult from a historical American perspective to be too thrilled about protecting.'' Rep. Peter Kostmayer, D-Pa., said he hated to be ``the skunk at the garden party,'' but had to wonder if, deep down, this wasn't a fight for cheap oil. ``I don't think that young men and young women of this country are prepared to spill their blood in the sands of Saudi Arabia to keep the price of gasoline cheap,'' Kostmayer said. Baker said protecting the world's oil supplies was an objective but ``not the overriding reason why America is there.'' Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass., just back from a visit with the troops in Saudi Arabia, said Saudi forces and U.S. Marines were in position to shed the first blood in a war, ``but I didn't notice any of our other allies.'' Baker said 26 nations ``have sent military assets of one form or another'' and he was hopeful others would. He offered to list other commitments, but only in closed session. The extrication question was raised by Kostmayer at the House Foreign Affairs Committee hearing: ``What if Saddam Hussein simply stays where he is ...? Could this go on for months or years? Where does this end?'' ``We have not put a time frame on it,'' Baker replied, ``because I'm not sure we can put a time frame on it now. ... It is important, yes, that we succeed, but also that we build a regional security structure that is able to contain the aggressive tendencies of a leader like this.'' Kostmayer persisted. ``Could it be years?'' Baker said he would not want to speculate because some continuing U.S. presence, on land or sea, would be called for in the new regional security structure he foresaw. ``These are questions that are going to have to be addressed down the line,'' he said, ``and they're questions that are going to have to be studied considerably.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Adds Missiles to Growing Force in Northern Desert
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Pentagon rules on coverage prohibit the disclosure of exact locations or of the strength of forces.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The United States is deploying missile batteries, multiple rocket launchers and mines in Saudi Arabia's northern desert to blunt any possible Iraqi thrust, military officials say. In the last two days, Patriot missile batteries designed to shoot down incoming missiles and multiple rocket launchers used to smash troop buildups have been brought in to reinforce U.S. positions closest to the Kuwaiti border. The weapons have been transported north over the past week in huge convoys that also carried hundreds of troops to forward camps. U.S. Marines at a base camp close to the Kuwaiti border said they were preparing to mine strategic north-south roads, but were taking special precautions to protect refugees fleeing Kuwait. Mines will be placed along a side road running south from Kuwait, with warnings posted for refugees, said the Marines, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The main highway from Kuwait to Dhahran in Saudi Arabia's oil-rich eastern province is to be be drilled and wired so mines can be placed at short notice to hinder any Iraqi advance. A Marine gunnery sergeant taking part in the mining operation pointed out a small bridge connecting a highway that runs through rough terrain. If the United States gets wind of a possible Iraqi attack, ``that'll be gone,'' he said. The deployments will help the United States improve its ground-based fighting capabilities after relying on air power for defense in the weeks following the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Commanders say that in about a month the buildup will offer enough firepower to make them comfortable about offensive operations if they are ordered to attack. At the Marines' forward base camp, the commanding officer, Lt. Col. Jim Mattis said his troops were in a defensive posture. ``We didn't come here to fight,'' Mattis said in an interview at the base command post. ``My concern is to defend the area to which I've been assigned. If someone wants to fight, we'll finish them off.'' Mattis said his troops can rely on air cover from Marine and Royal Saudi Air Force attack helicopters and fighter jets, including F-18s and vertical takeoff Harriers. On the ground, the Marines have tanks and other armored vehicles. The forwardmost U.S. forces are taking up positions in the desert behind Saudi and Arab troops manning the frontline just south of Kuwait. Scout patrols from the forward Marines _ the 7th Marine Expeditionary Brigade is within 40 miles of Kuwait _ have advanced beyond those forces on reconnaissance missions, said sources who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``They're just getting the lay of the land. It's nothing devious,'' one source said. The American forces appear to be growing more confident every day as slow-moving ships carrying heavy ground force armor arrive in the region. A cluster of ships carrying Marine amphibious forces are now a few days from the Persian Gulf. The convoys moving north include double-decker buses carrying hundreds of soldiers and dozens of transport trucks carrying tanks, artillery and other heavy equipment. There also are scores of refueling and other support vehicles for the tanks and infantry carriers. An Army official said troop and equipment movements were being made at night not to hide them, but because of the cooler temperatures and to avoid raising fears among Saudis. ``Driving through towns in the middle of the day with a half-mile-long row of tanks and rockets isn't a particularly good idea,'' he said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Most of the gear transported north in the past few days belongs to the 24th Mechanized Infantry Division, a Georgia-based unit armed with fast-moving M-1 tanks and Bradley Armored Fighting Vehicles, or AFVs. Still being unloaded at a Saudi port is similar heavy equipment for the 197th Infantry, which will join the 24th in the forwardmost U.S. positions in Saudi Arabia. The Air Force brought F-111 bombers into the region earlier this week and is adding to its fighter arsenal. Many of the new squadrons are being based in other Persian Gulf nations.

DOC.HEAD: Navy OKs Firing of Battleship Guns; Iowa Study Continues
DOC.TEXT: The Navy has lifted its ban on firing the battleship Wisconsin's 16-inch guns but an investigation continues into the explosion that claimed the lives of 47 sailors aboard its sister ship, the Iowa. The Wisconsin is in the Persian Gulf and is the only battleship deployed in the conflict there. Should U.S. forces take action, the ship's huge guns could blast shore points to protect a possible Marine land assault. The massive weapons can heave 2,700-pound shells more than 20 miles. A Navy statement issued Wednesday at the Pentagon said the battleship ``has been granted authority to begin live firing training and operations.'' Navy Secretary H. Lawrence Garrett III made the decision after consulting the service's top admiral, Adm. Frank Kelso. The decision came after ``extensive testing'' of the gunpowder bags used in the guns, said Navy spokesman Cmdr. Jim Mitchell. The Navy unit in charge of testing, the Naval Sea Systems Command, ``has now determined that the guns may safely fire certain lots of propellant,'' a Navy statement said. Mitchell said the Navy's investigation into the April 19, 1989 explosion aboard the Iowa is expected to be concluded later this year. Mitchell said investigators have found that there was a greater chance for an explosion in a gunpowder bag if a limited number of propellant grains were in the top layer _ known as the tare layer _ of the bag. The gunpowder bags are filled with several layers of pellets, or gun powder grains. Mitchell said investigators concluded during the past four months of new tests ``that 20 or more grains of powder in the tare layer provides a substantial safety margin, even if a bag of powder should be compressed by a high-speed overram during the loading of a 16-inch gun.'' He said the Navy had removed from service all powder bags containing less than 20 grains of powder in that layer. Still, he said, ``this does not imply that these powder bags were unsafe.'' Last year, the Navy said the Iowa explosion ``most probably'' was an intentional act by gunner's mate 2nd class Clayton Hartwig of Cleveland. The service accused Hartwig of placing ``some type of detonation device'' between the gunpowder bags while loading the 16-inch guns during gunnery practice on board the Iowa. However, the Navy admitted it only had circumstantial evidence. The Navy reopened its investigation of the explosion in May after an ``unexplained ignition'' of some gunpowder bags occurred during additional testing ordered by Congress. Some members of Congress, during their own investigation into the Iowa explosion, suggested that ramming the gunpowder bags too vigorously _ or instability in the gunpowder bags _ could have caused the Iowa explosion. The suspension of firing the huge guns aboard the battleships was ordered by Garrett on May 24. The Navy said the battleship Missouri will be authorized to conduct live firing upon completion of a series of certifications and inspections. The other two battleships _ the Iowa and the New Jersey _ are in port and are scheduled to be decommissioned in 1991 because of budget constraints.

DOC.HEAD: Radicals Agree to Plead Guilty to Bombing Charges
DOC.TEXT: Three radical leftists have agreed to plead guilty to a 1983 bombing at the U.S. Capitol and to setting off bombs at seven other sites in New York and Washington. As part of their deal with prosecutors, charges against three co-defendants are to be dropped. Laura J. Whitehorn, Linda S. Evans and Marilyn J. Buck are scheduled to appear in U.S. District Court on Friday to plead guilty to participating in a two-year campaign of ``armed propaganda'' to set off bombs at government buildings and private offices, according to court documents. The bombs caused property damage but did not injure any people. The Nov. 7, 1983 blast at the Capitol blew a hole in a wall outside the U.S. Senate chamber, damaged five paintings and knocked the door to Democratic leader Robert Byrd's office off its hinges. Bombing charges against three other members of the group, which called itself the Armed Resistance Unit, the Revolutionary Fighting Group or the Red Guerrilla Resistance, would be dropped as part of the deal. Law enforcement officials have linked the group of radicals to series of crimes dating back to the $1.6 million armed holdup of a Brinks armored car near Nyack, N.Y. in 1981. Buck is serving a 50-year sentence for participating in a string of armed robberies, including the Brinks holdup in which two policemen and a guard were killed. The plea agreement was revealed in court papers filed last week in federal court in Washington. The filing by U.S. Attorney Jay Stephens gave no reason for the government's decision to settle the case, saying only it was ``in the interest of justice.'' Attorneys familiar with the case said a Supreme Court ruling about double jeopardy in May influenced the government's decision to drop charges gainst Susan L. Rosenberg, Timothy A. Blunk and Alan Berkman. Both Rosenberg and Blunk are serving 58-year sentences for possession of an arsenal of explosives. They were arrested in 1984 while loading more than 600 pounds of explosive material into a rented storage bin in Cherry Hill, N.J. Berkman, a physician who is serving a 10-year sentence for possession of explosives, firearms and fake identity cards, suffers from Hodgkins disease. A seventh defendant in the case, Elizabeth Duke, is a fugitive. Rosenberg, Blunk and Berkman won dismissal of the charges against them in 1989 when U.S. District Judge Harold H. Greene held that evidence used to convict them of the earlier charges was the basis for the bombing indictment. But the charges were reinstated last fall when the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here found that the double-jeopardy rule did not apply to their case. The defense renewed its double jeopardy claim in June after the high court ruled in a New York case that evidence used to convict a person of one crime could not be submitted to charge the same defendant with a different offense. Greene has not ruled on that motion. According to the deal outlined in court papers, Whitehorn, 45, Buck, 43, and Evans, 43, agreed to plead guilty to conspiracy and malicious damage to the U.S. Capitol. The offenses carry a maximum 15-year prison term. Whitehorn also agreed to plead guilty to a fraud charge in connection with the possession of false documents found in the Baltimore apartment she shared with Buck and Evans. The charge carries a maximum five-year sentence. In addition to the explosion at the Capitol, bombs were detonated outside the National War College at Fort McNair here April 26, 1983; the Washington Navy Yard Computer Center on Aug. 18, 1983; and the Washington Navy Yard Officers Club on April 20, 1984. Bombs were also placed at the FBI's office on Staten Island, N.Y., on Jan. 28, 1983; the Israeli Aircraft Industries Building in New York on April 5, 1984; the South African consulate in New York on Sept. 26, 1984; and the New York Patrolmen's Benevolent Association on Feb. 23, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Classical Harpist Turns to Rock, Turns on Audiences
LaserPhoto CX1
DOC.TEXT: It's only rock 'n' roll, but she plays it on a harp. ``I hate to play classical,'' says Amy Lee, who entertains lunch crowds at The Art Institute of Chicago with hits by the likes of Pink Floyd, Led Zeppelin and the Rolling Stones. ``But when people request it, I get out my bag of Bach and my music stand and sit there, pluck, pluck, plucking.'' Lee, 34, got tired of black-tie formals, Bach and lounge-lizard pop tunes like ``Feelings'' when she got hooked on rock as a teen-ager. She has worked as a disc jockey and symphony musician, but her solo career took off after she performed rock 'n' roll during a 1981 jazz festival in Chicago. She was dubbed ``The Angel of Rock.'' ``I remember I got a standing ovation for playing `Stairway to Heaven,' '' she said. Lee looks the part of a rock angel. Decked out in bright colors, a short skirt, bold earrings and dark sunglasses, she taps her feet and sways as her fingers speed across the 6-foot, 47-string antique harp her father gave her when she was 7. ``The kind of music she makes should be paid attention to,'' said Alek Jakich, an inspector for the city of Chicago and a regular at the Art Institute's outdoor restaurant, where Lee has worked the last eight summers. ``When was the last time your heard Pink Floyd on the harp?'' Jakich asked. ``And it's great.'' Playing rock is a switch from when Lee performed with the Northwest Indiana Symphony and the Twin City Symphony of St. Joseph, Mich. Being alone on stage is also a switch. ``I'm usually background music,'' the 5-foot-5 blonde said at a performance Tuesday. ``So I decided, `Why not play something I like?' '' That day, her songs by the Eurythmics, the Kinks and The Police got her a complimentary glass of wine from two women having lunch, praise from a mother visiting the gallery with her toddler, and applause after nearly every song. Waiters came up to whisper several requests during her performance in the outdoor atrium scattered with white tables and matching parasols. ``Once they hear the rock songs, then they want to request them,'' said Lee, who also performs in lounges and has her own jazz group. ``I've gotten requests for Tom Petty and the Grateful Dead. But I also get requests for `Lady of Spain.' ''

DOC.HEAD: Tax Hike Said Needed for Education; Poll Says People Will Pay
DOC.TEXT: Increased taxes are inevitable in improving America's schools, state and local educators say as a national poll suggests Americans may be willing to pay. Kentucky Education Secretary Jack Foster, California State Superintendent Bill Honig and Pat Tornillo Jr. of the United Teachers of Dade, Miami, Fla. said Wednesday that tax increases are essential to finance the numerous education reform proposals by local, state and federal officials. But, they stressed that property taxes should not be the only funding source. ``The taxpayer issue is bugging everyone interested in school reform,'' said Foster. Their comments during an all-day education conference hosted by CBS News at Georgetown University underscored the results of a CBS News poll that showed Americans would support a tax hike if the money went to their own neighborhood schools. According to the poll, 71 percent of the 1,107 adults interviewed by telephone between May 30 and June 2 would be willing to pay $100 a year more in taxes if all the money were used for schools in their community. Of those with children in school, 77 percent said they would be willing to pay more in taxes. Forty-nine percent of those involved in the nationwide random sample would be willing to pay $100 more in taxes even if all the money were to be used to help pay for schools in other communities, the poll showed. ``We in Kentucky, and I think in every other state in the union, still continues to use property tax as the index against which to measure how much money can be raised,'' said Foster. ``Kentucky now raises less than half of its local school taxes from direct property tax.'' Foster said other funding now comes from income and utility taxes. Local school revenues, mostly from property taxes, account for 50 percent or more of school revenues in 20 states, the National Education Association said. A breakdown by percentage includes 89.6 in New Hampshire, 70.8 in Nebraska, 66.9 in Oregon, 63.4 in South Dakota, 60.6 in Virginia, 59.3 in Nevada, 59 in Michigan, 58.2 in Vermont, 57 in Colorado and 56.8 in Wisconsin. Also, 56.4 in Missouri, 56.3 in Maryland, 54.7 in New Jersey, 54.4 in Illinois, 53.2 in Massachusetts, 51.8 in Rhode Island, 51.7 in New York, 51.6 in Connecticut, 51.5 in Kansas and 50.2 in Arizona. New Jersey Gov. Jim Florio said that policy makers must not only focus on educational expenses but what it will cost not to implement the improvements, such as increased welfare rolls and larger prisons. He succeeded in pushing through a complex $2.8 billion tax package along with a controversial school financing formula designed to shift existing aid from rich suburban districts to poor, mostly urban systems.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: B.B. King is star number 1,917. The blues artist became the latest legend Wednesday on Hollywood's Walk of Fame. ``I can't talk very well without Lucille,'' said King, referring to his guitar. ``I don't know what else to say other than thank you, thank you, thank you. I really appreciate it.'' About 200 fans attended the ceremony. King, who will be 65 later this month, has recorded more than 50 albums over 41 years. His hits include ``Three O'Clock Blues'' and ``The Thrill is Gone.''

Dirty Harry is hanging up his Magnum. Clint Eastwood said Wednesday he plans no more sequels to the shoot-'em-up movies featuring a San Francisco detective known for his .44 and his taunting line to bad guys, ``Make my day.'' ``I don't know where you'd take him,'' said Eastwood, who has starred in five ``Dirty Harry'' films. ``The very dangerous thing about doing sequels is you can fall into a pattern of self-imitation. You'd have to have an awfully good script to take you away from that.'' Eastwood's latest venture as actor and director, ``White Hunter, Black Heart,'' explores the obsession of a movie director bent on bagging an elephant in Africa. Eastwood plays the director, modeled on the late John Huston. He spoke to reporters during a three-week retrospective of his films.

Todd Bridges, the former child actor acquitted in the shooting of an alleged drug dealer, has returned to his craft in a deputy sheriff's uniform for a part in ``The New Lassie.'' Bridges, who appeared in the series ``Diff'rent Strokes,'' began work Wednesday on the syndicated show about the world's most famous collie and was greeted by a dozen photographers and TV news crews. Bridges, who has admitted to past drug problems, has a role in one episode that will air later this season. ``Todd looked good. He looked clear-eyed,'' spokesman Cliff Dektar said. ``Todd is clean.'' Bridges was charged in last year's shooting of Kenneth ``Tex'' Clay, a convicted drug dealer, at a crack house in Los Angeles. He was acquitted of assault two weeks ago.

Julia Duffy, a six-time Emmy nominee for her role as a spoiled rich girl on ``Newhart,'' will star in the new TV comedy ``Baby Talk.'' The ABC series is based on the movie ``Look Who's Talking.'' Miss Duffy replaces Connie Sellecca, who appeared in the ``Baby Talk'' pilot. ``Who's the Boss?'' star Tony Danza provides the voice of baby Mickey. The series will make its debut at mid-season.

Barbara Mandrell's family feared she might attempt suicide after a near-fatal car crash in 1984, the country music star says in her autobiography. Mandrell said in the book, ``Get to the Heart,'' that her husband, Ken Dudney, emptied pistols he kept in their home and locked them away in a closet. She said she never considered using the guns. ``But I can see Ken's point in hiding them. I was a girl who did not have a great will to live,'' Mandrell said. Mandrell, 41, suffered a concussion, broken leg and other injuries in a collision near Nashville. The driver of the other car was killed. She said in the book due out next week that the accident changed her forever. ``Gone is the precocious little girl, so optimistic, so energetic, like a teen-ager out on her first date,'' she said. Mandrell once had a TV variety show with her sisters. Her hit songs include ``I Was Country (When Country Wasn't Cool)'' and ``Sleeping Single in a Double Bed.''

The Yale Review, the oldest literary quarterly in the country, has some powerful friends, but George Plimpton, Joyce Carol Oates and others may not be able to save it. The prestigious quarterly, which introduced Eudora Welty, Robert Frost, Robert Penn Warren, Virginia Woolf and Eugene O'Neill, is to be shelved after issuing its 79th volume in November. More than 50 novelists, critics, professors and poets have signed a petition opposing the decision to halt publication. The petition was delivered Tuesday to Yale President Benno C. Schmidt Jr. Schmidt announced in June that Yale would close the quarterly, citing financial problems, limited readership and the absence of any direct tie to Yale's academic programs. Annie Dillard, author of ``Pilgrim at Tinker Creek''; Plimpton, editor of The Paris Review, and Charles McGrath, deputy editor of The New Yorker magazine, were among those to sign the petition. Schmidt said he wasn't confident of raising the $1 million or so needed for an endowment to cover the magazine's annual cost of $60,000 to $80,000.
