DOC.HEAD: HHS Sets Goals for Healthier 1990s
DOC.TEXT: Federal health officials today unveiled goals for improving Americans' health over the next decade, to be achieved by encouraging healthy living and preventing disease. ``We can no longer afford not to invest in prevention,'' Dr. James Mason, assistant secretary for health in the Department of Health and Human Services, said in a 671-page report. ``From the perspective of avoiding human suffering as well as saving wasteful costs for treating diseases and injuries that could have been prevented, the 1990s should be the decade of prevention in the United States,'' he said. The report identifies 298 specific health objectives covering a range of areas, including fitness, nutrition, tobacco, alcohol, drugs, family planning, mental health, occupational and environmental health, food safety, cancer, heart disease, AIDS, infant health and sexually transmitted diseases. The key to good health, HHS Secretary Louis Sullivan said in his foreword to the report, is ``personal responsibility, which is to say responsible and enlightened behavior by each and every individual.'' Among the objectives to be obtained by the year 2000 were: _Increasing 30 percent the proportion of people who engage in regular, moderate physical activity for at least 30 minutes a day. In 1985, an estimated 22 percent of people were doing this. _Reduce the prevalence of overweight adults to no more than 20 percent, down from the current 26 percent. _Cut to 15 percent the proportion of adults who smoke. In 1987, an estimated 29 percent of the population smoked. _Reduce pregnancies to 50 per 1,000 girls under 18. In this age group, 71 per 1,000 girls became pregnant in 1985. _Increase use of automobile safety restraints to 85 percent of occupants, up from the current 42 percent who report using them. _Eliminate elevated blood lead levels in children under 5. Currently, 10 percent of these children have levels above 25 micrograms per deciliter. _Reduce infant mortality to 7 deaths per 1,000 births. Provisional data for 1989 shows a rate of 9.7 per 1,000. _Cut coronary heart disease deaths to 100 per 100,000. In 1987, 135 per 100,000 died from this disease. _Reverse the rise in cancer deaths, from 133 per 100,000 in 1987 down to at least the 1970 rate of 130 per 100,000 by the turn of the century. _Limit annual incidence of diagnosed AIDS cases to 98,000. An estimated 44,000-50,000 cases were diagnosed in 1989. The objectives in ``Healthy People 2000'' were developed in a three-year effort led by the Public Health Service and involved more than 300 voluntary and professional organizations and state health departments. They build on a similar effort begun in 1979 in which national goals were set for 1990. Data for the previous 10 years has not been compiled yet and an assessment of the first set of goals was not expected until next year. A mid-course review in 1986 found that about half the 226 objectives had been achieved or likely would be by the end of the decade. These included reductions in high blood pressure, smoking and motor vehicle accidents and increases in immunizations. But about a quarter of the objectives were not likely to be met and a similar proportion could not be measured. Targets of concern included infant mortality among minority and low-income women, drug abuse and the proportion of Americans who are overweight.

DOC.HEAD: White House Staff Chief Tells of Advice to Soviets
With PM-Bush Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Presidential chief of staff John Sununu, back from a managerial mission to Moscow, says the Soviet Union is going through a debate similar to what the United States faced in framing its own Constitution two centuries ago. Sununu and a team of top White House aides spent five days last week in Moscow and Leningrad. It was a return visit with Soviet efficiency experts who toured the White House and several Cabinet departments in June looking for tips on how to run the Soviet Union's rapidly changing government. Sununu said the Americans gave the Soviets plenty of nuts-and-bolts advice then. This time, he said, the Soviets were more interested in discussing broader issues of government, including how to balance the role of the central government in Moscow with demands for independence from the 15 Soviet republics. In an interview with news agency reporters Wednesday, Sununu said the Soviets are experiencing something like what ``our country went through about 210 years ago as we worked from the Articles of Confederation to our own Constitution.'' The framers of the U.S. Constitution had to go back then and ``convince the states that they ought to give up all the powers they had to the new central government,'' he said. In the Soviet Union, on the other hand, ``they're trying to convince the federal government to give back all the powers to the republics,'' Sununu said. ``But the same issues are being debated: the issue of currency, the issue of the banks, the issue of who owns the resources within the lands.'' Sununu said he is convinced that there is no turning back from the Soviet Union's march away from communism and towards a market economy. ``Not once in any of our discussions did the word `communism' come up. Not once,'' he said. ``We didn't find anybody who wanted to turn back'' from economic reforms. ``There was an undertone to all the discussions .. that a lot of the pulling and tugging of breaking it up is so that they can come back and renegotiate putting it back together again,'' said Sununu. ``Nobody seemed to be doing it just for the sake of stirring the pot. ... They all seemed to be very sincere in trying to work this thing out.'' Among other things, Sununu said he was asked what special perquisites went with working for the U.S. government. ``It was a big surprise for them'' to hear that top federal officials made less working for the government than they could command in business, he said. Sununu and his group met with Boris Yeltsin, the ex-communist party maverick and president of the Russian Republic, as well as Defense Minister Dmitri T. Yazov, Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze and other top Soviet officials. A meeting with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was on the schedule, but it was scrapped when Gorbachev wound up in a marathon meeting instead with Yeltsin that produced an agreement for radical economic reforms. Sununu praised the Kremlin's computerized personnel system, which he said tracks both job openings and top candidates. ``In some sense, we wish we kind of had one as detailed and as efficient as that,'' he said. The Soviets select people from a more narrow group and ``have almost everybody's background and capacity available at their fingertips,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Embargoed for Release 10 a.m. EDT, Time Set by Source
Bad Books, Poor Teachers Cripple Biology Education, Panel Says
DOC.TEXT: Books written to not offend adults, teachers who are poorly trained and a curriculum that ``seems designed to snuff out interest'' are all crippling biology education in America, a National Academy of Sciences panel said in a study released today. The study said correcting the flaws in the way American school children are taught biology will require changes on virtually every level of education _ from the preparing of teachers, to the attitudes of parents, school boards and local governments. Among the points made: _ Biology teaching starts too late in school and ``is generally of such poor quality that students learn to dislike science.'' _ Textbooks are often too long, abysmally crafted and written ``with the implicit aim of avoiding offense to a scientifically illiterate segment of the adult population.'' _ Schools of education, where teachers are taught to teach, ``present pedagogical information so unrelated to the specifics of teaching science as to be of little or no help.'' _ Middle and high school students are taught science as courses in memorizing terms which they soon forget. ``Most students leave the experience with the conviction that further exposure to science is something to be avoided if at all possible,'' the report said. _ It noted that a test given 12,000 American high school students showed that half who had not taken biology did as well or better than 40 percent of those who had taken such courses. ``Clearly,'' the report said, ``a great many children are learning almost nothing in their biology courses.'' _ ``Too many of our teachers,'' the report said, ``are recruited from the lowest academic quartile of the college population.'' Further, teachers are given little opportunity update their scientific knowledge or to interact with research scientists in industry or academia. ``The preparation of teachers needs drastic reform,'' the report said. To improve the system, the National Academy of Sciences panel these and other changes need to be made: _ Start teaching courses in science during the elementary school years and devote more class time to the subject. Orient middle-school courses toward human biology to help overcome misinformation about health, hygiene and disease. And, in high school, teach central concepts in an easy language instead of involving detailed, complex terms that must be memorized. The courses should laboratory work. _ Textbooks should be reviewed by the scientific community to assure accuracy and currency, and working scientists should assist school boards and teachers in evaluating proposed texts. _ Testing should be revised so that it does not drive the curriculum. The nation, the report said, should be more interested in teaching and materials than in ranking student performance. _ ``Research is need on what makes education programs for teachers effective,'' the study said. It recommended that science teachers should be given opportunities to train in actual laboratories of research scientists. Colleges should develop undergraduate training for teachers that includes advice from scientists on how best to teach science. _ Universities should offer summertime training programs for elementary, middle and high school science teachers. Continuing education of teachers should include not just what to teach, but how to teach. Though the panel declined to make a cost estimate, the report said that ``a major commitment of funds will be needed'' to accomplish the goals of improving biology education. The report was prepared by three committees that included more than 50 educators and scientists from many parts of the country and selected by the National Research Council. The council is an affiliate of the National Academy of Sciences.

DOC.HEAD: New York GOP Candidate Would Work For $1 A Year
DOC.TEXT: Republican candidate for governor Pierre Rinfret pledged that, if elected, he would work for $1 a year ``as long as the state remains in fiscal trouble.'' Rinfret, claiming Democratic Gov. Mario Cuomo had created ``a credit-card state'' that was on its way to bankruptcy, unveiled a plan to freeze state spending and cut taxes as a means of restoring New York's fiscal health. With New York facing a potential budget deficit he estimated at $2.4 billion for next year, Rinfret told a news conference Wednesday that he would ask state workers to accept a one-year salary freeze. He said that would save $300 million. Rinfret also said he would freeze most state spending next year to save an additional $800 million. In all, Rinfret said his proposals could cut state spending by $1.5 billion. He said an anticipated 3 percent growth in state revenues would provide the remaining $900 million to close the deficit. Cuomo campaign spokesman William Cunningham dismissed Rinfret's proposals as ``just a political document for press conference purposes. ... He's made a lot of assumptions.'' Cuomo press secretary Gary Fryer joked about Rinfret's pledge to work for $1 a year. ``I'm sure he'll be worth every penny of it,'' said the Cuomo aide. Fryer said Cuomo, who accepts $100,000 of the governor's $130,000-a-year salary, had no plans to make a similar pledge.
DOC.HEAD: Mecham: Government Workers Shouldn't Live In Sin
DOC.TEXT: State workers who engage in sex outside of marriage should not be allowed to keep their jobs, Republican gubernatorial hopeful Evan Mecham says. ``From my viewpoint, they shouldn't be in government service because they're lawbreakers,'' Mecham said in a campaign appearance. Arizona has laws against a variety of sexual acts, as well as against ``open and notorious cohabitation,'' but the laws are seldom enforced. Mecham was elected governor in 1986. He offended homosexuals, women, blacks, Hispanics, Jews and Orientals with a series of remarks and was impeached and ousted on unrelated charges in 1988. ``I never went out looking or declaring war on homosexuals,'' Mecham said in an appearance on Phoenix radio station KTAR. He said there are ``other lawbreakers too that shouldn't be allowed there. I'm not just picking homosexuals out. ``I don't know that we will ever launch a program to try to get everybody who's living a lifestyle that isn't totally within the cover of the law out because there are a lot of those people,'' said Mecham. Asked to elaborate after the program, Mecham said he believed any lawbreakers, including heterosexuals who engage in sexual acts without being married, should not be in government either. He made the comments Tuesday.
DOC.HEAD: Dukakis Criticizes His Lieutenant Governor
DOC.TEXT: An angry Gov. Michael S. Dukakis criticized his own lieutenant governor after she talked of taking over the ailing state government while he was gone on a European trade mission. Dukakis, who decided to postpone his trip, accused Lt. Gov. Evelyn Murphy of playing politics in her bid to win the Democratic nomination for governor. Dukakis spoke with Murphy on Wednesday, and afterwards said ``what I heard was a candidate who was trying to use this state's fiscal situation for personal political gain.'' Murphy had said she was waiting for Dukakis to leave the state so, as acting governor, she could push her own plan for curing the state's fiscal troubles. ``I'll put my proposals on the table if he continues on his trip,'' Murphy said. ``When I'm in charge, I'll show you how I make some decisions.'' She did not make any details of the plan public. And a Dukakis administration source said she even refused to provide the governor with details in a telephone conversation when he asked her for them. ``This is Alexandra Haig with Nixon's secret plan,'' said Dukakis spokesman Stephen Crawford. He referred to then-Secretary of State Alexander Haig's comments that he was in charge at the White House when President Reagan was shot. Richard Nixon said during the 1968 elections that he had a plan to end the Vietnam war, but did not make it public. Murphy has been trailing her two Democratic opponents, Francis X. Bellotti and John Silber, who have tried to link her with the state's fiscal disaster under the Dukakis administration.

DOC.HEAD: Keating Agrees to Abide by Restrictions on Finances
DOC.TEXT: Charles Keating Jr., a key figure in the savings and loan crisis, is agreeing to give notice of any large transactions and not to transfer assets out of the country. Under an agreement announced Wednesday by the Justice Department, Keating must file financial statements with the Office of Thrift Supervision and must tell that agency 48 hours in advance of any transactions exceeding $5,000. Those terms had previously been imposed on Keating by a preliminary injunction issued by the U.S. District Court in Los Angeles. Wednesday's announcement indicated he had agreed to them. Keating already has provided financial statements, which have not been disclosed. Regulators wanted to determine if Keating transferred money out of the country _ and out of their reach _ because he had traveled extensively in Switzerland and the Bahamas in the last few years. Keating has denied transferring any funds overseas. The Justice Department reached the agreement, which was filed in the Los Angeles court, on behalf of the Office of Thrift Supervision, an agency of the Treasury Department. The OTS had previously ordered Keating to prove his assertion that he is broke. The agency partially froze his assets in connection with its efforts to recover $41 million from Keating and five associates. The government's enforcement efforts stem from the collapse of Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif., which Keating controlled and has been accused of looting. Regulators estimate the failure may cost taxpayers $2 billion, ranking with Miami's CenTrust Bank as the costliest S&L failures. Keating earned huge salaries, lived lavishly and contributed heavily to politicians while he headed American Continental Corp., a development company based in Phoenix that owned Lincoln. His case has attracted particular attention because of his $1.3 million in contributions to the campaigns of five senators: Republican John McCain of Arizona and Democrats Alan Cranston of California, Donald W. Riegle Jr. of Michigan, Dennis DeConcini of Arizona and John Glenn of Ohio. Keating has contended he never broke any laws and that government officials are making him a scapegoat to conceal their own inability to prevent the S&L disaster. U.S. District Judge Stanley Sporkin in Washington recently dismissed Keating's lawsuit to recover control of Lincoln, saying actions by Keating and his cohorts ``amounted to a looting of Lincoln.'' After the ruling, Keating resigned as chairman and chief executive of American Continental, which is in bankruptcy proceedings.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmaker Says Cut 10 Percent of Government Overhead
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Lamar Smith, R-Texas, says he has a plan to reduce the federal deficit by cutting $27 billion from the government's administrative expenses. Smith wrote congressional colleagues Wednesday proposing to trim 10 percent of $270 billion spent on travel, phone calls, printing, lights and other costs. He said the idea is better than having across-the-board cuts, due to take effect automatically under the Gramm-Rudman budget-balancing law unless targets are met for reducing the deficit. ``What this says to federal office managers is `You need to determine within your office how to cut indirect costs 10 percent. You can do it by having one fewer training sessions. You can do it by taking less travel. You can do it by having fewer supplies,''' Smith said. Budget negotiators are scheduled to resume meeting this weekend seeking ways to reduce the deficit by $50 billion. Using data from the Office of Management and Budget, Smith said his staff determined the government will spend about $340 billion in overhead, or indirect costs, next year. Smith exempted about $70 billion in research and development appropriations to get the $270 billion figure. He said it does not include salaries.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Considers Regulating Dietary Supplements
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration is rethinking whether to regulate dietary supplements such as L-tryptophan, which has been linked to the deaths of 27 Americans. Although the agency started requiring a federal safety review before a nutritional supplement could be marketed in 1973, the FDA stopped trying to enforce its rule after two unsuccessful court cases. Since the mid-1970s, ``the FDA has largely maintained a hands-off posture towards dietary supplements in general,'' spokesman Jeff Nesbit said Wednesday. Since the health threat that resulted in all L-tryptophan-based products being taken off the market in March, however, the FDA has begun to review that policy. Acting FDA Commissioner James Benson recently asked agency officials ``to examine our regulation of this whole area,'' Nesbit said. L-tryptophan, an amino acid used to treat insomnia, depression and obesity, was ordered off the market after it was linked to an outbreak of a rare blood disorder called eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome. The syndrome has struck 1,500 people and killed 27, according to the federal Centers for Disease Control. The outbreak has been traced to one Japanese manufacturer of L-tryptophan. A study by Minnesota scientists linked the deaths to a change in the how the supplement was made. The main regulatory obstacle in the FDA's mind is a 1976 law, sponsored by then-Sen. William Proxmire, D-Wis., prohibiting the FDA from acting against makers of vitamins and minerals unless there is a clear public health risk. The Proxmire amendment does not address dietary supplements specifically, but FDA officials believe the law and the two court cases leave the agency with little power to act. Other dietary supplement makers say the FDA has the authority it needs.

DOC.HEAD: Government Changes Tune, Says No Extradition For Drug Lords Who Surrender
DOC.TEXT: In a major turnaround in Colombia's anti-drug strategy, President Cesar Gaviria has announced that cocaine traffickers who surrender will not be extradited to the United States. The new president said his decree Wednesday is part of a plan to end drug-related terrorism. A year-old war between the government and traffickers fighting extradition has left hundreds of people dead. ``Those who have been in crime and who have repented, and who voluntarily turn themselves in to judges in order to freely confess their crimes may be tried by our judges based on our judicial order,'' Gaviria said in a nationally televised speech Wednesday night. In July, the Medellin cocaine cartel declared a unilateral cease-fire in its terrorist attacks, apparently hoping that the new administration would end extraditions. Gaviria, who was inaugurated Aug. 7, said in his speech that criminals who turn themselves in will also face lighter sentences. ``Judges will be given the capacity to reduce sentences ... of those who turn themselves in, confess their crimes, lay down weapons and other goods linked to their crimes and cooperate with investigations.'' In repeated communiques, drug traffickers using the pseudonym ``The Extraditables'' have offered to turn themselves in to Colombian judges if the government promises to end extraditions. Their communiques bore the letterhead, ``We prefer a tomb in Colombia to a jail cell in the United States.'' Extradition is a sensitive issue in Colombia because many people believe sending people to be tried in a foreign country is an insult to national pride. Still, Colombia's justice system has so far failed to keep any major drug trafficker in jail. Traffickers often bribe or threaten officials into letting them go free. Many judges who refused to be intimidated have been murdered. Gaviria has said fortifying the judicial system is a major priority in his administration. The government plans to build special ``fortress cities'' where judges and their families can live and work free of intimidation. Gaviria's predecessor, Virgilio Barco, resumed extradited accused drug traffickers to the United States a year ago after drug bosses declared ``total war'' on the state. In his speech Wednesday, Gaviria said three Colombians currently awaiting extradition would be sent to the United States. But he said three other extradition requests by the United States have been rejected. Currently, 14 people are in Colombian jails awaiting extradition. The Barco administration extradited 22 Colombians. The government blames the Medellin cartel for killing more than 500 people, including at least two presidential candidates, in a long series of bombings and assassinations. The war began in August 1989 with the assassination of Sen. Luis Carlos Galan, a presidential hopeful of the governing Liberal Party who took a tough stand against the drug lords. Gaviria, Galan's campaign manager, became the party's winning candidate. In addition to the victims of the drug war with the government, thousands of people have died in fighting between rival drug gangs and violence blamed on right wing death squads financed by cocaine smugglers. Gaviria said the new judicial measures apply to members of paramilitary groups as well as drug traffickers. Members of paramilitary groups say they are merely farmers and ranchers seeking to defend themselves from leftist guerrillas. But human rights activists say the groups are drug-financed death squads that kill peasants suspected of sympathizing with guerrillas. In his speech, Gaviria reiterated his call for international cooperation in fighting drugs. He said Colombia has been successful in reducing cocaine supplies on U.S. streets. ``Once again we ask of the international community an effective solidarity which transends the realm of words and pep talks,'' the president said. He asked developed countries to limit drug consumption, money laundering, arms trafficking and the sale of chemicals used to process cocaine. Colombia's Medellin and Cali cartels supply most of the cocaine consumed in the United States and Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Japan
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 23,811.91, down 266.43 points, or 1.11 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Turns Down Wrongful Death Claim in Senator's Suicide
DOC.TEXT: Navy doctors were not responsible for the suicide of Sen. John East, a federal judge ruled in rejecting his widow's $3.5 million wrongful-death claim. Priscilla East had contended that government doctors who provide care for members of Congress did not promptly diagnose a thyroid disorder and that the delay led to her husband's suicide in 1986. U.S. District Judge Walter Black on Wednesday ruled the care the North Carolina Republican received at Bethesda Naval Medical Center was ``not perfect'' but did not constitute negligence. Terri Steinhaus, one of Mrs. East's lawyers, called the ruling unfortunate but said no decision had been made on whether to appeal. The lawyer said Mrs. East had no comment. A government lawyer said the decision vindicates the doctors. ``The physicians have had to live with a cloud over their careers for some period of time,'' said Assistant U.S. Attorney Ira Oring. Black's ruling came four months after an eight-week trial he presided over without a jury. East, 55, a first-term senator, killed himself by running his car in the closed garage of his Greenville, N.C., home. He left a note accusing his doctors of having ``ruined my health.'' East's hyperthyroidism was discovered after a resident doctor at Bethesda ordered a test on East in April 1985. Hypothyroidism occurs when the thyroid gland fails to produce a hormone necessary to regulate the body's metabolism. Mrs. East claimed Navy doctors could have diagnosed her husband's hypothyroidism much earlier. The delay triggered a severe depression that led to his suicide, she contended. East had been brought to the center in 1985 after lapsing into a near fatal coma. Shortly after regaining consciousness, East tried to kill himself by ramming a chair leg down his throat.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Household Cigarette Smoke Endangers Children
DOC.TEXT: A study published today says parents who smoke may raise the risk their children will get lung cancer when they grow up. The study in the New England Journal of Medicine is the first to suggest that passive smoking is especially hazardous for youngsters. It found that non-smoking adults who lived at least 13 years with two cigarette smokers during their childhood and adolescence face double the usual risk of getting lung cancer. ``The findings from this and other studies have made me feel it is a very prudent thing to discourage people from smoking in your house,'' said Dr. Dwight T. Janerich, who directed the study. His research, conducted at Yale medical school, suggests that exposure to smoke in the home early in life is to blame for 17 percent of all lung cancer among people who never smoked. The Environmental Protection Agency estimates that about 25,000 of the more than 150,000 new cases of lung cancer annually occur among non-smokers, and 40 percent of them, or 10,000 people, never smoked. If the latest estimate is correct, this means that about 1,700 cases each year are caused by childhood exposure to other people's cigarette smoke. ``Children are really a captive audience,'' said Dr. Alfred Munzer, a spokesman for the American Lung Association and a pulmonary specialist at Washington Adventist Hospital in Takoma Park, Md. ``They're the ideal guinea pig, because they have no way of escaping their parents' smoke. It's not surprising that they should show the effects of passive smoking.'' Lung cancer may occur long after people stop smoking. Janerich said secondhand smoke may be especially hazardous to children because they have so many years ahead of them in which to develop lung cancer. ``It makes a strong case that exposure to secondhand smoke as a child increases your risk as an adult. This is quite convincing,'' commented Dr. Stanton Glantz of the University of California at San Francisco. The study turned up no evidence that smoking by spouses or co-workers causes cancer, although the researchers cautioned that their work could not rule out this possibility. The study was based on a survey of 191 non-smokers in New York state who were diagnosed with lung cancer in the early 1980s. Researchers calculated their lifetime exposure to cigarette smoke and compared it with that of healthy non-smokers. The researchers calculated each person's ``smoker-years'' _ the number of years they lived in a house multiplied by the number of smokers there. For instance, someone who lived at home for 18 years with two smoking parents had an exposure of 36 smoker-years. The study found that exposure of 25 or more smoker-years during childhood and adolescence doubles the risk of lung cancer. Twenty-seven percent of the cancer victims had this level of exposure, compared with 15 percent of the healthy comparison group. Household exposure of less than 25 exposure-years while growing up did not appear to increase the risk of lung cancer. Exposure to a husband or wife's smoke made up less than a third of total household exposure on average, and it was not linked with an increased risk. Munzer said this might be explained by the fact that spouses who work spend relatively few waking hours together at home, so their exposure to smoke is short. While the study did not examine the effects of passive smoking on the heart, some believe this may be an even more important hazard. In other work, Glantz has calculated that secondhand smoke may cause 10 times as much heart disease as lung disease. This would make passive smoking the third leading cause of preventable death behind active smoking and alcohol abuse.

DOC.HEAD: NBC Big Ratings Winner Again
LaserGraphic
With PM-Nielsens-List
DOC.TEXT: ``Cheers'' bumped ``60 Minutes'' from the No. 1 spot in the ratings after two weeks in which the Persian Gulf crisis helped put the CBS news magazine on top. In the overall ratings last week, NBC claimed first place for the 16th week in a row, with seven of the top 10 shows, the A.C. Nielsen Co. said Wednesday. Sunday's repeat of ``60 Minutes'' contained no updates on the Persian Gulf. ``I think the biggest reason was that it was a holiday weekend,'' program spokesman Roy Brunett said. ``People just weren't watching television.'' In the latest standings, ``60 Minutes'' plummeted to a two-way tie for 15th with NBC's comedy ``Grand.'' Overall, NBC had a 10.6 average, well ahead of CBS with an 8.8. ABC was last with an 8.7. Each ratings point represents 931,000 households. NBC's spinoff of the Oscar-winning film ``In the Heat of the Night'' grabbed its highest ranking ever. The story of a white Southern police chief (Carroll O'Connor) and his black detective (Howard Rollins) was No. 2. Fox Broadcasting's young Bart Simpson suffered another staggering loss to Bill Cosby on NBC. A special repeat Monday made ``The Cosby Show'' No. 5 in the rankings. In its regular Thursday time slot against ``The Simpsons,'' Cosby was No. 11. The animated Simpsons finished in a four-way tie for 53rd place. Fox's preview of the fall sitcom ``Parker Lewis Can't Lose'' won its Sunday time slot with an 8.1. ``True Colors,'' another Fox comedy, fared less well in its Sunday debut, capturing a 7.8. ABC and Peter Jennings won the network evening news battle again with a 10 average. CBS and Dan Rather were second with 9.3 and NBC and Tom Brokaw had an 8.7. Here are the top 10 shows, their network and rating: ``Cheers,'' NBC, 16.6; ``In the Heat of the Night,'' NBC, 15.7; ``Empty Nest,'' NBC, and ``Designing Women,'' CBS, (tie) 14.6; ``The Cosby Show'' (special), NBC, and ``Murphy Brown,'' CBS, (tie) 14; ``The Golden Girls,'' NBC, 13.8; ``Roseanne,'' ABC, 13.6; NBC Sunday Night Movie ``I Know My First Name is Steven,'' NBC, 13.4, ``A Different World,'' NBC, 13.3.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Stocks Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar lost further ground against the Japanese yen Thursday, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange lost moderately. The dollar closed at 141.65 yen, down 0.65 yen from Wednesday's close. After opening at 141.48 yen, the currency ranged between 141.35 yen and 142.45 yen. The Nikkei Stock Exchange of 225 selected issues shed 266.43 points, or 1.11 percent, closing at 23,811.91. The index lost 829.30 points Wednesday. In bond dealings, the yield of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond edged higher at 8.240 percent as of 3 p.m. (2 a.m. EDT), up from Wednesday's close of 8.180 percent. The price stood at 82.50 points, down from 82.76 points. Currency dealers said the dollar started lower following its overnight decline in New York, but the currency was bought back over reports that a U.S. citizen was shot by Iraqi soldiers in Kuwait. Masakazu Kimura, a dealer with Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank, said the dollar moved lower over dollar-selling by life insurance firms in early trading but was later bought back after the unconfirmed shooting reports. A State Department official said the government believed the report of the shooting was well founded. In stock trading, the highly watched Nikkei index posted a moderate gain during early trading, but retreated after rounds of buying, securities dealers said. ``The index lost as much as 292 points at one point with many market players taking a wait-and-see position because of lowering of futures,'' said a Nomura Securities dealer, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Meanwhile, North Sea Brent crude oil for November delivery was valued at $29.20 a barrel in Tokyo, up from its close of $28.60 in London Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Town Hoping to Cash in on Famous Ambush
DOC.TEXT: Arcadia is finally cashing in on Bonnie and Clyde, 56 years after the outlaws were blown away in a police ambush outside town. Visitors will stroll Barrow Boulevard, Trigger Trail and Ambush Alley during a monthly flea market that begins here Sept. 14. The three-day Bonnie & Clyde Trade Days will include booths set up by more than 500 dealers. ``We're not famous for anything else around here and the names of Bonnie Parker and Clyde Barrow are known nationwide,'' said Lamar Ozley, a lawyer and investor in the project. ``We just hope we can draw as many people as Bonnie and Clyde the day their bodies were hauled into town.'' About 20,000 people crowded Arcadia that day in 1934 after Clyde Barrow and Bonnie Parker, low-life killers made into tragic heroes by the Warren Beatty-Faye Dunaway movie, died in their tan 1934 Ford Deluxe in a hail of gunfire eight miles outside town. ``The mortuary was in the back end of a furniture store,'' said William Dees, 83, whose father ran a nearby bank. ``I went in there. The people actually tore up the furniture, standing on it, walking on it to get a look at the bodies.'' Arcadia has a population of about 3,000, but it had only 700 when Bonnie and Clyde died. Situated in north-central Louisiana, Arcadia was a good hideout area for bandits in the 1930s. U.S. 80 was their interstate and Bienville Parish was near the Arkansas line and about an hour's drive from Texas for criminals who didn't care about speed limits. Four Texas lawmen had trailed Parker and Barrow through a half-dozen states, finally getting a break when a Bienville Parish farmer, Ivey Methvin, offered to set up an arrest in exchange for dropping charges against his son, Henry. Henry ran with Bonnie and Clyde. The Texans, joined by Bienville Parish Sheriff Henderson Jordan and his deputy, Prentiss Oakley, hid by the side of Highway 154 near the Methvin farm on May 23, 1934. When the outlaws' auto came by, the officer fired more than 100 rounds. ``Prentiss told me the ambush bothered him,'' recalled Homer Oakley, brother of the late deputy. ``The fact is, if he ever drank much before then, I didn't know about it. But after the ambush, everybody knows he started drinking.'' ``I think Prentiss and the sheriff aged overnight,'' said Hugh Watson, retired chairman of Premier Bank in Shreveport. ``They were never the same after that.'' Watson, 17 at the time, said he worked in an Arcadia sandwich shop and served Bonnie and Clyde the night before they were killed. ``We weren't busy so I sat on the curb while they sat in the car and ate. We chatted. She asked if I had a comb. I got her one and she combed her hair,'' he said. ``Both of them were polite, ordinary looking, though she had kind of a coarse look.'' Watson said he discovered their identities the next day when their pictures appeared in The Shreveport Journal. ``People must have read the paper and heard it on the radio because Arcadia filled up,'' he said. ``The car was hauled into town with the bodies still inside. People were taking pieces off the car for souvenirs. ``One girl I went to school with wound up with one of Bonnie's shoes.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Botany Student Apparently Poisoned by Deadly Mushroom
DOC.TEXT: A woman who studied botany in college was reported near death and in need of an emergency liver transplant today after eating what doctors think were poisonous mushrooms. Roberta Rogala, 55, was in extremely critical condition at the University of Chicago Hospitals, said spokesman John Easton. Doctors believe Mrs. Rogala and her husband, William, ate poisonous mushrooms last week at their cottage in Dewey Lake, Mich. Mrs. Rogala, who studied botany in college, picked mushrooms and cooked them to put on hamburgers, said her husband, who also got sick but recovered. ``They were the purest white, pristine-looking mushrooms,'' Rogala said. ``I remember because she said to me, `Anything this pure can't be bad.' '' Mrs. Rogala went into a coma Friday and doctors said had gone into complete liver failure. ``She's a person who came name you 55 different plants by their names, so I really just went along with her,'' Rogala said. ``It doesn't matter at this point what it was _ the damage is done. Right now, we need either a miracle or a liver transplant.''

DOC.HEAD: Traffic Is Heavy At Exiled Government's Hotel Headquarters
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A red carpet is rolled up just inside the main entrance of the hotel housing Kuwait's government-in-exile, primed to be slapped across the glossy marble for any passing head of state. The hotel near this mountain resort in southwestern Saudi Arabia is home and headquarters for the deposed emir, Sheik Jaber Al-Ahmed Al-Sabah, and the entire Cabinet. Nearly all senior government officials escaped when Iraq invaded on Aug. 2. Visitors to the hotel about 50 miles east of Mecca have instant access to a whole battery of ministers they probably could not have reached by telephone in Kuwait before the invasion. ``You want three ministers in an exclusive interview?'' a diplomat acting as a press liaison officer asks before presenting the ministers of health, housing and municipal affairs for a 15-minute chat in the lobby. Most activity centers around an upstairs conference room on the same floor as the emir's suite. Arabic wire service stories about Cabinet ministers on the road and expressions of support for Kuwait are pasted across a bulletin board outside the room. The one constant on the board is a photocopied newspaper picture of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq hugging a detained child next to one of Hitler in virtually the same pose. ``History Repeats Itself!'' is scrawled under it with red felt marker. The television in the outer reception room is tuned to CNN. Press visits are easily arranged through an American public relations firm that was hired after Saddam's frequent television appearances convinced the Cabinet that their seclusion was losing them the sound bite battle. Traffic into the Cabinet room can be fierce. Aides scurrying between a battalion of facsimile machines jostle for space with white-jacketed waiters pushing carts laden with crystal goblets and plates of nuts. Everyone rises when a senior member of the royal al-Sabah family passes, but otherwise there is little formality. A reporter conducting an interview in the Cabinet room is interrupted when someone sticks his head in the door and tells him he has a phone call. ``Go take it,'' says Planning Minister Suleiman Al-Muttawa. ``I'll be here.'' But no one wants to be there for too long and they hope soon to return to Kuwait, about 700 miles to the northeast. The ministers echo Al-Muttawa in saying, ``We're hoping it won't extend even a period of months.'' The spirit infects the whole building. Conversations that end at lunch with ``Until next time in Kuwait'' are picked up again at dinner. The Cabinet eats with everybody else, and both meals are sumptuous affairs usually involving two whole sheep. Special food carts are wheeled into the suite of the emir, who has appeared twice on television since the invasion but refuses all interview requests and rarely emerges. A diplomat who met with him as part of his president's delegation said, ``The emir was very much in despair, tired and despondent. He kept saying, `You lost money but I have lost my country.''' Cabinet ministers' days center around dealing with refugee problems, trying to monitor events inside Kuwait and planning for reconstruction. Derogatory nicknames for Saddam and the Iraqis creep into all conversations, ranging from madman to ``the new Tatars,'' a reference to the hordes that swept out of Asia in the 13th century and pillaged culturally advanced Islamic cities. Cabinet members bristle at any reference to support for Saddam from other Arab countries. ``We haven't come to power over the dead bodies of our compatriots,'' stormed Al-Muttawa. The word Palestinian brings a grimace due to the Palestine Liberation Organization's support for Baghdad. Al-Muttawa says there is a sense of ``shame and frustration'' among the ministers for having lost Kuwait's independence. Even when they heard about the invasion they thought Iraq would stop just inside the border and try to negotiate its land and oil demands. But the ministers can also joke about their plight. When someone mentions a chronic lack of hotel rooms, one pipes up: ``Delegate that to the housing minister.''

DOC.HEAD: Longest-Held Western Hostage Marks 2,000th Day In Captivity
DOC.TEXT: American journalist Terry Anderson has marked his 2,000th day in captivity with no new word on whether he may be released soon. Anderson, 42-year-old chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, reached the grim milestone on Wednesday. He is among six Americans, four Britons, two West Germans and one Italian held captive in Lebanon. Most are held by pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem militants. Anderson, of Lorain, Ohio, was kidnapped in Moslem west Beirut on March 16, 1985, by Islamic Jihad, or Islamic Holy War. The latest report on him came from former Irish hostage Brian Keenan, who said after his release Aug. 24 that he had seen Anderson during his four years in captivity. ``I saw Terry Anderson some time ago. He's in good form,'' Keenan said after he was freed by a group calling itself the Organization of Islamic Dawn. The Irishman said he spent part of his time in captivity with Anderson, noting they were in chains and blindfolded much of the time. Keenan said Anderson ``appreciates the letters that he received from his family. He has a picture of his daughter, Sulome, which is some great companionship for him.'' Sulome, Anderson's younger daughter, has never met her father. She was born nearly three months after he was kidnapped. Lebanese newspapers have published several pictures and letters from Sulome, her Lebanese mother, Madeleine, and the hostage's sister, Peggy Say. In Dublin, the papal nuncio to Ireland pleaded with Iran's outgoing ambassador on Wednesday to undertake all possible efforts to obtain the release of the remaining Western hostages in Lebanon. ``I am certain that you will do all in your power to see that innocent human beings, of no matter what nationality ... held captive against their will, shall be enabled to regain the freedom, the dignity to which they have a right,'' Archbishop Emmanuel Gerada said during a farewell reception for Iranian Ambassador Bahram Ghassemi. Ghassemi, who is taking up a post in the Iranian Foreign Ministry, was widely credited with assisting in obtaining the release of Keenan. Islamic Jihad and other Shiite kidnappers are linked to Hezbollah, or Party of God. The fundamentalist movement is Iran's main ally in Lebanon and is closely linked with radical figures in Tehran. Apart from Keenan, two Swiss Red Cross workers held hostage in south Lebanon were freed in early August. Islamic Dawn freed U.S. hostages Robert Polhill and Frank Reed 10 days apart in April as a ``goodwill gesture.'' But one of the kidnappers' reputed mentors said this week the situation has changed and that no more Americans will be freed because of the U.S. military intervention in the Persian Gulf in response to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. ``If there's going to be a hostage release, it will be Europeans and not Americans,''' said Hussein Musawi, who heads a pro-Syrian wing of Hezbollah. He had announced before Polhill and Reed were freed that they would be released. ``The United States has spearheaded the West's occupation of Saudi Arabia after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, and that has eliminated the chance of releasing American hostages in Lebanon this year,'' he said. Musawi condemned Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait but added: ``We don't believe that Saddam's aggression should be confronted by an American occupation of our lands.'' However, unconfirmed reports have indicated the Iraqi invasion could indirectly speed up the release of all Western hostages. Witnesses who were in Kuwait during the invasion said 15 pro-Iranian terrorists convicted there in the 1983 bombing of the U.S. and French embassies were seen fleeing the central prison. Islamic Jihad had demanded the release of the 15. A Shiite source who has close links with Hezbollah said two Lebanese among the 15, believed to be the main focus of Islamic Jihad's demands, have returned to Lebanon since the prison escape. The story has not been confirmed by the kidnappers or Hezbollah. Musawi said European hostages held in Lebanon ``would be in a more favorable position than others.'' Another Shiite source, who is familiar with Iran's situation, said the U.S. deployment in the Persian Gulf region would hinder Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani's efforts to pressure the kidnappers into releasing the six American captives. Rafsanjani wants to improve Iran's relations with the West and faces opposition by Iranian radicals. But Rafsanjani's internal power was consolidated last month when Saddam, fearing for his vulnerable eastern flank with Iran, agreed to withdraw his troops from areas occupied during the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war, exchange prisoners-of-war and share sovereignty of the Shatt-Al-arab waterway with Iran. This, and the apparent escape of the Kuwait 15, has raised speculation that Iran will be better placed to arrange hostage releases and that Anderson's kidnappers have got what they want. However, the Shiite source noted that ``with American soldiers deployed in the gulf, Rafsanjani would have to think twice before making any friendly gestures toward Washington.''

President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will come to Japan in April for the first visit by a Soviet leader, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu said today. The timing of the long-awaited visit was set today during talks between Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze and Kaifu, Japan Broadcasting Corp. reported. ``I'd like to make it a good start of discussion on a peace treaty and territorial issues,'' Kaifu was quoted by an aide as saying. A visit by Gorbachev is further evidence of warming relations between the two countries after a decades-long chill caused by a dispute over islands off northern Japan seized by the Soviets near the end of World War II. Moscow has rebuffed efforts by Japan to regain the islands. After a third and final round of talks today, Shevardnadze and Japanese Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama signed documents to lay the groundwork for the visit. Their agreements also would facilitate Japanese technical assistance for the ailing Soviet economy and aid for victims of the 1986 Chernobyl nuclear disaster. For years, Japan has insisted that the small group of sparsely populated islands must be returned before there could be any real progress in economic or political ties. For its part, Moscow has emphasized increased Japanese economic cooperation, particularly in remote Siberia. But both sides now show a willingness to discuss a broad range of cooperation while continuing their negotiations on the territorial dispute. It was not immediately clear if any progress had been made on the islands' issue during Shevardnadze's talks with Japanese officials. After their first day of talks Wednesday, the foreign ministers issued a joint statement calling for Iraq to withdraw immediately from Kuwait and to release all foreigners being held in the two Gulf nations. Nakayama urged the Soviets to begin a unilateral reduction of troops in the Far East, as they have done in Eastern Europe, a Japanese Foreign Ministry official said. But Shevardnadze ruled this out, saying troop reductions in the Far East can be discussed only in the context of the overall military balance in the region, said the official, who briefed reporters on condition of anonymity. Instead, Shevardnadze proposed a series of confidence-building measures to improve ties, including exchanges of military personnel and prior notification of large military exercises, the official said. Nakayama said the two countries should instead focus on their fundamental differences in order to reduce their ``wide gap,'' the official added.

DOC.HEAD: Lottery Winner Crushed to Death in Dumpster With Less Than $10
DOC.TEXT: A man who may have blown $188,000 in lottery winnings on drink, limousine rides and real estate was found crushed to death at a dump after apparently falling asleep in a trash bin, police say. A pauper's burial was planned for Roy Clark, who detectives said had less than $10 in his pockets when his body was discovered Friday. ``Poof!'' sheriff's Detective Tom McCann said of the lottery money. ``I guess he just blew it.'' Clark's body was compacted by a garbage truck and found at the Orange County dump after he earned $40 the day before as a day laborer. Police could not locate any relatives. Clark, 39, won $188,000 in the Florida lottery last September. Detectives said they have not been able to trace all his winnings but know he spent some riding around in limousines and buying rounds of drinks for friends. They said they also heard he invested in several businesses and bought a condominium in Hawaii and land in California. Friends said Clark carried a picture of a girl he claimed was his daughter, Brandy, a student at the University of New Mexico in Albuquerque. But detectives found that no one named Brandy Clark was registered as a student. Clark had worked for a sod company and lived at a Winter Park apartment complex in 1989, when he befriended neighbors Chuck and Sandy Herbert. He moved from the complex after he won the lottery and saw the couple only occasionally until April, when he told them he was having legal problems getting his lottery winnings and needed a place to stay, the couple said. Clark lived with the Herberts and their three children. He disappeared after telling the Herberts he would be gone for a few days on a business trip with his lawyer to try to get his lottery winnings, the couple said. The medical examiner determined that Clark suffocated. He had alcohol in his system, but detectives don't know whether he was drunk.

DOC.HEAD: Thieves Go Fishing at Banks, Make Away With $20,000
DOC.TEXT: Thieves used nylon string and fish hooks to reel in at least $20,000 in cash, checks and food stamps from night deposit boxes at three banks over the Labor Day weekend, police say. ``I still don't see how they could do it,'' Police Chief Washington Long said. `I don't think they were amateurs.'' The thefts, noticed when the banks reopened Tuesday, took an even odder turn when authorities discovered some of the stolen checks and food stamps dumped in night deposit boxes at two other banks, Long said. The stolen goods were sealed in plastic bags filled with what looked like vegetable oil. The oil made it difficult to lift fingerprints, Long said. The police chief said more than one person probably carried out the thefts, done with three-pronged hooks. ``I don't think one person would be out there fishing by himself _ somebody else had to be watching,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Asked to Consider Moral Questions in Military Use of Dolphins
DOC.TEXT: Critics are questioning the morality of the Navy's plan to train naturally playful dolphins to guard nuclear submarines. ``We are militarizing space ... and now we have the audacity to think we can militarize animals. It is insane,'' Jeanne Clark of Hempstead, N.Y., said at a hearing Wednesday night on the Navy's plan to use as many as 16 dolphins to guard its Trident subs at Bangor. Animal-rights activists protested military use of dolphins after news reports in 1988, citing Navy records, said 13 dolphins in Navy training had died from 1986 to 1988. Nearly half suffered from lack of appetite or stomach ulcers. Other ailments included hepatitis and pneumonia. The Navy recently reported that none of its 142 marine mammals had died since June 1989. Animal-rights groups sued the Navy in April 1989, arguing that bringing dolphins to Bangor required an environmental impact statement under federal law. No dolphins are now at Bangor. Eight Trident subs are stationed there. The groups dropped the lawsuit in May when the Navy agreed to conduct the environmental review. The assessment is due next summer; Wednesday night's hearing was on its scope. Laurie Raymond of the Progressive Animal Welfare Society in Seattle said the assessment should consider scientific questions such as the effects of stress and cold water on the warm-water dolphins. Most speakers made more emotional arguments. ``We are polluting the moral environment,'' said the Rev. Gretchen Woods of Kitsap Unitarian Universalist Association. Les Bivens, associate head of the biosciences division at the Naval Ocean Systems Center in San Diego, said it would be difficult to address moral questions in the impact statement. But he said, ``I do not think the people here have anything to worry about whatsoever.'' A federal Marine Mammal Commission investigation in 1989 found no major problems in the Navy's dolphin-training program. In Boston, meanwhile, protests from animal-rights activists have led an aquarium director to rethink plans to trade an aggressive, unsociable show dolphin to the Navy. The New England Aquarium would have sent Rainbow, an 11-year-old male, to the secret underwater mammal program at the San Diego center. Aquarium director John H. Prescott said Wednesday he believed the trade would be good for Rainbow. But he added, ``If it's causing public concern, I must pay attention. It's not a closed issue.''

DOC.HEAD: New Law Allows Morgue Visits for Young Drunken Drivers
DOC.TEXT: Visits to the morgue can be part of the punishment for young drunken drivers under a law signed by Gov. James R. Thompson. Thompson approved legislation Wednesday that allows judges to decide whether drunken drivers under age 21 should be forced to visit morgues and hospitals to see the bodies of people killed in alcohol-related accidents. ``It will leave a lasting impression on young offenders and holds the promise of reducing drinking and driving,'' the governor said in a statement. Thompson also lowered the boom on owners of noisy car stereos. He signed a law against playing stereos so loud that they can be heard 75 feet from the car. Violators face a $50 fine.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Expands Dialogue with Vietnam
DOC.TEXT: The United States will open talks with Cambodia in an effort to reach an agreement that could end that country's nearly 20 years of civil war, says Secretary of State James A. Baker III. ``We don't suggest for one minute that we're home on Cambodia, but we think things are moving in the right direction,'' Baker told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Wednesday. He said the United States would hold talks in Laos with representatives of Hun Sen, prime minister of the Vietnamese-backed Cambodian government. The United States said in July that it would begin talks with Vietnam on the Cambodian civil war. The Bush administration has withdrawn its diplomatic recognition of the Cambodian guerrilla coalition, which included the Communist Khmer Rouge.
DOC.HEAD: Bush Postpones Campaign Trip to California, Colorado
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is postponing for one week a political trip to Colorado and California because of his weekend meeting in Finland with Mikhail Gorbachev and budget negotiations with Congress, the White House says. Bush, who had planned to make the western swing next Tuesday and Wednesday, instead will go to Denver, Los Angeles and San Francisco on Sept. 18-19. He will help raise funds for Rep. Hank Brown, the Republican candidate for senator in Colorado, and for Sen. Pete Wilson, the GOP gubernatorial candidate in California, in Los Angeles and San Francisco.
DOC.HEAD: Airline Industry Concerned About Rash of FAA Retirements
DOC.TEXT: The airline industry says it is concerned about a rash of retirements among key Federal Aviation Administration personnel, including air traffic controllers. The Air Transport Association, which represents major carriers, said Wednesday that the agency's loss of 341 people last month jeopardizes the FAA's air traffic control and airways operations. FAA spokesman Fred Farrar confirmed the figure and said it was twice the normal number of retirees for a month. He said the increase was primarily because of concern over possible changes in federal retirement rules. There are approximately 50,000 FAA employees. The Bush administration, in congressional budget negotiations, has proposed eliminating a provision that allows employees to get back their individual retirement contributions in two annual lump sums. If the rules do change, only those who retired 30 days before the program expires Sept. 30 would be eligible to get the lump-sum payments. Farrar said it was too early to tell what impact stepped-up retirements might have on the air control system.
DOC.HEAD: Korean, Taiwanese, Hong Kong Imports Face U.S. Duty
DOC.TEXT: The United States will begin collecting anti-dumping duties on synthetic sweaters imported from South Korea, Taiwan and Hong Kong as a result of a decision by the U.S. International Trade Commission. The commission ruled in a 2-1 vote Wednesday that the imports are sold at less than fair value, causing material damage to the U.S. domestic industry. The decision means U.S. Customs will be ordered to charge duties on the imported sweaters, the commission said. The announcement did not give the rates of duty, which could bring a combination of higher prices for the imports and reduced shipments. The finding was requested in a petition filed earlier this year by the National Knitwear and Sportswear Association, a U.S. industry group. The commission said imports accounted for 75 percent of the 14.9 million dozen manmade fiber sweaters purchased by U.S. consumers in 1989 and for 77.7 percent of total sweater purchases that year of 33.9 million dozen. South Korean synthetic sweaters led the 1989 imports with 37 percent of value and 3.75 million dozen sweaters, followed by Taiwan with 31 percent and 3.1 million dozen and Hong Kong with 12 percent and 1.3 million dozen, it added.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Foreign Minister to Visit Iran Sunday
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq will send Foreign Minister Tariz Aziz and other officials to Iran on Sunday, the first such high-level visit since war broke out between the two nations 10 years ago, the Iraqi News Agency reported today. The news agency did not provide any other details in the one-sentence announcement. The visit was agreed to before Iraq invaded and annexed Kuwait a month ago. But thanks to concessions Iraq has since made, it will aim to create the conditions for a direct meeting between Iraqi President Saddam Hussein and his Iranian counterpart, Hashemi Rafsanjani. Saddam has wanted such direct talks for years but Iran refused. But last month an increasingly isolated Saddam accepted Tehran's demands for an Iraqi withdrawl from territory occupied in the closing stages of the Iran-Iraq war, which ended in a cease-fire in August 1988. The Iraq president also agreed to exchange all prisoners of war and share the Shatt-al-Arab, the border waterway that provides Iraq with its only access to the Persian Gulf. Iran had said direct talks could begin only after Iraq accepted a 1975 treaty establishing the Shatt-al-Arab as the boundary between the two countries. No Iraqi foreign minister has visited Tehran since the Islamic Revolution which ousted Iran's Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi in 1979. Iran has condemned Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, but also has criticized the deployment of the U.S.-led multinational force in the Persian Gulf. It has also called for the removal of foreigners from Saudi Arabia, the site of three of Islam's holiest sites, and for an Arab solution to the conflict. Iran has said it would honor the U.N.-imposed embargo on trade with Iraq along the countries' sommon 730-mile border. The Iraqi concessions also have strengthened Rafsanjani's hand against radical opponents, diplomats in Tehran said in telephone interviews. Rafsanjani has been locked in a power struggle with hard-liners opposed to contact with the West.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``The Soviet cooperation in the gulf has impressed us to the point where we are even more interested in being supportive economically if we can be.'' _ White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater, on Washington's willingness to re-evaluate past opposition to channel economic help to the Soviet Union.

``It will leave a lasting impression on young offenders and holds the promise of reducing drinking and driving.'' _ Gov. James R. Thompson, on legislation he approved that allows judges to decide whether drunken drivers under age 21 should be forced to visit morgues and hospitals to see the bodies of people killed in alcohol-related accidents.

``Take it from a guy who knows a lot about unwarranted criticism. ... Once they pile it on, they just don't know when to stop.'' _ Vice President Dan Quayle, alluding to NASA's problems in a speech to employees at Johnson Space Center in Texas a few hours before NASA scrubbed the launch of space shuttle Columbia for the third time.

DOC.HEAD: Famous Ballroom Bans Disco After Utah Tourist Slain
DOC.TEXT: At 71, Roseland still calls itself ``the home of refined dancing.'' But since disco and hip-hop cut in on the foxtrot and the cha-cha, trouble has also resided at the nation's most famous ballroom. The mirrored lobby, which displays the shoes of the greats who danced there and the names of spouses who met there, also has a metal detector. And instead of taxi dancers, the ballroom now employs a battalion of bouncers and guards. There have been two murders at Roseland in the past six years, 16 felonies in or around it this year and increasingly angry complaints from neighborhood residents about late-night noise and drug use outside the club. This week, opponents found a focus. A tourist from Utah was stabbed to death when a gang of youths allegedly robbed his father and used the money for admission to the ballroom. Later in the evening, in an unrelated incident, a man was shot and wounded on the dance floor. On Wednesday, the club announced it would end disco programs by the end of the month. ``Ballroom dancing is Roseland's heart and soul,'' said manager Hilary Feshbach, who promised to find alternatives to disco to keep the ballroom solvent. In the early evenings, Roseland is much the same as ever. Crowds of mostly elderly men and women dance the foxtrot, the cha-cha and other ballroom favorites. Their numbers have steadily declined and about 10 years ago Roseland started a disco that opened at midnight on Fridays and Saturdays after ballroom dancing ended. The late show has drawn roughly twice as many dancers as the ballroom music, but it also attracted a younger, more intoxicated and more violent crowd. Police Inspector Lowell Stahl calls the change after midnight ``like Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde.'' The scene outside is even more troublesome. ``It's a nightmare,'' says Allan Abramowitz, who lives with his wife and young son in an apartment building nearby. ``I invite you to stay in my apartment any Friday or Saturday night between 2 a.m. and 6 a.m. You'd hear the car boom boxes. I live on the 10th floor and my windows shake from the bass.'' It's a different kind of shaking than the kind for which Roseland is famous. The ballroom's ``Hall of Fame'' displays shoes worn by Betty Grable, George Raft, Gregory Hines and Bill ``Bojangles'' Robinson. A plaque bears the names of more than 725 couples who met and married there. Roseland opened in a former carriage factory in 1919 and later moved into a skating rink. Legend has it the owner, Louis Brecker, needed a place to take his fiancee dancing that stayed open longer than his native Philadelphia permitted. Brecker's Roseland was lively but orderly. House taxi dancers partnered patrons for 10 cents a dance, but they couldn't accept gifts from them. Jitterbuggers were discouraged from jittering too frenetically. The twist was banned altogether. But styles of music and dance continued to change. Eventually, Roseland gave in to disco in an attempt to cover vast overhead. ``We just couldn't fight it,'' said Nancy Brecker Leeds, the founder's daughter who sold the place in 1981. ``It was all around.''

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Plunge In Tokyo, Dollar Drops Further
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index fell for the fourth consecutive day today, and the dollar sank further against the Japanese yen. The Nikkei Stock Exchange of 225 selected issues, which plunged 829.30 points Wednesday, fell 266.43 points, or 1.11 percent, today, closing at 23,811.91. So far this week, it has shed 2,166.46 points, or 8.3 percent. Securities dealers said the market started in a buying mood today following an overnight gain on Wall Street, but weakened after reports that a U.S. citizen had been shot by Iraqi soldiers in Kuwait while trying to avoid capture. ``The shooting report was a negative factor, but the market now has become less sensitive to unfavorable factors'' related to the Middle East crisis, said Kazuhiro Nomura, a trader with New Japan Securities Co. He said the day's loss in the index was moderate. The dollar closed at 141.65 yen, down 0.65 yen from its close Wednesday, when it fell 1.75 yen. Today's close was the dollar's lowest since 141.55 yen on Oct. 25, 1989. After opening at 141.48 yen, it ranged between 141.35 yen and 142.45 yen. ``The dollar was bought back to the middle of the 142-yen level when the shooting report circulated in the market, but the dollar was under selling pressure by life insurance firms,'' said a dealer with Sanwa Bank, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The dealer said the dollar's retreat also resulted partly from cross trading in which traders bought the yen for European currencies such as Swiss francs and West German marks. In bond dealings, the yield of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond closed at 8.245 percent, up from Wednesday's close of 8.180 percent. The price slid to 82.48 points from 82.76.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Lower, Gold Firms
DOC.TEXT: The dollar sank in European trading this morning as traders concentrated on U.S. economic weaknesses. Gold was higher. The dollar closed in Tokyo at 141.65 yen, down 0.65 yen from its close Wednesday. That was the lowest closing rate since Oct. 25, 1989. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 141.09 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Wednesday: _1.5557 German marks, down from 1.5630 _1.2968 Swiss francs, up from 1.2963 _5.2140 French francs, down from 5.2375 _1.7540 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7607 _1,160.50 Italian lire, down from 1,166.00 _1.1500 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1532 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9045, compared with $1.8990 late Wednesday. A trader in Milan, Italy, said the market expected bad news for the U.S. economy when employment figures are released Friday. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $388.25 at midmorning, up from $387.75 Wednesday. In Zurich, the bid price was $388.00, from $385.75 late Wednesday. Gold in Hong Kong rose $3.57 an ounce today, to close at $387.59. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.84 a troy ounce, up from Wednesday's $4.78.

DOC.HEAD: Cambodia Welcomes Planned Talks With U.S.; Govt-Rebel Talks Delayed
DOC.TEXT: Cambodia's Vietnam-backed government has welcomed a U.S. offer to meet and discuss ending nearly 20 years of civil war, but it is unlikely to yield easily on relinquishing power to a U.N. administration. In Jakarta, Indonesia, talks scheduled for today involving the Cambodian government of Premier Hun Sen and representatives of its guerrilla foes failed to get off the ground as the parties bickered over who should sit at the table. Secretary of State James Baker III told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Wednesday that U.S.-Cambodian talks would be held in the Laotian capital of Vientiane. He called it ``the next logical step'' in U.S. support for peace efforts. U.S. diplomats in Bangkok say no date has been set for the meeting. A Cambodian official today called it ``another step forward in the solution of the Cambodian problem.'' Hor Nam Hong, minister responsible for external affairs on Phnom Penh's council of ministers, spoke to reporters in Jakarta. Washington backs the non-communist resistance forces of Prince Norodom Sihanouk and of Son Sann, who are allied with the Chyinese-backed communist Khmer Rouge. The three forcea are battling the government Vietnam installed in Phnom Penh after it invaded in late 1978 and toppled the Khmer Rouge, which had during a nearly four-year rule tried to transform Cambodia into a radical agrarian commune, sending nearly 1 million people to their deaths. Plans for the talks in Jakarta were on the verge of total collapse earlier in the week after key figures threatened not to come, and the meeting did not begin as scheduled today. But Sihanouk's son, Prince Norodom Ranariddh, today said his father would come to Jakarta on Sunday. In reponse, Hor Nam Hong said the premier now plans to arrive Friday. The feared Khmer Rouge, the strongest rebel group on the battlefield, had threatened to boycott the talks if Hun Sen and Sihanouk did not attend. The talks were expected to focus on formation of a transitional government to govern while elections are organized. Each of the four Cambodian factions is supposed to be represented on the council. On Aug. 28, the United States and the other permanent members of the U.N. Security Council _ Britain, China, France and the Soviet Union _ adopted a Cambodian peace plan under which the world body would hold interim authority and disarm and regroup the four armies. But while Phnom Penh welcomed a major U.N. role, President Heng Samrin said again last week that his intention was ``to maintain the status quo _ both politically and militarily.'' Richard Solomon, the U.S. assistant secretary of state for Asian affairs, expressed disappointment last week when asked if U.S. officials had succeeded in getting the Vietnamese to persuade Phnom Penh to back the U.N. plan. U.S. and Vietnamese officials met at the United Nations on Friday in their second round of talks on the Cambodian conflict. Solomon said the Vietnamese still want the armies to remain in place and Phnom Penh to hold interim authority.

DOC.HEAD: Man Admitted Putting Bag Over Wife's Head in Suicide
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Humphry in 13th graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: A man told police he helped his cancer-stricken wife commit suicide by tying a plastic bag over her head to asphyxiate her, fearing painkillers she had taken wouldn't kill her. Bertram Harper's taped statement to a detective was played in a courtroom Wednesday during a hearing to determine whether he should be charged in the Aug. 19 death of his wife, Virginia. ``I helped my wife carry out her wishes. That's all I've done,'' the 72-year-old California man later told reporters. Harper said once his wife lost consciousness in their motel room after taking about a dozen painkillers, he pulled the bag over her head and tied it around her neck with rubber bands knotted together. He said he waited about an hour to make sure she was dead, then called Romulus police. The 30-minute audio tape of Harper's police statement was played during a preliminary hearing on whether sufficient evidence exists to try Harper on charges of murder and conspiracy to commit murder. Harper described to police his wife's cancer and their earlier commitment to end each other's suffering if necessary. The couple chose to do that in Michigan because they understood the state has no law against helping someone commit suicide, Harper said. Harper told police his wife washed down the pills with coffee liqueur and lay on the bed while she pulled a clear plastic bag over her head. He said they removed the bag when she complained it was too hot. Harper said they tried to put the bag over her head twice more, but she kept moving her hands and head. Harper said he secured the bag over his wife's head only after she lost consciousness. ``If I hadn't placed the bag, I don't know what would have happened,'' Harper said on the tape. ``Eventually she probably would _ perhaps come out ... of the sleeping pills, but then she'd have been back to square one _ she'd have been back in pain.'' A deputy Wayne County coroner, Sawait Kanluen, testified that Mrs. Harper died of asphyxiation. Kanluen said she had liver cancer but neither that nor drugs she had taken in the suicide attempt killed her. Harper's lawyer, Hugh Davis, denied to reporters that the couple came to Michigan to carry out their death pact because of the case of Dr. Jack Kevorkian, who helped an Oregon woman commit suicide in a Detroit suburb on June 4. Kevorkian has not been charged. Prosecutors continue to investigate. Harper said he and his wife learned from a book by Derek Humphry, executive director of the Hemlock Society, that Michigan has no law against helping someone commit suicide. The Hemlock Society is an organization advocating the right of terminally ill people to end their lives when and as they choose. The society is financing Harper's defense. Harper was jailed for a week before a bail bondsman he never met posted his $25,000 bond. District Judge Henry Zaborowski adjourned the preliminary hearing until Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Dry Weather Across Much of Nation
DOC.TEXT: Mostly dry weather prevailed across the nation early today and no relief was in sight from heat in the Plains and the South. Scattered thunderstorms were forecast for today in those areas, but oppressive heat was expected to persist. Temperatures were likely to soar into the 100s. Scattered rain was forecast for the Rockies, parts of the Midwest and New England. Dry, hot weather was expected in the Pacific Northwest. Inland temperatures were expected to soar into the 90s. A cold front pushing across Montana, the Dakotas, Minnesota and Wisconsin was likely to hit the Great Lakes today. The high Wednesday in the Lower 48 states was 106 degrees in East St. Louis, Ill. DOC.HEAD: 10-Year Study Concludes Acid Rain a Problem, Not Crisis
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 2nd graf to CORRECT Thursday to Wednesday
DOC.TEXT: After a decade of study, a scientific review concludes that acid rain is ``a long term problem'' requiring tougher pollution controls but is not an environmental crisis. Nevertheless, the report released Wednesday by the National Acid Precipitation Assessment Program said steep cuts in sulfur dioxide emissions, especially from Midwest electric utilities, will be needed to reverse the environmental damage of acid rain. The report made no recommendation on how steep or how soon the reductions should be made. It said a cut of 10 million tons of annual sulfur dioxide emissions would result in the recovery of highly acidic lakes and reverse other environmentally damaging conditions. Legislation nearing approval in Congress calls for utilities to cut annual sulfur dioxide releases by 10 million tons, or roughly in half, by the end of the decade, The National Acid Precipitation Assessment Program was established by Congress in 1980 to improve understanding of acid rain. It spent $537 million to conduct its decade of study. The scientific group's report was embraced by both those who are supporting steep cuts in sulfur dioxide emissions as well as critics of such cuts. The critics contend that severe pollution controls costing as much as $5 billion a year is an overreaction to the extent of the acid rain problem. ``The report provides strong evidence that there is time to implement more cost effective ways in which to mitigate the limited environmental impacts of acid rain,'' said Richard Lawson, president of the National Coal Association. He maintained the findings show that acid rain ``does not pose an environmental emergency.'' Thomas Kuhn, president of the Edison Electric Institute, said the findings ``point out that the damage from acid rain is much less than was feared in the late 1970s and early 1980s.'' But Eileen Claussen, a senior director involved with air pollution issues at the Environmental Protection Agency, said the report ``clearly establishes the link between (sulfur) emissions and environmental damage'' and supports the Bush administration's call for tough pollution controls by coal-burning electric utilities. The report acknowledged that acid rain is affecting visibility across much of the East, causes damage to some forests, reduces soil nutrients, kills some aquatic life, erodes buildings and statutes, and can pose health problems to some humans. It said that acid rain has shown to be most damaging to aquatic systems in the Adirondacks of New York State where 14 percent of large lakes and nearly a third of the smaller ones were highly acidic. Less of a problem was found elsewhere along the mid-Atlantic region and New England. James Mahoney, director of the group that conducted the study, outlined the draft report to a final meeting of the group and said its findings have ``reduced the scientific uncertainties'' about acid rain. ``Acid rain is correctly viewed as a long-term problem which should be resolved by permanent measures,'' he said.
