Mahoney said that while the study supports many of the scientific views expressed over the years on acid rain it also rejected other ``more extreme views'' such as those who consider it ``a flat-out crisis'' or those ``who would say there's no problem at all.''

DOC.HEAD: Rights Group Says Death Squads Killing A Child A Day
DOC.TEXT: Amnesty International said today that death squads formed to fight lawlessness in Brazilian streets are killing children at a rate of about one a day. The worldwide human rights group said an increasing number of homeless children are turning to crime to survive, leading to an increase in murders by death squads partly manned by off-duty policemen. In a report released today, the group spoke of hundreds of such killings and said there were also many cases of children being beaten, tortured and mutilated by policemen on duty. It cited Brazilian rights groups for the estimate of a death a day. The organization reminded president Fernando Collor de Mello of his pledge June 22 to stamp out the abuses. He said: ``We cannot be and will not again be a country cited as violent in reports by Amnesty International.'' It said an Amnesty delegation met Collor last month and asked for ``immediate, concrete action'' to stop the killings. The report cited the case of three boys picked up in Rio de Janeiro by military police last month on suspicion of trying to break into a store. It said they were made to play Russian roulette, and a 13-year-old, Leandro Cardoso da Silva, was shot ``in the head and dumped outside a hotel by police. He later died in hospital.'' ``Poor children in Brazil are treated with contempt by the authorities, risking their lives simply by being on the street,'' the report said. ``Their most basic rights are trampled on by the very people who should safeguard them.'' It said the death squads kill children to clean up the streets, remove witnesses or keep an area safe. ``On-duty police officers have shot youths dead simply for failing to stop their motorcycle when signaled to do so or for allegedly insulting a police officer.'' It said that while some officers and judges deplore the abuses, ``the authorities have generally failed to take action.'' The few cases that are properly investigated ``often take years to go to trial and result in negligible sentences. ``Police are sometimes slow to intervene to stop death squad abductions as they are taking place. When two boys were taken from their home by armed men claiming to be police, other officers in a patrol car refused the mother's request to search for the boys. They were later found dead.'' The report said young people on the streets or in detention are routinely tortured and ill-treated by police. It said the police use electric shocks, burn children with cigarettes, throw hot water on them and beat them with truncheons.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS WASHINGTON-dated 1st item in rdp to CORRECT spelling of `Intimate' in last graf.
DOC.TEXT: Fitzhugh Green, a retired government official and biographer of President Bush, died of heart problems Wednesday at age 72. He died at Newport Hospital in Rhode Island. After more than 25 years in the federal government, Green resigned in 1970 to run for Congress from Rhode Island as a Republican. After losing, he returned to Washington, working for the Environmental Protection Agency from 1971 to 1977, and again from 1983 to 1985. Green wrote several books, including ``George Bush: An Intimate Portrait'' published in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Fed Says Citibank Can't Sell Insurance Despite Delaware Law
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Reserve Board has ordered Citicorp to close its insurance operations in Delaware in a decision analysts say casts serious doubt on the ability of banks to expand into the insurance business. The decision, announced by the Fed on Wednesday, involves Family Guardian Life Insurance Co., a company controlled by Citicorp's wholly-owned Citibank of Delaware. The Fed announcement noted that Family Guardian was acting under a new Delaware law that permits state chartered banks in Delaware to ``conduct broad insurance agency and underwriting activities through a separate department or division of the bank or through a subsidiary of the bank.'' However, the Fed said it determined that ``these activities were not consistent with the board's regulation'' governing bank holding companies such as Citicorp. The Delaware law that took effect in May capped years of debate and lobbying by the banking and insurance industries and quickly led to the establishment of insurance operations by a number of leading banks in Delaware. The Fed decision, similar to one involving South Dakota several years ago, is in line with the insurance industry arguments that state laws are pre-empted by the Federal Bank Holding Company Act that does not allow a subsidiary of a bank holding company to engage in a business that the parent company is not allowed to engage in.

DOC.HEAD: Nineteen Masterworks Stolen, Included Picasso and Renoir
DOC.TEXT: Nineteen paintings worth more than $2 million, including works by Picasso and Renoir, were stolen by thieves who lowered themselves into a 5th-floor apartment by rope, police said today. Police said there was no burglar alarm system in the studio apartment in Cannes, owned by a former government official and used by his 30-year-old son, who works as a night watchman. The son, Armand Schwarz-Fuchs, discovered the theft when he returned from work early Wednesday, police said. Among the works reported stolen were paintings by 19th and 20th century masters Pablo Picasso, Pierre-Auguste Renoir, Edgar Degas, Amedeo Modigliani and Edouard Manet. Officials initially estimated the value of the stolen paintings at nearly $2 million, but police said today that the value was likely to be much higher. French press reports suggested there was uncertainty as to the origin of the paintings, and police said they wanted to talk with the apartment's owner, Jacques Schwarz-Fuchs, 62. A retired member of the Council of State, Schwarz-Fuchs reportedly is ill and receiving medical care in the eastern city of Strasbourg. According to police, the thieves broke through a balcony window of the apartment in Cannes after lowering themselves by rope from the roof, two floors above. There have been several major thefts of privately owned art works in the past two years in Cannes and nearby Nice. In December, eight oil paintings by Henri Matisse, valued at more than $12 million, were stolen from a Nice apartment. The works were recovered in January, and a suspect was sentenced to three years in prison.

DOC.HEAD: Shuttle Mission Scrubbed Because of Yet Another Fuel Leak
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 3rd graf, `Engineers worked...', to UPDATE with quote from official this morning. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `The launch...'. SUBS 8th graf pvs, `The seven...', to UPDATE with astronauts leaving for Houston.
DOC.TEXT: NASA engineers, embarrassed again by a space shuttle that can't fly, set off anew today on a hunt through a tangle of pipes for an elusive fuel leak that grounded Columbia for a third time. ``It is a real booger to try to find and isolate,'' shuttle boss Robert Crippen said after the mission was scrubbed Wednesday, 7{ hours before Columbia was to have lifted off at 1:20 a.m. today with the $150 million Astro observatory. Engineers worked on a troubleshooting plan through the night, but Crippen said that even if the hole is found immediately, Columbia could not leave on its long astronomy mission for at least three or four days and probably longer. ``We've got pretty good test data from what we did during the tanking and detanking of the fuel tank,'' NASA spokesman George Diller said this morning, referring to Wednesday's pouring of hydrogen into the half-million-gallon fuel tank. ``We've been looking at it all night and we will have some educated guesses later in the afternoon,'' he said. Because there are some propellants still on board, repair crews will not be able to enter the tail section of the orbiter until late afternoon, he said. At that time, NASA has scheduled a briefing for reporters by administrator Richard Truly and the top man in the agency's space flight program, William Lenoir. The launch would have been the 36th shuttle flight and the first in four months after a summer of similar leaks for NASA. That is the longest gap between missions since flights resumed following the Challenger disaster. NASA thought it had cured Columbia of leaks by installing new plumbing between the orbiter and its huge tank. Crippen said the leak that forced the first launch postponement, in May, was gone, but another leak appeared Wednesday inside the rear compartment. ``I think this leak has been there all along,'' he said. ``Trying to isolate it out from the other leak ... confused the data.'' ``My first reaction was frustration,'' said program scientist Ed Weiler. ``But my next thought was, `My God, I'm glad they stopped, some of my friends are aboard.' '' Hydrogen is highly combustiblle. The seven Columbia crewmen left for their training base in Houston at dawn. ``We will be ready when Columbia is fixed,'' said commander Vance Brand. The shuttle's rear compartment is a maze of pipes, pumps and valves that feed three huge engines, which push the shuttle into orbit once its booster rockets are spent. ``We do not consider that the vehicle is safe to fly,'' Crippen said. It was the second scrub in less than a week. Last Thursday, a day before the scheduled launch, launch control found that it could not communicate with one of the four telescopes in Columbia's cargo bay. That problem was fixed over the weekend. The telescopes, designed to study stars, galaxies and other hot objects, was supposed to have gone up in a shuttle in March 1986, but all flights were postponed because of the Challenger disaster two months earlier. Columbia must be on its way by Sept. 14 or face yet another delay. The shuttle Discovery, on a neighboring launch pad, has priority for a flight that must take place between Oct. 5 and Oct. 23 to send a probe winging toward orbit around the sun. The alignment of planets for that mission won't be right again for 13 months. Wednesday's countdown was stopped as technicians noticed an alarming buildup of hydrogen while the fuel was pouring into the shuttle tank at the rate of 8,400 gallons a minute. The concentration of hydrogen was 10 times over the limit when officials called a halt. They continued filling the tank, trying without success to isolate the leak. The problem is another in a series that began with the launch of the Hubble Space Telescope in April. The $1.5 billion telescope was supposed to see to the beginning of the universe; instead, it needs corrective lenses that can't be put on by astronauts until 1993. In May, the Columbia leak was discovered during fueling and the shuttle was trundled back to its hangar for tests and a new connecting pipe. The old one was found to be contaminated with tiny glass beads that made a path for leaking gas. In June, a fueling test on sister ship Atlantis showed it, too, had holes and the entire three-shuttle fleet was grounded. Last month, the Magellan space probe went into orbit around Venus after a 158-million-mile trip that began in May 1989. The euphoria was dampened when engineers twice lost touch with the probe. They said Wednesday that Magellan will start mapping the surface of Venus later this month _ even if they don't figure out the communications blackouts. Vice President Dan Quayle alluded to NASA's problems a few hours before the scrub in a televised speech to NASA employees from the Johnson Space Center in Texas. He said the space agency is up to doing the job it was assigned to do. ``Take it from a guy who knows a lot about unwarranted criticism,'' he said. ``Once they pile it on, they just don't know when to stop.''

DOC.HEAD: Israel Says United States Will Supply Patriot Missiles
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister David Levy said today the United States will supply Israel with Patriot anti-ballistic missiles and other advanced weapons it requested in light of the Persian Gulf crisis. Israel has asked Washington to bolster the Israeli military, maintaining that it faces dangers from Iraq and from new American arms being supplied to other Arab nations still technically at war with the Jewish state. Levy, who is in Washington, was interviewed on Israel radio today, a day after meeting with Secretary of State James A. Baker III. He said the United States agreed to meet Israel's request that it be supplied with additional weapons to maintain army superiority over its neighbors in the Middle East. ``Israel's qualitative edge is not only a basic American principle, but will be ensured by supplying Israel with all it needs to assure this superiority,'' Levy told Israel. He added that as part of the agreement, Israel would receive the Patriot anti-ballistic missile. In the gulf crisis, the United States has deployed Patriot missiles in Saudi Arabia to reinforce U.S. positions near the Kuwaiti border. The United States began its buildup of forces in Saudi Arabia after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Levy did not mention other specific weapons Israel had requested. The Israeli daily Maariv reported earlier this week that the government also asked for more F-16 jet fighters and Apache anti-tank helicopters than the United States earlier pledged to supply. The Defense Ministry said Thursday it had no information on the Patriot agreement. It has refused to discuss specific requests for U.S. arms, saying Israel does not disclose weapons transactions. U.S. officials made no announcement on the reported arms agreement. Israel receives $1.8 billion in U.S. military aid annually, more than any other country. Israel also gets $1.2 billion in other assistance, making it the largest recipient of U.S. aid overall.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Offers U.S. President Access to Country's Airwaves
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lead, EDITS thereafter to tighten
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Saddam Hussein today offered to televise comments by President Bush to the Iraqi public. He made the proposal in response to U.S. officials' complaints about the extensive air time given the Iraqi president in the West. Naji al-Hadithi, the director general of the Information Ministry, said he had received the instructions from Saddam and that an Iraqi television crew was ready to go to Washington to conduct an interview with Bush. He said the order was given so that Bush ``will have access to Iraqi public opinion.'' Iraqi Information Minister Latif Jasim told the Iraqi News Agency: ``The U.S. president has said that President Saddam Hussein has been fortunate to have the opportunity to address the American people and that he also would like to present his viewpoint to the Iraqis.'' The Bush administration reportedly has grown to hate what it calls the ``Saddamathons'' on CNN. The Atlanta-based network, carried by satellite around the world, has devoted hours of air time to Saddam's speeches, informal news conferences and a meeting with Western detainees. The other American networks also have given extensive coverage to Saddam since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 prompted the United States to send forces to Saudi Arabia. The interview with Bush would be unprecedented on Iraqi TV, a state-owned network that broadcasts a total of 14 hours each day on two channels. Baghdad television broadcasts interviews with Iraqi officials and, infrequently, with foreign dignitaries visiting Baghdad. It has never carried an interview with a foreign leader conducted abroad. Since the crisis started, Iraq's official media has carried extensive articles, commentaries, editorials and broadcast reports critical of the United States, the deployment of the U.S. multinational force and of Bush personally. Cartoons depicting Bush in a variety of guises and situations have become extremely popular in Iraq. Iraq's government daily Al-Jumhuriya today carried a cartoon showing Bush in an Arabic robe and headdress under the caption, ``Emir Bush.''

DOC.HEAD: Congressman Criticizes Legal System in Fairchild Execution Case
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Tommy Robinson criticized the legal system after the U.S. Supreme Court upheld a stay of execution for a convicted murderer who contends Robinson beat a confession out of him while sheriff. ``These legal maneuvers could go on for years,'' Robinson said in a statement issued through a spokesman, Rex Nelson. ``The time has come for Congress to limit the number of appeals that can be filed by those on death rows across the country,'' he said. Barry Lee Fairchild, 36, was spared execution by injection Wednesday when the high court declined to lift a stay granted the day before by a federal appeals court. Fairchild was convicted in the 1983 slaying of Air Force nurse Marjorie Mason. Also Wednesday, the FBI confirmed it was investigating reports of civil rights abuse by the Pulaski County sheriff's office, which Robinson headed when Fairchild was arrested. The FBI wouldn't say if the investigation covered the period when Robinson was sheriff. Fairchild's attorneys have contended in appeals that he was beaten into confessing by Robinson and his deputies. Robinson, a Republican, denies the allegations. ``I am tired of attorneys who waste a court's time and waste our tax money,'' Robinson said in the statement. ``I also am tired of groups that try to make heroes of convicted murderers and rapists. The rights of Barry Lee Fairchild were never violated.'' Robinson said he would work in the closing days of the congressional session for passage of a bill limiting federal court appeals. His tenure in Congress ends in January because he chose to run for governor instead of for re-election. Robinson lost the GOP gubernatorial primary in May. A three-judge panel of the 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ordered U.S. District Judge G. Thomas Eisele to look at new evidence presented by Fairchild's attorneys. Among the evidence are affidavits from four black men who claim they were accused of Ms. Mason's slaying and were beaten by Robinson or his deputies. Eisele said he will consider the new evidence Nov. 13. Assistant Attorney General Jack Gillean said three of the four men who submitted affidavits were suspects in the 1983 murder. He said police questioned the men days before Fairchild was arrested and questioned. Hall said the existence of the other suspects wasn't revealed to the lawyer for Fairchild at his trial, Joe O'Bryan. Such information could have helped convince the jury that ``police rounded up blacks and beat on them until they elected which one was the best one to be charged,'' Hall said. Gillean said he was told by the Pulaski County sheriff's office that the information about the three suspects was in the department case file and has no reason to believe it was withheld. O'Bryan said he hadn't known at the time of any other witnesses who might testify about coercion.

DOC.HEAD: Firefighters Treated to Air Conditioned Buses at Summer Blazes
DOC.TEXT: Hot firefighters have a cool respite from battle against major summer blazes thanks to the ``good neighbor policy'' of a bus agency. The Port Authority of Allegheny County has provided firefighters with air conditioned buses at the scenes of large summer fires for five years. The authority provides the buses six to 10 times each summer as part of a ``good neighbor policy'' with police and fire departments, Fincke said. ``We rely on the police heavily for help in traffic control, for security measures,'' he said. ``We try to help them when we can.'' Firefighters are grateful. ``When you come out of a building that's maybe a couple hundred degrees on the inside, if it's hot outside, you don't get much relief,'' firefighter Robert Walker said. ``If you go in the bus, you can cool down quite a bit.''

DOC.HEAD: S.C. National Guard Unit Getting Serious
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 15th graf, `I could...', to CORRECT `to' to `got'.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The 265th Quartermaster Detachment of the South Carolina National Guard is one of the reserve units called up for duty in Saudi Arabia. National Writer Fred Bayles is following the 14 Guardsmen as they prepare for deployment.

The usually raucous ride to the mess hall was quieter this noon as Sgt. Williams' words sank in. ``We don't have time for any attitudes,'' he told his men, all neighbors from around Allendale, S.C. ``An attitude is going to get people hurt when we're over there. We're on the same team and it's time to act like a team.'' The short lecture before lunch was just another sign that things are getting serious for the 14 members of the 265th Quartermaster Detachment. The water purification unit from the South Carolina National Guard trained hard this past week for deployment to the Mideast. But now the pace is even harder. The men go about the day's activities wearing gas mask packs and web gear to get used to the weight. Their forest-patterned battle dress fatigues have been exchanged for desert camouflage. Every early morning session of PT _ physical training _ sees more miles run, a subject of mild grumbling among the unit, where the average age is 35. ``If Saddam Hussein was chasing your ass across the desert you'd all do another five miles,'' chided Capt. Robert Appiah, the regular Army officer preparing the men for overseas. Every night goes a little later as the 265th commander, Sgt. Ronnie Jackson, pushes his men to practice radio communications, chemical protection and field operations. For Williams, the second in command, it is a question of survival. Called John by his men and his superiors, the usually smiling non-commissioned officer has been less cheerful these last few days. ``You realize what could happen and it makes you more serious,'' said the 42-year-old father of three. Williams, a computer programmer, is the only member of the unit who experienced combat. He has shrapnel scars in his back to remind him of the ambushes and firefights in Vietnam. They give him an appreciation of training and teamwork. ``I could get knocked off or Ronnie could get knocked off, so it's important that everybody learn to do every job,'' he said in his soft voice. ``You've got to look at every man as the one who might have to take over.'' The push to get ready has had its casualties. For Spc. Henry Harris, the 51-year-old retired teacher, it was sore knees. Sgt. Bill Bostick, 42, has a bad back. Sgt. Earnest Deloach reinjured a hamstring. All three were given light duty after being forced to report to sick call. The three went reluctantly, fearing they might be sent home. ``There was no way I was going to go if that was the case,'' said the 38-year-old Deloach. After giving blood for an AIDS test, a requirement of all troops facing deployment, Spc. Ulysses Calhoun stretched out on a couch and suggested he might need a long rest. Someone asked if he would like cookies and juice. ``No,'' said Calhoun, ``I believe a big T-bone and a 12-pack will fix up my blood just right.'' Still, for every light moment there is a reminder of the future. After lunch the 265th joined hundreds of reservists for a general briefing at the post's movie theater. When it ended the unit was asked to stay for a briefing on Saudi Arabia. The reservists filed out, some stopping to wish the unit luck. The 265th quickly found itself a lonely island of olive drab in a sea of red chairs. ``Damn,'' said Spc. Willie Badger, looking around the empty theater. ``All these people and we're the only ones going?''

DOC.HEAD: Oil Overflows Protective Dike, Spills Into Waterway
DOC.TEXT: About 5,000 gallons of heavy heating oil spilled early this morning into a creek that feeds the spill-plagued waterway known as Arthur Kill, the Coast Guard said today. Coast Guard Petty Officer David Cook said a 6 million-gallon storage tank collapsed around 4:30 p.m. Wednesday at the Hess Oil terminal on the shores of the waterway in Perth Amboy. Nearly all of the No. 6 heating oil was contained in dikes, but about 5,000 gallons overflowed at 1 a.m. into Woodbridge Creek, Cook said. The creek, which Cook said is not navigable, has been double-boomed to keep the oil from reaching the Arthur Kill. Cook said the Coast Guard is investigating why the storage tank collapsed. The overflow has been stopped, but oil still remains on the ground and is being pumped into other tanks, he said. More than 1 million gallons of oil have spilled into the Arthur Kill and the nearby Kill Van Kull this year, including a 570,000-gallon spill from an Exxon refinery in Linden, N.J., into the Arthur Kill on Jan. 2. The Arthur Kill, a widely used shipping channel, separates Staten Island, N.Y., and New Jersey. Kill is an old Dutch word for stream.

DOC.HEAD: Formal Talks End Without Agreement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout to ADD quotes, date of next talks, additional protest reports. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: President Roh Tae-woo told North Korea's Prime Minister today during a historic meeting that he hoped for a summit soon that could set the stage for Korean unification before the end of the century. ``Korea cannot remain the last divided nation on earth, separated by Cold War,'' Roh said. The two countries' prime ministers wound up two days of formal talks today without any major agreements, but Seoul officials said privately they were not displeased. South Korea's goal had been to open up dialogue with the communist North. Another round of discussions between the two nations is scheduled for Oct. 16-19 in the North Korean capital of Pyongyang. Roh's meeting with Prime Minister Yon Hyong Muk marked the first time a leader of South Korea has received an official representative of the rival North Korean government. ``To effectively solve pending issues between the South and the North, the top leaders of both sides should meet as soon as possible and set the framework for mutual cooperation,'' Roh said, according to an aide. The meeting was the climax of talks between the two Korea's prime ministers on easing political and military tensions _ discussions at the highest level between the rival states since the division of the peninsula in 1945. ``The first prime ministers meeting in 45 years should be a starting point for unification,'' Roh said. ``To achieve unification in this century, authorities of South and North Korea should continue dialogue and open the way for unification.'' With South Korean Prime Minister Kang Young-hoon also attending, Roh met the North Korean prime minister for about 20 minutes, said Lee Soo-jung, spokesman for the president. Afterwards, Roh spoke with six other North Korean delegates and three of their aides. Meanwhile, sporatic protests were staged to coincide with the meetings. Some of the protests demanded the withdrawal of 43,000 U.S. troops stationed in South Korea, saying their presence hinders dialogue on unification. About two dozen radical students unfurled a unification banner and tossed anti-American leaflets outside a hotel where South Korean political leaders held a dinner. Eight people were arrested. About 500 radical students yelling anti-U.S. and anti-government slogans clashed with police outside Seoul's Kunkuk University. At Cheju University in southern Korea, about 300 students fought police with firebombs for an hour protesting anti-communist security laws, news reports said. In southern Kwangju city, students burned an American flag in front of a U.S. Air Force facility, according to news reports. Earlier in the day, five dissidents were arrested when they tried to enter the hotel where the meetings were held. They wanted to deliver a letter to the premiers. One of the five was the wife of Suh Kyung-won, a former opposition legislator sentenced to prison for 10 years illegally visiting North Korea. In the final meeting, North Korea reiterated its demands that South Korea release jailed dissidents, halt a joint U.S. military exercise and stop efforts to seek its own seat in the United Nations, said an official speaking on condition of anonymity. The Joongang Daily News said South Korea had offered to discuss the three issues if certain conditions were met, but that North Korea did not immediately accept. The newspaper quoted unidentified officials as saying South Korea offered to consider a suspension of the Team Spirit military exercise with U.S. forces if North Korea was willing to remove offensive forces along the heavily armed Korean border. The newspaper also said South Korea agreed to consider releasing dissidents jailed for traveling illegally to the north if the north agreed to sign accords permitting travel, mail and transportation between the two nations. The paper said South Korea had offered to delay applying for U.N. membership, a major point of contention. Both nations, each claiming to represent the entire peninsula, have permanent observer status at the United Nations.

DOC.HEAD: Most Americans Would Flunk Sex Knowledge Test, Survey Says
With PM-Sex Questions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to CLARIFY lubricant type and explanation of its effect, SUBS 4th graf to CORRECT statistic on menopause and CLARIFY description of erection question. Pickup 5th graf, ``I'm not surprised...'' Note contents.
DOC.TEXT: Most Americans would flunk a test of basic knowledge about sex, says a new survey that's old news to sex experts. Fifty-five percent of people surveyed could not get at least 10 of the 18 questions right in the test, designed by the Kinsey Institute. Half didn't know that a woman can become pregnant while having her period, the report said. Half also did not know that oil-based lubricants, like petroleum jelly, shouldn't be used with condoms or diaphragms. Such substances can erode microscopic holes in condoms or diaphragms, the Kinsey report said. Half the respondents incorrectly believed anal intercourse itself can cause AIDS, even if neither partner is infected by the virus; nearly 30 percent incorrectly said that menopause causes most women to lose interest in sex; and only 35 percent knew that problems with achieving erections usually begin with physical causes. ``I'm not surprised at all'' by the poor showing, Virginia Johnson Masters, director of the Masters & Johnson Institute in St. Louis, said in a telephone interview. She said people just do not seem to absorb factual information they hear about sex, unless a sex-related problem affects them or a family member or friend, or they are health professionals who deal with sexual problems, or they have a good understanding of sexual function and behavior. The results also made sense to Debra Haffner, executive director of the Sex Information and Education Council of the U.S., a nonprofit organization that promotes sex education. The group ``believes that until there is comprehensive sexuality education for all people from childhood through adulthood, that we will continue to see this alarming degree of sexual ignorance that causes both personal pain as well as significant disease and dysfunction,'' she said. Kinsey institute director June Reinisch said Wednesday the questions were drawn from those most often asked of the institute. They represent facts that ``people need to know for both their physical health and their mental health,'' she said. Nearly every question ``affects people's feelings about themselves, their self-esteem,'' she said. A recurring theme in questions asked of her, she said, is ``Am I normal? ... The reason we don't know what's normal is that we're not taught what's going on.'' Among the poll's other findings: Only about 25 percent knew that the typical American has first intercourse at age 16 to 17, or that an estimated 30 percent to 40 percent of married men have had an extramarital affair. And only 21 percent knew that more than a quarter of American men have had a sexual experience with another male as a teen-ager or adult. Poll results emphasize a need for sex education of pre-teen children and of medical school students, because the poll found people turn to doctors for sex information, Reinisch said. Less than 20 percent of poll participants got at least 12 questions right, and only five people out of the 1,974 polled answered at least 16 questions correctly, Reinisch said. Participants from the Midwest generally scored best, with 55 percent passing, followed by 47 percent in the West and 40 percent in the South and Northeast, she said. Overall there were no differences in accuracy by sex, but men did better in questions about rates of sexual behavior and women in questions about sexual health care and contraception, Reinisch said. The poll is described in a new book, ``The Kinsey Institute New Report on Sex.'' At a news conference, Reinisch said the poll was financed by book publisher St. Martin's Press and the Kinsey Institute for Research in Sex, Gender and Reproduction. In addition, The Roper Organization, which conducted the poll, was ``very generous,'' she said. The poll involved face-to-face interviews with a nationally representative sample of Americans, done last October as part of a larger Roper survey. Twelve questions were answered on a questionnaire that a person slipped into an envelope before returning to the interviewer. The margin of error was plus or minus 3 percentage points. The overall percentages exclude 263 participants who answered 10 or fewer of the 18 items. The remaining participants were still a representative sample, Reinisch said.

DOC.HEAD: Returned Hostage Starts Fifth Grade
DOC.TEXT: There were yellow ribbons everywhere as 10-year-old Jennifer Anderton reported to her fifth grade class in Larkspur Elementary School, fresh from one month as a hostage in Kuwait. ``Let's start school,'' she said without hesitation Wednesday, giggling with joy as 180 schoolmates and teachers greeted her at the school in the foothills of Douglas County. Classmates crowded around her on the front sidewalk, around the flagpole and beside the golden-iced cake, scripted in amber-colored icing: ``Welcome Home, Jenny.'' Then principal Cheryl Dunkle led the whole student body in the pledge of allegiance to the American flag. Jerrifer's pals Delisha Donnelly and Justin Sinn wouldn't have imagined such a reunion several months ago, when Jennifer left for a two- to five- year stay in Kuwait with her parents, Bonnie and Richard Anderton. The Iraqi invasion shattered those plans, trapping Jennifer and her parents, Bonnie and Richard Anderton, in the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait City since early August. Jennifer and her mother were allowed to return to Colorado on Monday. Her father, an engineer, is still in Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Investigators Begin Searching Apartment Of Gainesville Slaying Suspect
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with authorities saying searches of Humphrey's apartment, grandmother's apartment under way. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `Four women...'.
DOC.TEXT: Investigators in the slayings of five Gainesville students today searched the apartment of an 18-year-old part-time student charged with beating his grandmother. Alachua Sheriff's Lt. Spencer Mann also said that 180 miles away, in Indialantic, task force investigators also were searching the home of Edward Lewis Humphrey's grandmother, as well as his black Cadillac parked there. ``The searches were begun simultaneously'' at about 9:30 a.m., Mann said. Mann said search warrants were obtained late Wednesday, and would remain sealed temporarily. Today was the first time investigators have acknowledged obtaining search warrants in the case. They have said Humphrey is one of eight suspects. The Gainesville Sun reported in today's editions that investigators on Wednesday searched a Gainesville Best Western motel room where Humphrey's mother had stayed in August. Investigators released no details on that search. Humphrey's attorneys were in court this morning asking a Brevard County judge to reduce Humphrey's $1 million bond. He was arrested Aug. 30 on a charge of aggravated assault after he allegedly battered his 79-year-old grandmother. An initial bond of $10,000 was increased after task force investigators said he was a possible suspect in Gainesville. Investigators have refused to confirm a Miami Herald report Wednesday that the five college students' bodies were posed for maximum shock value. Police have previously said, without elaboration, that the killer appeared to have left taunting ``messages'' for them in the way he arranged evidence at the scene. Meanwhile, an expert who examined the off-campus apartments for fingerprints with a high-tech light-intensifying device said the killer was methodical and cautious and had left practically no evidence behind. Four women and a man, all students at the University of Florida or Santa Fe Community College, were slain last month in three attacks that terrorized the town. Three victims were mutilated; one of the three was decapitated, police said. The killer placed the severed head in the direct line of vision of anyone entering the apartment and positioned a mirror in an apartment to show another victim's body to anyone who happened to look in the window, the Herald said. The killer also poured bleach onto the genitals of the four women victims in an apparent attempt to confuse investigators about whether they were sexually assaulted, the newspaper said, citing unidentified sources. Police would not confirm the report and have refused to say whether the victims were sexually assaulted. On Monday, however, police Capt. R.B. Ward said: ``In the scene, the set-up, there was a message _ to law enforcement, to whoever. ... He was very calculated, very methodical in the way the person did things, as well as left things.'' After examining the apartments for fingerprints, Dr. Michael West, a deputy medical examiner and forensic dentist from Hattiesburg, Miss., said Wednesday, ``I've never been associated with a crime scene that had so many violent attacks and so little evidence left behind.'' ``This individual that perpetrated these crimes is not your average criminal,'' West said. ``He's very methodical, and very neat. He doesn't leave any traces of his presence in the crime scenes.'' He said he turned up prints but that they probably belonged to residents of the apartments. He said he was certain the killer left no prints. Only Humphrey and Stephen Michael Bates, a 30-year-old Lakeland short-order cook, have been mentioned publicly as suspects. Bates has been held in the Polk County Jail on $100,500 bail since his Aug. 29 arrest in an unrelated assault case. About 600 people attended a memorial service for the victims Wednesday. Michael Browne, student body president, said, ``This hurt so badly because the people taken from us were just like us.'' The victims were Christa Hoyt, 19; Sonja Larson, 18; Christina Powell, 17; Tracy Paules, 23; and Manuel Taboada, 23.

DOC.SECOND: PM-Pebble Beach Sale, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0512,0292
DOC.HEAD: Japanese Compay Buys Famed Pebble Beach Golf, Resort Area
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 4th graf, `Pebble Beach...', to include lone cypress tree as part of sale. Picks up 5th graf, ``Company officials...'. A version moved on sports wires and financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: A Japanese company is the new owner of the Pebble Beach Co., which owns and operates luxury resorts and golf courses on Monterey Bay. Ben Hogan Properties bought the 5,300-acre property 110 miles south of San Francisco from a real estate partnership, company officials announced Wednesday. Its Japanese parent company is Cosmo World Corp. The purchase price was not disclosed, but local sources said it was more than $1 billion. Pebble Beach Co.'s properties include the Pebble Beach Golf Links, The Lodge at Pebble Beach and the Inn and Links at Spanish Bay. The property also includes famed Spyglass Hill and Del Monte golf courses, 17-Mile Drive and substantial real estate parcels on the Monterey Peninsula. The sale also includes the famous lone cypress tree, a popular tourist attraction on a windswept finger of rock along the 17-Mile Drive near Carmel. The tree has been photographed by such famous photographers as Ansel Adams and Edward Weston; recently, the Pebble Beach Co. was embroiled in a dispute with professional photographers when the company barred commercial use of photos of the tree, which is the company's trademark. Company officials said they expect no changes in the management of the resort area. Cosmo World Corp., headed by Minoru Isutani of Tokyo, is a privately held company that has built more than 15 golf courses in Japan as well as other projects in Europe and the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Upholds Dismissal of Iran-Contra Case
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court today upheld a judge's dismissal of charges against an Iran-Contra scandal defendant because the government refused to allow the defense to use classified materials. Joseph Fernandez, the CIA station chief in Costa Rica from 1984-86, was entitled to the material to defend himself against charges that he lied to investigators about a scheme to send military aid to Contra rebels in Nicaragua, said a three-judge panel of the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. Fernandez planned to use the classified evidence to argue that he did not lie about his knowledge of former National Security Council official Oliver North's involvement in the scheme and the type of supplies being sent to the Contras. ``Whether a jury would believe Fernandez's defense is speculation. But to preclude the jury from considering evidence relevant to this defense would be to deprive him of fundamental constitutional protections,'' said the opinion by Judge J. Harvie Wilkinson III. He was joined by Judges William W. Wilkins Jr. and Robert F. Chapman. The 40-page opinion deletes numerous mentions of sensitive national security information. U.S. District Judge Claude M. Hilton of Alexandria dismissed the case last November after the government refused to submit the classified material sought by Fernandez. The former CIA station chief had been indicted on two counts of lying to investigators and two counts of obstructing justice. He was accused of telling investigators that a Costa Rican airstrip was for training that country's military in case of an invasion by Nicaragua when in fact the airstrip was used to illegally resupply the Contras. He also was accused of falsely saying he did not know of North's involvement and did not know that supplies he helped deliver to the Contras in 1986 contained military aid. Fernandez asked to disclose nearly 5,000 classified documents at his trial.

DOC.HEAD: High Church Officials Also Sometimes Stumble Sexually
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS 11th graf of b0394 of Sept. 5, _Roman Catholic . . . lay miniter., to fix spelling of hierarchy.
With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Sexual straying sometimes hits in high ecclesiastical circles, jarring officialdom and the rank and file. When an ordinary priest or minister gets involved in a sexual tangle, a frequent occurrence according to studies, it's scarcely noticed, and often not publicly at all. But reactions are intense when it happens to high magisterial prelates, as shown by several recent cases. Careers are toppled and questions swarm about why the respected churchmen let it happen. ``It's individually complicated, but it's related to the collapse of the clerical culture, a collapsing of all hierarchical structures,'' said Eugene Kennedy, a noted Roman Catholic psychologist. ``Supports to a celibate life of authority, prestige and privilege were given when the hierarchical structure functioned, but these do not exist anymore. The rules become more difficult to see and the role is blurred.'' Under the circumstances, he added in a telephone interview, ``these kinds of failures wouldn't surprise me.'' While deviation from the celibacy rule marked recent cases of notable Roman Catholics and that of a Greek Orthodox bishop, it was an extra-marital affair that tripped up an eminent Protestant leader. The Rev. Allen Boesak, 44, a renowned anti-apartheid leader in South Africa, resigned Aug. 10 as president of the World Alliance of Reformed Churches after admitting a sexual liaison with a television producer. ``A prophet is human and gets scared,'' the repeatedly jailed and threatened Boesak once told American Presbyterians. ``A prophet fails often. He can give in to temptation. And if that happens, who will confront the world?'' Other prominent cases include: _ Roman Catholic Archbishop Eugene A. Marino, 56, of Atlanta, the first black archbishop in the American hierarchy, resigned July 10 after revelations of a two-year ``intimate relationship'' with a young woman singer and lay minister. _ The Rev. Bruce Ritter, 63, founder of New York City's Covenant House and a multimillion-dollar string of shelters for young runaways, resigned last February after accusations of sexual affairs by male youths. An investigative report released in August found he had a consistent pattern of sexual misconduct. _ Greek Orthodox Bishop Anthimos, 57, resigned as head of the church's Denver diocese in 1987 at the behest of Patriarch Dimitrios I of Istanbul, Turkey, after the bishop was accused of seducing a priest's daughter and keeping her in ``sexual servitude.'' In Greek Orthodoxy, priests are allowed to marry, but bishops are vowed to celibacy, as are Roman Catholic priests and bishops. These four cases involved ecclesiastical heavyweights with honored positions and powerful influence in their churches, a different level than the promotional TV preachers snared in sex scandals. Jim Bakker, 49, who left his PTL network in 1987 after revelations of extra-marital sex with former church secretary Jessica Hahn and hush money paid to her, was sentenced last fall to 45 years in prison for defrauding contributors. Jimmy Swaggart, on his TV show in 1988, tearfully confessed ``moral failure'' and a New Orleans prostitute recounted paid sessions with him. Both Swaggart and Bakker were defrocked by the Assemblies of God, Swaggart after refusing a year-long disciplinary suspension. The TV preachers, focused on their own individual followings of mostly impersonal and remote audiences, contrast distinctly with high-ranking church dignitaries, but none is immune to sex scandal. The U.S. Protestant and Eastern Orthodox establishment of the National Council of Churches was rocked in 1983 when former United Bishop James Armstrong resigned both as bishop and as council president, saying he had failed his family and the gospel, later indicating female involvement. A brilliant, leading member of the French Roman Catholic hierarchy, Cardinal Jean Danielou, 69, died of a brain hemorrhage in 1974 in the Paris apartment of a young go-go dancer and prostitute. Police and church authorities tried to hush it up but abandoned the attempt after a French weekly published details. Danielou was carrying much cash and some theorized he hoped to buy her freedom from racketeers using her for prostitution. Kennedy, a much-published professor at Loyola University in Chicago, said that clergymen, as trusted counselors of distressed people seeking solace, are susceptible to sexual involvement if they aren't careful. ``This is common in all the helping professions,'' he said. ``Whenever someone has an emotional need, they quickly transfer that need to the person helping. But counselors are trained to understand what's happening. ``That's what it means to be professional, to accept someone's problem without being entangled in it. If they are, then they are no longer able to help.''

DOC.HEAD: Suspected Collaborator Killed, Palestinian Shot by Troops
DOC.TEXT: Masked Palestinian youths Thursday beat to death a 70-year-old Arab man who was suspected of selling land to Israelis in the occupied West Bank, Arab reports said. The victim, identified as Sami Khurshi of the village of Jaius, allegedly sold lad that eventually was incorporated into a Jewish settlement, villagers said. The slaying was claimed in slogans painted on walls and signed by the Black Panthers enforcement squad, the villagers said. The army said it had no information about the killing. Khurshi's death raised to 256 the number of Palestinians killed by fellow Arabs since the Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation began in the West Bank and Gaza Strip in December 1987. Most were suspected of collaborating with Israeli authorities or dealing in drugs or prostitution. At least 728 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians in the revolt. Forty-seven Israelis have died. In Gaza City on Thursday, a Palestinian man was shot in the head by Israeli troops who were pursuing masked stone-throwers, the army said. The man, Tasir Rahman, 23, was reported in serious condition at Saroka Hospital in Beersheva. Meanwhile, Palestinian shops and offices were shuttered in the territories in a general strike called by the Moslem fundamentalist movement Hamas, or Zeal. The strike was called to show solidarity with Iraqis and Kuwaitis. In leaflets distributed in the territories, Hamas has opposed the Iraqi takeover of Kuwait but has also expressed opposition to U.S. troops in the region. A major Hamas leader who had been jailed for most of the past 30 months was freed this week, residents in the Gaza Strip said Thursday. He is Dr. Abdel Aziz Rantisi, a physician who was a founder of Hamas and is said to have written the first leaflet distributed during the uprising. Rantisi, a resident of the Khan Yunis refugee camp in Gaza, was convicted and sentenced to 30 months in prison for his role in founding Hamas. Israeli authorities describe Hamas as a paramilitary fundamentalist Moslem group.

DOC.HEAD: Government Disperses Opposition Rally; Second Time in Week
DOC.TEXT: Security forces used tear gas and truncheons Thursday to disperse government opponents who tried to hold a protest march in the city center. It was the second time in a week opposition parties have been prevented from marching. President Felix Houphouet-Boigny legalized opposition parties in May after unprecedented unrest in this West African nation, but authorities have often refused the parties permission to hold rallies. Soldiers carrying automatic rifles took up positions Wednesday night in downtown Abidjan after the government warned it would block demonstrations. Authorities alleged that the government opponents hope to disrupt the visit of Pope John Paul II, who arrives Sunday to consecrate the huge basilica that Houphouet-Boigny had built in his hometown of Yamoussoukro. The scheduled reopening of high schools and universities, closed in April after violent protests, was delayed until after the pope's visit. Opposition parties have accused Houphouet-Boigny's government of corruption and blame it for the collapse of the country's economy. Houphouet-Boigny has ruled Ivory Coast since it gained independence from France in 1960. The government has been unable to pay its foreign debt for two years, and many foreign firms have left the country. Tax rates are among the highest in the world.

DOC.HEAD: Government Closes University To Prevent Student Violence
DOC.TEXT: The military government closed Khartoum University on Thursday and ordered students off the campus after repeated strikes against new regulations. Thousands of students have been protesting a new system that requires payment for housing and food, which formerly were provided without charge. The first strikes were staged last month and lasted three days each. Opponents say the rules will make education affordable only to the relatively well-to-do. Sudan is among the poorest countries in the world. On Wednesday, striking students occupied lecture halls and prevented non-strikers from entering. Police have not intervened, but the government apparently was concerned that violence could erupt. In previous years, students in conflict over various issues have attacked one another with sticks and knives. Abdeen Mohamed Ali Saleh, the university's acting vice president, announced the indefinite closure of the university, which has 9,000 students. He said the move was taken to prevent ``escalation of a situation that may result in human and material loss.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Judge Says Gallery, Director Must Stand Trial
DOC.TEXT: A judge ruled today that an art gallery and its director must stand trial later this month on obscenity charges for displaying five sexually graphic photographs by Robert Mapplethorpe. Dennis Barrie and the Contemporary Arts Center already were scheduled to go on trial Sept. 24 each on one misdemeanor charge of using children in material involving nudity. The obscenity case will be heard the same day. In his ruling today, Hamilton County Municipal Judge David Albanese rejected a defense request to dismiss the obscenity charge. Defense lawyers had contended that the pictures were a legitimate art exhibition and immune from Ohio's obscenity law. ``That is contrary to the ... law,''' Albanese said. ``The affirmative defenses and issues of credibility are for the trier of the case to decide.'' Albanese today also granted a prosecution request to limit the obscenity case to the five photographs described in the indictment against Barrie and the center. He rejected defense claims that the jury had to consider all of the photos in the exhibition _ including shots of flowers and sculpture _ because the show was a survey of Mapplethorpe's life. ``A photograph makes an immediate impression,'' Albanese said. ``The court finds that each photograph has a separate identity.'' He said prosecutors only have to prove that one of the photographs is obscene to win a conviction. Among photographs at issue in the case are separate shots of a boy and a girl with their genitals exposed. The maximum penalty for each charge is a $1,000 fine and six months in jail for Barrie and $5,000 fine for the Contemporary Arts Center. The charges were filed April 7, the day the six-week exhibition opened to the public. The exhibition closed May 26, after 81,000 people had visited the gallery. The Mapplethorpe exhibition opened Aug. 1 at the Institute for Contemporary Art in Boston. A court clerk in that city on Wednesday refused a request to file obscenity charges.

DOC.HEAD: Biden Says Drug Situation Worse Than a Few Years Ago
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New material, editing throughout with hearing.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Joseph R. Biden Jr. agreed today with the Bush administration that advances have been made in the war against drugs, but said the situation still remains far worse than it was a few years ago. ``It's been a year (since the administration announced its national drug control strategy) and I think you've made some great progress,'' Biden, D-Del., chairman of the Judiciary Committee, told national drug control policy director William J. Bennett. However, Biden said, ``We have a way to go to get even to the '84 level, much less dealing with this problem.'' ``We're not saying the war is over.... We're certainly not saying it will be over soon,'' Bennett responded. President Bush had said Wednesday, ``I think America is making progress against drugs and will continue to do so.'' Bush and Bennett released a document showing declines in emergency room admissions for cocaine and heroin, surveys showing Americans' increasing hostility toward illegal drugs, and increases in prices for cocaine and reductions in its purity, indicating a reduction in supply. The statistics indicate the wholesale price of a kilo of cocaine now ranges from $17,500 to $35,000, up from a range of $11,000 to $25,000 last year. But Biden noted that the wholesale price in 1984 was $40,000 to $50,000. In addition, he said, while the number of cocaine-related emergency room cases declined slightly last year to 42,145 at hospitals checked by the federal government, those emergency rooms had only 10,248 cocaine-related cases in 1985. Bennett asked Biden if he could persuade his colleagues on Capitol Hill to continue their pattern of giving the drug war even more money than the administration requested. ``It'll be a hell of a lot harder to do it this year than it was last year or the year before,'' Biden said. On Wednesday, Bush told staff aides and reporters that after a year there ``is still too much violence, too much destruction, too many innocent victims.'' He said drugs remain ``an international menace'' but declared that his administration would ``remain on the front lines until this scourge is licked for good.'' The Judiciary Committee issued a report on Wednesday hailing as a major success an increase in spending on Justice Department efforts to combat drugs to more than $3.8 billion this year, $1.5 billion over the 1989 level. The report also pointed to increases in drug agents, cocaine prices and criminal convictions. Among major failures, though, it listed cuts in the ranks of the Border Patrol and other agencies as well as relaxed controls on some military assault-style weapons tied to the drug trade. The mixed review ranged from praise for expanded treatment facilities to concern that the administration may have undercounted by as much as two thirds the number of hard-core cocaine addicts, which it put at 2.4 million. Rep. John Conyers, D-Mich., told a news conference that Bush and Bennett ``cannot deny that we are losing the drug war in our inner cities.'' ``Prevention and education efforts directed at the educated middle-class appear to be having a dramatic effect,'' said Conyers, who chairs the House Government Operations Committee. ``Treatment programs have room for clients who can afford to pay.'' ``However, the chronically addicted cannot pay when they are poor and unemployed, as is often the case,'' the lawmaker from Detroit added. New York City police Commissioner Lee Brown told the Judiciary Committee that initial enthusiasm over the war on drugs was dampened by a lack of federal aid to local police. He said New York was designated a ``high-intensity drug area'' under the program and thus made eligible for increased funding. But he said none of the $4 million in additional aid went directly to local police. Los Angeles Police Chief Daryl Gates said the drug strategy ``may not be perfect, but I think it is a good one.'' He said the price of cocaine is up while the quality may be deteriorating as a result of the war against drugs. But both officials said heroin, overshadowed in recent years by the cocaine plague, is now making a comeback on the streets of their cities. Brown said heroin seizures skyrocketed 80 percent in New York last year and are up 20 percent this year. Gates said the figures were similar in Los Angeles and described the phenomenon as an unintended consequence of the war against cocaine.

DOC.SECOND: PM-Cannery Union Killings, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0573,0460
DOC.HEAD: Former Union Boss Arrested in 1981 Killings of Anti-Marcos Activists
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rewrites throughought to add comment from Baruso's lawyer, background on civil lawsuit, other detail. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A former union president whose gun was used to kill two anti-Marcos activists in 1981 has been arrested in the slayings, police said today. Constantine ``Tony'' Baruso was president of the Alaska Cannery Workers Union when Gene Viernes and Silme Domingo were gunned down in the union offices in Seattle on June 1, 1981. Baruso was arrested at his home in Tacoma late Wednesday on a warrant charging him with two counts of aggravated first-degree murder, Seattle Police spokesman Mark Amundson said. Dan Donahoe, a spokesman for the prosecutor's office, said he would not give details of the charges but said a news conference would be held later in the day. Baruso was being held in the King County Jail on $500,000 bail. Baruso's attorney, Anthony Savage, said that he was surprised at the arrest but that the criminal charges would give Baruso an opportunity to clear his name. Baruso, who told authorities the gun used in the case had been stolen from him, was never previously charged criminally in the case, but was found liable for millions of dollars in damages in a federal lawsuit brought by the victims' families. Three men, members of a Filipino gang called Tulisan, were found guilty of murder at the original criminal trial. Prosecutors in that case argued the killings stemmed from an internal union dispute in which Domingo and Viernes were working to end gang-dominated gambling in Alaska fish canneries. In the civil lawsuit, however, family members contended the slayings were ordered from Manila because of Domingo's and Viernes' activism against the martial-law regime of then-Philippines President Ferdinand Marcos. A U.S. District Court jury last December awarded the families $15.1 million from Marcos' estate and from his widow, Imelda. U.S. District Judge Barbara Rothstein later found Baruso and Marcos friend Dr. Leonilo Malabed of San Francisco liable for an additional $8.4 million. Baruso, a prominent member of the Seattle Philippine-American community, testified in both the criminal and civil trials, but repeatedly invoked his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination. Evidence in the civil trial indicated Baruso flew to San Francisco two weeks before the murders and picked up $15,000 from Malabed, who was accused of maintaining a Philippines intelligence ``slush fund.'' The plaintiffs alleged Baruso kept $10,000 for himself and gave $5,000 to the triggermen. Authorities identified Baruso's gun as the murder weapon, but said Baruso told them the weapon had been stolen from him. Baruso was later convicted of embezzling money from the union.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Cites U.S.-Soviet Cooperation in Gulf Crisis
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New thruout; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today U.S.-Soviet cooperation in the Persian Gulf crisis is an example of the benefits of the warming relationship between the two nations, a partnership he hopes to strengthen in a weekend meeting with Mikhail Gorbachev. Bush said the United States remains resolute in its goals in the gulf region, where U.S. troops have been dispatched to defend Saudi Arabia from threatened aggression by Iraq's Saddam Hussein after his invasion of Kuwait. Bush also said he saw ``a real opportunity'' in an Iraqi proposal for him to speak on their state-run television. ``The president has a very distinct message that he wants to give to the people of Iraq,'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said as the president flew here to address a rally for Kansas Gov. Mike Hayden's re-election drive. Before departing the White House, Bush took a flurry of calls from world leaders about the gulf crisis and his upcoming summit with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev. He placed a call himself to Syrian President Hafez al-Assad, an ally with the West in the stand against Saddam Hussein's seizure of Kuwait. Bush complained last week that he was not getting equal time to get his message across to the people of Iraq. Saddam Hussein has been interviewed by CBS-TV anchorman Dan Rather and his speeches, delivered through a spokesman in Baghdad, have been aired at length on CNN and other American networks. ``Iraq's information minister has offered to broadcast a message from President Bush to the people of Iraq on their state-run television,'' Fitzwater said. ``We have not heard from Iraq directly we accept their offer of a broadcast to the Iraqi people. The president will tape a message to the Iraqi people in the next few days will be provided to the Iraqi information minister.'' Naji al-Hadithi, director general of Iraq' information ministry, said earlier today in Baghdad he was making the offer on Saddam's instructions. He said an Iraqi television crew was ready to go to Washington to interview Bush. That won't be necessary, the White House said. ``We'll produce it ourselves,'' said Fitzwater, who said the White House envisions a 10 to 15 minute broadcast that will also be made available to the rest of the world. He said Bush is not worried about the possibility of censorship. ``We assume that their offer means they will broadcast it in its entirety,'' his spokesman said. ``The president has a very distinct message that he wants to give the people of Iraq (about) our purpose for being in the gulf. He thinks this is a good opportunity,'' Fitzwater said. ``We take them at their word.'' In his remarks in Topeka, Bush said the past year has seen ``new levels of cooperation between our two nations.'' ``The Persian Gulf shows what this cooperation can achieve. ... This meeting can further expand cooperation between the U.S. and Soviet Union,'' Bush said. Bush also said the United States is resolute in the goals of its military presence in the gulf region. ``We will not stand by while one country devours another unthreatening country whole,'' he said of Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. ``Our cause may not be easy but it will always be right.'' On a separate matter, the White House said there is no new U.S. economic aid package for the Soviet Union in the offing. Bush heads to Helsinki, Finland, Friday night and will meet with Gorbachev there on Sunday. ``We will be talking to the Soviets about technical assistance,'' said Fitzwater, but ``there's no new economic aid package.'' Bush called U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar Wednesday night to thank for his efforts to solve the gulf crisis. Perez de Cuellar went to Jordan last week for talks with Iraq's foreign minister that failed to produce a breakthrough. Bush received phone calls this morning from Turkish President Turget Ozal, French President Francois de Mitterrand and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl to discuss the Gorbachev summit and the gulf situation. Bush also called Syria's Assad to discuss the gulf crisis. Today was Bush's first trip on a Boeing 747 commissioned as the new Air Force One. ``It's so much roomier. My heavens,'' Bush said. He gave reporters a rare peek at his personal office and quarters in the nose of the plane. ``It's great. I'm sitting here with the briefing book for the Helsinki summit,'' Bush said as he sat with a seatbelt on at his large wooden desk. The plane has a range of 7,140 miles and an airborne refueling capacity. After his appearance at the Hayden fund-raiser, Bush was off to Florida to attend a rally in Tallahassee for Rep. Bill Grant of Florida. Hayden, seeking his second four-year term, faces a surprise Democratic challenger in state Treasurer Joan Finney, who defeated former Gov. John Carlin for the Democratic nomination. In Tallahassee, Bush will attend a rally for Grant, who faces Democrat Douglas ``Pete'' Peterson. Grant had no Republican primary opponent. He is a former Democrat who switched parties last year, and is seeking re-election in a heavily Democratic congressional district.

DOC.HEAD: Businesses Trimming Plans for New Plants, Equipment
DOC.TEXT: American businesses plan to increase spending for new plants and equipment just 5.1 percent over 1989, the smallest growth in three years, the government said Thursday. Analysts said the Commerce Department survey shows that businesses remain leery of a softening economy and worried about falling profits. The department said the survey found businesses planning to spend $526.9 billion for expansion and modernization this year, the fourth consecutive year of increased business investment. But while the projected investment would top last year's record $501.6 billion, the 5.1 percent increase would be less than half of the 10.4 percent spending gain in 1989 and the lowest since a 3.1 percent advance in 1987. Capital spending rose 9.5 percent in 1988. The new estimate also is down from the 5.5 percent spending increase that businesses said they planned in the previous survey completed in May. ``It confirms the economy is sluggish and expectations for the future are that it will continue to be sluggish,'' said economist Thomas Runiewicz of the WEFA Group in Bala Cynwyd, Pa. After-tax corporate profits, which rose just 1.5 percent from January through March, fell 0.2 percent in the second quarter and many analysts expect them to fall farther in the last half of the year. Businesses often are reluctant to make capital investments as their profit margins weaken. Runiewicz said the bulk of the survey was completed before the Persian Gulf crisis and added that higher prices and uncertainty after the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait could cut investment spending even further. The survey was begun in July and completed in mid-August. However, economists at Mitsubishi Bank in New York suggested in their current newsletter the crisis would have little effect on 1990 investments, ``given that most of this spending is already set in motion.'' Runiewicz said business investment contributed to the growth in the nation's economy in 1988 and 1989 and said the slower increase in capital spending this year would further reduce growth. Many analysts have been looking for continued business investment to help keep alive an economy that has been weakening for more than a year as the Federal Reserve kept a tight rein on credit to curb inflation. Some economists said even before the oil-price shock associated with the Persian Gulf crisis that the economy is headed for a slight recession later this year. Spending on replacements for aging plants and equipment and expanded facilities also helps boost U.S. productivity, an increasingly important factor in view of the stiff competition the nation faces from overseas. Before adjusting for inflation, the department projected a 5.4 percent increase for all businesses this year to $534.8 billion after gains of 11.4 percent last year and 11 percent in 1988. It said the investment increase for all industries includes a 4.7 percent gain for manufacturing companies and a 5.8 percent advance for companies engaged in mining, transportation and other non-manufacturing businesses. Manufacturers are projecting investment spending this year of $192.4 billion. The gain includes a 2.6 percent increase by industries making durable goods _ big-ticket items expected to last at least three years _ and a 6.4 percent increase by those engaged in non-durables such as food and clothing.

DOC.HEAD: New Area Code For Pentagon
DOC.TEXT: The area code for the Pentagon will change from 202 to 703 effective Oct. 1, the Pentagon said Thursday. The change is in line with new telephone dialing procedures being implemented by C&P Telephone in the Washington, D.C., area. As of Oct. 1, Pentagon callers will be required to dial 10 digits when making a local call outside their particular area code. For example, a caller in the Pentagon, which is in Virginia, will have to dial the area code and the seven digit local number to reach a number in the District of Columbia. Long distance dialing will remain unchanged. In addition, all telephone numbers with the 694 prefix in the Pentagon will be changed to 614 as of Oct. 1, the announcement said. The 694 prefix is used in Stuart, Va., in the 703 area code region.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Comedian Jay Leno will perform two shows for U.S. troops stationed in the Persian Gulf during the Thanksgiving holiday, the United Service Organization announced Thursday. Leno's appearances will be the first USO shows in the area since Iraq invaded Kuwait, but others will follow. ``We're all seeing that the enemy the troops are fighting right now is boredom and loneliness,'' said Kevin McCarthy, executive producer for the USO. ``Jay Leno will fix that. If the troops are still there at Thanksgiving, this will be a welcome break.'' Troops will be admitted to the Leno shows without charge, and Leno is performing for free, the USO said.

The Novi Police Department has a claim to fame it can't get rid of. Locked in a file cabinet, along with stolen license plates and a few bad checks, is a light blue scarf worn by Madonna during the filming of her video ``True Blue.'' ``If it wasn't for the notoriety of this scarf, it would be in the Dumpster,'' said Detective Max Roder. He and Detective Ralph Fluhart recovered the scarf after it and a Madonna dress were stolen from an MTV-sponsored display at the Twelve Oaks mall in 1988. Each has written to the music video network asking it to claim the swath. Their letters have gone unanswered. ``This is the first I'm hearing about any of this,'' David Cohn, director of national promotion for MTV, said Wednesday in Los Angeles. He said he would look into the matter after tonight's MTV video music awards program. A 20-year-old Dearborn woman pleaded guilty in 1989 to stealing the dress. She was placed on two years' probation and ordered to receive psychological counseling. Fluhart said the department would like to auction it this fall, with proceeds going to its drug awareness program.

Former U.S. Secretary of State Henry Kissinger is planning to visit China, the U.S. Embassy said Thursday. Embassy spokesman Edward Loo said Kissinger was scheduled to arrive Friday, but added the embassy was not involved with the visit and could provide no other information. The Foreign Ministry, Kissinger's host, said no information was available. China considers Kissinger an ``old friend'' since he made a secret visit in 1971 that set the stage for the resumption of relations between China and the United States after a 23-year rift. Since then, Kissinger has visited China at least 15 times, most recently last November. He was among the first prominent Americans to come to China in the months following the June 1989 military attack on pro-democracy protesters that left hundreds, perhaps thousands dead. Kissinger has defended the Chinese leadership's handling of the pro-democracy movement, claiming that no other government in the world would have tolerated the occupation of Tiananmen Square by protesters as China did.

Everybody else wore Buddy Holly glasses; Paul McCartney stuck to John Lennon-style wire rims. Other than that, McCartney was entirely in the spirit of things at his annual birthday tribute to Holly, one of the founding fathers of rock 'n' roll. ``I think from an early age all of us were wildly influenced by the man,'' McCartney said at Tuesday's bash at the Lone Star Roadhouse. Then he launched into a rocking rendition of Holly's ``Oh, Boy!'' Holly, who was killed in a plane crash in 1959, would have turned 54 Friday. This was the 15th annual tribute to him by Paul and Linda McCartney, and the first not held in London. McCartney owns the copyrights to Holly's songs, which are about to hit Broadway in the form of ``Buddy: The Buddy Holly Story,'' the London musical. There were plenty of Holly songs Tuesday night. The cast of the musical cranked out a few of the master's hits. Then, it turned things over to the celebrities, including McCartney, E-Street Band members Garry Tallent and Max Weinberg, Pat Denizio of the Smithereens, Ricky Van Shelton, Steve Forbert, Joe Ely and two of Holly's original Crickets _ drummer Jerry Allison and bassist Joe B. Mauldin. Among the songs: ``Well . . . Alright,'' ``Rock Around with Ollie Vee,'' ``True Love Ways,'' ``Wild Child,'' ``Heartbeat,'' ``Love's Made a Fool of You'' and, most appropriate of all, ``Not Fade Away.''

Talk about fearless. Don Rickles says he once mercilessly insulted mob boss Joey Gallo and lived to tell about it. Gallo, as it turned out, didn't. Rickles, who's appearing with Frank Sinatra and Pia Zadora this week, recalled the incident in an interview. He said he was performing at the Copacabana nightclub in New York in 1972 when Gallo came to see the show. Bodyguards appeared backstage before the show to tell Rickles their boss didn't want to be teased. ``That's like painting a bull's eye on yourself,'' Rickles said. ``A guy sits in the front row smoking a big cigar and surrounded by five bodyguards and I'm supposed to ignore him?'' Rickles said he hit on Gallo repeatedly and Gallo couldn't stop laughing. Afterward, Gallo invited Rickles to his 43rd birthday celebration at Umberto's Clam House. Rickles declined. A few hours later, four men walked into Umberto's and gunned down Gallo. ``Frankly, I didn't go because I was a little nervous. And besides, I didn't like clams,'' Rickles said.

The Internal Revenue Service has canceled the public sale of comedian Pat Paulsen's troubled winery operation and property in northern Sonoma County. The forced sale of Paulsen's home, winery, and the village of Asti, which he owns, had been set for Sept. 13. The IRS seized the property and put it up for sale to recover $277,000 in unpaid taxes owed by Paulsen and his first wife, Jane Paulsen. But on Wednesday IRS officials said the sale won't proceed because of legal challenges by the Paulsens' bankruptcy attorney, David Replogle. Replogle said the Paulsens' property is protected from creditors under Chapter 11 of the federal Bankruptcy Act. The Paulsens' total debt is $2 million. ``The IRS is not above the law _ they have to follow the same rules as everyone else,'' Replogle said.

DOC.HEAD: Government, ANC Talks Continue Amid Unrest
LaserPhoto Available
DOC.TEXT: Talks between the African National Congress and government officials on a no-violence pact Thursday failed to quell unrest in black townships. Police in the Soweto township fired tear gas and shotguns to disperse rival black factions in street clashes. Police said at least one person was stabbed to death and 16 were injured, but Soweto residents said three people died. Police also fired tear gas to disperse a crowd that burned a shop in the Sebokeng township south of Johannesburg, the government-run South African Broadcasting Co. reported. ANC and government delegations met for 2{ hours in Pretoria for talks that were expected to focus on the status of ANC guerrillas and the township fighting, which has claimed more than 550 lives since Aug. 12. No statements were issued after meeting. A radio station reported the groups would meet again Tuesday. The ANC formally suspended its 29-year guerrilla campaign Aug. 6. The cease-fire has improved prospects for negotiations on a new constitution to give blacks a voice in national affairs. But ANC leader Nelson Mandela and other groups have pressed for an independent probe into army involvement in the deaths of 11 people this week in Sebokeng. Black leaders, including the South African Council of Churches and an Anglican group led by Archbishop Desmond Tutu, have accused soldiers of opening fire unneccesarily. Black townships around Johannesburg have been wracked by more than three weeks of fighting between Zulu backers of the conservative Inkatha movement and Xhosas and other blacks loyal to the ANC. Some black leaders have accused police of fueling the violence by siding with Inkatha. Police and the government deny the accusation. The Star newspaper reported Thursday that masked white men joined a group of blacks in attacking a Sebokeng migrant workers' hostel before dawn Tuesday. It said the attack killed 19 people and caused a crowd of township residents to gather at the hostel. Soldiers later opened fire. In March, police fired on protesters in Sebokeng, killing five and wounding 150. A special judicial review panel concluded the gunfire was unjustified. President F.W. de Klerk said Thursday the continuing unrest could hinder negotiations on black-white power sharing but that talks would continue. ``There can be no real reform before stability,'' the president said. The white-led government and the ANC, the main black opposition group, have been holding periodic talks since May.
