In Pretoria on Thursday, Law and Order Minister Minister Adriaan Vlok led the government delegation. The ANC group was headed by Jacob Zuma, a member of its policy-making National Executive Committee. Only three of the seven ANC members appointed to meet with the government showed up. The man named to lead the ANC group, Chris Hani, was not present. He has been in the nominally independent Transkei homeland since the government dropped him from a list of ANC leaders granted temporary amnesty to participate in peace talks. Hani, leader of the ANC's armed wing, has said the ANC would seize power if talks with the government break down. De Klerk says he wants to end the apartheid system of racial segregation and negotiate a constitution with opposition groups. But he opposes black majority rule and a one-man, one-vote system. In Stockholm, Sweden, meanwhile, the fourth International Conference Against Apartheid in Sport ended Thursday with delegates urging a tightening of boycotts against South African athletes. Despite recent political changes in South Africa, the conference said relaxing the boycotts ``would seriously prejudice'' progress toward ending apartheid. Sports officials from South Africa and black African nations are scheduled to hold formal talks for the first time in Harare, Zimbabwe, Nov. 3-4. Officials from the International Olympic Committee will attend.

DOC.HEAD: Teen Who Held Hostages In School in Georgia Surrenders After 5{ Hours
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE witness quote that boy had three guns, add later estimate of number of students involved, other detail. Picks up 7th graf pvs `One of...'.
DOC.TEXT: A high school sophomore held a half-dozen or more schoolmates at gunpoint for several hours today, demanding such things as soft drinks, candy and a school bus before finally surrendering to police, authorities said. Forsyth County Sheriff Wesley Walraven said the youth surrendered shortly before 2 p.m., about 5{ hours after the incident began, and was being taken to the county jail. There were no injuries. The boy and the hostages attended the combined South Forsyth middle school-high school, said Joyce Shadburn, a spokeswoman for the county's school superintendent. Sgt. J. Frix of the sheriff's department said the boy held 40-50 hostages at first, but most were released during the morning. He estimated that fewer than 10 remained hostage by the time the boy surrendered. The boy's name was not released. Stan Harrison, the school's football coach, said the boy was armed with a rifle, a shotgun and a handgun. Two other coaches struggled with the boy when he first produced the weapons, and one gun went off during the struggle, he said. ``He's a good kid and a smart kid,'' Harrison said. ``I think he has a little trouble at home.'' Ms. Shadburn said some of the hostages were freed in exchange for candy and soda. The only other demand was for a school bus, she said, adding that a bus had been taken to the scene. One of the freed girls, Shelly Dixon, said the boy told ``us to stand up and put our hands on our heads. He started cussing at us. He said if we said anything, he'd shoot us.'' Capt. Jerry Padgett of the Forsyth County Sheriff's Department said the situation generally stayed calm as authorities negotiated with the student. The sheriff's department was called in by the school around 8:30 a.m. Other students were evacuated from the school, and streets in the area were blocked, authorities said. ``They have the area barricaded off. It's not in a residential area.'' The school is located about five miles south of Cumming, a town of 2,100 north of Atlanta. Buses were arranged to take the evacuated students home, Ms. Shadburn said.

DOC.HEAD: Government Maps Strategy for Better Health
DOC.TEXT: Federal health officials Thursday mapped a national strategy to improve the health of all Americans by the end of the century, putting the spotlight on preventing rather than curing illness. The blueprint outlines 298 health objectives _ everything from cutting the rate of infant deaths to increasing use of seat belts to reducing the number of smokers. ``We can no longer ignore the fact that, individually and as a nation, prevention is the single most important factor in maintaining good health,'' said Dr. Louis Sullivan, health and human services secretary. He called for ``a national priority for personal responsibility and for choices that maintain or improve the health status of our citizens. ``Such a climate would enhance the independence of our citizens by preventing illness or disability, and this would, in turn, free up resources for those who do encounter disease or disability,'' he said. He noted that the United States spent $600 billion on health care in 1989, and he said that if the same course is followed, the bill would be $1.5 trillion by the turn of the century. The 671-page report identifies specific health objectives covering a range of areas, including fitness, nutrition, tobacco, alcohol, drugs, family planning, mental health, occupational and environmental health, food safety, cancer, heart disease, AIDS, infant health and sexually transmitted diseases. Sullivan said he was especially concerned about the disparity in health status among Americans, particularly for the low-income minority population. ``In almost every category of mortality listed, minority deaths are greater than that of the white population,'' he said. For example, black infants die at twice the rate of white infants. Although he stressed the importance of personal behavior, Sullivan said the nation must find ways to make health care more accessible to ``the most vulnerable among us.'' He made no new proposals. Among the goals for 2000 are: _To increase to 30 percent the proportion of people who engage in regular, moderate physical activity for at least 30 minutes a day, up from an estimated 22 percent in 1985. _To cut from 26 percent to 20 percent the proportion of overweight adults. _To reduce from 29 percent to 15 percent the proportion of adult smokers. _To reduce pregnancies to 50 per 1,000 girls under 18, from 71 per 1,000 in 1985. _To increase use of safety restraints to 85 percent of automobile occupants from the current 42 percent. _To cut infant mortality to 7 deaths per 1,000 births. Provisional data for 1989 show a rate of 9.7 per 1,000. _To reduce coronary heart disease deaths to 100 per 100,000, from 135 per 100,000 who died from this disease in 1987. The objectives in ``Healthy People 2000'' were developed in a three-year effort led by the Public Health Service and involved more than 300 voluntary and professional organizations and state health departments. The blueprint builds on a similar set of goals that were set more than a decade ago to be achieved by this year. In assessing progress made by the mid-1980s, health officials said nearly half of the 226 objectives had already been or would likely be reached on time. A final evaluation won't be made until 1992 after all the data for the decade is compiled, officials said. However, it is already apparent that a high proportion of the 25 percent of 1990 objectives that won't be met involve poor health of minority populations, said Dr. James Mason, assistant secretary of health. ``We really as a nation are going to have to target those (medical and preventive services) to those people'' who have not had access to good health care, Mason said.

DOC.HEAD: A Night of Dancing and Death
DOC.TEXT: On the street, his name is Rocstar. He runs with his posse, FTS, a loosely knit crew known for graffiti and a love of loud dance music. To police, he is simply Yull Gary Morales, 19, of Queens, accused murderer. Morales and seven other young men were arrested Monday and charged with the Sunday night stabbing of a Utah tourist on a subway platform. The suspects allegedly wanted cash for a night of drinks and dancing in Manhattan; instead, they wound up charged with murder. Residents of the well-maintained, middle-class Queens neighborhood where several members of the gang lived described the suspects as guys who hung out at the schoolyard, drinking beer, smoking dope and spray painting their names on the wall. On Thursday, one member was spray-painting something else: a memorial to stabbing victim Brian Watkins. Watkins, 22, of Provo, tried to intervene as the gang robbed his father and punched his mother in the face. The gang often meets in the Flushing section; coincidentally, Watkins had traveled to the same area to watch the U.S. Open tennis tournament. On the night that Watkins was slain, several members of the gang met in the two-story, stucco home of 18-year-old Ricardo Lopez. The entire group hooked up at a subway station to head into Manhattan and the Roseland Ballroom, with a brief stop for a mugging to finance the evening. ``They used to come here,'' said Lopez's mom, Louisa Rodriguez. ``I used to throw them out because I knew they were up to no good.'' It was not clear if she was home at that night's meeting. Morales was one of the founders of FTS, which some locals said was an obscene acronym. Others says it stands for ``Flushing Top Society''; either way, it's one of about a half-dozen gangs in the area. Initiation into the gangs involves different rituals. Some FTS members said it requires its members to mug somebody _ ``getting paid,'' they call it _ before they join. Other gangs require aspiring members to run a gantlet of gang members who beat and kick him; a variation is putting the youth inside a circle and letting him fight his way out. FTS has been around for about three years. At its peak in 1988, it had about 250 members. Morales had been its leader, although he lost face two years ago for backing down in a gang fight, associates said. Police say he didn't back down when Watkins defended his mother from the attackers. Instead, Morales fatally stabbed the tourist, police said. Morales was not the only one armed that night, police said. Emiliano Fernandez, 18, allegedly used a box cutter to slice the pants pocket of Watkins' father and steal his wallet, which contained $200. Fernandez, whose street moniker is ``Trauma,'' was the only convicted criminal in the group, authorities said. Several of the others had pending charges: Lopez had an upcoming trial for auto theft. Pascual Carpenter, 18, was arrested Aug. 27 for carrying a gun on the subway. Ricardo Nova, 18, was twice arrested for fare beating; Luis Fernando Montero was busted once for the same thing. Anthony Anderson, 18, was arrested after a schoolyard fistfight last year. Only Johnny Hincapie, 18, had no arrest record. All eight are now charged with murder, two counts of robbery and assault in Watkins' slaying. On Thursday, FTS member Papo Love and about two dozens other people were back in the schoolyard at JHS 189. Love, 19, had spent the whole night creating a spray-painted memorial to Watkins. Watkins' first name was in bright red, orange and purple, with his last name a blue outline with a grey interior. Written alongside the name was ``Rest in peace'' and a peace symbol. ``I gave that tribute to him,'' said Love. ``I feel sorry for him because he lost his life for defending his mom.''

DOC.HEAD: Military Hospitals Prepared to Handle Casualties of War
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUB 5th graf, `The U.S...' to delete extraneous material. PIckup 6th graf, `The state-of-the-art...
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bkt
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. military has built a sophisticated network of medical facilities in the Saudi desert, including 15 hospitals that officials say are equipped to treat virtually any type of combat wound. The hospitals include two medical ships being deployed in the Persian Gulf, along with 13 facilities spread out across the eastern province of the desert kingdom. Hundreds of doctors and nurses, who can perform anything from neurosurgery to heart surgery to orthopedic surgery, have been flown in to care for the estimated 60,000 U.S. troops so far deployed in Operation Desert Shield. Washington says the American troops are here to defend Saudi Arabia in case of an attack by Iraq. The scope of the medical system clearly shows that officials want to be prepared should war break out. ``Our hospitals are just as capable, if not more capable, of doing anything we do in the states,'' Col. Jerome Faust, commander of the 44th Medical Brigade, said Thursday. His brigade runs the Army's hospitals in Saudi Arabia. The U.S. Navy is building a 500-bed hospital in the desert. Defense Department guidelines prohibit describing specific locations and places. The state-of-the-art facility is housed in 24 air-conditioned caramel tents, which include intensive care units, an operating ward, and a laboratory and X-ray unit. ``We have it all. We're a little city,'' said Capt. Richard Mayo, the hospital's commander. ``This is larger than any ground facility we had in Vietnam.'' When fully staffed, the hospital will have a staff of 900, 800 of them medical personnel. At another location, the Army is building a ``bubble'' hospital, a 200-bed facility with a pharmacy attached. It is housed in a series of caterpiller-shaped inflatable rubber structures that resemble giant inner tubes. A tubine engine heats and cools the interior. About 1.5 million tons of equipment, from narcotics to hospital beds, were shipped from the United States for this hospital. Soldiers have worked mostly at night to set up the facility because of the searing daytime temperatures. Twenty doctors will eventually be assigned to it. Like the others, the hospital will be almost exclusively for Americans. Saudis may be treated occasionally at U.S. facilities, but the kingdom has its own modern system of medical care. Besides the hospitals, each military unit, such as a Marine brigade in the desert, has doctors and paramedics assigned to it. In combat, their role is to keep wounded soldiers alive until they can be taken to a hospital.

DOC.HEAD: Humorist Jokes About Pacemaker
DOC.TEXT: Humorist Minnie Pearl poked fun at her health Thursday in urging federal government employees to support the United Way. Miss Pearl, honorary co-chairwoman for an eight-county United Way fund drive, said she wears a pacemaker but joked that ``the doctor must have put it in wrong. Every time my husband kisses me, the garage door goes up.'' She also managed to joke about her 1985 breast cancer surgery. ``They gave me the breast of an 18-year-old, so I'm 18 years old from the waist up,'' the 77-year-old Grand Ole Opry star told more than 80 people at the breakfast meeting.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Criticize Reduced Overnight Deliveries
DOC.TEXT: A Postal Service decision to slow delivery of some first-class mail in the face of a new rate increase ``is going over like a lead balloon,'' Postmaster General Anthony M. Frank was told Thursday. Telling Americans that longer delivery times for some mail results in improved service is ``doublespeak _ it doesn't compute, it doesn't jibe,'' Rep. Glenn English, D-Okla., said at a hearing by the House Government Operations subcommittee on government information. Frank said the payoff will be more consistent delivery time. ``We asked the American people (in surveys) what good service is and they said it is getting it there every time so they can count on it,'' Frank said. The Postal Service concluded that mail users want speed but want consistency more. Delaying some overnight deliveries will affect less than 5 percent of first-class mail, he said. ``The result will be a win-win situation _ improved mail service for our customers and improved efficiency for the Postal Service.'' Frank said the change in overnight deliveries was not begun as a cost-saving measure and has nothing to do with the pending 5-cent increase in the price of a first-class stamp. Critics said many mail users feel they will be getting less service but paying more for it. ``It's going over like a lead balloon,'' said Rep. Frank Horton, R-N.Y. On July 28, the Postal Service reduced the number of non-local overnight deliveries; starting later this month, about 5 percent of letters that now require two days for delivery will require three. Even with the changes, Frank said, ``We are committed to deliver more than half of all the first-class mail in this vast country overnight.'' The changes are taking effect over objections of the consumer advocate for the Postal Rate Commission. Stephen A. Gold, director of that office, told the subcommittee the Postal Service should have done a cost-benefit analysis and tried to determine how much speed mail users were willing to forgo in the interest of consistent delivery times. Cary H. Baer, vice president of the Readers Digest Association Inc., which spends $100 million a year for U.S. postage, tentatively endorsed the changes because of their potential ``to significantly improve consistency of delivery while having only modest impact on speed.''

DOC.HEAD: Mystery Brick Stumps City Officials
DOC.TEXT: When the city finished rebuilding a main thoroughfare last week, the final brick was engraved with Mayor Sophie Masloff's name and placed in the downtown street. But who is Fred Fischer and why did he have his own engraved brick on Grant Street near the mayor's? That question stumped city officials, including Mrs. Masloff. ``I never heard of him,'' the mayor said Wednesday. ``Fred Flintstone?'' asked Albert J. Neri, the mayor's press secretary. ``Yeah, I think he was around when we started the project.'' The mystery was solved by Deborah Liotus, the city's assistant director of engineering and administration. She said Fred is a project engineer for the city. ``The contractor had made up several bricks at his own cost for people who worked on the project,'' she said. ``Fred didn't want his. So they put it in the street.'' Ms. Liotus said the brick, which was removed Wednesday afternoon, was supposed to be placed with the engraved side down.

DOC.HEAD: Poll Says Symington Ahead of Mecham
DOC.TEXT: Fife Symington leads Evan Mecham by 11 percentage points in the race for the Republican gubernatorial nomination in Arizona, a statewide poll says. Twenty-nine percent of the Republicans who were questioned said they favored Symington and 18 percent favored Mecham, according to the poll conducted by Political-Media Research Inc. of Washington. Amongthe other candidates, Sam Steiger led with 16 percent, followed by Fred Koory with 12 percent and Bob Barnes with 2 percent. The poll was sponsored by Tribune Newspapers and KPNX-TV in Phoenix. Some 819 people were questioned between Saturday and Tuesday for the poll, which has a margin of error of 3.5 percentage points. Former Phoenix mayor Terry Goddard was shown to be well ahead of Dave Moss, his opponent in next week's Democratic primary. Goddard got the nod from 59 percent to Moss' 13 percent. The poll also showed that Goddard would defeat Symington and Mecham if the general election were held today.
DOC.HEAD: Nuke Plant Shutdown Ballot Measure Key Issue In Governor's Race
DOC.TEXT: A ballot proposal to shut Oregon's only nuclear power plant appears to have strong support among voters and is a key issue in the governor's race. Democratic gubernatorial candidate Barbara Roberts surprised observers in July when she endorsed a shutdown of the Trojan plant near Rainier, but she is heartened by the results of two polls taken last month. The Nov. 6 ballot measure to force closing the plant is supported by 73 percent of 600 registered voters surveyed in a poll for The Oregonian newspaper. The measure was supported by 63 percent of those surveyed in a poll for Portland station KPTV. Republican gubernatorial candidate Dave Frohnmayer says closing the plant is a bad idea that could leave the state vulnerable to future energy shortages. Political tensions in the Persian Gulf make this the wrong time to consider shutting Trojan, says Frohnmayer, the state attorney general. Roberts has cited concerns about storage of radioactive waste. ``Dave has painted me as an extremist because of my position on the nuclear safety issue,'' Roberts said. The results of polling on the issue ``may represent that Dave Frohnmayer is out of touch with Oregonians,'' Roberts said Wednesday. Frohnmayer noted that a similar measure on the 1986 ballot was favored in early polling but eventually was defeated.
DOC.HEAD: Celebrezze Apologizes For Staff `Reporter'
DOC.TEXT: The campaign of Democratic gubernatorial candidate Anthony J. Celebrezze Jr. apologized Thursday for a staff member who posed as a reporter at a news conference held by Republican opponent George Voinovich. The Celebrezze campaign released a statement saying it had learned that a staff member posed as a reporter for the Ohio State University Lantern during a briefing Wednesday in which reporters questioned Voinovich by telephone. ``This action was not authorized by the ... campaign, nor does it comport to the philosophy or character of our candidates,'' Melinda Swan, Celebrezze campaign press secretary, said in a news release. She said four persons involved had been reprimanded, and that a letter of apology from campaign manager Thomas Winters would be delivered to the Ohio State Lantern. The Celebrezze staff member posed as a Lantern reporter. The staff involved have had their pay docked, including two managers who did not authorize or condone the act, but accept managerial responsibility, Swan said. The funds, some $500, will be given to the Ohio State University School of Journalism, Ms. Swan said. Curt Steiner, spokesman for the Voinovich campaign, dismissed the incident as a staged event to make the Celebrezze campaign look good. He noted previous allegations by Celebrezze that a television company hired by Voinovich posed as a TV station news crew in December to gain access to a Celebrezze news conference. Videotape of the session subsequently was used in a Voinovich commercial critical of Celebrezze.

DOC.HEAD: Cake is Clue: Sweet Talk For Drug Chief Bennett
DOC.TEXT: The cake was the tipoff that drug control chief William Bennett was not going to face many tough questions from a key Democratic senator on the first anniversary of the war on drugs. ``It's been a year and I think you've made some great progress,'' Senate Judiciary Chairman Joseph R. Biden told Bennett after giving him the chocolate-iced cake outside the hearing room. Bennett had no problem with that assessment. The two also agreed that much remains to be done and that Congress must be pushed to provide the money for that war even as it faces other problems such as the Persian Gulf, the deficit, and the savings and loan crisis. In fact, the most severe critic of the Republican administration's drug war was Sen. Arlen Specter, a Republican from Pennsylvania. Like some House Democrats, Specter called for dividing federal drug war money equally between law enforcement and treatment and education. The breakdown is now almost 70 percent for law enforcement, the rest for treatment and education. President Bush and Bennett marked the first anniversary of the national drug control strategy Wednesday with a white paper showing improvements in the drug war. The statistics cited declines in emergency room admissions for cocaine and heroin, surveys showing Americans' increasing hostility toward illegal drugs and increases in prices for cocaine and decreases in its purity, indicating a reduction in supply. The wholesale price of a kilo of cocaine now ranges from $17,500 to $35,000, up from a range of $11,000 to $25,000 last year. But in 1984, Biden noted, the wholesale price was $40,000 to $50,000. The number of cocaine-related emergency room cases declined slightly last year to 42,145 at hospitals checked by the federal government. Biden pointed out that those same emergency rooms had only 10,248 cocaine-related cases in 1985. But Biden, D-Del., took pains not to blame Bennett. ``The fact that the problem is still extremely bad is not a comment on what I consider the extremely good job you have been doing,'' Biden told him. Bennett assured Biden that the drug issues remain a top priority for Bush, who said Wednesday that the issue ``remains No. 1'' for him despite the other crises that seem to preoccupy the White House these days. ``We're not saying the (drug) war is over,'' Bennett said. ``We're certainly not saying it will be over soon.'' Bennett said some communities were making more progress than others largely because of local efforts, but he said the federal government should take the lead to demonstrate the importance of the matter to state and local governments. The Judiciary Committee issued a report Wednesday hailing as a major success an increase in spending on Justice Department efforts to combat drugs to more than $3.8 billion this year, $1.5 billion over the 1989 level. The report also pointed to increases in drug agents, cocaine prices and criminal convictions. Among major failures, though, it listed cuts in the ranks of the Border Patrol and other agencies as well as relaxed controls on some military assault-style weapons tied to the drug trade. The mixed review also contained praise for expanded treatment facilities as well as concern that the administration may have undercounted by as much as two-thirds the number of hardcore cocaine addicts, which it put at 2.4 million. Bennett and Biden agreed Thursday to have their staffs work out some common figures. Bruce Carnes of Bennett's office told Biden he believes the Judiciary Committee's number is too high because it overcounts some groups of the population such as those arrested, and the government's figure is too low because it misses some groups such as those who are incarcerated.

DOC.HEAD: Oilmen to Give Soviets Production Tips; Look for Possible Investments
DOC.TEXT: American oilmen heading to the Soviet Union at the behest of President Bush are prepared to share new technology that might immediately boost Soviet oil production, Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher said Thursday. The trip also will give U.S. businesses a chance to ``be in the vanguard'' of potentially profitable ventures with the Soviets, Mosbacher said. Fifteen chiefs of U.S. corporations and Mosbacher leave Saturday for a six-day round of meetings with Soviet officials about what kind of technical assistance the United States can give the Soviets on oil production, housing, transportation, food processing and telecommunications. The group will stop in Helsinki, Finland, on Sunday to meet with President Bush after his summit with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The business leaders will meet with Gorbachev in Moscow later in the week. ``It's a chance for (Bush) to sort of exchange ideas, give them an update (and tell them) from a political and international standpoint how important their mission is,'' Mosbacher said of the Helsinki stop. Mosbacher told reporters that the U.S. oilmen had a decade's worth of technological advances they could share that might help the Soviet Union boost its production beyond the current 12 million barrel-a-day output. For instance, he said, the Soviets are unfamiliar with the U.S. practice of ``fracking,'' or pumping fluid and sand into a formation to increase the drain of oil, Mosbacher said. Giving them that expertise might have almost an immediate impact, he said. The Soviet Union, the world's largest oil producer, receives 70 percent of its hard currency from its oil. Improving production would have a dramatic impact on the Soviet economy, Mosbacher said. American oil companies, as well, stand to gain because of the potential joint profit ventures with the Soviets, he said. H. Leighton Steward, chairman of the Louisiana Land and Exploration Co. of New Orleans, said the mission will allow him to help Bush and could open investment possibilities for his oil company. ``In our estimation, there is a tremendous amount of oil and gas reserves still to be found'' in the Soviet Union, Steward said. He expects next week's trip to involve preliminary discussions about new techniques rather than any specific proposals for new drilling possibilities. Mosbacher said the oilmen might actually visit Soviet oil fields. Steward and other oilmen making the trip, such as Chesley Pruet, who owns an oil company based in El Dorado, Ark., said the effort to boost Soviet oil production was crucial in light of the Middle East situation. ``Their potential reserves are greater than all the reserves in the Persian Gulf,'' Pruet said. American companies could help the Soviet Union's lagging oil production by providing them with new technology, Steward said. ``One reason the Russians are not further along is they simply have been short of funds. They simply haven't had the capital to bring themselves up to date technologically,'' Steward said. At the Houston economic summit of industrial nations in July, the Bush administration balked at providing the Soviet Union with cash grants or loans but agreed to provide the technical assistance. About 80 other nations receive American technical assistance, which can range from teaching Tunisia about banking to developing a fly-resistant wheat in Morocco. The U.S. business leaders also will discuss ways the Soviets could improve their transportation system, housing situation and food processing abilities _ all areas where the Soviets have asked for help. Other companies that will be represented include: Archer-Daniels-Midland Co. of Decatur, Ill.; Atlantic Richfield Co. of Los Angeles; Chevron Corp., of San Francisco; Dresser Industries of Dallas; Fortune magazine of New York; Glenair International of Del Mar, Calif. Also, PaineWebber of New York; Pepsico Inc. of Purchase, N.Y.; Sea-Land Service, Inc. of Edison, N.J.; Shelter Systems Group of Hainesport, N.J.; Texaco Inc. of White Plains N.Y.; Transisco Industries of San Francisco; and United Telecommunications of Westwood, Kan. James B. Hayes, publisher of Fortune, said he thought he could ``contribute to the Soviets' understanding of free-market business management techniques.''

DOC.SECOND: PM-San Diego Mayor, 2nd Ld - Writethru, a0604,0429
DOC.HEAD: Ex-San Diego Mayor's Convictions Set Aside
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, `The court ...' to CORRECT that decision was 5-2 sted 4-3
DOC.TEXT: Former San Diego Mayor Roger Hedgecock, forced from office after being convicted of hiding campaign contributions, won a new trial today from the state Supreme Court on his 12 perjury convictions. The court also set aside Hedgecock's remaining conviction, for conspiracy to violate campaign disclosure laws, to let a San Diego judge consider allegations that a bailiff improperly influenced jurors by talking about the case and getting them liquor. In 1985, Hedgecock was convicted of failing to disclose more than $350,000 in contributions to his successful 1983 campaign for mayor. The money allegedly came from principals in J. David & Co., an investment firm that later collapsed. Prosecutors said some of the contributions violated local election laws. Hedgecock's one-year jail sentence and $1,000 fine have been stayed during his appeal. He now works as a San Diego radio talk show host. Hedgecock, 44, said today that he was confident the ruling ``is going to be the beginning of setting the record straight on this pretty unfortunate episode in my life and the life of San Diego.'' The former mayor had contended he was guilty of no more than bad bookkeeping, and claimed he was the target of a vendetta by District Attorney Edwin Miller. Hedgecock said a retrial would be ``a horrifying waste of resources (and) time.'' Miller's office had no immediate comment on the ruling or on whether a retrial would be sought; a news conference was scheduled for later in the day. The court voted 5-2 to overturn the perjury convictions on the grounds that then-Superior Court Judge William Todd told the jury that the alleged deliberate errors and omissions in Hedgecock's campaign finance reports were ``material,'' or substantial enough to support perjury charges. The issue of whether the inaccuracies were material was a factual question to be decided by the jury, said the Supreme Court opinion by Justice Joyce Kennard. The court ruled unanimously that a hearing could be held to consider allegations that the conspiracy conviction was also improper because the court bailiff purportedly made remarks that pressured the jurors into convicting Hedgecock and supplied liquor for a party the night before the verdict. Todd had dismissed those allegations on the basis of written statements from jurors and the bailiff, saying he was not authorized to call witnesses at a hearing.

DOC.HEAD: Five Killed in Gunfire at Railway Platform
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with railway platform shooting, picking up 10th graf pvs bgng: `Some black leaders ...'
DOC.TEXT: Two gunmen opened fire on a crowded train platform, killing five people and wounding nine, police said Thursday. Violence also continued in black townships. Col. Frans Malherbe said the attackers began shooting ``for no rhyme or reason'' at the Jeppe station in Johannesburg. ``They didn't say anything,'' Malherbe said. ``They just walked up and opened fire.'' All the victims were black, and so were the assailants, police said. The gunmen fled the scene before authorities arrived. Earlier, police in the township of Soweto fired tear gas and shotguns to disperse rival black factions in street clashes. Police said at least one person was stabbed to death and 16 were injured. Soweto residents said three people died. It was not known if the Johannesburg attack was linked to township fighting between Zulu followers of the conservative Inkatha movement and Xhosas and other blacks loyal to the African National Congress. The clashes have claimed more than 550 lives since Aug. 12. Also Thursday, the ANC and government officials met in Pretoria to discuss a no-violence pact, the status of ANC guerrillas, and other issues. A radio station reported the groups would meet again Tuesday. No statements were issued after meeting. The ANC formally suspended its 29-year guerrilla campaign Aug. 6. That improved prospects for negotiations on a new constitution to give blacks a voice in national affairs. But ANC leader Nelson Mandela and other groups have pressed for an independent probe into army involvement in the deaths of 11 people this week in Sebokeng. Black leaders, including the South African Council of Churches and an Anglican group led by Archbishop Desmond Tutu, have accused soldiers of opening fire unneccesarily. Some black leaders have accused police of fueling the violence by siding with Inkatha. Police and the government deny the accusation. The Star newspaper reported Thursday that masked white men joined a group of blacks in attacking a Sebokeng migrant workers' hostel before dawn Tuesday. It said the attack killed 19 people and caused a crowd of township residents to gather at the hostel. Soldiers later opened fire. In March, police fired on protesters in Sebokeng, killing five and wounding 150. A special judicial review panel concluded the gunfire was unjustified. President F.W. de Klerk said Thursday the continuing unrest could hinder negotiations on black-white power sharing but that talks would continue. ``There can be no real reform before stability,'' the president said. The white-led government and the ANC, the main black opposition group, have been holding periodic talks since May. In Pretoria on Thursday, Law and Order Minister Minister Adriaan Vlok led the government delegation. The ANC group was headed by Jacob Zuma, a member of its policy-making National Executive Committee. Only three of the seven ANC members appointed to meet with the government showed up. The man named to lead the ANC group, Chris Hani, was not present. He has been in the nominally independent Transkei homeland since the government dropped him from a list of ANC leaders granted temporary amnesty to participate in peace talks. Hani, leader of the ANC's armed wing, has said the ANC would seize power if talks with the government break down. De Klerk says he wants to end the apartheid system of racial segregation and negotiate a constitution with opposition groups. But he opposes black majority rule and a one-man, one-vote system. In Stockholm, Sweden, meanwhile, the fourth International Conference Against Apartheid in Sport ended Thursday with delegates urging a tightening of boycotts against South African athletes. Despite recent political changes in South Africa, the conference said relaxing the boycotts ``would seriously prejudice'' progress toward ending apartheid. Sports officials from South Africa and black African nations are scheduled to hold formal talks for the first time in Harare, Zimbabwe, Nov. 3-4. Officials from the International Olympic Committee will attend.

DOC.HEAD: Textile Workers' Booster Has Bought Suits in South Korea
DOC.TEXT: South Carolina Democrat Ernest F. Hollings, the Senate's biggest booster of protecting the jobs of U.S. textile and apparel workers from import competition, has had suits custom-made in South Korea. At the request of U.S. Embassy officials, Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., two weeks ago brought back a custom-made suit from South Korea that Hollings had a Seoul tailor sew from U.S.-made fabric. Lugar was one of 32 senators who in July voted against a Senate-passed bill by Hollings that would restrict imports of clothing and fabrics in order to ``keep up the standard of living'' of U.S. textile and apparel workers. The House is expected to act later this month on the bill, which was twice vetoed by former President Reagan. President Bush has opposed the bill and administration officials have said they will urge him to veto it also. A spokesman for Lugar described his boss' action as ``a simple personal favor'' for a colleague, saying the embassy had asked Lugar if he would deliver the suit to Hollings. Hollings, whose state is one of the largest manufacturers of textiles and clothing, is not willing to talk about the suit, his spokesman, John Patterson, said Thursday. The Washington Post quoted the owner of the Seoul shop as saying he charged Hollings $100 to sew the suit together from wool fabric the senator had sent him. The tailor also said Hollings had bought suits in his shop during visits to South Korea in 1988 and 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Science Panel Urges Complete Overhaul of Biology Education
DOC.TEXT: The National Research Council on Thursday called for major reforms in biology education including classroom study of ``creepy crawly critters'' and games of ``What if...?'' Biology education in America is hampered by teachers who are poorly trained, books written to not offend adults and a curriculum that ``seems designed to snuff out interest,'' according to a study released by the council, an affiliate of the National Academy of Sciences. ``By a variety of criteria, the nation is doing a poor job in teaching science,'' said Timothy Goldsmith, a Yale biology professor. Goldsmith, one of the biologists and educators who wrote the study, pointed to unflattering comparisons of American students' test results with their foreign counterparts and steadily declining interest in science among U.S. students. Goldsmith said biology and all other sciences should be taught in ways that are more interesting and personal to the children. ``The entire curriculum... needs to emphasize science as a process of understanding _ an open-ended game of `What if ...?' and `What else could that possibly mean?' _ rather than a stupefying exercise in memorizing terminology,'' he said. Jane Butler Kahle, a science professor at Miami University in Oxford, Ohio, said science teaching should be a ``hands-on process'' where elementary children can study mice, hamsters, mealworms _ ``those creepy crawly critters'' _ and examine their environment. Middle school programs should emphasize human biology, she said, while high schools focus on laboratory investigative activities and more core concepts. The experts said children aren't spending enough time on science. They should start learning it young, preferably age 5, they said, and should spend at least an hour a day on it _ preferably in the morning when they are more open to learning. Kahle said science education now takes a mere 18 minutes a day in most kindergarten through third grade classes and up to 26 minutes for children in fourth through sixth grades. Textbooks, teachers and testing also could use improvement, the report said. Textbooks are often too long, abysmally crafted and written ``with the implicit aim of avoiding offense to a scientifically illiterate segment of the adult population,'' it said. The panel also said schools of education, where teachers are taught to teach, ``present pedagogical information so unrelated to the specifics of teaching science as to be of little or no help.'' ``Too many of our teachers are recruited from the lowest academic quartile of the college population,'' said the study, adding that teachers are given little opportunity to update their scientific knowledge or to interact with research scientists in industry or academia. The study also recommended that testing be revised so it does not drive the curriculum. The report was prepared by three committees that included more than 50 educators and scientists from many parts of the country and selected by the National Research Council.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 15th graf pvs, Eleven have, to update numbers
DOC.HEAD: Administration Cautiously Endorses Colombian Plan
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration on Thursday cautiously endorsed the Colombian government's offer to spare cocaine traffickers extradition to the United States if they surrender and confess their crimes. ``If the government and people of Colombia are now able to enforce their own laws against drug trafficking _ prosecuting, convicting, and incarcerating these thugs _ so much the better,'' Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said in a statement. But Thornburgh warned that ``if the so-called extraditables fail to take advantage of this opportunity to surrender, confess their crimes, and serve jail sentences, we will continue to support Colombia's effort to arrest and extradite them to the United States for trial.'' Under the decree issued Wednesday by recently inaugurated President Cesar Gaviria, drug lords wanted by U.S. authorities would not be extradited if they surrender and cooperate with Colombian efforts to root out the cocaine cartels. Thornburgh and William Bennett, national drug policy director, both praised the announcement. Thornburgh said the prosecution of drug traffickers in Colombia would satisfy the Bush administration's goal ``to seize these drug kingpins and bring them to justice.'' ``There can be no substitute for the removal of these traffickers from society and the dismantling of the drug organizations they operate,'' Thornburgh said. Under the decree announced by Gaviria, Colombian judges would be empowered to impose shorter sentences for suspects who confess and cooperate with local investigations. Gaviria also announced plans to build ``fortress cities'' where Colombian judges will live and work free of intimidation from the drug lords. Bennett's chief spokesman, Benjamin F. Banta IV, said the drug policy director ``thinks this is a good and positive step by the new Colombian government to help in the war on drugs.'' The offer of leniency and a promise that drug traffickers wanted in the United States won't be extradited provide an incentive for many suspects to surrender, Banta said. A senior law enforcement official, speaking on condition of anonymity, called the decree a ``gutsy political move'' in a country where extradition is a touchy political issue. Gaviria's offer appeared to be, at least in part, a response to repeated offers from the drug traffickers to surrender to Colombian judges in return for a promise to end the extraditions that had been resumed last year by then-President Virgilio Barco. Barco's decree touched off a declaration of ``total war'' by the Medellin cartel. Since then, 22 Colombians have been extradited to face federal drug charges in the United States. Twelve have either been convicted at trial or pleaded guilty; one was acquitted. An additional nine are awaiting trial. Two others were killed in shootouts with Colombian authorities. The Justice Department has asked for extradition of 16 suspects in Colombian custody and the Bogota government has so far agreed to turn over three of the accused drug traffickers, said spokesman Dan Eramian.

DOC.HEAD: Starving People Break into Warehouse, 20 Killed in Fire
DOC.TEXT: Starving people broke into a warehouse Thursday, accidentally setting it ablaze, and the West African military force sent to try to end Liberia's civil war said at least 20 people were killed. The city has been cut off from the outside world for more than two months because of the war, and its last food stocks were exhausted this week. Doctors said some children had begun dying of starvation. Further details of the fire deaths were not available. Except for a few fishing boats that dared enter the city with their catches, no new food was arriving in Monrovia. Thousands of people seeking food mobbed the five-nation intervention force. But the soldiers had little to offer and were waiting themselves for rations. Rebels loyal to Charles Taylor ended the several-day lull in fighting in the capital by shelling the city's small airfield. Commanders of the West African force had hoped to open the field to flights soon, but the attack made it clear they would have to drive Taylor's rebels out of range of the strip before operations can resume. Gambian President Sir Dawda Jawara urged West African states and the international community to send food to Liberia. Jawara heads the West African regional group that sent 3,000 soldiers to Liberia in an effort to end the 8-month-old tribal war, which has claimed at least 5,000 lives. Ghana, Gambia, Nigeria, Guinea and Sierra Leone have contributed troops to the force, created by the Economic Community of West African States. The Ghanian commander of the intervention force, Lt. Gen. Arnold Quainoo, met Jawara this week to press for emergency food aid. Jawara also met this week with Burkina Faso leader Capt. Blaise Compaore, who has criticized deployment of the intervention force. Compaore has been accused of supporting Taylor's efforts to force the West African soldiers to leave Liberia. Jawara said Compaore promised to try to use his influence with Taylor to accept a cease-fire. Liberia's president, Samuel Doe, and Taylor's rival rebel leader, Prince Johnson, welcomed the arrival of the intervention force and have observed an informal cease-fire. Taylor has refused any compromise but has been unable to capture Monrovia. The fighting began began Dec. 24 when the rebels invaded from neighboring Ivory Coast, accusing Doe of corruption. The war has driven more than 500,000 refugees into Ivory Coast, Sierra Leone and Guinea, the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees reported. Ivory Coast, Sierra Leone and Guinea have not been able to provide much help to the refugees in their countries because their governments are deeply in debt and face serious budget problems.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Says Britain Will Increase Persian Gulf Forces
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
LaserPhoto LON9
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said Thursday that Britain plans to step up its deployment to the Persian Gulf, saying the United Nations has already taken sufficient steps to allow military force against Iraq. ``To use no military force without the further authority of the Security Council would be to deprive ourselves of a right in international law,'' Mrs. Thatcher told an emergency session of Parliament. ``It would hand an advantage to Saddam Hussein and could put our own forces in greater peril. For these reasons, I am not prepared to limit our freedom of action,'' she said. Mrs. Thatcher's remarks were jeered by the opposition, although all of Britain's political parties are united in supporting sanctions and backing participation in the U.S.-led military buildup in the Persian Gulf. The governing Conservative Party and the opposition Labor Party are divided over whether legal authority already exisits to use force if sanctions fail to drive Iraq out of Kuwait. Labor leader Neil Kinnock argued that military action without new U.N. authority would enhance Iraq President Saddam Hussein's stature among traditionally anti-Western Arab nations. ``The potential consequences of taking action that doesn't have complete and unarguable U.N. authority include further turmoil, terrorism, an increase in nationalism and fundamentalism the destabilizing, possibly of strategic allies,'' he said. It was the first time that Parliament _ not due to return from its summer break until Oct. 15 _ has been recalled for an emergency sitting since the outbreak of the British-Argentine war over the Falkland Islands in 1982. Saying the U.S. military deployment in the gulf deserved strong support, Mrs. Thatcher noted that Britain had already contributed three squadrons of warplanes and small numbers of ground forces to guard airfields. ``We believe some additional forces will be needed and their composition is under consideration,'' she said. She gave no further details. Some U.S. congressmen argue that European nations should also deploy large numbers of ground troops to underline joint involvement. Mrs. Thatcher says sanctions should be given months to work, but has insisted repeatedly that the military option cannot be ruled out. ``History has many examples of perfidy and deceit,'' said Mrs. Thatcher. ``This ranks high among them and shows that nothing that Saddam Hussein says can be trusted. ... Iraq's actions go back to the laws of the jungle.'' She added, ``The person who takes such (action) against one state will take it against another if he is not stopped and his invasion reversed. ... We will persevere until he is.''

DOC.HEAD: Parents, Students Don't Mind Juice Box Ban
DOC.TEXT: Elementary school pupils got a lesson in civic responsibilty and environmental ethics Thursday and were a little more thirsty because of it. Students streaming into Dora L. Small Elementary School couldn't bring juice boxes for snack or lunchtime as part of Maine's ban on the popular 8{-ounce containers. Maine is the first state in the country to outlaw the boxes. Environmentalists contend the aseptic containers, made from bonded layers of plastic, paper and aluminum, can't be recycled and went against the state's goal of recycling half its solid waste by 1994. The ban took effect Saturday, just before the school year began. The boxes weigh less than glass or metal, they're unbreakable and are easy to stash in a lunchbox or backpack. Many parents said they didn't mind the ban. But they admitted that packing something for their children to drink is a little harder without being able to use the handy, single-serving containers of juice and fruit drink that come with straws. ``It's a pain,'' said Sheri Allen, whose daughter Amy is a first grader at Small School. ``I used them and I've stopped using them. Now, my daughter doesn't have anything to drink at snack time, that's what it amounts to because I can't fit two thermoses in her lunchbox.'' Kathy Duca, whose two children attend nursery school, said she liked using the juice boxes and isn't sure the ban is fair. ``I agree the juice box containers aren't good for the environment,'' she said. ``But I don't think they can just get rid of one thing when there are so many other materials that pollute the environment, like plastic containers.'' Several said keeping Maine's environment clean is worth the sacrifice. ``If it's not recyclable, we shouldn't use it,'' said Wendy Athearn as she walked to school with her son, a kindergarten pupil. ``We've got to do something with all this trash building up.'' ``I agree with the ban completely,'' added Kathie Barton, another parent with her children in tow. ``I also think milk cartons should be banned.'' Other parents, like Ted O'Meara, said the ban hasn't been a problem. ``My son's been bringing extra juice in a thermos.'' His son, Ben, a first grader at Small, shrugged his shoulders and wrinkled his nose when asked if he minded not being able to drink juice boxes anymore. Other pupils also seemed oblivious to the ban, shrugging their shoulders or giving blank stares when asked about the new law. Sharon Langella, the school's secretary, said she hadn't heard any complaints from parents.

DOC.HEAD: CDC Reports `Unusually High Levels' Of Rare Viral Encephalitis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release 5 p.m. EDT. Time set by source.
DOC.TEXT: Two potentially deadly kinds of viral encephalitis have reached high levels among virus-carrying mosquitoes in at least five states, federal health officials said Thursday. Only seven cases of St. Louis encephalitis and two cases of Eastern equine encephalitis have been confirmed in humans in the United States this year, the Centers for Disease Control said. But testing of mosquitoes this summer has detected ``unusually early and high levels'' of the viruses, the CDC said. CDC researchers warned that encephalitis is a potentially deadly illness, with fatality rates as high as 30 percent. Symptoms include fever, headache, stiff neck and, in serious cases, nervous-system disturbances. The last major outbreak of St. Louis encephalitis, the most common type, struck nearly 3,000 people 15 years ago. ``In different locations, the risk is going to be different,'' said Dr. Ted Tsai, a Colorado-based encephalitis specialist with the CDC. ``Only certain mosquitoes carry these viruses. Only vector mosquitoes are capable of transmitting infections.'' The CDC reported high levels of encephalitis viruses in Massachusetts, Texas, Florida, New York and New Jersey, ``indicating a potential risk for epidemic transmission.'' In Massachusetts, which has had heavy rainfall _ good for mosquitoes _ for two years, the risk was anticipated, the CDC said. One 7-year-old boy has been diagnosed with Eastern equine encephalitis, and four more human cases are suspected. Officials ordered the spraying of 700,000 acres in swampy southeastern Massachusetts with the pesticide malathion, but the $1 million program was harshly criticized when thousands of tiny fish died, apparently from fallout. ``But if you don't do anything and there's a human case, the public outcry is going to be, `You didn't do enough,' '' Tsai said. In Texas, tests in central Houston showed as many as 25 per 1,000 mosquitoes carrying St. Louis encephalitis virus. As many of 60 percent of wild birds showed signs of infection. Two human cases were confirmed; both patients died. In Florida, high St. Louis encephalitis infection rates were noticed in flocks of chickens. Five human cases were confirmed, and a sixth was suspected, in three central Florida counties. In New York and New Jersey, tests have shown high Eastern equine encephalitis infection rates in groups of mosquitoes. Elsewhere, a fatal case of Eastern equine encephalitis has been reported in South Carolina, a presumed case has been found in North Carolina, and cases in horses have been reported in Georgia and Maryland. Encephalitis is an inflammation of the brain. St. Louis encephalitis, about 5 percent fatal in humans, and Eastern equine encephalitis, about 30 percent fatal, are part of a family of viruses known as arboviruses. Federal health officials reported 108 cases of various arboviral encephalitis types last year.

DOC.HEAD: On the Home Front, Tears of Joy and Longing
DOC.TEXT: After a month of worrying and waiting, Donnita Cole got good news Thursday: Her husband is alive and well in Baghdad. ``I had a good crying spell this morning and now I am fantastic,'' said Mrs. Cole, of Odessa, Texas. ``My adrenalin surge is so powerful right now that I can't even sit down.'' While some other American families celebrated the return of a loved one from Iraq and Kuwait, Mrs. Cole was momentarily happy with the knowledge that her husband, John Cole, was alive and apparently in good health at a Baghdad hotel. She said her husband sent her a message through the State Department, saying, ``I am all right and in Iraq.'' Still, Mrs. Cole said she won't rest easy until her husband is home. He had been working in Kuwait as a supervisor for OGE Drilling of Houston. ``The message calms my fears right now,'' she said, ``but that does not tell me what tomorrow's going to bring. I am living hour to hour, minute to minute. Anything could change that quickly.'' For the Subh family of Davenport, Iowa, the waiting ended Wednesday when 15-year-old Taleb Subh returned from Kuwait. ``I don't know how to describe it,'' said his father, Nabil Subh. ``I'm very, very moved. I can't believe I'm holding him right now.'' Taleb had been visiting relatives in Kuwait City when Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. ``It was great. Kuwait City was beautiful,'' he said, ``but then I woke up and it was just changed. It was like going to a different country. You see soldiers, you don't see people anymore.'' His father said a Palestinian identification card that officials of the Palestine Liberation Organization gave to Taleb helped get him through some checkpoints in Iraq. He left Baghdad on Tuesday along with 23 other Americans who had been held hostage in Iraq and Kuwait. Taleb sounded anxious to get home when he was approached by reporters during a stop at Newark International Airport in New Jersey. ``I'd like to talk to you all, but I have a lot to do,'' he said. After an emotional reunion at O'Hare International Airport in Chicago with his parents, his two brothers and his sister, he was a little more expansive, despite having gone more than 60 hours without sleep. ``I want to get back to school and do what I was doing before,'' he said. ``I plan to kick back and relax.'' Another American freshly back from the Persian Gulf conceded Thursday that he may have been a bit hasty when he sharply criticized the State Department for failing to do enough to get Americans out of Kuwait and Iraq. ``My remarks regarding the State Department may have been a little wild, because my wife tells me as far as she knows they have been making every effort to get us out of Kuwait,'' Lloyd Culbertson said in an interview in El Paso, Texas. ``If that's true, I'm sorry I told the reporters what I did,'' he said. But later in the same interview, Culbertson said: ``I am not sorry for what I said about the State Department.'' Culbertson, 76, was trapped in Kuwait for about a month after Iraq invaded the country. He was among 47 Americans allowed to leave Kuwait after the Rev. Jesse Jackson's meeting with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. He returned to Texas on Sunday. ``If it were not for the grace of God and Jesse Jackson, we would not be here,'' Culbertson said Sunday when he arrived at Washington-Dulles International Airport. ``The State Department has not lifted a finger for us.'' ``I don't agree with Jesse Jackson's political beliefs,'' he said Thursday. ``But he got me out. Shouldn't I say thank you? I was worried for my life at times and he got me out.''

DOC.HEAD: Daughter of Timothy Leary Dead From Jail Hanging
DOC.TEXT: The jailed daughter of 1960s LSD guru Timothy Leary died of an apparent suicide two days after she was found hanging by a shoelace from the bars in her cell, authorities said Thursday. Susan F. Martino, 42, was found Monday hanging in her cell at the Sybil Brand Institute, where she was in custody after being judged mentally unfit to stand trial on a charge of shooting her sleeping boyfriend. Martino, who was taken unconscious from the jail to Santa Marta Hospital, died Wednesday evening, said Mary Landreth, a Sheriff's Department spokeswoman. Pending an autopsy, the death was classified a possible suicide hanging, said coroner's office spokesman Bob Dambacher. ``I can't talk right now. I'm upset,'' the 70-year-old Leary said from his Beverly Hills home. ``She was found by deputies Monday morning ... during a routine 20-minute cell block check,'' Landreth said. ``Martino was hanging by a shoelace attached to her cell bars. Martino was alone in her cell.'' In May 1989, Martino was committed to the jail's mental health unit until doctors could find her psychologically fit to stand trial for attempted murder. Martino was accused of shooting boyfriend Joel Chavira, 38, as he took a nap Dec. 19, 1988. He survived the attack and told officers he found Martino holding a gun in the kitchen of her Glendale home. Chavira, who was hospitalized briefly, told police Martino denied shooting him. The woman's daughter also said she had not fired the shot. Martino pleaded innocent in January 1989 to a charge of attempted murder. At the time, her father said, ``I am extremely distressed about this tragic event. I am praying for the young man's continued recovery.''

DOC.HEAD: Photographer Robert Frank Donates His Archive To National Gallery
DOC.TEXT: Swiss-born American photographer Robert Frank is donating works representing his entire 45-year career to the National Gallery of Art for its photography collection, gallery officials announced Thursday. The Frank archive includes 61 vintage photographs, negatives from about 2,000 rolls of film, 2,296 contact sheets, nearly 1,000 work prints and 34 pictures bound in a volume titled ``Black, White and Things.'' Gallery director J. Carter Brown said the gifts by Frank, regarded as one of the leading photographers of the post-World War II period, will be ``unrivaled by any other private or public holding of his work.'' The gifts will be included in a National Gallery exhibition of Frank's works in 1992. The archive ranges from Frank's earliest works as a student in Switzerland in the 1940s to recent images from the late 1980s. They will join a photography collection that includes the first such gift to the National Gallery, a set of 1,600 Alfred Stieglitz pictures donated by artist Georgia O'Keeffe in 1949. The gallery's collection has expanded in recent years with gifts of more than 260 pictures by Ansel Adams, Walker Evans and Paul Strand.

DOC.HEAD: Prison Warden, Five Guards Killed in Armed Assualt
DOC.TEXT: A warden and five guards were killed Thursday by armed men who broke into a prison in a small town on the Caribbean coast, police said. Fifteen men carrying automatic weapons entered the prison and fatally shot the warden and two guards, according to a national police statement. They then fled the scene with three guards, whose bullet-riddled bodies were later found on the outskirts of the city, Turbo, the statement said. Turbo is in northern Colombia near Panama. Police said the attackers freed four prisoners. They also stole prison weapons, including 13 rifles, shotguns and revolvers. The statement said the attackers, still at large, have not been identified.

DOC.SECOND: AM-New Air Force One, 1st Ld-Writethru, a0606,830
DOC.HEAD: New Air Force One Makes First Official Flight
DOC.TEXT: President Bush was upgraded to first class Thursday when a Boeing 747 jumbo jet made its first official flight as the new Air Force One. ``It's marvelous in every way _ the latest in technology and certainly very, very comfortable,'' Bush said as he stepped aboard the plane for a quick hop across the country for political rallies in Topeka, Kan., and Tallahassee, Fla. The president planned to be back at the White House Thursday evening. ``It's so much roomier. My heavens,'' Bush said. ``It is magnificent.'' Some of the stewards chided reporters not to scuff up the new airplane. ``Be careful those cameras don't scratch the walls,'' one said. Congress and the Reagan administration decided in 1986 to spend a quarter billion dollars on a pair of jumbo jets to replace two well-preserved but aging Boeing 707s that had flown a total of 5.5 million miles. The delivery was almost two years late. For a president who already has logged a record 200,000 miles in the air in less than 20 months in office, the new jet will allow Bush to whet his appetite for travel and comfort. The comforts range from a shower-equipped presidential lavatory to an airborne office with a large wooden desk to a fully decked conference room that could accommodate more than half the Cabinet. The seats throughout the jet are first-class size; Bush and his top staff have large leather reclining chairs. There are televisions galore, 85 telephones, the latest in computers, memory typewriters, a paper shredder, two galleys with ovens and microwaves and, for the president and first lady, a spacious private cabin with two couches that convert to twin-size beds. There's enough freezer space on the plane to store 2,000 meals. The White House physician could perform emergency surgery in a separate medical room. The plane has a range of 7,140 miles without refueling _ about 1,400 miles further than the old Air Force One _ and an airborne refueling capacity that will be used only in emergencies. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said it's more fuel-efficient and quieter than the old Air Force Ones, which exceeded Federal Aviation Administration noise standards. Bush invited reporters _ but not camera crews or photographers _ to glimpse his private suite in the nose of the plane. His private quarters are decorated in brown and rust tones, with an upholstered wall mural depicting a rustic sunset. Asked if he planned any one-day trips to the Persian Gulf, Bush quipped: ``Stay tuned. Have plane, will travel.'' Bush said he checked out the cockpit, but the onetime Navy fighter pilot said he had no plans to take the controls. ``A little sitting there maybe, but I wouldn't understand how to start this thing,'' Bush said. Col. Danny Barr, the Air Force One pilot since 1989, was at the controls of the new jet. The president's first landing in Topeka was bumpier than the usual smooth setdowns for which Air Force One is famous but the plane had a smoother landing in Tallahassee. Bonnie Newman, the president's assistant for management and administration, flew several trial runs on the jet, including a trip last week to Hawaii when she became the first passenger to try the presidential shower. ``It was refreshing,'' she said with a laugh. While the contract called for the government to pay $266 million for the two jumbo jets, the actual cost reportedly ran closer to $400 million. White House officials say Boeing absorbed much of the overrun. The second plane is to be delivered next year. The new plane has separate cabins for guests, Bush's senior staff and other aides as well as for his Secret Service contingent and the press corps that travels with him. It seats 70 passengers and 23 crew members, half again as many as the old plane. It provides room for two additional members of the media _ a total of 13 reporters, photographers and television crews. The passengers on the maiden flight had nine movies to choose from, viewed on overhead televisions in each cabin with the sound provided by individual headsets. Thursday's offerings included ``The Abyss,'' ``Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade,'' ``Young Einstein'' and ``Steel Magnolias.'' The walls of the plane were bare, but officials said photos would be hung. The outside of the jet is decorated in the same colors President John F. Kennedy chose for the Air Force One put into service in 1962: white and royal blue over a thin gold stripe, with the bottom and the big cowlings for the engines in robin's egg blue. The old Air Force One featured a single narrow center aisle, where VIPs had to weave their way past flight attendants, Secret Service agents and the media on their way to the lavatories. Flight attendant Becky Schulz said it will be more work running around the longer two-story plane, but will mean ``a lot less stress.'' ``You won't be stepping over people's feet all the time,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Family of Subway Stabbing Victim: Don't Let Him Die in Vain
With AM-Tourist Suspects, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The family of a Utah man fatally stabbed in a Manhattan subway station demanded justice Thursday, urging people to get involved and challenging New York City to safeguard its public transit users. ``Please don't let Brian die in vain,'' the family of Brian Watkins pleaded in a statement after his parents canceled a news conference. Watkins, 22, was stabbed Sunday night when he tried to intervene as a group of youths robbed his father and punched his mother in the face. The parents, Sherwin and Karen Watkins, returned from New York Wednesday night after testifying before a grand jury. They had scheduled a news conference at a hotel in their hometown, but decided on the advice of prosecutors not to go through with it. ``We advised them it would not be in the interest of the case,'' said Gerald McKelvey, a spokesman for the Manhattan district attorney's office. Instead, the Watkins' 26-year-old son, Todd, read a 10-minute statement to reporters on behalf of the family as his parents, looking haggard, were seated nearby. ``We challenge the public transportation system of New York City to hire competent people and train them to react in emergencies and reward and discipline them for their services,'' has ``a quiet guy. He has problems and has seizures and takes pills for them.'' The youth had a seizure last week, Abercrombie said, and another student made fun of him. But police would not speculate on the reasons for the hostage-taking.

DOC.HEAD: Environmental Group Denounces Helms; Lists 12 `Dirtiest' in Congress
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 4 grafs to UPDATE with criticism from Right-to-Life Committee
DOC.TEXT: An environmental lobby group named its congressional ``dirty dozen'' Thursday and presented Sen. Jesse Helms with what it called a ``lifetime achievement award'' for opposing environmental legislation. ``While many other lawmakers have been acquiring the knowledge that pollution imperils our communities and our planet, Helms has been acquiring the seniority to help thwart efforts to protect our air and water,'' said Ruth Caplan, executive director of Environmental Action. ``It's his cumulative record that's so bad,'' Caplan said at a news conference, contending Helms has voted consistently against environmental issues the lobby group supports. Helms' office did not immediately return telephone calls seeking comment. Helms, R-N.C., was first named to the list in 1978 but wasn't one of 1990's ``dirty dozen.'' The group's latest list includes three senators and nine members of the House. The only Democrat among them is Sen. Howell Heflin of Alabama. The other senators are Minority Whip Alan Simpson of Wyoming and Mitch McConnell, R-Ky. The House members are: Bob Michel, R-Ill.; Larry Craig, R-Idaho; Bill Dannemeyer, R-Calif.; Bill Emerson, R-Mo.; Clyde Holloway, R-La.; James Inhofe, R-Okla.; Stan Parris, R-Va.; Denny Smith, R-Ore.; and Arlan Stangeland, R-Minn. Debbie Locker, a spokeswoman for Heflin, said the rating was based on a limited number of votes and did not take into account Heflin's overall environmental record during his 12 years in the Senate. ``Sen. Heflin is for doing anything to protect the environment as long as it does not mean people in Alabama will lose their jobs,'' she said. Stangeland spokesman Tom Hanson said Environmental Action was highlighting a few test votes and ignoring Stangeland's role as a leader in reaching compromises on environmental issues. ``He looks for solutions that are environmentally safe and economically sound,'' Hanson said. McConnell's re-election campaign manager, Steven Law, said the senator's top priority was protecting jobs in Kentucky's energy-dependent economy. ``The problem is that Kentucky relies heavily on its coal, uranium and oil exploration industries,'' Law said in Louisville. ``You cannot possibly satisfy these left-wing Washington groups and also protect Kentucky jobs.'' Environmental Action charted 12 votes in the Senate and House that it considered this year's most important on such issues as clean air, oil spills, water pollution and world population control. Each member's record in key committee votes and on home-district environmental issues was also taken into account, Caplan said. Environmental Action has issued a dirty dozen list in every congressional election year since 1970, except for 1980 and 1982. In 1984 the list was made up of Reagan administration officials instead of members of the House and Senate. Environmental Action, a research, education and lobby group, says it has about 20,000 members nationwide. The National Right to Life Committee criticized the inclusion of the population-control vote, which would have earmarked $15 million for the United Nations Population Fund. Under current law, U.S. tax dollars cannot go to the fund because it operates programs in China, which uses forced abortions and sterilizations to carry out its one-child-per-family policy. ``It is an outrageous distortion to claim that a congressman is anti-environment because he opposes compulsory abortion,'' said Douglas Johnson, the committee's legislative director. Caplan said the vote was included because ``the pressure of population growth on the environment can undo all the progress we have made.''

DOC.HEAD: Proverbs, Clothes, Weather Figure in Korean Talks
With AM-Korea
DOC.TEXT: Historic talks this week between the prime ministers of North and South Korea were hard to capsulize, even for the participants themselves. They frequently resorted to proverbs. ``Where there is a will, there is a way,'' said the North Korean arrival statement by An Byong Su, director of the Committee for Peaceful Unification of the Fatherland. ``There is a saying that too many captains make the boat climb the mountain (instead of sail on the water),'' North Korean Premier Yon Hyong Muk told his South Korean counterpart on the first day of talks. ``If we make haste, the boat will capsize,'' replied South Korean Prime Minister Kang Young-hoon. ``Nothing ventured, nothing gained,'' Kang said later in a dinner speech.

Clothes may not make the person, but they do have impact. One noticeable difference between the 90 North Koreans visiting this week and their countrymen who visited on a small exchange program five years ago was clothes. In 1985, all the men wore the same suits, the same shoes, the same ties and the same shirts. This week there was variety in color and style. Some reports described the visitors as having a new cosmopolitan look, and one newspaper claimed to have placed a spy in the hotel laundry who found foreign labels, mostly from Eastern Europe or Japan. Two things were the same, however: the North Korean men all wore their hair brushed straight back in a style favored by Communist ruler Kim Il Sung. And all wore a lapel pin bearing Kim's picture.

What do leaders of two hostile nations discuss with dozens of live microphones under their chins while they wait for formal talks to begin? What else? ``You had heavy rains this summer in the North, didn't you?'' asked South Korean Prime Minister Kang. ``We had torrential rains along the Taedong River, but suffered little damage thanks to many dams,'' replied North Korean Premier Yon. Both smiled broadly as the cameras clicked.

One of the North Korean delegates was a four-star general who last visited Seoul in an armored tank. Gen. Kim Kwang Jin, 72, vice minister of the armed forces, told reporters his tank battalion rolled through the capital city and drove as far south as the central town of Taegu during the 1950-53 Korean War. ``Years have elapsed since the bloody war,'' he said. ``I come now to reunify the nation, not by rifle or tanks but through dialogue.'' North Korea invaded the South to start the war, which ended in an armistice. A peace treaty has never been signed.

Seoul Mayor Koh Kun bemoaned a dilemma common to big cities when, in a dinner toast to the visiting delegation, he said Seoul had a ``my car'' phobia. He said there are 600 new cars a day on the streets and traffic is horrendous. He didn't need to elaborate for the visiting North Koreans. The official motorcade taking the delegation to its hotel was involved in a five-car accident. Two North Korean delegates were injured. The North Korean premier's car was damaged, and two of the official vehicles had to be left for tow trucks.

DOC.HEAD: Estonian, Soviet Talks Suspended; Kremlin Stalling Alleged
DOC.TEXT: Talks between officials from Estonia and the Soviet parliament were suspended Thursday after the Soviet side announced it had no authority to engage in negotiations, Estonian media reported. The Estonian side accused the Soviets of ``unprofessional'' conduct, because both sides signed a protocol three weeks ago agreeing to negotiations on the political and economic relations between the independence-minded republic and the Soviet Union, according to the Estonian News Service. On Tuesday, Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis accused the Soviets of delaying the start of independence negotiations with that republic, refusing to reply to its suggestions on the start of negotiations. Representatives of the Baltic republics say the Soviets may be stalling on negotiations because Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia have said they will seek full independence and won't sign a union treaty. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has been promoting the treaty to try to keep the nation of 15 republics from splintering. ``It is clear that those were right who said that (the Soviets agreed to the) talks not to reach an outcome but just for the sake of talks,'' Andrei Birov, the Estonian delegation's spokesman, said in an interview with the Estonian Telegraph Agency. Thursday's session at the Kremlin between the Soviet and the Estonian parliamentary delegations was the third round of talks. During the second round, on Aug. 30, Soviet delegation chief Nikolai Gritsenko started to use the word ``consultations'' instead of ``negotiations,'' the Estonian News Service quoted Ulo Nugis, the head of the Estonian delegation, as saying. On Thursday, Gritsenko said the Soviet delegation was authorized ``only to hold consultations,'' and later added: ``We can hold negotiations only between independent states, but Estonia is only a Soviet republic, according to the Soviet Constitution,'' the news service reported. It was then decided that the meetings between the Estonian and Soviet delegations would be halted temporarily and only groups of experts from both sides will continue contacts, it added. ``In my mind, the reason for such behavior is an understanding that Estonia will not join the new union treaty,'' said Endel Lippman, an Estonian government minister who is in charge of negotiations with the Soviets. The official news agency Tass, in its account of Thursday's events, said the delegations met ``as part of continuing consultations between the U.S.S.R. Supreme Soviet and the Estonian leadership'' and did not report the suspension of the talks. Last month, Estonia's parliament declared that the constitution of the Estonia Soviet Socialist Republic was no longer effective and that Estonia was not a part of the Soviet Union. The declaration was part of a package defining the basis for Estonia's independence negotiations with Kremlin representatives. On March 30, Estonia declared a transition period toward independence. Gorbachev rejected that move, as well as a similar step by Latvia and an outright declaration of independence by Lithuania.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Still Seeking $50 Billion in Deficit Cuts
