DOC.TEXT: Congressional leaders of both parties said Thursday they still want $50 billion in deficit cuts for next year, despite the Persian Gulf crisis and the weak economy. Their comments came on the eve of the resumption of budget bargaining between Congress and the Bush administration. White House officials said President Bush will participate for about 90 minutes Friday when negotiators meet at Andrews Air Force Base in suburban Maryland. Since the negotiations broke off in August for Congress' summer recess, some participants for both sides have suggested working for a somewhat smaller deficit-reduction package, perhaps in the $30 billion to $40 billion range. They say such a plan would be less of a shock to the U.S. economy, which has shown signs of slowing. But Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., and House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., told reporters that negotiators should stick to the goals they were working toward when the talks recessed: $50 billion next year, and $500 billion over the next five years. Gephardt said Democrats also want the package to protect the poor and middle class, encourage U.S. energy security and prod economic growth. ``The health of our economy and the living standards of our people demand no less,'' he said. Separately, House Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill., and Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., said they also believed the $50 billion-$500 billion formula should be negotiators' goal. ``Hopefully it is time to make the tough choices,'' Dole told reporters. Bush has been saying publicly for weeks that he wants to work toward a $50 billion package for next year. Democrats and Republicans met separately on Capitol Hill Thursday, making last-minute preparations for their bargaining. Their aim is to work out a deal by Monday. Congressional leaders and White House officials hope that, with the negotiators secluded on the air force base, chances will improve for a bipartisan compromise. They also suggest that the setting _ and the fact that the base generally is closed to reporters _ might cut down on partisan posturing on both sides. Administration officials, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said Bush would fly by helicopter to the air base to open the bargaining session on Friday morning and remain for about 90 minutes. He will return to Andrews later in the day to fly to Helsinki for his one-day meeting on Sunday with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev. Administration officials said Bush does not plan to participate directly in the budget-summit talks after Friday's appearance Speaking at a Republican fund-raiser on Thursday in Topeka, Kan., Bush said ``time is running out'' for finding a budget agreement since the new fiscal year begins in just a few weeks. ``I've kept the faith _ and, yes, took some heat _ through five long months of budget talks,'' Bush said. ``We've got to draw the line on spending, break free once and for all from the tired old mindset that says for every new problem we must create a new bureaucracy.'' ``So I say, Congress get with it. ... The time for avoiding tough decisions is gone. The time for action is now. Let's fix this budget mess once and for all.''

DOC.HEAD: Nicaraguan President Cancels Trip to U.S.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 2 to ADD dropped first name, title. Picks up 3rd pvs, `Mrs. Chamorro...'
DOC.TEXT: President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro has canceled a planned October trip to the United States because of the Persian Gulf crisis, a top official said Thursday. ``This trip definitely doesn't serve the interests of Nicaragua, given the intense attention on the Persian Gulf conflict in the minds of all the North American people,'' Minister of the Presidency Antonio Lacayo said on his return from Washington. He spoke in a radio interview. Mrs. Chamorro had planned to go to Washington to thank the Organization of American States for assistance in the electoral process that led to her Feb. 25 election victory over the Sandinistas. Backed by a coalition, she defeated President Daniel Ortega and took office April 25. She also was to meet with President Bush. Lacayo said the decision to cancel the trip was made by Nicaragua.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets May Raise Use of U.N. Force in Persian Gulf
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Leads with 6 grafs to CORRECT that Soviet spokesman did not specifically call for sending a U.N. force to Persian Gulf, but raised possibility of such a force. picks up 6th graf pvs, ``Although Iraq, etc.''
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet spokesman on Thursday raised the possibility of Kremlin support for a U.N. military force in the Persian Gulf and said Mikhail S. Gorbachev may discuss the idea with President Bush at their summit. Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov did not make clear whether the Kremlin envisioned U.N. troops acting independently or replacing U.S.-led forces in the region. The Soviet Union has not sent troops to join the U.S.-led multinational force deployed in the gulf since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. It previously left open the possibility of joining a U.N. force, but Gerasimov appeared to take this a step further by raising the issue himself at a news conference. ``We have to go back to the U.N. charter and revive certain clauses of this charter, in particular the clause about the military staff committee, which may have armed forces _ international armed forces _ at its disposal so as to keep international peace and security,'' he said. The committee consists of senior officers from the five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council: the United States, Soviet Union, China, Britain and France. It has been inactive since 1946, but last month the United Nations Security Council said it should play a role in enforcing sanctions against Iraq. Gerasimov said Gorbachev may raise the idea with Bush at Sunday's meeting in Helsinki, Finland. Garasimov, however, said it was unlikely the two nations would issue a joint ultimatum to Iraq since the Kremlin prefers multilateral action. Although Iraq is a longtime ally of the Soviet Union, Gorbachev has condemned its invasion of Kuwait and repeatedly called for Iraqi troops to withdraw. In talks Wednesday with Gorbachev and other top officials in Moscow, Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz gave no indication his country was willing to leave the oil-rich sheikdom, Gerasimov said. ``I see indications to the contrary, because ... Iraq is sending its citizens and Palestinians into Kuwait and giving them documents to live there permanently, which may change the demographic balance in Kuwait,'' Gerasimov said. ``It's a small country ... so they can change the demography, and then they can hold a referendum and vote for Kuwait joining Iraq.'' A senior Western diplomat commenting on Aziz's visit said, ``The Soviets agreed to see him, but they said rather pointedly they wanted to hear something new.'' The diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said he did not see evidence that Aziz brought anything new to Moscow. The Soviet Union has voted for U.N. resolutions imposing an economic embargo on Iraq and allowing the use of military force to halt ships carrying goods to or from Iraqi ports. In recent years, U.N. troops have been deployed to troubled areas to monitor cease-fire lines and try to keep the peace. Not since the Korean War of 1950-53 and Congo rebellion of 1960-64 have U.N. soldiers undertaken a ``police action.'' The Korean and Congo forces were directed by the full Security Council, not the military staff committee. Gerasimov dismissed a proposal by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to link the withdrawal of Iraqi troops from Kuwait to Israel's pullback from its occupied territories. ``It is this aggression by Iraq that is on top of the agenda, and I don't think we should link this aggression with any other issue, otherwise the resolution of this conflict will be indefinitely postponed,'' he said. Earlier Thursday, Aziz endorsed a call for an Islamic holy war against Western forces on the Arabian peninsula and accused Bush of being a bad Christian because he condemned the Iraqi invasion but did not heed the plight of Palestinians living under Israeli occupation. The Tass news agency reported Thursday that French President Francois Mitterrand telephoned Gorbachev to discuss the gulf crisis and other Mideast issues. Soviet media, meanwhile, have put the U.S. military involvement in the gulf in a favorable light. The evening television news program ``Vremya,'' in a report from Saudi Arabia, showed American soldiers mingling with their Saudi counterparts. A Soviet correspondent said the United States ``did not leave its longtime ally and oil donor Saudi Arabia alone to face their opponent ... The Americans were the first to respond to their distress signal.''

DOC.HEAD: Wounded American Will Be Detained After Hospital Release
DOC.TEXT: An American trying to evade capture was shot and wounded by an Iraqi soldier in Kuwait, the State Department said Thursday. Iraqi officials say the unidentified man ``will be discharged from the hospital within 24 hours, but will remain in their custody. They promise us consular access at that time,'' said agency spokesman Mark Dillen. Dillen, accusing the Iraqis of ``outrageous behavior,'' said the man was wounded in the forearm while trying to escape out of a window at his Kuwait apartment. The incident occurred as Iraq mandated a law imposing a sentence of life imprisonment on people who try to leave the country without permission. Meanwhile, an undisclosed number of American citizens are expected to leave Kuwait and Iraq on Friday on what the State Department hopes will be regular evacuation flights arranged by the U.S. embassy. In addition to American women and children whom the Iraqis have been allowing to leave since late last month, U.S. officials said they hoped adult men with medical problems also would be allowed to depart. Asked whether the Friday charter will be part of a daily exodus, Dillen said, ``I don't want to speculate about the future beyond this first flight.'' VOA broadcasts to Kuwait are encouraging Americans there to stay in touch with the American Embassy. ``We are hoping to start air evacuation within the next few days from Kuwait through Baghdad to Amman,'' a text of the broadcast says. There are an estimated 2,200 Americans in Kuwait and 300 in Iraq. Twelve Americans were aboard a Canadian-chartered flight Thursday. Dillen's account of the incident involving the wounded American was partially provided by an American eyewitness who later was taken by Iraqi authorities from Kuwait to Baghdad. Iraqi officials in Baghdad confirmed the American was injured, but said the injury was not serious, Dillen said. ``We hold the Iraqi government responsible for the health and welfare of all American citizens held against their will in Kuwait and Iraq,'' Dillen said. ``Reports that Iraqi soldiers are using live fire in their efforts to round up foreigners are extremely disturbing, and yet another indication of the lengths to which the Iraqis are willing to go to carry out their inhumane policy of using innocent foreigners as shields while denying them the right to leave.'' The State Department lodged a protest with Iraqi Ambassador Mohamed al-Mashat, who told reporters the American was violating curfew. ``Soldiers are under orders to enforce the curfew,'' he said. ``To enforce the law, you (Americans) use firepower in the streets. Now we are in an emergency situation.''

DOC.HEAD: FCC Head Opposes Interim TV Standard
DOC.TEXT: Companies that say the United States should adopt cheaper, interim technology before moving to a full high-definition TV system got some bad news Thursday from the head of the Federal Communications Commission. FCC Chairman Alfred Sikes, in his strongest statement yet on how quickly the nation should shift to HDTV, told a broadcasters' seminar that he saw little possibility the commission would decide to allow so-called enhanced-definition TV to be used before full HDTV. While not slamming the door completely on the interim EDTV, which is being promoted by a consortium that includes NBC-TV, Sikes said the commission's preliminary decision to try to adopt a ``simulcast'' HDTV system for the nation in early 1993 probably would not be changed. ``I do think any objective review of the record will show that the simulcast HDTV option we have pointed toward has greater public interest'' than EDTV, Sikes said in prepared remarks for a meeting of the Association of Maximum Service Television. He said HDTV ``affords broadcasters the ability to be fully competitive in the future video services marketplace.'' Sikes is among those concerned that Japanese or European manufacturers not dominate the HDTV market, which most observers believe will be a huge business in the next century. At Thursday's meeting, he rejected assertions that the FCC was moving too quickly to adopt an HDTV standard, while citing Japan's long lead in bringing HDTV to the public. NBC and the David Sarnoff Research Center, along with electronics giants Thomson Consumer Electronics and Philips Consumer Electronics, have proposed EDTV as a less-expensive means of improving today's TV images. EDTV, while less sharp than HDTV, could be sent out by stations on a single channel. But viewers would need a new set to receive the improved EDTV image. Simulcast systems would send programs normally on one channel and the same programs in HDTV on a separate channel. A new set also would be required to receive the HDTV signal. The NBC consortium says EDTV would require relatively inexpensive equipment changes at TV stations. Sikes said that adopting EDTV first would create unnecessary costs for stations and viewers and could cause viewers to resist buying EDTV sets if they knew that HDTV would soon make those sets obsolete. The NBC consortium, hedging its bets, also is among a half-dozen companies that will offer simulcast HDTV systems for testing by an industry-sponsored laboratory that will recommend an HDTV standard to the FCC. Testing is to begin this year or early next year. HDTV promises crystal-clear pictures and compact disc-quality sound. Proponents see numerous medical, military and educational uses for sharper TV images.

DOC.HEAD: Bridge Barricaded in Mohawk Dispute Reopened After Two Months
DOC.TEXT: The Mercier Bridge linking Montreal to its south-shore suburbs opened Thursday for the first time following an eight-week standoff between armed Mohawks and police. As army pipers played, hundreds of cars and trucks drove onto the bridge from suburban Chateauguay, through the Kahnawake Mohawk reserve and past armored personnel carriers in the early morning mist. Commuters had started lining up their cars an hour earlier, horns honking impatiently as they waited for the army to wave them through. ``It's about time,'' one man on his way to work at a Montreal refrigerated warehouse told a radio station. ``The government should never have let this happen in the first place.'' The bridge normally handles about 70,000 vehicles during the daily rush hour. It was barricaded by natives from the Kahnawake reserve after provincial police staged an abortive attack on a Mohawk barricade at Kahnesatake near Oka, Quebec, on July 11 in which an officer died. The bridge closure led to violent demonstrations by south-shore commuters, including an incident last week in which a white mob hurled stones at a convoy of Mohawk women, children and invalids escaping the reserve. The stage was set for the reopening when barricades at Kahnawake came down last week after an agreement was reached between the army and Mohawks. But in Kahnesatake _ where the Mohawk deadlock began over a land dispute _ soldiers spent Wednesday firming up their positions around the last Warrior stronghold. Federal Indian Affairs Minister Tom Siddon met with a delegation of native leaders in Ottawa on Wednesday. But he stopped short of committing the government to either of the two requests made by the Indian delegation _ that the army retreat at least 100 yards away from Mohawk lines, and that Ottawa assume an active role in the negotiations. Among the native leaders who met with Siddon were George Erasmus of the Assembly of First Nations, Canada's largest native group. Erasmus said the federal and Quebec governments must get involved in a new round of negotiations to resolve the stalemate at Kahnesatake, 18 miles west of Montreal. About 400 soldiers have backed some 20 warriors and 30 Mohawk women and children into a piece of land about the size of two football fields, bordered by a highway and a lake. On Wednesday the soldiers surrounded the site with razor wire and set up a floating barricade on the lake. The Mohawks say they won't lay down their arms until a policing arrangement is worked out that would preclude the Quebec provincial police from taking control once the crisis comes to an end. Natives say they fear reprisals from the police for the death of one of their officers in the botched raid in July. The deadlock at Oka began when provincial police stormed a barricade the Mohawks erected to stop the town's plans to expand the local golf course, saying the property in question was part of their ancestral land. Elsewhere in Quebec, about 100 Micmac Indians blocked a stretch of highway, just across the border from Cambellton, New Brunswick. The Indians felled trees and used rocks and abandoned cars to set up two roadblocks. They said the barricades would remain until the Oka crisis is resolved.

DOC.HEAD: Post Says Foundation Ignored Discount in Purchasing Neuharth Book
DOC.TEXT: The Gannett Foundation purchased 2,000 copies of the autobiography of its chairman, Allen H. Neuharth, raising questions about whether it was trying to boost the book's standing on national bestseller lists, The Washington Post said Thursday. Neuharth, in response, was quoted as saying he was on The Post's ``enemy list.'' Neuharth said that Post Executive Editor Ben Bradlee was out to ``get him'' and that ``playing a non-news story like this on page one when the world is full of real news is typical of the personal journalism The Post uses to try to get its enemies and help its friends.'' He was quoted in a statement by Foundation President and Chief Executive Officer Charles L. Overby. The foundation said that it spent $40,000 to buy the copies of ``Confessions of an S.O.B.,'' that the books were donated to college libraries and journalism schools, and that there was no attempt to manipulate sales. Overby said in his statement that purchase of the books ``was consistent with our mission of teaching young journalists and other young people how to succeed in life.'' Neuharth was chairman of Gannett Co., the nation's largest newspaper group, until he retired 17 months ago to head the foundation. He told The Post his autobiography sold 164,000 copies in hardback between September 1989 and the end of last year. It was on The New York Times bestseller list for several weeks. The Post, quoting Gannett editors and people connected to the foundation, said the foundation's motives were suspect because it bought the books at full retail prices in stores around the country. The foundation could have obtained the books at a sizable discount from Neuharth's publisher, Doubleday Inc., but only retail purchases count on bestseller lists compiled by The New York Times and Publishers Weekly. The Post said Overby asked some of Gannett Co.'s 81 daily newspapers to buy books at stores in their cities. The foundation then reimbursed the editors for the cost of the books. Michael Kagay, editor of news surveys for The New York Times Book Review, said the purchase of 2,000 copies normally would not have much effect on how a book fares on the bestseller list. The Times does not reveal the names of the approximately 3,000 bookstores it surveys in compiling its list and ``if someone tried to influence the list, most of their purchases would be wasted. They wouldn't know which stores to go to,'' Kagay said. Overby, in his statement, said Neuharth, now traveling outside Washington, ``laughed heartily when I read him'' The Post story.

DOC.HEAD: North-South Talks Produce No Agreements, but Both Sides Upbeat
DOC.TEXT: South Korean President Roh Tae-woo on Thursday told North Korea's prime minister their nations must hold a summit to set the stage for eventual unification of the divided peninsula. ``Korea can't remain the last divided nation on Earth separated by Cold War,'' Roh said at the first meeting between a South Korean head of state and a North Korean leader. It came after two days of historic talks between the prime ministers of the hostile nations. Roh's meeting at his office with the communist premier, Yon Hyong Muk, was seen as indicating North Korea's tacit recognition of rival South Korea. The nations, divided since 1945, have never officially recognized each other. The North has ignored past summit proposals and officials did not react publicly to the latest one. Although talks between Yon and his South Korean counterpart, Kang Young-hoon, failed to produce any tangible agreements, officials of both sides were upbeat and agreed to meet next month in North Korea's capital. ``Unlike in the past, there was a realistic discussion,'' said South Korean Unification Minister Hong Sung-chul. ``I think the talks were successful and a step forward.'' ``I'm optimistic there could be progress,'' said An Byong Su, spokesman for North Korea. s. At Thursday's meeting of the prime ministers, North Korea reiterated its demands that South Korea release jailed dissidents, halt a joint U.S. military exercise and stop efforts to seek its own seat in the United Nations, Seoul officials said. North Korea also demanded the withdrawal of the American troops stationed in the South under a mutual defense treaty, they said. Lengthy proposals presented for easing military and political tensions and setting up various exchanges will be discussed at future talks, spokesmen for the two sides said. Red Cross authorities may soon open talks aimed at helping reunite 10 million members of families separated by the division of the peninsula and the 1950-53 Korean War. The premiers' meeting was the highest-level contact ever between the Koreas. The Korean peninsula was divided into the communist North and the capitalist South in 1945. The border is sealed and there is no mail or other form of communication between the nations. The North Korean premier and his 89-member entourage were scheduled to return home by way of the border village of Panmunjom on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Summer Heat Lingers in Midwest, South
DOC.TEXT: Minnesota and Wisconsin were drenched Thursday, leaving some spots under 18 inches of water, and areas in the Midwest and South baked in oppressive triple-digit heat and high humidity. Thunderstorms were active during the morning, and thunderstorm winds caused damage near Constantine, Mich. Heavy rain from strong thunderstorms flooded roads and basements across northeast Minnesota and northwest Wisconsin. In Minnesota, 18 inches of water covered roads in Morgan Park and several roads in southern St. Louis County were washed out. Water was waist deep on streets in Carlton County and some highways to Clouquet were closed. Showers and thunderstorms continued into the afternoon in northern Ohio, southern Lower Michigan, northern Wisconsin and southern Upper Michigan, as well as along the Texas Gulf Coast, the Louisiana coast, and the Florida peninsula. Showers and thunderstorms were scattered in West Virginia, western Virginia, west central Alabama, south central Kansas and northwest Oklahoma, northeast Colorado and western Nebraska, southeastern South Dakota, western Minnesota, northeast California and Oregon. In Kansas, the heat index, combining the temperature with humidity levels, was forecast at up to 105 degrees in central and eastern parts of the state. Advisories for excessive heat were posted through Friday for northeast and north-central Texas. The heat index was forecast from 105 to 112 degrees. Northwestern Louisiana had heat indexes ranging from 105 to 112 degrees, too. The heat index was forecast in the range of 105 to 110 degrees in central Indiana and 110 to 115 degrees in the southern part of the state. High temperature records for Thursday were broken in Kansas City, Mo., with 99 degrees, surpassing the previous 97-degree mark; Meridian, Miss., with 102, besting the record 100; Pensacola, Fla., with 94, beating 93; and Tupelo, Miss., with 103, beating 101. Thursday's low for the Lower 48 was 38 degrees at Truckee, Calif. In the eastern Atlantic Ocean, Tropical Storm Isidore became stronger with sustained winds near 70 mph and higher gusts. At noon, the center of Isidore was 800 miles west of the Cape Verde Islands and moving northwest 15 mph. Isidore threatens no major area of land.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwait Says Iraq is Plundering Hospitals, Blood Banks
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq has plundered Kuwait's blood banks and its hospitals, stripping the facilities of intensive care equipment and incubators and causing the deaths of patients, Kuwait's ambassador said Thursday. ``We do have some reports of the inhuman practices,'' Kuwaiti Ambassador Mohammad Abulhasan told reporters. He said health authorities in occupied Kuwait had provided him with reports of the looting of medical equipment. In a letter to the Security Council, he said, ``The delicate medical equipment used in the intensive care units of many Kuwaiti hospitals has been seized and taken to Baghdad. This has led to the death of many patients who were receiving intensive care. ``The incubators in maternity hospitals used for ... premature children have been removed, causing the death of all the children who were under treatment,'' his letter said. ``Plasma deposits at the blood bank have been removed and transferred to Baghdad,'' he continued. ``The inmates of mental hospitals and centers for the disabled have been released and allowed to roam in the streets without any care or attention,'' the ambassador added. Last week, the ambassador said all five of Kuwait's regular hospitals had been emptied of patients to be used by Iraqi troops and citizens, causing the deaths of several elderly patients who depended on life-support equipment. In remarks to reporters Thursday, Abulhasan said ``We have reports also of looting of reservoirs of food for Kuwait and moving it to Iraq. It has taken place since the first week of the occupation'' that began Aug. 2. When asked if any deaths by starvation had occurred in Kuwait, he replied, ``Not yet.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Will Go On Iraqi TV, Spokesman Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 3rd graf pvs `Iraqi Ambassador ...' to UPDATE with Fitzwater saying U.S. will provide package for Iraqi television. Picks up 4th graf pvs `On another...' DELETES now outdated 9th graf pvs `The president ...' INSERTS 2 grafs after 25th graf pvs `We will ...' to ADD Bush comments in Florida. Picks up 26th graf pvs `Bush's trip ...'
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will accept Saddam Hussein's offer to broadcast a message to Iraq, but only on his own terms, Bush's spokesman said Thursday. The president will make a tape in lieu of an interview with an Iraqi TV crew. ``It's a real opportunity,'' Bush said of Saddam's offer to televise the U.S. leader's comments. Bush's spokesman said the president had ``a very distinct message'' to give the Iraqi people about American reasons for the massive military buildup in the Persian Gulf. Iraqi Ambassador Mohamed al-Mashat said in Washington that ``of course'' Iraqi TV would air Bush's message ``in its entirety without editing. Here you edit, in Iraq we do not edit.'' Spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Bush's address would be eight to 10 minutes long. ``We will have a whole package for broadcast on Iraqi television, and then we'll have a State Department interpreter who will provide the interpretation some way'' into Arabic, Fitzwater said, adding that the tape will be released generally. On another topic, looking ahead to this weekend's superpower summit, Bush said he will use the meeting not only to discuss the Persian Gulf with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev but to press for a quick resolution to strategic arms talks. Before embarking on a one-day political trip to Kansas and Florida on Thursday, Bush spoke by telephone with a number of world leaders on the gulf situation and his upcoming meeting with Gorbachev. They included Syrian President Hafez al-Assad, Turkish President Turgut Ozal, French President Francois Mitterrand and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, the White House said. He also called United Nations Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar to thank him for his unsuccessful try at resolving the gulf crisis in talks last week in Iraq. Bush also met Thursday with Israel's visiting foreign minister, David Levy in Washington. Naji al-Hadithi, director general of Iraq's Information Ministry, said in Baghdad that an Iraqi television crew was ready to go to Washington to interview Bush for a broadcast on state-run television. Fitzwater said that wouldn't be necessary _ ``we'll produce it ourselves.'' ``Although we have not heard from Iraq directly, we accept their offer of a broadcast to the Iraqi people. The president will tape a message to the Iraqi people in the next few days which will be provided to the Iraqi information minister,'' Fitzwater told reporters accompanying Bush on Air Force One. Bush has said he wished he could have the media access in Iraq that Saddam has had on U.S. television. The Iraqi president's statements and appearances have been broadcast widely, many of them on live and unedited CNN reports. ``The president has a very distinct message that he wants to give to the people of Iraq about our purpose for being in the gulf. He thinks this is a good opportunity,'' Fitzwater said. On a separate matter, Fitzwater said that there is no new economic package for the Soviet Union in the offing, although the Sunday summit meeting in Helsinki will offer a chance to talk about ``technical assistance.'' He had said on Wednesday that because of Soviet cooperation in the United Nations-led sanctions against Iraq, Bush was willing to look anew at potential financial aid for the ailing Soviet economy. Fitzwater noted Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher was leading a team of American business executives to Moscow to discuss investment opportunities. They will stop in Helsinki during the summit. Fitzwater said Bush has not yet decided whether to attend the Oct. 3 Berlin ceremony celebrating Germany's reunification. Speaking at a Kansas fund-raiser for Gov. Mike Hayden's re-election bid, Bush said that while the Persian Gulf is expected to consume much of the conversation at the summit, he also wants to focus on arms control. ``I will continue to press for a prompt resolution of the START treaty,'' he said of the Strategic Arms Reduction Talks that officials hope will produce agreement by the end of the year on reducing nuclear weapons. Noting the international condemnation of Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait and sanctions against Saddam, Bush said: ``We will remain united. In that spirit, I look forward to Sunday's meeting with President Gorbachev in Helsinki.'' He pointed to ``new levels of cooperation'' between the superpowers, and said the Persian Gulf situation ``shows what this cooperation can achieve.'' ``This meeting can further expand cooperation between the U.S. and Soviet Union,'' he said. Bush also reiterated the U.S. determination to ``do whatever it takes to help our men and women restore peace'' in the Middle East. ``We will not stand by while one country devours another unthreatening country,'' he said. Later, at a fund-raiser for Rep. Bill Grant, R-Fla., Bush condemned Saddam Hussein anew. ``Our argument is not with the people of Iraq,'' Bush said. ``Rather, it is with Iraq's dictator who uses innocent travelers as shields, who now ... holds hostages from many countries. But he must know that our policy ... will not be altered by this brazen blackmail.'' Bush's trip Thursday marked his first flight on the new Air Force One, a specially equipped Boeing 747 that replaced his aging 707. ``It's marvelous in every way _ the latest in technology and certainly very, very comfortable,'' Bush said as he stepped aboard. ``It's so much roomier. My heavens. ... It is magnificent.''

DOC.HEAD: Protesters Denounce `Red Terror' at Lenin Statue in Ukraine
DOC.TEXT: About 30 nationalists gathered Thursday night at the foot of a statue of Vladimir Lenin in a Ukrainian city for a candlelight vigil to denounce 72 years of ``red terror,'' the Tass news agency reported. The demonstrators in Donetsk placed a garland of barbed wire around the base of the statue to the founder of the Soviet state, Tass reported. A ribbon attached to the wire said ``To V.I. Lenin _ on the 72nd Anniversary of Red Terror,'' the news agency said. Another streamer reportedly bore the words: ``100 million victims.'' Tass said the demonstrators, all members of a Ukrainian nationalist movement, held lighted candles in the vigil, which lasted about an hour. The Tass account was headlined ``Insulting Vigil at Lenin Monument in Donetsk,'' and said passers-by expressed anger and bewilderment at the protest. Police asked the demonstrators to disperse, and one of the participants tried to slash his veins to protest what he called illegal police actions, Tass reported. He received medical assistance, and the demonstrators dispersed, the news agency added. Donetsk, the center of the eastern Ukraine's Don River coal basin, was the site this summer of a one-day strike by miners demanding less interference from the Communist Party. Miners in Donetsk also joined a long, bitter coal strike in the summer of 1989 over low wages and consumer goods shortages. Statues of Lenin have been vandalized with increasing frequency across the Soviet Union in recent months, and some have been dismantled on the orders of local authorities, to the dismay of the Soviet leadership.

DOC.HEAD: Teacher, Students Walk to School in Display of Energy Conservation
DOC.TEXT: A high school teacher felt the Persian Gulf crisis down to the soles of his feet Thursday when he dramatized energy conservation by walking 11 miles to his classroom. Scores of students joined Don Chenoweth, voting with their feet in favor of reducing U.S. dependence on foreign oil supplies. ``The prices are going up,'' says Coleman Davis, a 14-year-old freshman at Concord High School who walked several miles. ``So if lots of people from our school walked, we'd save gas.'' The idea grew from Chenoweth's senior government class, where students began discussing methods of energy conservation in the face of rising fuel prices. ``In the course of the conversation, I threw out the challenge: If I walk to school one of these days, how many students would be willing to do the same,'' he said while walking the final yards. ``If nothing else, they'll get a little firsthand involvement with current events.'' Chenoweth left his Mishawaka home at 3:45 a.m., walking with school counselor Don Mann, and arrived shortly after 7 a.m., nearly 30 minutes ahead of schedule. Chenoweth, 57, doesn't offer himself as model of fitness or restraint in driving. He says his exercising is usually limited to an occasional evening stroll, and he's put 146,000 miles on his 1982 Pontiac. Many people have forgotten the conservation lessons enforced by oil crises of the 1970s, he said, and for his students, those years are dim history. ``I did tell them about the 1970s, how we were mandated by the government to turn back the heat in public buildings, and encouraged to do other things,'' he said. ``They were not aware that the 55 mile-per-hour speed limit really came about in an attempt to save fuel, not an attempt to slow us down to save lives.'' About 300 students agreed to give up cars and school buses for the day and walk, said Principal Robert Sutton, who walked the two miles from his home. No one kept count of how many participated, but scores of students appeared on foot in groups of three and four, already looking tired and sweaty shortly after 7 a.m. ``Four miles _ we did it,'' said Lee Anne Grice. ``We are having an energy crisis right now, so I thought it would be a good way to show my support.'' Sophomore Chris Carrel, 15, left his motor scooter, which gets about 75 miles to the gallon, at home to prove his point. ``The Iraq thing kind of makes it worthwhile,'' he said. ``Saves me some gasoline.'' Chenoweth and Mann arrived sweaty but smiling, then showered and changed for class. ``I may move closer if we try this again,'' said Mann.

DOC.HEAD: Dukakis Allies Move To Quash Lieutenant Governor's `Palace Revolt'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Dukakis leaving. Pick up 5th graf pvs: `Murphy, who ...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BX7
DOC.TEXT: After being held a political hostage by a mutinous lieutenant governor, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis departed on a European trade mission Thursday as his allies moved to quash the rebellion. Dukakis had delayed his travel plans Tuesday after Lt. Gov. Evelyn Murphy threatened to seize control of Massachusetts' feeble finances once he left. ``I think the episode of the past 24 hours is really kind of pathetic,'' Dukakis said at a brief airport news conference before boarding his plane to Germany. While Dukakis allies moved to quash the rebellion Thursday, with references to a new form of ``Murphy's Law'' and an ``attempted bloodless coup,'' Murphy said her boss was acting ``weird'' by not letting her assert herself. ``There's no good will here and certainly no mutual respect,'' Murphy said. Dukakis said he did not speak to Murphy on Thursday, but he said he believed her assurances that she would act responsibily in his absence. But he said he could cut his trip short if anything occurs that affected the government's stability. Murphy spokeswoman Jody D'Urso said the lieutenant governor, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for governor, would not take any action Thursday night. D'Urso did not rule out Murphy acting later. Murphy, who is lagging in her Democratic primary race to succeed Dukakis, had been a strong supporter of the governor in his 1988 bid for the presidency. But with the state in a fiscal disaster and Dukakis not seeking re-election, politicians have treated him as a liability. Murphy took the anti-Dukakis revolt to a new level Wednesday when she disclosed she was waiting for the governor to leave the state so, as acting governor, she could push a secret plan for solving the state's financial woes. Dukakis decided to postpone his travel plans, prompting some observers to say he was being held hostage by his own lieutenant governor. Dukakis bitterly denounced the tactic as a maneuver designed to gain favor with voters in the gubernatorial race. On Thursday, aides to Dukakis echoed that charge. ``Here's a lady who isn't going to get elected governor no matter what she does, and she is dangerously flirting with the economic health of the commonwealth of Massachusetts. That's irresponsible,'' said L. Edward Lashman, state secretary of Administration and Finance. Lashman said he isn't publicly supporting any candidate in the Sept. 18 primary. According to recent public opinion polls, Murphy is well behind her two Democratic opponents _ former state Attorney General Francis X. Bellotti and John Silber, who is on leave as Boston University's president. Before this week, she tried gently to disassociate herself from Dukakis, claiming she warned him in the spring of 1988 that the state was headed for trouble. Murphy insisted Thursday that she was simply looking out for the well-being of the state, which discovered this week its tax collections had fallen short for the second month in a row. That prompted Dukakis to order cabinet members to find $150 million worth of cuts. Murphy said quicker action was needed, but she refused to reveal her strategy, even to Dukakis during a phone conversation. ``She's elevated Murphy's Law to an art form,'' said Stephen Crawford, a Dukakis spokesman. ``Whatever can go wrong, she'll make sure goes wrong.'' In her defense, Murphy told a radio station Thursday: ``I can't understand why he's so concerned and what this strange behavior is about. ... Frankly, I find the governor's response yesterday weird.'' Murphy's actions, however, caused some defections within her ranks. William Currier, a campaign coordinator, resigned because of her moves against Dukakis. ``It's almost an attempted bloodless coup,'' he said. If Murphy tries to make changes as acting governor, he said, cabinet secretaries might either disregard her, or Dukakis could reverse the action once he returned. Currier also questioned how Murphy could ``solve problems in 10 days that hundreds of people couldn't solve in two years.'' The state's fiscal mess has given Massachusetts the lowest bond ratings of any state. Lashman said Thursday that Wall Street had started to send positive signals since the state adopted a tax and budget package and Dukakis ordered new cuts once it became apparent they were necessary. He said Murphy's actions could undo efforts to rebuild the state's image.

DOC.HEAD: The Brezhnev Suite: Available for $525 a Night
DOC.TEXT: A hotel suite used by former Soviet leader Leonid I. Brezhnev will be rented out to foreign tourists for $525 a night by an American entrepreneur, Tass reported Thursday. The businessman, Kristianu Tomesku, plans to turn vacation cottages and hotel suites once used by the Communist Party elite into luxury accommodations for foreign tourists in the southern Soviet republic of Moldavia, Tass said. Tomesku will open a network of casinos, restaurants, bars, swimming pools and tennis courts in the Kholerkan and Kodru hotel and cottage complex in the Moldavian capital of Kishinev and its suburbs, the Soviet news agency reported. The digs, which Tass described as ``comfortable,'' previously were used as recreation sites by members of the republic's government and high-ranking Communist Party officials. A room at one of the hotels will cost $80 a night, the report said, while the ``Blue Suite,'' which was used by high-ranking officials, will go for about $350 nightly. ``Those foreigners who like exotics and wish to stay in the luxurious suite in which Leonid Brezhnev was accommodated some time ago will pay $525 a day for it,'' the Tass report said. Tass gave no further details on the luxury suites, the background of Tomesku, or how he obtained the property _ except to say he is leasing it. Brezhnev ruled the Soviet Union from 1964 until his death in November 1982. Under Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Brezhnev has been blamed for fostering complacency and cronyism during his years in power, which Soviet officials call the ``period of stagnation.'' The press has published other details of his lavish lifestyle, including a white marble mansion in Azerbaijan built for Brezhnev so he could stay there during a 1982 visit. He stayed there two days.

DOC.HEAD: Legislators Demand Control Over EGerman Secret Police Files
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers criticized a treaty laying the foundation for German unity Thursday because it fails to give East Germans control over the secret files of the former Communist regime. The treaty that reconciles many of the differences between the two German states came up for a first reading in Parliament. Several legislators were irate over the vagueness of the provision dealing with the files kept by the former secret police. A group of activists who helped lead the revolution that toppled the Communists have been occupying the former state police headquarters where the files are kept. They began a sit-down protest on Tuesday and are demanding that East Germans have access to the files and that secret police still working in the government be fired. Even Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere said the provision in the treaty, which he personally approved, should be modified to deal more specifically with the fate of the files. Later, his top unity negotiator, Guenter Krause, said on West German radio that East Germans should be allowed to know what is in their files. The files are an emotional issue in a nation that was largely kept in check by the smothering and frequently sinister activities of the giant secret police network. The activists and many lawmakers are demanding that East Germans have the right to read the files that were kept on them. Records were kept on an estimated 6 million of the 16 million Germans. The treaty between the German states says the files will temporarily remain on East German land but will be administered by a West German official until a united German parliament, to be elected on Dec. 2, makes a final decision on their future. However, activists and many lawmakers said the agreement was tantamount to giving the files to West Germany because the united parliament will be dominated by lawmakers from the larger country. Some lawmakers demanded the rejection of the 900-page state treaty that aims to reconcile many of the social and political differences between the two nations, which are to merge on Oct. 3. Lawmakers are expected to hold a final vote on the treaty next week.

DOC.HEAD: Black Editor Resigns To Protest Exclusion Of White Candidate Profile
DOC.TEXT: An editor at the Washington Afro-American resigned Thursday after saying the minority-owned weekly newspaper refused to profile a mayoral candidate because he is white. Robyn Denise Yourse, who is black, said Thursday she submitted her resignation to publisher Frances Murphy after Murphy refused to include a story on City Council Chairman David Clarke in a 36-page issue of the paper. ``I felt that the reasons given for yanking the profile were racially biased,'' said Yourse. ``It was a decision in all good conscience I could not agree with.'' Yourse declined to elaborate on her discussion with the publisher, who also is black. ``Her reasoning was clear to me, and I will say it had nothing to do with the candidate's views,'' Yourse said. ``Beyond that, I do not wish to embellish.'' Murphy denied that Clarke was excluded because of his race, claiming that other candidates who did not receive the paper's endorsement were not given full-length feature articles. ``We're just a weekly, and we don't have the space,'' Murphy said. ``There were lots of people who didn't (get articles), so you can't say it is black and white.'' She added that she was uncertain whether the paper had prepared an article on the council chairman. ``There are some we did, and some we did not do,'' Murphy said. ``I just don't know.'' But an Afro-American staffer, who asked not to be identified by name, said Clarke had been the subject of a feature story. ``They had it ready,'' the staffer told The Associated Press. ``He came up there, he was interviewed, and a story was prepared.'' Clarke is the only white vying for the city's Democratic mayoral nomination. His four opponents are black. Clarke, a Washington native and veteran of the civil rights movement, has been ranked third or fourth in recent public opinion polls. The Afro, which endorsed Ray for mayor in Thursday's edition, has long been a source of news and influence in Washington's black community. The newspaper lists its circulation at 10,000, which would make it the most widely-read of six minority-published weeklies in the nation's capital. In recent weeks, the paper has published profiles of candidates John Ray, Charlene Drew-Jarvis, Sharon Pratt-Dixon and Walter Fauntroy.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Cracks Down on Fleeing Foreigners, Threatens Life in Prison
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with Westerners arriving in London, others en route from Jordan; SUBS 12th graf pvs to CONFORM. Pickup 13th graf pvs, `An Air...' ^With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: As hundreds of foreigners trapped in Iraq and Kuwait struggled to get out, Iraq on Thursday imposed a law mandating possible life imprisonment for those caught trying to leave without permission. A plane with 136 Canadians, 12 Americans and 10 Irish who had been in Kuwait and Iraq arrived in London late Thursday on a Nationair flight chartered by Canada's government, airport authorities reported. All but 24 of the passengers were flying on to Toronto after a brief refueling stop, they said. A British Airways charter with 250 women and children on board departed early Friday from Amman for London. They arrived Thursday in Jordan on two Iraqi Airways jets, one carrying 150 passengers and the second 100, said British Ambassador to Jordan, Anthony Reed. Iraq's justice minister, Akram Abdul-Kader, ordered public prosecutors and police to revive a 1987 law that ``a foreigner violating the entry and exit procedures ... will be sentenced to life or temporary imprisonment, and all cash in his possession will be confiscated.'' In an interview with the official Iraqi News Agency, monitored in Nicosia, he said: ``Courts and prosecutors are called upon to make no exception in implementing this law in light of the present circumstances.'' The minister added that foreigners must report any change in address within 48 hours or face prison terms of one to three years, plus fines of $300 to $1,500. Hundreds of Westerners in Iraqi-occupied Kuwait are in hiding to avoid being captured by Iraqi troops. Some foreigners keep constantly on the move, often avoiding Iraqi soldiers with the help of Kuwaiti friends. Abdul-Kader repeated an order given Aug. 24 that anyone caught harboring a foreigner would face charges of espionage, punishable by death. Earlier, a British convoy carrying 182 women and children arrived in the Iraqi capital from Kuwait. The Iraqi president, Saddam Hussein, has said women and children may leave but men must stay. The latest arrivals were put in a hotel, where presumably they will await official permission to leave the country. Some men were believed to be among the group. The convoy left Kuwait on Thursday at 9:15 a.m. for the 14-hour drive across the desert to Baghdad, British diplomats in Iraq said. The diplomats, speaking on condition of anonymity, said about 60 women and children were in the group, including 50 Britons, nine Americans and one West German. U.S. Embassy officials were trying to arrange travel for the group to the Jordanian capital of Amman aboard an Iraqi Airways flight. Another 306 foreigners arrived in Baghdad on Tuesday in a convoy from Kuwait. Four Irish women and children made it to Amman on Thursday on an Iraqi Airways flight from Baghdad. An Air France jet landed in Paris about dawn Thursday carrying 153 Westerners, including three pregnant women, who had traveled from Baghdad overnight. There were at least nine Americans on board. A Western source in Baghdad said the United States was trying to persuade Iraq to allow an Iraqi Airways jet to airlift some Americans directly out of Kuwait without the overland trip to Baghdad. An estimated 1,300 Americans remain in Kuwait, which has been occupied by Iraqi soldiers since Aug. 2. There are believed to be a total of 11,000 Westerners trapped in Iraq and Kuwait. Joanna Restall of Brighton, England, is one of the Westerners who have managed to get out of the region in relatively small batches the past week. She arrived in London early Thursday from Baghdad. Ms. Restall was part of a convoy Saturday that made a hair-raising drive across the desert from Kuwait City. Ms. Restall, 29, who had been teaching English in Kuwait, said the people left behind in Kuwait are frightened, particularly the men. ``They can't go out, the shops are closed, there are lots of wrecked cars everywhere _ it's like a ghost town,'' she said. The Iraqis have moved some Westerners to strategic facilities, such as military bases, to deter possible attacks by Western forces.

DOC.HEAD: United States Will Negotiate Commercial Space Code
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration will enter negotiations with the European Space Agency to set guidelines for multinational commercial space ventures, the White House said Thursday. The guidelines would cover undertakings with countries without market economies like the Soviet Union and China. The negotiations are intended to develop ``principles of free and fair trade,'' the White House said, so that U.S. space-launching firms can compete in an international market free of what they contend is unfair foreign government support. The White House said Bush has approved a new National Space Policy Directive designed to ``encourage the growth of U.S. private sector space activities'' and calling for the talks. The new policy was influenced by the end of Cold War tensions with the Soviet Union and the administration's view that some restrictions, formerly imposed under national security guidelines, can be eased, said an administration official. Another source close to Bush's National Space Council, which developed the policy, said the easing of restrictions is another sign the Cold War is over. The sources spoke on condition that their names not be used. The new policy requires that national security restrictions on technology transfers still must be taken into account with any commercial launching venture with foreign countries. The guidelines are meant to replace the ad hoc approval practices that governed past decisions on space launch firms, such as Bush's recent authorization for a U.S. firm to participate in a launching project in Cape York, Australia. That firm, USBI Co. of Hunstville, Ala., eventually hopes to launch American-made satellites on Soviet rockets from the Cape York. USBI would provide program management, engineering and development for the launching facility and the Soviet Union would provide the boosters. The United States government is not involved in the project. The new policy's major contribution to such future ventures is predictability, said Courtney Stadd, senior director of commercial space for the National Space Council, which is headed with Vice President Dan Quayle.. ``We're trying to work out the principles of free market play,'' he said comparing it to the early days of aviation when there were no rules governing international flights. It requires that U.S. government satellites be launched only on U.S.-manufactured rockets. It also opens the possibility of government incentives ``to encourage technical improvements to reduce the cost and increase the reliability of U.S. space launch vehicles,'' according to a White House fact sheet. The administration will begin negotiations with the European Space agency sometime later this month on an agreement that ``defines principles of free and fair trade,'' it said. U.S. rocket launching firms have complained that European space firms have unfair advantages due to government asistance.

DOC.HEAD: Troubled NASA Focusing on Fuel Pump as Leak Source
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 19th graf, `The repairs . . .' to RESTORE first reference, title for Winterhalter. ^With AM-Space Shuttle-Delays
DOC.TEXT: NASA said Thursday it will replace the fuel pump that likely caused its latest failure to get astronauts back in space and try again in mid-September to launch Columbia. NASA Administrator Richard Truly said a new pump will be installed this weekend. If that seems to correct the problem, a fourth launch attempt will be made to launch the shuttle with an astronomical observatory early the week of Sept. 17. ``It's not a 100 percent guarantee. But it's the one shot we have to get the Astro mission airborne'' before Discovery's scheduled flight with the Ulysses satellite in October, Truly said. The unit is bolted in and can be replaced easily, said launch director Bob Sieck. Crews cannot enter the compartment until Friday because propellants remain aboard, preventing a new pump from being installed until Saturday. On Wednesday, NASA called off its third attempt to send Columbia on a mission to study some of the hottest objects in the universe with the $150 million Astro observatory. Thursday's early morning launch was scrubbed after hydrogen flooded into the rear compartment. Officials continued filling Columbia's massive external tank to pinpoint the source and narrowed their search to the shuttle's three recirculation pumps. Each of the shuttle's three main engines has a pump. Officials were uncertain which one might be leaking or whether there were other holes. The pumps are part of the plumbing in the rear of the shuttle, where pipes range in diameter up to 17 inches. They are directly in front of the huge engines and are accessible through side doors. ``We're not talking about a large leak. We're talking about an extremely small leak,'' said Forrest S. McCartney, director of Kennedy Space Center. ``It's very elusive and very frustrating.'' ``It is a real booger to try to find and isolate,'' shuttle boss Robert Crippen said. If a new pump does not correct Columbia's leaks or the launch is delayed too long, the mission will wait until after Discovery's flight with Ulysses, a satellite being sent on a five-year journey to explore the sun's polar regions. Discovery must lift off between Oct. 5 to Oct. 23 to take advantage of the proper planet alignment. ``Ulysses is our first priority and we will not compromise that,'' said William Lenoir, head of NASA's space flight program. Columbia's seven astronauts left for their training base in Houston at dawn. The mood at the space center was one of disappointment mixed with relief. ``My first reaction was frustration,'' said program scientist Ed Weiler. ``But my next thought was, `My God, I'm glad they stopped, some of my friends are aboard.' '' Hydrogen is highly combustible. NASA had to replace a pump once before _ on Atlantis last year. It delayed the launch with the Magellan space probe for six days. In May, NASA's first attempt to launch Columbia for the Astro mission ground to a halt at almost the same moment during fueling as more than a half-million gallons of liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen were flowing into the tank Wednesday. The earlier attempt, too, was delayed by leaks _ in two places. The space agency returned Columbia to the hangar, replaced a bad valve and plugged leaks. The lines were tested with helium at room temperature rather than with liquid hydrogen, a highly combustible fuel that contracts metal because of its extreme cold. The repairs gave NASA the confidence to proceed with another launch attempt, said David Winterhalter, director of systems engineering and analysis for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The second try, last week, was called off because of communications problems with one of Astro's four telescopes. Columbia's long flight with Astro and its astronauts, four of them astronomers, was to have revitalized NASA's stalled shuttle program. The last shuttle flight was in April, when Discovery carried the defective Hubble Space Telescope into orbit. A month after first discovering Columbia was leaking, the shuttle Atlantis was found to have a similar problem and the entire fleet was grounded. John Logsdon, director of the Space Policy Institute at George Washington University, said he is confident NASA will fix the leak and that shuttles soon will be flying again. ``We've launched 35 of these things. It's not like the system can't work. We know it can work,'' Logsdon said. ``This is the kind of vexing problem that will pop up along the way.''

DOC.HEAD: Hard-line Russian Communists Drown Out Reformers at Congress
DOC.TEXT: Hard-line Communists from across the Soviet Union headed back home Thursday after spending three days lamenting President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reforms and arguing that socialism has a bright future. Traditionalists far outnumbered reformers among the 2,585 delegates to the Communist Party Congress of the Russian Republic, the largest of the Soviet Union's 15 republics. They applauded fiercely Thursday when a little-known Leningrad delegate, Mikhail Popov, said Gorbachev's perestroika reform program was ``not a revolution but a counterrevolution.'' They clapped even louder when Popov warned that efforts to create a market-based economy would help black marketeers. Gorbachev sat silently on the podium during Popov's speech and most of the three-day session in the Kremlin's cavernous marble Palace of Congresses. He finally addressed the congress Thursday afternoon, just before it ended, but his speech was closed to both Soviet and foreign reporters. Reformers who dared to speak in the open sessions were jeered and heard deliberately disruptive applause, which the official Soviet press agency Tass described as ``bad-tempered clashes.'' One young delegate, Vladimir C. Zaitsev of Murmansk, incurred the wrath of the hard-liners by suggesting their leader, Russian Communist Party First Secretary Ivan K. Polozkov, did not have the confidence of the people. Zaitsev's 10-minute speech was interrupted so many times he grew red-faced and was barely able to continue. On Tuesday, a traditionalist from the Siberian city of Tyumen, Ivan Vtorushin, suggested the country would be better off if it returned to the way things were in 1985, the year Gorbachev came to power. The purpose of the congress was primarily organizational: to complete the creation of a separate Russian branch of the Communist Party. Until this year, Russian Communists were simply members of the Soviet Party and did not have their own organization. The Russian Party was founded at a first congress in the Kremlin in June, when Polozkov was elected its leader. That congress was widely seen in the Soviet Union as an attempt by traditionalists to reassert themselves after being eclipsed for several years. Since June, several reformers have quit the Russian Party. Others, such as economist Pavel Bunich, have publicly condemned the Russian Party as ``rightist'' and called for Polozkov to resign. Polozkov, 55, has accused the pro-reform Soviet media of conducting a campaign against him and discrediting traditional socialist values. He said Thursday he would not step down. Despite their high profile during the congress, the influence of the hard-liners appears limited. They do not have the authority to make laws, and the party has lost both its official leading role in society and much of its unofficial grip on Soviet life.

DOC.HEAD: Persian Gulf Crisis At-A-Glance
DOC.TEXT:
Here, at a glance, are the major developments Thursday in the Persian Gulf crisis:
Iraq said it would enforce a 1987 law calling for possible life imprisonment for foreigners caught trying to leave Iraq or Kuwait without permission. An undisclosed number of American citizens are expected to leave Kuwait and Iraq on Friday on what the State Department hopes will be regular evacuation flights arranged by the U.S. embassy. In addition to women and children, U.S. officials said they hoped adult men with medical problems would be allowed to depart.

An American trying to evade capture was shot and wounded by an Iraqi soldier in Kuwait, the State Department said. Iraqi officials say the unidentified man, who was wounded in the forearm while trying to escape out a window of his Kuwait apartment, ``will be discharged from the hospital within 24 hours, but will remain in their custody,'' said agency spokesman Mark Dillen.

Saudi Arabia committed several billion dollars toward defraying the cost of the U.S. forces protecting the kingdom's oil fields from Iraqi aggression. The commitment came in response to a direct appeal by Secretary of State James A. Baker III.

The buildup of U.S. military forces in the Persian Gulf region has reached 100,000 men and women, but Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said it is ``too soon as yet'' to halt the flow of troops and weaponry.

President Bush has accepted Saddam Hussein's offer to broadcast a message to Iraq, but only on his own terms, spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. The spokesman said Bush would tape record ``a very distinct message'' for the Iraqi people. Iraqi Ambassador Mohamed al-Mashat said in Washington Iraqi TV would air Bush's message ``in its entirety without editing.''

A nightmare of foul-ups and conflicts has stalled relief for 70,000 Asians from Kuwait stranded in open desert in Jordan, aid workers said. Meanwhile some 45,000 desperate Bangladeshis, Indians, Sri Lankans and others camped at Shaalan I, on a rocky, scorpion-infested plain, awaiting clearance to officially enter Jordan. Thousands of others were at Shaalan II and at the Ruweishid border post, waiting to join an estimated 105,000 others already in the Jordanian capital. Each day, an estimated 20,000 people reach the border.

A Soviet spokesman raised the possibility of Kremlin support for a U.N. military force in the Persian Gulf and said Mikhail S. Gorbachev may discuss the idea with President Bush at their summit. Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov did not make clear whether the Kremlin envisioned U.N. troops acting independently or replacing U.S.-led forces in the region.

Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said that Britain plans to step up its deployment to the Persian Gulf, saying the United Nations has already taken sufficient steps to allow military force against Iraq.

Aboard the USS Robert G. Bradley in the Persian Gulf, Cmdr. Kevin J. Cosgriff told The Associated Press his ship was challenging an average of 10 tankers and freighters daily to enforce the blockade on Iraq. Its helicopters check out almost as many vessels. The Robert G. Bradley is one of nine U.S. warships involved in interdiction operations to enforce the U.N. blockade against Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Three Arrested For Selling Drugs In Capitol Complex
DOC.TEXT: Three congressional employees were arrested on Thursday and charged with narcotics distribution out of a House of Representatives parking garage, U.S. Capitol Police said. Six people have been arrested since June for selling drugs in the Capitol complex, which includes the Capitol Building and the House and Senate office buildings, police said. John Robine Mickens, 27, of Landover, Md., and Charles Anthony Vinson, 24, of Fort Washington, Md., were arrested Thursday and charged with distribution of crack cocaine. William Robert Woodburn, 33, of Leonardtown, Md., was arrested later and charged with distribution of cocaine. Woodburn is employed by the Architect of the Capitol as a labor leader, and Mickens and Vinson are employed by the Architect of the Capitol as garage attendants. ``I think its shocking and indeed hypocritical to allow the American people to believe that we have a handle on this very serious national security problem,'' said Rep. Charles Rangel, Chairman of the Select Committee of Narcotics. A three-month undercover investigation gave officials their first arrest earlier this summer when a man sold drugs to an undercover agent on June 13, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: International Center Set Up to Help Polluted Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: Hungarian President Arpad Goencz planted a tree Thursday to mark the opening of an international environmental center to help Eastern Europe cope with its widespread pollution problems. Proposed by President Bush when he visited Hungary in July, the Regional Environmental Center is an independent organization for training and information on energy efficency, public health and regional cooperation on pressing environmental problems. It is designed to provide data on environmental issues, but not to get involved in political decisions in Eastern European countries, said Lee Pasarew, director of its project development team. Peter Hardi is the executive director. ``The opening of this center today is only the latest in a remarkable series of events that history will record as the revolution of 1989,'' William K. Reilly, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, said in an opening speech. Eastern European countries are struggling with the results of a chronic disregard for the environment that characterized the Communist regimes overthrown last year. Antiquated factories central to their economies still spew tons of waste into the air and water. Many forests are damaged, if not decimated, by acid rain. Reilly said Wednesday that the center was a ``way of providing legitimacy, involvement'' for Eastern European environmentalists who had been previously suppressed. Half of the $10 million needed to start the center was donated by the United States. The European Community gave $2.5 million; Hungary $800,000; and the Netherlands, Austria and Canada $1.5 million total. Finland and Norway made smaller contributions. Any country may join the center by contributing money, but only Eastern European countries may join free of charge.

DOC.HEAD: Five Killed, 14 Wounded in Gunfire at SAfrican Railway Platform
Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with 14 injured in train shooting,
DOC.TEXT: comment by Mandela on police investigations, details of talks loyal to the African National Congress. The clashes have claimed more than 550 lives since Aug. 12. Also Thursday, the ANC and government officials met in Pretoria to discuss a no-violence pact, the status of ANC guerrillas and other issues. A radio station reported the groups would meet again Tuesday. No statements were issued after the meeting. The ANC formally suspended its 29-year guerrilla campaign Aug. 6. That improved prospects for negotiations on a new constitution to give blacks a voice in national affairs. But ANC leader Nelson Mandela and other groups have pressed for an independent probe into army involvement in the deaths of 11 people this week in Sebokeng. Mandela said Thursday investigations begun by the government would be a ``whitewash.'' Black leaders, including the South African Council of Churches and an Anglican group led by Archbishop Desmond Tutu, have accused soldiers of opening fire unneccesarily. Some black leaders have accused police of fueling the violence by siding with Inkatha. Police and the government deny the accusation. The Star newspaper reported Thursday that masked white men joined a group of blacks in attacking a Sebokeng migrant workers' hostel before dawn Tuesday. It said the attack killed 19 people and caused a crowd of township residents to gather at the hostel. Soldiers later opened fire. In March, police fired on protesters in Sebokeng, killing five and wounding 150. A special judicial review panel concluded the gunfire was unjustified. President F.W. de Klerk said Thursday the continuing unrest could hinder negotiations on black-white power sharing but that talks would continue. ``There can be no real reform before stability,'' the president said. The white-led government and the ANC, the main black opposition group, have been holding periodic talks since May. They met for 2{ hours on Thursday at police headquarters in Pretoria for talks that were expected to focus partly on the township fighting. No statements were issued after the meeting. News reports said the groups would meet again next week. Law and Order Minister Minister Adriaan Vlok led the government delegation. The ANC group was headed by Jacob Zuma, a member of its policy-making National Executive Committee. Only three of the seven ANC members appointed to meet with the government showed up. The man named to lead the ANC group, Chris Hani, was not present. He has been in the nominally independent Transkei homeland since the government dropped him from a list of ANC leaders granted temporary amnesty to participate in peace talks. Hani, leader of the ANC's armed wing, has said the ANC would seize power if talks with the government break down. De Klerk says he wants to end the apartheid system of racial segregation and negotiate a constitution with opposition groups. But he opposes black majority rule and a one-man, one-vote system. In Stockholm, Sweden, meanwhile, the fourth International Conference Against Apartheid in Sport ended Thursday with delegates urging a tightening of boycotts against South African athletes. Despite recent political changes in South Africa, the conference said relaxing the boycotts ``would seriously prejudice'' progress toward ending apartheid. Sports officials from South Africa and black African nations are scheduled to hold formal talks for the first time in Harare, Zimbabwe, Nov. 3-4. Officials from the International Olympic Committee will attend.

DOC.HEAD: Videotape Shows Killing of Victim Tied to Tree
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `Assistant State ..., to CLARIFY nature of cooperation and illegal activities. Note contents.
DOC.TEXT: An admitted murderer wouldn't watch a courtroom showing of a videotape that shows her firing four shots into her victim. Her ex-boyfriend testified Thursday she later bragged about the killing. The videotape was shown during a sentencing hearing for Deidre Hunt, 21. She has admitted shooting 19-year-old Mark Kevin Ramsey last Oct. 20 in woods west of Daytona Beach as part of a tangled murder-for-hire plot. Her former boyfriend, Newman Taylor, said she told friends she was trying to become a paid assassin and part of Kosta Fotopoulos' ``Hunter-Killer Club.'' ``She said `Do you know what it feels like to grab someone by the hair and blow their brains out? It feels good,' '' Taylor, 21, testified. Assistant State Attorney David Damore said Fotopoulos, 31, was trying to arrange the death of his wife, Lisa, in hopes of inheriting her money. He made the tape to ensure Miss Hunt's cooperation in finding a killer and to eliminate the youth as a possible witness in other illegal activities the men were involved in, Damore said. Prosecutors say she and Fotopoulos tied Ramsey to a tree and shot him. Miss Hunt said Ramsey's murder was videotaped by Fotopoulos. The state also says other witnesses told them Hunt bragged about the killing and showed off sneakers stained with Ramsey's blood. The videotape was viewed by a courtroom of spectators Wednesday. Miss Hunt turned away and plugged her ears with her fingers as the tape was shown. The videotape shows her pulling a silencer-equipped .22-caliber pistol from her waistband and checking it. She raises her arm and fires three times rapidly. Ramsey grunts as the first bullet hits him, then grunts again and raises his left leg in agony. He slumps forward, groans ``God.'' Miss Hunt then lifts Ramsey's head by the hair, places the gun against his temple and fires again. Ramsey collapses to the ground. The state was seeking the death penalty in the hearing before Circuit Judge S. James Foxman. The defense argued for the only alternative, a life sentence with no possible parole for 25 years. Miss Hunt also has pleaded guilty to the Nov. 4 killing of Brian Chase, 18. As part of the murder plot, he was to break into the Fotopoulos home and shoot Mrs. Fotopoulos as she slept. He did, but was then shot to death by Fotopoulos, who called police to report that he had killed an intruder who shot his wife, authorities said. Mrs. Fotopoulos survived and later filed for divorce. Fotopoulos faces trial on two murder counts for the deaths of Ramsey and Chase. During opening statements at the sentencing hearing, the defense said Miss Hunt was abused as a child, is an emotional cripple and can't appreciate the enormity of her actions.

DOC.HEAD: Angry French Farmers Seize, Slaughter 386 British Sheep
DOC.TEXT: Farmers angered by falling meat prices seized a truck Thursday carrying 386 British sheep, slaughtered the animals and left their carcasses outside a government building, officials said. It was one of the worst in a series of attacks in recent months by French cattle and sheep farmers who complain they cannot earn enough income because of foreign competition. The truck, which originated in Scotland, was intercepted early Thursday near Limoges, central France. The farmers killed the sheep at a slaughterhouse before dumping the carcasses in the streets and garden outside a local government office in Bellac. Security forces confronted some farmers, reportedly firing tear gas after being pelted with stones and eggs. No injuries or arrests were reported. During the night, about 100 farmers staged a protest in Chateau-Chinon, a central town where President Francois Mitterrand once served as mayor. They set bales of hay on fire and sprayed liquid manure at riot officers, police said. Farmers from southwestern France set loose 200 sheep Thursday in the streets of Nyons to protest falling prices, police said. The sheep had been stolen during the night from a truck. On Wednesday, farmers burned a truckload of meat near the Belgian border and forced two trucks in Normandy to stop until a veterinary inspection was conducted, British agriculture officials have complained about the lack of arrests of farmers involved in attacks on British meat trucks. France's agriculture minister, Henri Nallet, issued a communique Wednesday warning that offenders faced prosecutions.

DOC.HEAD: Trial of Eight Cuban Exiles Begins
DOC.TEXT: The trial of eight Cuban exiles accused of drug trafficking began Thursday in the eastern province of Camaguey, Cuba's government news agency Prensa Latina said. The eight are U.S. residents, the agency said, but did not provide hometowns. The government prosecutor asked the court for 10- to 20-year prison sentences for the six men and two women, the agency said in a dispatch monitored in Mexico. They are being tried in Camaguey, capital of the province 340 miles southeast of Havana, on charges of illegally entering the country, trafficking and possession of drugs and toxic substances, the agency reported. The group was arrested in the northern part of Camaguey province while picking up a drug shipment, according to Prensa Latina. It was not clear if they were on land or offshore.

DOC.HEAD: Union Says 10 NBC Layoffs Due to New Contract, Plans Boycott
DOC.TEXT: A union at NBC said 10 of its members were laid off because of a new contract NBC put into effect last month, so now it plans a boycott against NBC and sponsors of the network's shows. NBC denied the accusations of the National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians and characterized the threatened boycott as an effort to harass the network. The skirmish was the latest since NBC's Aug. 15 implementation of a new four-year contract that the union's members rejected twice. They struck NBC in 1987 in a bitter walkout lasting 17 weeks. No strike is imminent this time because the union says it has decided to employ what it calls ``the inside game'' _ keep its members on the job as its lawyers fight NBC's action in various ways. The 10 union members being laid off work at NBC-owned WMAQ-TV in Chicago include Mike Cunningham, a member of the union's negotiating committee and secretary of the union's local there, NABET spokesman John Krieger said. Kreiger, whose union says it represents more than 2,300 people in NBC's 5,800-member work force, attributed the layoffs to NBC's new contract. NBC spokesman Joe Rutledge said the 10 layoffs had been planned for late last year and early this year, but were delayed ``to assist with vacation relief needs during the summer.'' The layoffs ``have absolutely nothing to do with the new contract,'' he said. Asked if more layoffs are planned, he replied: ``Not to my knowledge.'' Krieger made public an Aug. 28 letter from NABET to Lane Kirkland, president of the AFL-CIO. The letter said a boycott against NBC is part of the union's strategy to fight the contract that the network put into effect. In addition to NBC, the boycott will be against the company's owner, General Electric, and sponsors who advertise on NBC-owned television stations and NBC's more than 200 affiliated stations, Krieger said.
