No date has been set, but the boycott ``will happen very shortly,'' he said. Rutledge responded that a boycott ``would certainly qualify as harassment. It's regrettable. . . . A boycott serves no one's interest and will gain NABET members absolutely nothing.'' Until the union ratifies the contract that NBC has put into effect, he added, members won't be eligible for the pay raises it provides.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Industry Forms $800 Million Corporation To Respond To Spills
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to CORRECT spelling of Port Hueneme.
DOC.TEXT: A new corporation backed by the oil industry will spend $800 million over the next five years on a nationwide system designed to clean up the worst oil spills, its president announced Thursday. The cost is three times the original estimate of a petroleum industry task force which set up the Marine Spill Response Corp. Corporation President John D. Costello said the increases were necessary to do the job. The company plans to construct five regional centers in areas where major oil spills are most likely to occur: the New York-New Jersey area; Port Everglades, Fla., north of Miami; Lake Charles, La., near the Texas border; Port Hueneme, Calif., north of Los Angeles, and Seattle, Wash. The worst spill in U.S. history occurred in Alaska on March 24, 1989. But Costello told a news conference the vastly improved spill response capability in Alaska is now greater than it will be at any of the corporation's regional centers. However, he said Marine Spill Response is negotiating to work out what role it might play in Alaska. The corporation is funded by dues from companies in the oil industry, including owners, shippers and purchasers of crude oil and petroleum products who have formed the Marine Preservation Association. Each pays according to the number of barrels handled. But if a company spills oil, it will have to pay for the cleanup, even if it is a dues-paying member of the association, Costello said. In addition to the regional centers, Marine Spill Response will have vessels at about nine other sites, ready for any spill along coastal areas of the Atlantic, Pacific or Gulf of Mexico or around Hawaii, the Virgin Islands or Puerto Rico, said Costello, a retired Coast Guard vice admiral. ``We're excited by the prospect of creating the world's largest, best-equipped and best-trained oil spill cleanup organization,'' he said. Each regional center will have the ability to handle a spill roughly as large as the record 11-million-gallon spill of crude oil from the Exxon Valdez in Alaska's Prince William Sound, he said. Regional centers can combine forces to handle even larger spills. The corporation expects to spend $315 million on initial equipment, including ships, trucks, booms, skimmers, dispersants and tools for dealing with wildlife and damaged shorelines. The company, with about 400 employees, will administer spill response but will contract most of the work out to scores of other companies, Costello said. He said it would supplement existing private and government cleanup operations. ``We don't want to replace anybody who's there, absolutely not. They're doing a fine job,'' he said. The company was set up to fulfill the terms of federal oil spill legislation signed by President Bush last month. The bill gives oil companies until February 1993 to show they can contain and clean up a worst-case oil spill. Costello said the new company would be fully operational by then and could provide some limited response even earlier. The oil spill law also increased the liability of shippers from a ceiling of $150 per gross ton of the tanker to $1,200 per gross ton. Costello said liability laws in some states should be changed to allow for a quick response to oil spills. He said that although his company would have no problem, because it is a non-profit corporation, its subcontractors might be inhibited. The company grew out of an American Petroleum Institute task force on oil spills which determined in June 1989 that neither the government nor the oil industry had the equipment or personnel ready to deal with a catastrophic spill. The new corporation will have its headquarters in Washington, but will be independent from the petroleum institute, with a board of directors made up of people outside the industry.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Extends Favored Trade Status To Czechoslovakia
DOC.TEXT: President Bush notified leaders of Congress Thursday that he is extending most favored nation trade status to newly democratic Czechoslovakia. The move, announced while Bush was on a political trip to Topeka, Kan., and Tallahassee, followed earlier presidential actions this year liberalizing trade relations with the former communist state.

DOC.HEAD: Plan To Deny Federal Benefits to Drug Convicts Draws Fire
DOC.TEXT: The federal government intends to test a new weapong in the fight against crime _ denying student loans, federally backed mortgages and other federal benefits to convicted drug users in Rhode Island. Gov. Edward D. DePrete hailed the plan Thursday as a sensible approach to the drug problem, but civil libertarians complained that it would be unfair. The head of a national prosecutors' group said violators would be losing only ``yuppie-type benefits.'' DiPrete announced that Rhode Island had been awarded a $150,000 Justice Department grant to set up a system for tracking drug convicts. A never-used, two-year-old federal law allows state and federal judges to bar drug convicts from receiving federal contracts and benefits that include farm subsidies and pilots' licenses. ``It's breaking new ground,'' DiPrete said at a Statehouse news conference. ``We feel the federal law makes sense. It's one tool in the arsenal and it's worth a try.'' But the American Civil Liberties Union, which fought the proposal when it was debated in Congress, denounced it as unnecessarily punitive. ``I can't see any beneficial purpose being served by denying individuals certain benefits simply because of the nature of the offense that happens to be the big political issue of the time,'' said Steven Brown, executive director of the ACLU's Rhode Island affiliate. Law-enforcement officials said they knew of no cases where the law had been used since it was passed in November 1988. People convicted for a first offense of felony drug trafficking could be ineligible for federal programs for five years. Benefits would be denied for 10 years on a second offense and for life on a subsequent conviction. Felony drug possession convictions could make someone ineligible for one year on a first offense and five years on subsequent convictions. The ACLU tried to have programs such as student loans and grants exempted, said Janlori Goldman, the ACLU's legislative counsel in Washington. ``Many student loans and grants are needs-based,'' she said. But the law specifically exempts only retirement, Social Security, health, disability, veterans' or public housing benefits. Richard Wintory, director of the National Drug Prosecution Center in Virginia, said the law still punishes people who might not get prison, but exempts those who would be harmed by losing federal benefits. ``The benefits that we're talking about ... are yuppie-type benefits, they are middle-class benefits, they are government freebies,'' Wintory said. ``Those are the people now that in the criminal justice system get off the lightest. These are the stockbrokers, lawyers, wealthy white kids.'' The law also bars judges from denying benefits if someone was addicted to drugs but had no treatment available or who had undergone treatment and overcome a drug dependency. ``It's a pretty milquetoast provision as it is,'' Wintory said.

DOC.HEAD: Former Union Boss Arrested in 1981 Killings of Anti-Marcos Activists
DOC.TEXT: A former union boss, whose gun was used to kill two anti-Marcos activists nine years ago, was charged with aggravated first-degree murder in the slayings, prosecutors said Thursday. Constantine ``Tony'' Baruso was president of the Alaska Cannery Workers Union when Gene Viernes and Silme Domingo were gunned down in the union offices on June 1, 1981. Baruso, 62, was arrested at his home in Tacoma late Wednesday on a warrant charging him with two murder counts, said King County Prosecutor Norm Maleng. Baruso was being held Thursday in the King County Jail on $500,000 bail. An arraignment hearing was scheduled Friday. Baruso's attorney, Anthony Savage, said his client would plead innocent. The charges arose out of new information that came to light during a recent civil lawsuit filed by the victims' relatives, Maleng said. Criminal charges initially were not filed against Baruso because of insufficient evidence, he said. ``I've always said that this was an open case and that we would be willing to look at any new evidence which might cast light on Baruso's involvement with these murders,'' Maleng said. Authorities identified Baruso's handgun as the murder weapon but said Baruso told them the weapon was stolen from him. Baruso was later convicted of embezzling money from the union. Prosecutors would attempt to establish that Baruso's involvement in the killings stemmed both from his interest in controlling the union and in halting Viernes' and Domingo's work to end gang-dominated gambling in Alaska fish canneries, Maleng said. Maleng also said prosecutors would try to show that Baruso conspired with then-Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos and Dr. Leonilo Malabed of San Francisco, a Marcos friend, to kill the two activists. Savage said Thursday he was surprised to hear of his client's arrest. ``I'm disappointed,'' Savage said. ``We'll do our best to fight it.'' Three men, members of a Filipino gang called Tulisan, were found guilty of murder at the original criminal trial. Prosecutors in that case argued the killings stemmed from an internal union dispute in which Domingo and Viernes worked to end the gambling in Alaska fish canneries. But in the civil lawsuit, family members contended the slayings were ordered from Manila because of Domingo's and Viernes' activism against Marcos' regime. A U.S. District Court jury last December awarded the families $15.1 million from the estate of Marcos, who died in Hawaii after he was ousted in a coup, and from his widow, Imelda. U.S. District Judge Barbara Rothstein later found Baruso and Malabed liable for an additional $8.4 million. Family members expressed joy Thursday at Maleng's decision to file murder charges. ``I knew that whether it took 10 to 20 years, someday he (Baruso) would pay for these murders,'' said Cindy Domingo, Domingo's sister. Joining her at a press conference was Domingo's widow, Terri Mast, and their attorney, Michael Withey. ``We're convinced that the evidence against Baruso is overwhelming,'' Withey said. Aggravated first-degree murder is the only crime in Washington that carries the possibility of the death penalty. If prosecutors decide not to seek death, the only alternative upon conviction would be life in prison without parole.

DOC.HEAD: Foreigners Warned Not to Try Escaping; Soviets Favor U.N. Force
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with U.S. lodging protest in shooting of American in Kuwait, SUB 9th graf pvs with 2 grafs; pickup 10th graf pvs, `Washington and...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LON9
DOC.TEXT: Iraq tightened the screws on trapped Westerners on Thursday, warning that anyone trying to leave without permission could face life in prison. The Soviet Union raised the possibility of Kremlin support for sending a U.N. military force to the Persian Gulf. Saudi Arabia committed several billion dollars toward defraying the enormous cost of the U.S. forces protecting the kingdom's oil fields from possible Iraqi aggression, U.S. and Saudi officials announced. U.S. officials said the Saudis would, at a minimum, pick up all fuel, water and transportation costs for the 60,000 American troops now in Saudi Arabia. Earlier this week, Secretary of State James Baker III told Congress the U.S. presence would cost about $6 billion by year's end. Both U.S. and Saudi officials declined to provide a specific price tag for the commitment. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher pledged more forces to bolster the U.S. contingent in the gulf. She did not elaborate on the deployment plans. Egypt, too, said it was beefing up its small gulf contingent. At the United Nations, diplomats said U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar planned to send an envoy to occupied Kuwait to meet with diplomats whose embassies are surrounded by Iraqi troops, and with trapped foreigners. Baghdad would have to give its consent for the visit. The State Department again blasted Iraq for its treatment of foreign nationals, including the shooting of an American in Kuwait who was trying to avoid capture. Department spokesman Mark Dillen called Iraq's behavior ``outrageous'' and the deparment summoned the Iraqi ambassador to the United States, Mohamed al-Mashat, to lodge a formal protest. Al-Mashat later called the incident ``unfortunate.'' He told reporters the man had been ``slightly injured'' because ``he violated the curfew and not because he was picked up as an American.'' Washington and Moscow, meanwhile, scrambled to prepare for the weekend superpower summit they hope will bring a break in the nearly 5-week-old crisis. President Bush said the United States was determined to force Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to withdraw from Kuwait, which Iraqi troops overran Aug. 2 in a dispute over land, money and oil. ``We will not stand by while one country devours another unthreatening country whole,'' Bush said at a Kansas fund-raiser. ``Our cause may not be easy, but it will always be right.'' In a surprise move, Bush said he would make a statement for broadcast to the Iraqi people, saying he saw ``a real opportunity'' to explain the U.S. view. Baghdad had offered to broadcast an interview with Bush, but the White House said the president would tape a statement instead. Statements by the Iraqi president _ which White House wags call ``Saddamathons'' _ have received ample air time in the United States, and the Bush administration was reportedly irritated about this. Word that Moscow might support a U.N. military force in the gulf came from Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov. He indicated Mikhail S. Gorbachev may discuss the idea with Bush at their summit Sunday in Helsinki, Finland. Previously, the Soviets had said only that they might participate if the United Nations decided to deploy a military force. ``We have to go back to the U.N. charter and revive certain clauses of this charter ... which may have armed forces _ international armed forces _ at its disposal so as to keep international peace and security,'' Gerasimov told reporters. Gerasimov spoke a day after Iraq's foreign minister, Tariq Aziz, met with Gorbachev and displayed no softening in Iraq's refusal to leave Kuwait. Moscow and Baghdad were longtime allies, but Gorbachev has condemned the Kuwait invasion as ``treachery.'' Expenses escalate daily for the U.S. military deployment, and Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady arrived Thursday in Seoul, South Korea, the latest stop on a tour to press allies for funds. Secretary of State James A. Baker III was making the same pitch in Saudi Arabia, where much of the U.S. force is deployed. In Iraq, the outlook grew grimmer for trapped foreigners. Baghdad said those caught trying to leave without permission could face life in prison. Justice Minister Akram Abdul-Kader said authorities were reviving a 1987 law that ``a foreigner violating the entry and exit procedures ... will be sentenced to life or temporary imprisonment, and all cash in his possession will be confiscated.'' The State Department said Iraqi authorities had informed U.S. officials that an American shot by Iraqi police in Kuwait was expected to be discharged from a hospital shortly but will remain in Iraqi custody. The department spokesman, Dillen, said the American was wounded while attempting to evade capture at his apartment in Kuwait City. ``We hold the Iraqi government responsible for the health and welfare of all American citizens held against their will in Kuwait and Iraq,'' Dillen said. Westerners were continuing to make their way out of Iraq and Kuwait, under Saddam's promise to free foreign women and children. Western men are being held as human shields to protect Iraqi installations. An Air France jet flew into Paris from Jordan on Thursday carrying 153 Westerners allowed to leave Iraq, including at least nine Americans. A Canadian-chartered Iraqi plane carrying 157 people, most of them Canadians, was headed for Toronto after leaving Iraq and Kuwait and letting off five people during a stopover in Turkey. A dozen Americans were among the passengers. The State Department also said it expected a U.S.-chartered Iraqi Airways flight would leave Baghdad on Friday. A British Airways charter took off from Amman for London early Friday carrying 250 British women and children refugees from Kuwait, happy to be free but expressing fears for husbands left behind. They arrived Thursday in Jordan on two Iraqi Airways charter flights from Baghdad. A British convoy arrived in Baghdad from Kuwait on Thursday with 182 women and children. British diplomats in Baghdad said a second convoy, including nine Americans, had also left Kuwait. Asians and Arabs were having an easier time than Westerners at getting Iraqi permission to leave, but a much more difficult time getting home. More than 100,000 Asian refugees are stuck in Jordan, lacking transportation to get them back home. Meanwhile, there were signs the international unity against Baghdad might be cracking. China and Iran suggested that food and medicine should be sent to Iraq despite the U.N. economic sanctions. Chinese Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Li Jinhua said Thursday the U.N. embargo ``does not include supplies intended strictly for medical purposes and foodstuffs for humanitarian purposes.'' Iran's President Hashemi Rafsanjani said last month that Iran would abide by the embargo, but the English-language Tehran Times, which is close to Rafsanjani, said in an editorial Thursday that providing food and medicine was a ``humanitarian question.'' In other developments: _Arab diplomats in Baghdad said King Hussein of Jordan might fly to Moscow for talks with Gorbachev in advance of the Helsinki summit. The Jordanian monarch returned home Thursday after two days of talks with Saddam. _Oil prices soared over $31 a barrel Thursday, reaching that plateau for the second time since the Persian Gulf crisis as traders bet that supply shortages will develop. _The stock market took a sharp dive in the face of rising oil prices, with the Dow Jones industrial average falling 31.93 points to 2,596.29.

DOC.HEAD: Ousted Party Chief Seen in Public for First Time in Over Year
DOC.TEXT: Ousted Communist Party chief Zhao Ziyang was seen in public for the first time in about 16 months, playing golf with his wife, Japanese diplomats said Thursday. The sighting was the first since May 1989, when Zhao made a tearful visit to students demonstrating for democracy in Tiananmen Square. A month later, after the violent June 3-4 military crackdown, Zhao was stripped of all his posts. He was accused of ``splitting the party'' by supporting the popular pro-democracy movement, which officially is referred to as a ``counter-revolutionary rebellion.'' The diplomats said Zhao and his wife played golf for about two hours Tuesday at a course near the Ming Tombs, a popular tourist stop about an hour's drive north of Beijing. They said Zhao, whose hair had thinned and turned gray, was guarded by about 10 security personnel. The diplomats were entertaining Japanese visitors when they saw Zhao's entourage, the Japanese Embassy said.

The 15 chiefs of U.S. corporations going to the Soviet Union this weekend with Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher plan to offer American know-how on such fundamental items as efficient housing and transporting goods. ``It's kind of back to the basics ... You walk up a stairway in a Soviet building and none of the steps are the same. They can't even finish a floor flat, things you and I take for granted,'' said Mark Hungerford, chairman and chief executive officer of Tanscisco Industries Inc. of San Francisco, a rail car company. ``They can get rockets to the moon, so it's not like they're incapable, but they've never focused on these things before,'' Hungerford said. He is one of 15 chief executive officers of U.S. companies scheduled to leave for Moscow on Saturday for a week-long visit to discuss what kind of ``technical assistance'' the United States can give the Soviet Union.

NASA engineers, embarrassed again by a space shuttle that can't fly, set off anew today on a hunt through a tangle of pipes for an elusive fuel leak that grounded Columbia for a third time. ``It is a real booger to try to find and isolate,'' shuttle boss Robert Crippen said after the mission was scrubbed Wednesday, 7{ hours before Columbia was to have lifted off at 1:20 a.m. today with the $150 million Astro observatory. Engineers worked on a troubleshooting plan through the night, but Crippen said that even if the hole were found immediately, Columbia could not leave on its long astronomy mission for at least three or four days and probably longer. The launch would have been the 36th shuttle flight and the first in four months after a summer of similar leaks for NASA. That is the longest gap between missions since flights resumed following the Challenger disaster.

Most Americans would flunk a test of basic knowledge about sex, says a new survey that's old news to sex experts. Fifty-five percent of people surveyed could not get at least 10 of the 18 questions right in the test, designed by the Kinsey Institute. Half didn't know that a woman can become pregnant while having her period, the report said. Half also did not know that some lubricants, like petroleum jelly, shouldn't be used with condoms or diaphragms. Petroleum jelly weakens rubber. Half the respondents incorrectly believed anal intercourse itself can cause AIDS, even if neither partner is infected by the virus; only 30 percent knew that menopause doesn't cause most women to lose interest in sex; and only 35 percent knew that problems with achieving erections usually are physical and can be treated.

White House and congressional budget negotiators have agreed on almost nothing during three contentious months of bargaining. And now that they are about to resume discussions, Saddam Hussein has made the job even harder. Iraq's conquest of oil-rich Kuwait has meant higher fuel costs, and that has threatened to further slow the already sputtering U.S. economy. Dispatching American troops to Saudi Arabia has driven up Pentagon spending. Those changed economic and political circumstances will complicate efforts to shrink the federal deficit when administration officials and congressional leaders resume budget talks on Friday. In preparation, House Democrats and Republicans held separate budget sessions Wednesday and planned additional sessions today.

In a major turnaround in Colombia's anti-drug strategy, President Cesar Gaviria has announced that cocaine traffickers who surrender will not be extradited to the United States. The new president said his decree Wednesday is part of a plan to end drug-related terrorism. A year-old war between the government and traffickers fighting extradition has left hundreds of people dead. ``Those who have been in crime and who have repented, and who voluntarily turn themselves in to judges in order to freely confess their crimes may be tried by our judges based on our judicial order,'' Gaviria said in a nationally televised speech Wednesday night. In July, the Medellin cocaine cartel declared a unilateral cease-fire in its terrorist attacks, apparently hoping that the new administration would end extraditions.

DOC.HEAD: Physician Incomes On the Rise, Survey Says
DOC.TEXT: The median net income of office-based physicians rose 12.8 percent last year to $132,500, and the credit may go to the doctors themselves. They are becoming better businessmen. A survey by the magazine Medical Economics found the 1989 median income rose $14,770, the biggest dollar increase in the 61 years the survey has been conducted by the financial publication for physicians. The article describing the study suggested higher incomes resulted more from better business practices, especially more efficient bill collection, than from a larger number of patient visits or higher fees. It points out, in fact, that while median gross receipts rose sharply, much of the revenue ``was gobbled up by a 19.8 percent rise in professional expenses _ the steepest such increase of the decade.'' Nevertheless, the higher incomes could provoke controversy because they come at a time when business, insurers, patients, federal officials and the medical profession itself are seeking to hold down steadily rising costs. The article points out that while the typical doctor ``had lost six of his nine most recent yearly skirmishes with inflation, 1989 put him comfortably ahead for the decade.'' While the Consumer Price Index rose 64.4 percent from December 1979 to December 1989, the article states that ``doctors cumulative annual earnings growth for the period topped that figure by 8.4 percentage points.'' However, doctors in family or general practice earned considerably less than the median, with the former grossing $211,540 and netting $97,340, and the latter grossing $170,423 and netting $86,860. The study was based on questionnaires mailed in January to 31,976 medical doctors in private, office-based practice. By the mid-May cutoff date, 9,762 responses had been trimmed to a working sample of 6,484 questionnaires. The magazine stated that the survey was representative in terms of physicians' field of practice, region and age, and therefore ``likely to be representative in other ways as well.'' The responses showed cardiovascular surgeons as the highest paid of all medical doctors, with a gross income of $493,750 and a net of $296,300, followed by neurosurgeons at $455,560 and $256,600, respectively. Orthopedic surgeons, plastic surgeons and ophthalmologists followed, all with net incomes exceeding $200,000. Obstetric and gynecological specialists, thoracic surgeons, anesthesiologists and ear-nose-throat specialists followed at just under $200,000. Among other specialties, general surgeons were said to have netted a median of $143,130, internists $110,500, psychiatrists $103,570 and pediatricians $101,800. The highest median net for medical doctors in general was found in the South Atlantic states, at $143,500, in the Mid-South at $143,300 and in the Far West, including Alaska and Hawaii, at $135,420. In order below them were the Southwest states at $132,500; the Mideast states of New York, Pennsylvania and New Jersey at $131,790; the Great Lakes region at $125,830; New England at $125,000; and the Great Plains at $123,750. The survey found the highest gross and net incomes in Florida, at $282,500 and $157,950 respectively, representing a one-year increase of $34,820, or 28.3 percent. In his commentary, Medical Economics editor Don Berg stated that ``this year could well be the last one of really big increases'' before Medicare caps and other restrictions begin.

DOC.HEAD: Plugging in on Stage: The Other World Of Trip Shakespeare
DOC.TEXT: Trip Shakespeare has been living on the road for three years. The van rides are long, the hotels look the same but business hassles are left to others. It doesn't feel bad compared to what the Minnesota-based band was doing before, holding onto part-time jobs and making the rounds at the local clubs. No one's longing for that way of life. Trip Shakespeare is happiest on stage, when they can open up to each other, learn a few things about themselves and create a world a little prettier than the one they come down to once the instruments are unplugged. ``That is almost the ultimate goal for us making music,'' explained bassist John Munson. ``That's something we want to do in performance, create a different world, a place where everyone can be, where the audience can be, forget the drudging pains of life and bill collection and so on.'' Fitting for a band that numbers Dr. Seuss and Rocky and Bullwinkle among its influences, Trip Shakespeare includes plenty of fractured fairy tales on ``Across the Universe,'' their first album on a major label, A&M Records. ``The Slacks'' is a naughty dance song about a one-eyed lady from France with a fatal weakness for magic trousers. There's also ``Snow Days,'' a call from indoors to poor Mrs. Braintree, a Minnesota schoolteacher and chilly northern woman stranded in a winter blizzard, and ``Pearle,'' whose lovely heroine meets her fate along the gullies by Deegan Curve. The love songs are open and painful, with no trace of bitterness or hardened acceptance of loss, only a childlike grief over something so natural being taken away. Just listen to the ballad ``Drummer Like Me,'' when the singer slips into a gentle falsetto on ``Oh listen, some drummers have shaky time,'' his voice full of doubt and fear. ``A lot of people that come to see us are pretty wide-eyed, there's not a lot of cynicism,'' Munson insisted. ``Because we jam a lot, do it differently every time, there has to be a level of trust between the band and audience. And the audience is of all different sizes, shapes and colors. They're open to what we're saying.'' ``One thing that the songs have in common is they are works of the imagination,'' added guitarist-pianist Dan Wilson, who spoke of ``Honey Tree,'' another ballad. ``The honey tree is someplace beyond this world. The garden where that romance takes place is other-earthly. It's real, in the same way that a dream is real.'' Trip Shakespeare formed in Minneapolis in late 1986 as a trio, the members including Matt Wilson, Dan's brother and who also writes all the lyrics, Munson, and drummer Elaine Harris. Dan Wilson joined a year later. There are no rap songs or exotic drugs or summer arts festivals called Trip Shakespeare. The band members simply made up the name one night and liked the sound of it, literary and humorous at the same time. They released a pair of albums, ``Applehead Man'' and ``Are You Shakespearienced?,'' on independent labels before signing with A&M. The sound is, appropriately, not quite of this world, a combination of garage bands, folk harmonies and oldies albums sold on late-night television. ``Somebody came up to us and said, `I know, the Left Banke and Jeff Beck,' '' Munson recalled. ``And then someone will come up and say the Zombies and Mott the Hoople, or, `You guys sound like a cross between Peter, Paul and Mary and Led Zeppelin.' ``A lot of things about the band just sort of developed organically. We never sat down and said, `Let's cop a folk sound,' or `Let's get on that alternative music jag.' '' Records are made with live shows in mind and it works in the other direction. The same way movie studios preview films to test audience reaction, Trip Shakespeare experiments with its material on stage, bending notes to the roar of the crowd. ``The road I travel is not divine,'' they sing on ``Turtledove.'' The routine these days is pretty simple: hit town, set up the equipment and play, try to give the audience and themselves and a world of honey trees in the sky and blessings on the ground. ``About a year after Dan joined the band, we were in Iowa City playing to about 250 people in a small room,'' Dan Wilson said. ``We took one song and wrestled with it on stage. ``We stretched it, pulled it at its edges, and ran off on tangents for 25 minutes, just exploring the contours of the song with each member taking off in different directions. That was a moment when we realized something special was happening.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PM Tues Sept. 11

DOC.HEAD: Filmmaking Brothers Go for the Action _ and Focus
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: You want action? Send for the Norris brothers, Chuck and Aaron. Chuck we know about. He's the nimble-footed, stolid-faced destroyer of evil. Aaron is his younger brother, a former stuntman, now director of Chuck's films, including the current ``Delta Force 2.'' They recently got together at MGM for a discussion on how they work together. ``Aaron's first film as director was `Braddock: Missing in Action 3.' But Aaron had worked with me for 12 years as stunt coordinator on my films,'' Chuck said. ``I'd seen him as a second-unit director. As I watched him, I said, `This guy has a tremendous amount of creative talent; he's very focused. If he ever gets the opportunity to direct, I think he'll do exceptionally well.' '' The opportunity came when the director of ``Braddock'' quit. The producer rejected Chuck's suggestion of his brother as director. Because of lack of preparation, the substitute director ``got lost'' during the Philippines locations. Aaron to the rescue. ``One thing about Chuck is: He has focus. He knows where his character is and where he should be at that given scene. It's a great quality,'' Aaron said. ``We collaborate as a team, because one man never runs an entire movie. The director has the focus of the entire film, but he listens to everyone around him. That's why you hire all these talented people.'' What happens when they disagree? Chuck recalled a scene in ``Delta Force 2'' for which Aaron's instructions ran counter to Chuck's instincts. The director suggested shooting the scene two ways, deciding later which one was right. ``We looked at the dailies the next day, and he was right,'' Chuck laughed. ``I never questioned him after that.'' Any chance of sibling rivalry affecting their work together? Chuck commented: ``Aaron's a lot younger than me. When we were growing up, our mother had to work so I baby-sat Aaron. I must have spanked him a few times, because now he's paying me back.'' ``That's the beauty of this whole thing,'' added Aaron with a laugh. ``For anyone who has had an older brother, this is a chance to get back at him for all that stuff he gave me when I was young. I put him through his paces on `Delta Force 2.' '' Indeed, Chuck Norris does some of his most perilous stunts, including the scaling of a 12,000-foot peak and leaping out of an airplane. ``But there's a limit,'' Aaron said. ``I came up through the stunt community. I understand where that limit is. But he's real game. I get him in tight places, but you go first and foremost for safety. The last thing I ever want to do is hurt anybody.'' For ``Delta Force 2,'' the Norris brothers returned to the Philippines, which doubles for Colombia, where Chuck is warring against the biggest drug lord of all. Will they become a permanent team? ``I would like for it to be, whether Aaron directs or produces,'' answered Chuck. ``If it works out that way, we'll be a team in whatever the capacities may be. We work well together.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PM Wed Sept. 12

For release Friday PMs, Sept. 7, and thereafter ^Sunken Treasure Surfaces on Cable Special
DOC.TEXT: There's something reassuring about watching a televised treasure hunt on the bottom of the sea. In this type of reality TV, there are no killings or threats of gasoline shortages, no naval blockades or smiling dictators stroking a captive child. There are just lovely dreams of gold. That's not to say it's easy finding, let alone digging up, sunken treasure a mile and a half below the waves. The two-hour ``Treasures of a Lost Voyage,'' airing Sunday night on cable's Discovery Channel, demonstrates why. The long-lost ship, S.S. Central America, had to be pinpointed under thousands of square miles of ocean off the South Carolina coast. The recovery crew then had to endure unpredictable weather, temperamental, space-age retrieval equipment, and costly legal fights with other searchers and a host of insurance companies over who actually owns the estimated 3 tons of gold nuggets, assay bars and coins that sank with the ship in 1857. ``It's a battle of man against nature. It's also a battle of man against machines,'' said Barry Schatz, one of three project directors for the Ohio group of investors and scientists that located the wreck site in June 1986. Schatz also could have said lawyer against lawyer. It took four years and precedent-setting court rulings in a Norfolk, Va., federal court for his Columbus America Discovery Group to establish the legal right to a treasure that could be worth $1 billion at auction. While the court battle dragged on, Columbus America's innovative 6-ton robot retriever-camera vehicle, Nemo, quietly plied the wreckage, bringing up more than 2,000 pieces of gold bars and coins through last summer. Experts believe that represents about a third of the gold that weighed down the steam sidewheeler Central America when it foundered in a hurricane in September 1857 while en route from Panama to New York. It will take this and another summer-fall salvage season, at least, for Nemo to collect the most-accessible artifacts from an area the size of a football field, Schatz said. The ship, which carried 500 passengers and freight from the California gold fields, took three days to sink as passengers and crew bailed in vain. Four hundred twenty-five people died, with some of the survivors telling of desperate passengers jumping overboard fatally weighted down with gold. The Discovery program combines documentary footage of the gold rush era with footage from the exciting 1986 discovery, along with satellite-delivered views from the recovery vessel Arctic Discoverer to update the progress of current salvage efforts. Nemo's cameras reveal startling images of piles and ``waterfalls'' of gold coins, bars and other artifacts. The views are carried by wire up to a computer-crammed control room on the recovery vessel. There, far from the crushing pressures and dark cold of the wreck site, scientists under the direction of geologist-historian Bob Evans control retrieval and research. It is increasingly common for TV cameras to accompany adventurers or journalists _ even diplomats _ into the heat of the action, but in this case, television actually helped make the event happen. The Columbus America group, in what Schatz said was a first, established its right to bring up the gold by ``possessing'' the site through TV images, rather than actually laying hands on the booty through manned diving. ``We were able to exert a presence and take possession as if we were actually physically there,'' Schatz said, calling the new legal doctrine ``telepresence'' or ``telepossession.'' ``This will have very important applications for outerspace law,'' he said. The search for the S.S. Central America, begun by Columbus America founder Thomas Thompson, was motivated by gold, but scientists realized the search would afford a unique opportunity to study the ocean-bottom environment. ``The shipwreck is a biological oasis,'' Schatz said. ``It has attracted an incredible diversity of deep sea life.'' Three as yet unidentified species of life have been retrieved, as well as a type of sponge that may prove useful in fighting arthritis, he said. These unexpected spinoffs are icing on the cake for an already spectacularly successful salvage effort. ``The investors said `Hey, let's find gold,' '' Schatz said. ``But they're really proud to be part of this other activity as well.''

Elsewhere in television ... DONAHUE EXAMINES DEATH IN GAINESVILLE: The syndicated ``Donahue'' series is scheduled to do today's show from Gainesville, Fla., with its topic the slayings of five college students there. Donahue's special one-hour show will include city officials, students, residents and an expert on serial killers, a ``Donahue'' spokeswoman says. Afterwards, the star will hold what the show calls an ``informal press conference.''

DOC.HEAD: London Fall Theater: Politics, Joan Collins and the Redgrave Family
DOC.TEXT: Current affairs dominate the new plays, and Joan Collins and the Redgrave family are lending stardust to the revivals as the London stage prepares a typically busy fall season. Collins returns to the stage Sept. 19 to play the barbed divorcee Amanda in Noel Coward's ``Private Lives.'' Co-starring Keith Baxter, the play will run at the Aldwych Theater through Jan. 12, 1991. The stylish 1930 comedy marks the actress's first West End appearance since ``The Last of Mrs. Cheyney'' in 1980. Collins is more widely known as the elegantly bitchy Alexis on TV's ``Dynasty,'' but her theatrical roots date back to the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art (RADA), which she attended in the 1950s. In 1958, Vanessa Redgrave graduated from RADA's rival, the Central School of Speech and Drama, and is among the world's most acclaimed actresses. In December, at a theater to be announced, she joins sister Lynn and Jemma Redgrave, daughter of her actor brother, Corin, in Anton Chekhov's ``Three Sisters.'' Jemma replaces Vanessa's daughter, Joely Richardson in the role of the youngest sister, Irina. The production, which runs Dec. 5-March 2 at the Queen's Theater, follows this summer's production of ``Three Sisters,'' starring three Irish thespian sisters: Sorcha, Sinead and Niamh Cusack. That production, which ends Sept. 29, has been a sellout in both Dublin and London. ``Three Sisters'' is Redgrave's first stage role since her controversial Broadway performance last fall in a revival of Tennessee Williams' ``Orpheus Descending.'' ``Love Letters,'' A.R. Gurney's two-character American play about a lifelong epistolary relationship, has its West End debut at Wyndham's Theater on Oct. 1. Robert Wagner and Stephanie Powers, co-stars of the TV series ``Hart To Hart,'' will play the leads for one month, with other stars expected to follow if it is a hit. But mostly, the season's new plays are heavy on politics and reflect recent headlines. The Royal Shakespeare Company's London season is focused on ``Moscow Gold,'' Tariq Ali and Howard Brenton's play about the era of glasnost and perestroika under Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev. David Calder portrays Gorbachev and Sara Kestelman is his wife, Raisa. They head a cast of 33 playing 102 parts. Mrs. Gorbachev has not yet replied to an invitation to attend the premiere Sept. 26 at the Barbican Theater. On Oct. 10, the Royal Court Theater opens Caryl Churchill's ``Mad Forest,'' an impressionistic look at Romania after Nicolae Ceausescu's execution last December. First performed in June with student actors at the Central School, the play was inspired by Churchill's visit to the country last spring. Before opening here, ``Mad Forest'' will be performed in Bucharest at the invitation of Andrei Serban, the new artistic director of the city's National Theater. England's Royal National Theater comes to life with David Edgar's ``The Shape of the Table,'' scheduled to open Nov. 8, the day before the first anniversary of the crumbling of the Berlin Wall. The play, about recent events in the Eastern bloc, uses the tables at which new governments were negotiated as a metaphor for the governments themselves. Edgar was the adaptor of ``The Life and Adventures of Nicholas Nickleby,'' the Charles Dickens extravaganza that won the 1980 Tony award for best play. Sir Michael Hordern, 78, plays a retired schoolmaster in Keith Waterhouse's ``Bookends,'' opening the week of Oct. 22 at a theater to be announced. The show, directed by Ned Sherrin, co-stars Dinsdale Landen as Hordern's former star pupil. It comes from the author, director and producer whose hit, ``Jeffrey Bernard Is Unwell,'' is in its 11th month on the West End. American drama will be represented by Jerry Sterner's off-Broadway hit ``Other People's Money,'' opening Oct. 17 at the Lyric. Martin Shaw plays the Wall Street shark originated in New York by Kevin Conway. Maria Aitken, who was John Cleese's wife in ``A Fish Called Wanda,'' co-stars. Virtually the only big new musical is ``Into the Woods,'' the London premiere of Stephen Sondheim and James Lapine's 1987 Broadway show about fairy tales. The production, opening Sept. 25 at the Phoenix, promises to be more stylized and less lighthearted than its Broadway predecessor. Under Richard Jones' direction, Julia McKenzie stars as the Witch, and Imelda Staunton is the Baker's Wife. Otherwise, London continues to host such hardy musical perennials as ``Cats,'' ``Les Miserables,'' ``Aspects of Love,'' ``The Phantom of the Opera,'' ``Me and My Girl'' and ``Miss Saigon.''

DOC.HEAD: With AM-AP Arts: London Theater
Broadway Hit Musical Readies for British Bow
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: ``Into the Woods,'' Stephen Sondheim's Broadway musical fairy tale, takes on a grimmer look in London, with blood-streaked walls and a moon that crashes down in the second act. ``It's a steady descent into bleakness and blackness,'' said Julia McKenzie, who plays the witch in the 1987 Sondheim-James Lapine musical opening Sept. 25 at London's Phoenix Theater. The show, budgeted at 1.2 million pounds ($2.23 million), is directed by Richard Jones and designed by Richard Hudson, a team who have been working jointly in opera and the subsidized theater for the past decade. ``Into the Woods'' is the second Sondheim musical to receive a major British production this year. His 1984 ``Sunday in the Park With George'' finished a 15-week run June 16 at the Royal National Theater. ``Into the Woods'' won three Tony awards including one for Sondheim's score, but some critics saw it as a schizophrenic work whose halves never quite meshed. The first act sends such fairy tale characters as Little Red Riding Hood and Cinderella ``into the woods,'' where all end up living happily ever after, their wishes fulfilled. In Act 2, their happiness proves short-lived. A marauding giant emerges in the woods, bringing death and devastation and belatedly teaching the characters the importance of responsibility and companionship. McKenzie, inheriting Bernadette Peters' Broadway role, said this new production would differ greatly from its predecessor. For a start, the British cast can use its own accents, because the show is set in no particular country. ``It's going to be very much one piece here,'' she said. ``It won't look as pretty (as in New York); therefore, you'll be more prepared for the ending.'' This is McKenzie's fourth Sondheim musical in London following ``Company,'' ``Side by Side by Sondheim,'' and ``Follies.'' Sondheim is writing a song for her ``Into the Woods'' role that wasn't in the long-running New York version. Designer Richard Hudson said he based his sets on extravagant drawings from Victorian children's books, German fairy tales culled from London's Goethe Institute and the 19th-century French illustrator, Gustave Dore. ``It's a question of finding the right balance,'' he said. ``I'm quite keen to make the show nastier. It's entertaining and delightful, but there are moments where you go, `Oh my God.' '' Accordingly, the wallpaper of Act 1 will be seen peeling in Act 2; the benign moon hovering over the set will crash to the ground; and when the wolf kills the grandmother, the walls will be streaked with blood. ``It's been very, very meticulously worked out,'' said Hudson, explaining that the tone should be ``kind of pessimistic.'' Director Richard Jones wanted it to rain on stage at the end, but they decided against that,'' Hudson said. ``The irony is that these characters all talk about `happy ever after' but their lives are not that brilliant.'' The show walks ``a very, very fine line between shock horror and laughter that is near hysteria,'' said McKenzie.

DOC.HEAD: Pontiac Firebird Formula: Muscle Is Back
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto,Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Climb inside the 1991 Pontiac Firebird Formula and you'd swear it was 1967 all over again. Just like during the muscle car era, there's no slinking quietly around the streets. The throaty rumble of the 1991 Firbird's V-8 engine just emanates from below _ even at idle. Inside are all the trappings of a traditional American sports car: low, body-hugging cloth seats, rear legroom that's miniscule, and that big hump in the middle of the floor that indicates the car is rear-drive, as always. Sure, the front and rear fascias have been restyled for the new model. But all they succeed in doing is giving even more sporty flair to the car than the previous model had, and a new rear spoiler adds to the ``look-at-me'' Firebird package. Some things never change. Horsepower, image and flair were hallmarks of the earliest Firebird. They remain today. The test car, a bright, speeding-ticket-red Firebird Formula, had me fighting butterflies in my stomach when I punched the accelerator and felt the car surge forward. There was no waiting as the optional, tuned-port fuel-injected, 5-liter engine mated to five-speed manual transmission responded, capable of delivering 225 horsepower. Suspension was stiff, offering good handling but a rough ride over harsh bumps. But I wasn't on the bumps for long. This car just flew over them. Fuel economy was as expected, a bit low at just 16 miles per gallon in city driving. I had to get used to looking over the air dam on the front hood. It is positioned right in front of the driver, and with my 5-foot-4 stature, I had to sit up straight and peer over the dam. I also had to get used to the long, heavy doors. They took a big heave to shove open. And there wasn't a lot of space in the rear hatch area. Still, no one can really expect great storage space in a sports car. Besides power and handling, the sound system and ambience are important. In the Firebird, the premium sound system with graphic equalizer, a $150 option, was superb; and the smallish, thick steering wheel seemed a perfect fit. The dashboard design harkened back to the 1960s, when the top shelf of the dashboard jutted way in toward passengers. In the 1991 Firebird, there was about a 3-inch overhang where the top of the dash came over and stuck out above the wide array of large, traditional, analog gauges. Typical buyers of the Firebird Formula are men (70 percent) who are single, said company spokesman Reg Harris. Two-thirds are under age 35, and between 30 percent and 40 percent have college degrees, he said. The Firebird in all its models, the standard Firebird, Firebird Formula, Firebird Trans Am and Firebird Trans Am GTA, sells particularly well on the West Coast and in the Carolinas and the Southeast, he added. It is interesting to note that more than two-thirds of Firebird purchasers are first-time new-car buyers. Harris said they tend to fall into one of two categories. The first group is people who put great emphasis on the ``look'' of their car, they want the ``car of their dreams.'' They are not necessarily car enthusiasts, but they do want their car to give them a certain, powerful image, he said. The second group is people who like domestic cars, who are ``traditional car'' fans. Harris said these people can be conservative in accepting new automotive technology and want a vehicle that's tried and true. They certainly get it with the Firebird. Introduced in February 1967, the Firebird has racked up sales of more than 2.2 million over the last 23 years. The best model year was 1978, when 175,607 were sold, according to Pontiac. In recent years, sales have hovered around 50,000-60,000. For 1991, the company looks for sales between 50,000 and 55,000. Prices range from $11,985 for the standard Firebird to more than $23,400 for the top-of-the-line GTA. Competitors include the Ford Mustang, which has a 5-liter engine model that starts around $12,100, the Eagle Talon, which starts around $13,000, and the Toyota Supra, which starts at more than $22,800. Consumer Reports says 1983-87 Firebird V-8s were much worse than average in owner complaints of trouble, and the 1988 model was worse than average. Harris said the company has made many improvements to bolster quality.

DOC.HEAD: Harkin Battles History and Republicans in Senate Race
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Freshman U.S. Sen. Tom Harkin is battling history in his bid to defeat Republican challenger and congressman Tom Tauke. Iowa voters never have given a Democratic U.S. senator another term in office and Tauke is doing his best to ensure that Harkin doesn't become the first. The two men are waging the most expensive political fight in Iowa history. Harkin plans to spend $6 million, and Tauke, a six-term congressman from northeast Iowa, hopes to answer with $5 million. Nowhere in the country, Harkin warned supporters recently, will voters have a clearer choice this year and nowhere will Democrats be pushed harder. ``They're coming after me with everything they've got,'' said Harkin. The candidates began airing television commercials last spring. They have disagreed on abortion rights, the Persian Gulf crisis and how they're paying for their well-financed campaigns. Through it all, Harkin, 50, has clung to a stubborn lead of 10 to 12 percentage points in most polls, though he's dropped perilously close to 50 percent in those surveys. Republicans argue that Tauke, 39, has positioned himself to overtake Harkin in the stretch, while Democrats say Tauke hasn't made a dent in that lead and is running out of time. ``We're surprised that the race is not closer,'' said Harkin spokesman Phil Roeder. ``A year ago heading into this campaign, we anticipated it would be a dead heat going into the final couple of months and it's not.'' ``We couldn't be happier with where we are,'' said Tauke spokesman Allen Finch. ``It's Labor Day and Harkin hasn't moved in over a year and we've stayed within 10 points.'' Harkin has emerged as a pesky critic of Republican presidents, and GOP officials concede he's a tough campaigner. ``Absolutely, this is a tough one,'' said Iowa Republican Chairman Richard Schwarm. ``This Senate race was going to be tough any time, but Tom Harkin has proven relatively slippery.'' Democrats have built a voter registration edge of roughly 100,000, ``but a Republican can certainly win statewide in Iowa with those numbers,'' said Schwarm. The candidates are conducting an unprecedented series of four prime-time debates broadcast on live commercial television throughout the state. Tauke dug himself into a hole in the most recent campaign debate focusing on abortion rights, some analysts say. In a state where nearly two-thirds of voters consider themselves pro-choice, Tauke staked out the hardest of anti-abortion positions, ruling out abortions even for rape and incest victims. Harkin took a more moderate approach, outlining a generally pro-choice position but saying he would be willing to consider measures such as limited requirements that a parent be notified before a minor gets an abortion. Tauke's staffers argue that he has long held anti-abortion views, and couldn't afford to waffle on the issue. Critics said he missed a chance to reach out to more moderate voters. Democrats saw it as one more thing going their way. ``I don't think we've seen a challenging candidate run such a poor campaign,'' said Iowa Democratic Party spokesman Joe Shannahan. But Finch argued that issues like abortion are fading from voters' minds in the face of world events. ``I think what can be said is the Persian Gulf has overshadowed virtually all other issues,'' he said. ``We've got our base solidified and we're in single digits and we'll seek to take the message to the voters as they increasingly pay attention to the race,'' said Finch. Tauke is completely supportive of President Bush's efforts in the Persian Gulf. Harkin has argued that more pressure should be exerted on other nations for greater support, and he has criticized Bush's decision to activate reserve units. Tauke criticizes Harkin for raising 90 percent of his larger contributions from outside the state. Harkin responds that he has backed campaign finance legislation thwarted by Republicans in Congress. Both candidates are veteran campaigners. Harkin represented southwest Iowa's 5th District for 10 years before ousting incumbent Republican Sen. Roger Jepsen in 1984. Tauke has represented the heavily Democratic 2nd District for 12 years.

DOC.HEAD: Arnold Shapiro Makes Movie of Charles Stuart Story
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Tuesday in 7th graf is Sept. 25.
With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Producer Arnold Shapiro had a head start in shooting the CBS movie on Boston's Stuart murder case _ or so it would seem. He just happened to have a camera crew in the area the night of the incident, arriving at the scene minutes after Charles Stuart was shot and his pregnant wife, Carol, was mortally wounded. The crew _ working for Shapiro's CBS series ``Rescue 911'' _ was chasing the ambulance that pulled up to the bleeding couple on the evening of Oct. 23, 1989. The dramatic footage of the Stuarts being removed from their car and given emergency treatment was broadcast last February to a wide audience. But the ``Rescue 911'' crew shot on videotape, and the Stuart movie became a 35mm film project. The two mediums don't cut together effectively, so everything was re-enacted. Shapiro's location in Boston that night gave him a head start of a different kind, however. In the industry rush to film the Stuart story, the producer had a leg up on the competition. ``We had all this research and all the contacts,'' Shapiro said. ``Everyone in Hollywood wanted to do the movie. But we'd already been on it.'' ``Good Night, Sweet Wife: A Murder in Boston,'' scheduled for Tuesday night, stars Ken Olin as Stuart and Margaret Colin as Michelle Caruso, a reporter who doubted Stuart's story of the shootings. Boston police had vigorously searched for the killer in the city's black community after Stuart said the couple had been attacked by a black man. A black suspect even was jailed for a time, sparking allegations of police racism and raising ethnic tensions. Charles Stuart, who was white, eventually became the prime suspect in the slaying of his wife. As a web of evidence engulfed him, he committed suicide in January of this year. ``The racial issues this story raises are not unique to Boston. We need to explore why Stuart was able to fool virtually everyone,'' Shapiro said. ``A large part of this movie is trying to understand Stuart's behavior. If one police department is more skeptical the next time a similar crime occurs, I will be fulfilled.'' Michelle Caruso, a crime reporter for the Boston Herald, was one of the few people who doubted Stuart's story from the start, he said. ``This shows you should not act in haste,'' Shapiro said. ``The media and the police bought Chuck Stuart's story hook, line and sinker. He said a black man did it, and that set off a near racial war. The husband or the boyfriend is always a suspect in a murder like this. Why wasn't Chuck? Because his self-inflicted wound was so bad he nearly died.'' Shapiro moved the Stuart movie's production site to Chicago to avoid any incidents in Boston, where passions still run high over the case. The movie also stars B.D. Wong, James Handy, Bruce McGill, Michael C. Gwynne and Annabella Price as Carol Stuart. Jerrold Freedman directed from a screenplay by Dan Freudenberger. ``All the actors looked at the `911' show and all the raw footage to make it as accurate as possible,'' Shapiro said. ``It's been a challenging movie to make. As of this date, the grand jury hasn't come back with its findings about whether any living person should be charged. There are some things we may never know that Chuck Stuart may have taken to the grave.'' The Stuart film was to have been broadcast opposite the season premiere of ABC's ``thirtysomething,'' which also stars Olin. But MGM Television, producers of ``thirtysomething,'' objected, and the Stuart movie was postponed a week. This is not the first time Shapiro has turned a documentary situation into a television movie. His 1978 Academy Award-winning documentary ``Scared Straight'' became the 1980 CBS movie ``Scared Straight! Another Story.'' The walls in Shapiro's office are covered with pictures and mementos that attest to his documentaries on aviation, the battle of Iwo Jima, American prisoners of war, the Unknown Soldier and the Korean War. As his ``911'' goes into its third season, he's preparing a new reality series for CBS called ``True Detectives,'' which will tell stories of professional and amateur sleuths who solved baffling mysteries. The biggest challenge in filming the Stuart story, Shapiro said, was not the uncertain ending, but cutting the wealth of material to fit a two-hour format. ``I think this is a story that could have happened in any American city,'' he said. ``It offers some broad national lessons. You can't say enough about the horror of violence against women and children. That one reason alone would be enough for me to make this movie.''

DOC.HEAD: Gypsies at a Glance
With BC-Gypsies-No Violins, b0781
DOC.TEXT: Here are some facts and figures about Gypsies:

NUMBERS _ An estimated 6 million Gypsies live in Eastern Europe, including 3 million in Romania, 1 million in Hungary, 1 million in Bulgaria, 600,000 in Czechoslovakia and about 40,000 in Poland. No official statistics exist.

LANGUAGE _ Romany is spoken by most unassimilated Gypsies. It is an ancient language rooted in Sanskrit or early Hindi, and has evolved differently in each East European country. Some versions of Romany are so divergent that Hungarian Gypsies, for instance, have trouble communicating with those from Romania or Bulgaria.

HISTORY _ The first Gypsies arrived in Europe about 900 years ago from northern India, but mass migrations to the continent did not begin until the 14th century. Their nomadic lifestyle and refusal to adapt led to increasing persecution in western Europe and migration to the eastern regions, where they were allowed to work as itinerant craftsmen and musicians and in other nomadic occupations. Pressure to conform was applied systematically in the late 18th century, when Austria's Queen Maria Theresa, who controlled much of eastern Europe, issued decrees designed to assimilate Gypsies forcibly into the serf class. Persecution continued, culminating in the Nazi extermination of an estimated 500,000 Gypsies.

DOC.HEAD: The Fall TV Season: Here Comes Another One Just Like the Other Ones
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS 12th graf, ABC's ``America's . . . of themselves., to fix name of show to ``America's Funniest People'' sted ``America's Funniest . . . Part II''; CORRECTS 30th graf, NBC ran . . . the 17th., to say ABC also running a few early previews.
DOC.TEXT: For weeks, the denizens of midtown Manhattan had puzzled about the strange, pervasive grinding noises audible in the streets and in the the corridors of the towering skyscapers. It turned out, of course, that the sounds were network television executives wearing out the enamel on their molars. What has gone wrong with the Republic? they wondered. From 90 percent of the potential TV audience in 1980, the Big Three had sunk to splitting 65 percent between them. Where had all the people gone? The fall television season of 1990 was approaching. They were out of ideas. There was nothing left to do but make something up. Or head for the sidewalk, either by the elevator or a long, whistling free fall out the window. So they came up with 35 new shows, the greatest number of original programs in TV history. Nineteen of them _ 54.3 percent _ are situation comedies. And, as usual, there are precious few programs worth celebrating. The biggest disappointment is Fox Broadcasting Co., which got a reputation for innovative programming. Fox scared the Big Three spitless by stealing 10 percent of the viewership without even reaching the entire country. Judging by its fall offerings, the weblet has gone from limber youth to doddering old age. Five of its 10 shows are sitcoms. One, ``True Colors'' is the mildest statement about biracial marriage since ``Good luck, you crazy kids. You're going to need it.'' It does not remotely resemble innovative programming. Even though Corin Nemec plays a greedy little hustler, the network's ``Parker Lewis Can't Lose'' is a fun, fine high-school fantasy bound to appeal to younger viewers. It's just too bad that the show, Fox's best new comedy, stops at satirizing high school. ``American Chronicles,'' a slick, sleek documentary, is visually classy, but its popular appeal is uncertain. ``DEA'' is visually distinctive but turns out to be just another cop show that's underwritten somewhat more than most. Both Fox and ABC have done their bit to hasten the demise of home video programming. ABC's ``America's Funniest Home Videos'' has tacked on the wretched ``America's Funniest People,'' and Fox has added ``Haywire'' to its ``Totally Hidden Video.'' Both shows feature Americans making fools of themselves. ABC offers only six new shows, which reflects the strength of their established programs. Half of the new crop are sitcoms, and only two of the six are worth watching. ``Gabriel's Fire'' brings James Earl Jones back to television, where his strength and dignity are sorely needed. He plays an ex-con ex-cop who brings the skills of both to his job as a lawyer's investigator. ``Cop Rock'' is Steven Bochco's engaging knockoff of Dennis Potter's stylish ``Pennies from Heaven'' and ``The Singing Detective.'' But even those two PBS miniseries never tried to blend rock music and police action. The show works, but it's an open question whether music supervisor Mike Post can find composers capable of keeping up the standard set by Randy Newman in the series premiere. Third-ranked CBS, whose 11 new shoes were the most offered by any network, had the fewest shows ready for reviewers. Some of them won't see the airwaves until October. ``Evening Shade'' will have to fall through the earth's crust to fail. Is it even possible that a sitcom could fail with a cast of Burt Reynolds, Marilu Henner, Elizabeth Ashley, Ossie Davis, Charles Durning and Hal Holbrook? ``WIOU'' _ also not available for previews _ has a cast that includes John Shea, Helen Shaver, Mariette Hartley, Dick Van Patten, Harris Yulin and Phil Morris. It's about TV journalism and has all kinds of chances to fail. The little screen has not been kind to comic book superheroes, so unless ``The Flash'' has great special effects and even better writing, the Scarlet Speedster's prospects for renewal are dimmer than the Six Million Dollar Man's. They're not dimmer than ``E.A.R.T.H. Force,'' which is by turns pompous, improbable, ungrammatical and unintentionally funny. Five of NBC's nine new shows are worth making time for. The long pilot episode for ``Parenthood'' was one of the best shows in the preview crop, with Ed Begley Jr. and William Windom in peak form. It's a half-hour that cries out for another 30 minutes just to let the characters breathe. Despite the grim-sounding premise of a high school musical comedy, ``Hull High'' makes a joyful noise. It's clever, funny, full of subtle touches, and it genuinely likes teen-agers and the people who teach them. Another winner is ``American Dreamer,'' which brings the wonderful Carol Kane back to TV and proves that Robert Urich can indeed do comedy. The script is funny and the chemistry between Kane and Urich is unmistakable. ``The Fanelli Boys'' is the best sitcom NBC has to offer. Mama (Ann Guilbert) and her four sons are a funny bunch. ``Law & Order'' stars George Dzundza as a police detective who arrests criminals, and Michael Moriarty plays the prosecutor who tries them. The hour goes quickly. There may be other worthwhile shows, but they're still not available to reviewers. The start of the network season still is Sept. 17, but the network executives have thoroughly confused things by trying to stir up interest in the shows they've already got in the can. NBC ran a ``double pump'' and previewed several shows ahead of that date. Fox put out early episodes of its shows, too. CBS and ABC scheduled a few early shows the week before the official season. At the end of August, A.C. Nielsen Co. expanded its known ``universe'' of U.S. television households from 92.1 million to 93.1 million, even though the audience is dwindling and becoming as independent-minded as a hog on ice. What would happen if the executives gave a fall TV season and nobody came?
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Weekend Editions, Sept. 15-16

DOC.HEAD: AGATHA CHRISTIE: The Queen of Crime Reigns 100 Years After Her Birth
DOC.TEXT: The tidy gray hair, impeccable tweeds and respectable air immediately identified Dame Agatha Christie: an upper-middle-class Englishwoman of a time and place when class defined a person's life. Child of prosperous and loving parents, loyal wife and devoted mother, she was a woman who spent more than 50 years writing about murder, hatred, jealousy and guilt with a cool skill that made her one of the best-selling novelists ever. Dame Agatha, born Sept. 15, 100 years ago, wrote 147 short stories, 15 plays and 90 novels, most of which are still readily available at neighborhood bookstores. They have sold more than 2 billion copies in 45 languages, and 14 years after her death they sell about 25 million copies a year, her publisher says. Some of them sell better now than when first published _ and this without sex, obscene words, overt violence or naked passion. ``She was the patron saint of insomniacs,'' Anthony Curtis said in the Financial Times after her death in 1976. ``Her readers were not merely legion, they included most literate persons above the age of 10.'' Despite her fame, Agatha Christie spent most of her life well out of the public eye, a shy and intensely private woman who probably would have been dismayed to discover what a fuss is being made over her centenary. Her birthplace, the south coast town of Torquay, is holding an international crime writers convention, a series of lectures on the author and the world championships of the mystery board game Cluedo (Clue in the United States). The local theater is reviving Christie plays, new editions of her books are appearing and hotels are holding ``murder weekends'' for guests to play detective. ``The Mousetrap,'' her most famous play, is still going strong in London after 38 years and has been seen by more than 8.5 million people. Lavish films of Christie stories have been huge TV and film successes. Actors as diverse as Peter Ustinov, Albert Finney and David Suchet have portrayed detective Hercule Poirot, while Angela Lansbury and Joan Hickson pick up Miss Marple where Margaret Rutherford left off. An Agatha Christie murder seems cozy and polite, committed for the most part out of sight by the most ordinary people. Her books are filled with comfortable stereotypes of benign clerics, gossiping spinsters, foolish servants and retired military men. Less comfortable racial and religious stereotypes also crop up. Some critics say Agatha Christie was not a particularly good writer, and she was always modest about her gifts. ``I'm very lowbrow,'' she said in 1971 while expressing surprise at being made a Dame by Queen Elizabeth II. ``A lot of people have written books.'' But others, such as H.R.F. Keating, admire her: ``She was very skillful, her timing was marvelous ... and she was a very good storyteller. ``She was a reasonably ordinary person in herself and didn't attempt to be more in her writing. So she appeals to the ordinary in all of us,'' said Keating, author of the Inspector Ghote mysteries and president of the venerable Detection Club of crime writers, which Christie headed for many years. She had a powerful imagination and an inventiveness that blossomed, so she said, in the bath. There she ate apples as she soaked, plotting her next story. Her most famous character is Poirot, the tidy Belgian detective with the waxed mustache who solved 34 of her mysteries in books and dozens more in short stories. Christie introduced him in her first novel, ``The Mysterious Affair at Styles,'' published in 1920. The endearingly egotistical Poirot, with his patent leather shoes and exquisite tailoring, solves puzzles with his ``little gray cells,'' imposing order on tangled clues in the same meticulous way he arranges his perfectly symmetrical life. Christie brought Poirot back in 1926 for ``The Murder of Roger Ackroyd,'' the book that made her famous with a shocking ending that nobody, but nobody, could guess. Readers who had watched every one of the suspects eliminated cried foul when they found out whodunit _ but they didn't stop reading Agatha Christie. Seven months after ``Roger Ackroyd'' made her a celebrity, this reserved woman with a horror of publicity created a sensation. Agatha Christie disappeared Dec. 3, 1926, the day her husband, Col. Archibald Christie, told her had fallen for a young woman named Nancy Neele and wanted a divorce. Agatha's car was found abandoned and a nationwide search began. She was found 11 days later in a northern England hotel, reportedly suffering from amnesia and registered as Teresa Neele. She never explained, not even in her posthumously published autobiography. The Christies divorced in 1928. Their only child, Rosalind, grew up with her mother. In 1930, Agatha Christie married Max Mallowan, a distinguished archaeologist 13 years younger than she, whom she met on a trip to Iraq. Eight years after ``Roger Ackroyd,'' Christie wrote one of her most famous books, ``Murder on the Orient Express,'' in which Poirot questions suspect after suspect on a snowbound train and can't seem to eliminate them. Almost as famous as Poirot is Jane Marple, the English spinster whose lifelong study of her village neighbors has taught her about motive. ``Human nature is much the same everywhere,'' Miss Marple points out, homing in on the murderer without dropping a stitch of her knitting. Christie's skills were self-taught. Her mother believed education would be hard on her eyes, so she kept her at home, a substantial house where she was born Agatha Miller, the youngest of three children. Her wealthy American father was fond of his club. Her doting mother presided over a household run by servants, and young Agatha absorbed the details of upper-middle-class life that would set so many scenes in her mysteries. These settings, enhanced in nostalgic detail in films and television, today seem as much a part of the Christie appeal as do the stories. Here, perhaps more perfect than they ever really were, are the 1930s chic of London's bright young things and the sun-dappled, country-house leisure of a class that thought it would rule for eternity. Preserved forever are the rural hamlet with a constable on his bicycle, and the seaside hotel with its potted palms and string quartet. Christie was not like the sheltered women who populate her fictional villages. She traveled widely, knew personal scandal and despair, and met and observed people from many cultures. But her modest manner is the image that lasts. ``I'm not very good at talking,'' she once said. ``Writing is a great consolation to people like me who cannot express themselves well any other way.'' She said it wasn't easy. ``The real hell ... is having to tie up all the loose ends in the last chapter. By the time you've done it you're sick of everybody in the book.'' She wrote Poirot's and Miss Marple's last cases in the 1940s for posthumous publication, but allowed Poirot's ``Curtain'' to be published before her death. One secret she kept for nearly 20 years, until 1949, was Mary Westmacott, the name under which she wrote six straight novels. ``Absent in the Spring,'' published in 1944, was ``the one book that satisfied me completely ... the book I had always wanted to write, that had been clear in my mind.'' But these novels never captured the public as her mysteries did.
