DOC.HEAD: Rendell and James: The New Queens of Crime
With BC-AP Arts: Christie
DOC.TEXT: Far from Agatha Christie's rural village, two of today's best crime writers have staked out their territory on the grimy streets of the inner city and the secret anxieties of suburbia. Ruth Rendell and P.D. James hold their own at the top of best-seller lists and, in the eyes of some critics, have moved the crime novel toward mainstream fiction. Their concern for the ``why'' of crime and their talent for making killer and victim as real as your next-door neighbor separate them from most of the writers of the Golden Age of crime writing. From the 1920s through the 1940s, the upper-class sleuths of Dorothy Sayers, Ngaio Marsh and Margery Allingham, with their servants and exciting escapades, offered millions of readers an escape from the Depression and World War II. In those classic tales, distinguished crime writer Julian Symons says, ``The General Strike of 1926 never took place, trade unions did not exist and when sympathy was expressed for the poor it was not for the unemployed but for those struggling along on a fixed inherited income. ... Murder was committed over and over again without anybody getting hurt.'' Ruth Rendell told a literary gathering, ``Long before I was first published, the crime writer had ceased to be expected to assemble 12 people in a country house, murder one of them and have a snowstorm maroon the rest indoors.'' Rendell's 34 novels may provide escape from the reader's own worries, but they offer no refuge from the dark side of human nature. The perverse and sexually maladjusted turn up in the world of her ruggedly honest provincial detective, Inspector Reginald Wexford, and his up-tight sidekick, Burden. But in her non-Wexford stories and the books she writes under the name Barbara Vine, they get the upper hand. ``A Judgment in Stone'' is about a family slain by their housekeeper because they discovered the secret that shamed her all her life. She could not read or write. In a ``A Demon in My View,'' judged the best crime novel of 1976, the killer takes to strangling real women when he is deprived of the store dummy he liked to throttle every now and then in the cellar. Rendell's writing reflects her time, with its urban frustrations, mental stress and sense of the individual losing control of his own life. Like Rendell, Phyllis Dorothy James does not back away from violent death. And the reader is not excused from the room. Murder, she says, is ``the ultimate crime, the one for which you can't ever make reparation.'' Murder and its discovery are central to the book and ``we should see it, experience it,'' she said in a British Broadcasting Corp. radio series on mystery writers. ``The character of the victim is just as important as the character of anyone else in the book,'' James said. ``Unless we understand him and care something about him, we're not going to care whether he dies or not.'' Her widowed police Inspector Adam Dalgliesh, a poet, finds his criminals by following clues in the traditional murder mystery style. But the author uses her strong Anglican faith and interest in moral dilemmas to enrich her 11 mysteries and stretch the limits of crime fiction. She has no interest in crime novels in which the murderer is a psychopath or has ``no sense of sin.'' ``She is more interested in using the detective story to write a novel of character,'' says critic H.R.F. Keating, author of the Inspector Ghote mysteries. ``She has, always, a whodunit interest which keeps your head down in the book. But as you read on, wanting to know whodunit, you get these pictures of very real and interesting people, seen in a moral climate.'' There's a constant presentiment of imminent disaster in Rendell's work, something she attributes to her childhood _ a loving father who nonetheless ``looked for sorrow rather than happiness in life'' and a mother, ``a vague, strange woman,'' whose multiple sclerosis was little understood in those days. ``So I think I was imbued from a very early age with a sense of doom,'' the 60-year-old writer said. P.D. James, 70, says she has been fascinated with death since childhood. ``I had a feeling always when people made plans: `Yes, but we might not be here.' '' Her view of humanity is stern. The doctrine of original sin, she said, ``seems to me pretty well to conform to the facts. ... We are fallen in the sense that basically we are selfish and violent creatures disposed, really always, to put our interests first.'' The great sadness of her own life _ a young husband who returned from the war a schizophrenic and spent the rest of his life in and out of hospitals _ does not appear to have altered her perspective. ``I never felt `why me?' probably because it doesn't need very much imagination to look at the world and see greater suffering. And `why not me?' ''

DOC.HEAD: Minnesota Governor's Race Tops 11-Election Primary Lineup Tuesday
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Rudy Perpich is a non-stop booster of Minnesota and, not coincidentally, his own political fortunes in a tight gubernatorial primary that is one of 11 elections Tuesday to fill out the 1990 campaign lineup. ``We are without doubt the No. 1 state in the nation,'' Perpich tells voters as he campaigns to stave off a tough primary challenge from Mike Hatch, a former state commerce commissioner. In other Tuesday primaries, Arizona Republicans will decide whether to endorse Evan Mecham's bid to regain the office from which he was ousted two years ago, while veteran politicians in New Hampshire and Vermont also are making comeback bids. Jesse Jackson is on the District of Columbia ballot for the symbolic office of ``shadow senator,'' his first bid for an office other than president. Voters in the nation's capital also will choose candidates in the race to succeed Marion Barry as the city's mayor. Also going to the polls on the busiest day of the primary season are voters in Connecticut, Maryland, New York, Rhode Island, Utah and Wisconsin. Only four states _ Massachusetts, Washington, Hawaii and Louisiana _ have yet to hold primaries. Runoffs are scheduled to settle contests in Oklahoma and Florida. While the parties choose their nominees, independent candidates are playing an unusually significant role. Former Republican Sen. Lowell Weicker is running as an independent and leading in the polls in the race for governor of Connecticut. Rep. John Rowland already has the Republican nomination for governor, while Rep. Bruce Morrison and state legislator Bill Cibes are competing for the Democratic nomination. Gov. William O'Neill, a Democrat, is retiring. In the District of Columbia, Barry is running as an independent for a seat on the city council where he served before being elected mayor in 1978. Barry was convicted last month on a misdemeanor charge of possession of cocaine. City council members John Ray, Charlene Drew-Jarvis and David Clarke, congressional delegate Walter Fauntroy and lawyer Sharon Pratt Dixon are the Democratic contenders to succeed Barry. Former police chief Maurice Turner is unopposed for the Republican nomination for mayor. Jackson, who moved to Washington from Chicago a year ago and mulled entering the race for mayor, is one of four Democrats seeking nomination to become one of two shadow senators, whose job would be to lobby Congress to make the city the 51st state. Shadow senators lobbied Congress to win support for statehood for Tennessee, Michigan, California, Minnesota, Oregon and Alaska. Perpich has served as governor of Minnesota for 10 years. He was appointed to finish the last two years of former Gov. Wendell Anderson's term in 1978 and then won election to the office in 1982. Hatch has mounted a strong challenge this year, focusing on scandals involving two close Perpich associates and a perception that Minnesotans are looking for a change. ``After eight years, past mistakes and personal vanities become the focus of an administration,'' said Hatch. Perpich countered by telling Minnesotans they were living in the best state in the nation. ``There isn't a state that's better than we are,'' he said during a televised debate with Hatch. ``In 1983, we couldn't compete with South Dakota. Today, we're beating the world.'' The governor also scored a late spring coup when Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev paid a one-day visit to the state after his June summit with President Bush. A mid-August poll showed Perpich and Hatch were in a dead heat among members of the Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party, the state's equivalent of the Democratic Party. But a survey published Wednesday said Perpich had opened a 17-point lead over Hatch. An unusual race also is taking place for the GOP nomination for governor of Minnesota. State auditor Arne Carlson had an 18-point lead in the latest poll over Jon Grunseth, a St. Paul businessman who was endorsed by the state party. Party leaders attacked Carlson as out of step with their positions on crime, gun control and abortion. The attacks abated only after a backlash from contributors who threatened to withhold funds. In the Democratic Senate primary, college professor Paul Wellstone and state Agriculture Commissioner Jim Nichols are competing for the nomination to oppose GOP Sen. Rudy Boschwitz. Millionaire developer Fife Symington is the front-runner for the Republican nomination for governor of Arizona, but no one is prepared to write off Mecham's chances to capture the nomination in the five-candidate field, particularly if there is a low turnout. The 66-year-old former car dealer was elected governor in 1986 and impeached and removed from office two years later on the basis of allegations he misused funds from supporters and interfered with the police investigation of an alleged death threat by one of his aides. But the impeachment charges generated less controversy than many of Mecham's positions as governor, particularly his opposition to a state holiday commemorating the birth of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. In the Democratic primary for governor, former Mayor Terry Goddard of Phoenix has only token opposition. Three Democrats are battling in Rhode Island to challenge Republican Gov. Edward DiPrete, whose approval rating in a Brown University poll dipped below 20 percent. Mayors Joseph R. Paolino Jr. of Providence and Francis X. Flaherty of Warwick and businessman Bruce G. Sundlun are in a close Democratic race. DiPrete, first elected governor in 1984, is heavily favored over talk show host Steve White in the GOP primary. In Vermont, Gov. Madeleine Kunin, a Democrat, is retiring after three two-year terms. Kunin was elected governor after Republican Richard Snelling decided not to seek re-election in 1984 to a fifth term. Now it's Snelling's turn and he is running to succeed Kunin. Both Snelling and Democrat Peter Welch face only token opposition in their party primaries. In neighboring New Hampshire, voters in both parties have plenty of choices. Former Sen. John Durkin, a Democrat who lost his seat to Warren Rudman in 1980, is attempting a comeback in a crowded primary. Also competing for the Democratic nomination to succeed retiring GOP Sen. Gordon Humphrey are Nashua Mayor James Donchess and businessman John Rauh. In the GOP primary, Rep. Bob Smith is favored over Thomas Christo, who has complained that White House chief of staff John Sununu, a former New Hampshire governor, has intervened on behalf of Smith. In the New Hampshire governor's race, former state Democratic Party chairman Joseph Grandmaison is favored to win his party's nomination to challenge Republican Gov. Judd Gregg. The biggest issue in the campaign for the Republican nomination for governor of Maryland has been whether front-runner William Shepard acted properly when he designated his wife, Lois, as his candidate for lieutenant governor. That move prompted Ross Z. Pierpont to launch his fourth campaign for governor. Whoever wins will have a formidable task challenging incumbent Democratic Gov. William Donald Schaefer, heavily favored for renomination. Two Republican congressional primaries hold the interest in Utah. In the Second District, former Rep. Dan Marriott and geologist Genevieve Atwood are competing for the nomination to challenge Democratic Rep. Wayne Owens. In the heavily Republican Third District, Rep. Howard Nielson is retiring and former state Sen. Karl Snow and think-tank chairman and businessman John Harmer are seeking the GOP nomination to succeed him. Bill Orton, a Provo lawyer, is the Democratic nominee. In Wisconsin, Republican Gov. Tommy Thompson has only token primary opposition. His Democratic opponent, Assembly Speaker Thomas Loftus, has no primary opposition. In New York, Gov. Mario Cuomo and his GOP opponent, Pierre Rinfret, already have their party nominations and will not even be listed on Tuesday's primary ballot.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Sept. 9

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Crisis Is Media Test
DOC.TEXT: Troops, tanks and planes remain poised at the ``line in the sand'' drawn by President Bush in the Gulf crisis. Both sides have held their fire, but another struggle has been taking place in the form of a public relations war, complete with communiques, satellite TV and news conferences. How good a job has the U.S. news media done in sorting it all out? The Associated Press checked with six specialists for their opinions on that element of the conflict. Here are their responses:
DOC.HEAD: EVERETTE E. DENNIS, executive director, Gannett Center for
DOC.TEXT: Media Studies:

There is a tendency for the story of this crisis to follow two tracks _ one a story of global political intrigue, another a moral tale of right and wrong, of hero and villain. Either course obscures the fact that the presence of American troops in Saudi Arabia (and, of course, Iraqi troops in Kuwait) is essentially an economic story: At issue is the world's oil supply, and not least the United States'. . . . The media try to map out the issues, to explain who the parties are and what they are saying, to assay interests and motivations. . . . (But) the press soon goes beyond the story of global politics to the people on the ground, the naval and military personnel who ultimately fight a war if there is to be one. While well-intentioned, this coverage sometimes serves only to trivialize the larger issues. At the same time, however, some of that coverage leads us to question precisely what and who we are fighting for and whether the price of American lives is worth paying. Recently some journalists have begun to probe at these points, but if previous conflicts are any guide, the larger prospect for the press is not encouraging.
DOC.HEAD: MARTIN A. LEE, co-author of ``Unreliable Sources: A Guide To
DOC.TEXT: Detecting Bias In News Media'' and co-founder of the group Fairness & Accuracy in Reporting:

Good journalism is supposed to show at least two sides of an issue, but coverage of the Gulf crisis has been very one-sided. U.S. news media have allowed Bush supporters to virtually drown out articulate critics of his Persian Gulf policy. Instead of asking tough questions, we've seen too much media cheerleading and saber-rattling on behalf of the president. Supposedly neutral reporting has often given way to worshipful prose about the ``masterful leadership'' of the commander-in-chief. Reporters ought to be raising the real issues. Doesn't Bush's rhetoric about ``Saddam controlling the oilfields'' ring hollow when OPEC, in cahoots with Western oil companies, would continue to fix prices? Is it worth risking 10,000 American lives for the emir of Kuwait, who owns nearly as many wives as Imelda Marcos has shoes? Should U.S. soldiers be deployed in support of the anti-democratic Saudi regime which tortures its own people? Amid all the talk about Saddam Hussein's ``naked aggression'' and ``trampling of international law,'' media pundits have rarely uttered the ``p'' word: ``Panama.'' Bush's invasion violated international law just as much as Saddam's invasion, but one would never know that from the U.S. media.
DOC.HEAD: REID COLLINS, CNN anchor in Washington:
DOC.TEXT: I think we've been having a difficult time in reaching the public with the longevity of this commitment. We haven't been too careful about explaining what seems to be a long period of continued Western presence in a fairly hostile environment. If there is anything remiss, it may be that. I don't think (criticism of excess coverage of Saddam) is founded. It is imperative to know thine enemy, if you want to put it on a strictly partisan basis. It's a matter of degree _ there comes a time when the seventh interview of Saddam Hussein becomes suspect. We are now trying to figure out `how did we get there?' There has been some exposition of the roots of this thing, the historical problems that beset Kuwait and its relations to Iraq. We haven't looked into this as much as we should. ... The hostages invariably take over the news and they become what I imagine what Saddam Hussein wants them to become, one of the primary issues. The administration has been forced to do its utmost to downplay the hostages.

DOC.HEAD: Woods Hole Celebrates 60 Years of Ocean Exploration
DOC.TEXT: Beginning in 1930, with $3 million from the Rockefeller Foundation and a small ship called Atlantis, scientists began exploring the ocean from this tiny seaport at one corner of Cape Cod. Since then, oceanographers from Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution have discovered vast underwater mountain ranges, strange life forms in the Galapagos Islands, hot water springs miles beneath the ocean surface and even the RMS Titanic. Even the movie ``Jaws'' featured Richard Dreyfuss as a scientist from Woods Hole called in for his expertise on the great white shark. Indeed, after 60 years of exhaustive research, experimentation and technology, scientists at Woods Hole can say this with pride: Men have now seen 1 percent of the ocean floor. One percent? This from a nation that sent men to the moon two decades ago? Scientists at Woods Hole will tell you that time and money would be better spent here. ``It's much more important that we use the tremendous technology we have to understand ourselves,'' said John Steele, a senior scientist at Woods Hole and former director of the institution. ``We have major scientific problems as well as social concerns here on Earth.'' The success of the scientists at Woods Hole is remarkable given the lack of glamour attached to oceanography and the scarcity of funds available for research. The government spends about $390 million in oceanographic research annually. In contrast, President Bush proposed this year a $15.2 billion space agency budget. ``Perhaps we aren't as good at selling ourselves as NASA,'' said Steele. ``But we also all had, even scientists, the mistaken belief that the bottom of the ocean was flat and uninteresting. ``Without the capabilities of Woods Hole and other institutions, we wouldn't understand the Gulf Stream and why it's important to problems of climate. We wouldn't have made wonderful discoveries under the sea bed and we wouldn't have appreciated the marine life in the deep ocean.'' It can be as tricky to send scientists down to the ocean's average depth of 12,000 feet as it is to send astronauts into space. The incredible pressure and the absence of light make the construction of underwater vehicles and other technology laborious and expensive. But the marine biologists, geologists, engineers, divers, technicians, chemists, physicists and many others who comprise the 900 employees at Woods Hole believe many of the solutions to the world's environmental crisis may lie beneath the ocean surface. Woods Hole is the largest private oceanographic institute in the world and relies mostly on grants, about 80 percent of them from the federal government. Unlike its West Coast counterpart, the state university-affiliated Scripps Institute in La Jolla, Calif., Woods Hole does not receive state money. It has an operating budget of $67 million a year. As a result, Woods Hole scientists have been likened to entrepreneurs, each in charge of their own destiny and relying on their creativity and vision to come up with successful grant proposals. Among the 350 projects at Woods Hole, one of the most eagerly anticipated is the World Ocean Circulation Experiment, a global study of sea patterns. The 10-year, $100 million project will track how the ocean influences climate over periods longer than weather forecasts of a few weeks. Scientists from the Soviet Union, China, Brazil, Britain, France, Spain and Australia, among others, are part of the project. They began gathering at Woods Hole more than three years ago to map the project. ``The ocean plays a significant role in determining the impact of the greenhouse effect,'' said Terrence Joyce, a senior scientist at Woods Hole who is directing the hydrographic program for the World Ocean Circulation Experiment. ``WOCE will give us an idea of how the ocean affects climate change and allow us to better predict the future.'' Woods Hole, or WHOI (pronounced ``Hooey'' by local residents and employees), has been on the cutting edge of oceanography and marine science since its inception. It was founded following a recommendation of the National Academy of Sciences that an American oceanographic lab was needed on the East Coast. The sprawling ``campus'' of Woods Hole dominates the small town, which extends like a little finger off the southwestern corner of Cape Cod. The large brick buildings of Woods Hole line the village's main street, with water on both sides. The campus consists of four large laboratories and a variety of smaller buildings in the village of Woods Hole and on the nearby 200-acre Quissett campus. The institution offers a graduate degree program for future oceanographers with the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Work at sea is conducted aboard three large research vessels, a smaller coastal vessel and the Alvin, a three-person, deep-water submersible. During World War II, Woods Hole researchers developed anti-fouling paint, which prevented barnacles from forming on the hulls of boats, and the bathythermograph, an instrument that gives a record of temperature layers in the ocean. Since 1964, scientists at Woods Hole have been able to penetrate the ocean frontier with the aid of Alvin, which has made more than 2,000 dives all over the world and can go as deep as 13,000 feet. Alvin's most dramatic early mission was reminiscent of the film ``Dr. Strangelove.'' In 1966, two military planes collided over Spain and a hydrogen bomb fell into the Mediterranean. Alvin pilots found the device and then relocated it after it slipped down a steep slope during a recovery attempt. In 1974, Alvin joined Project FAMOUS, a French-American undersea study and collected the first-ever photographs and samples of the Mid-Atlantic Ridge. Woods Hole has a celebrity scientist, Robert Ballard, who discovered the wreck of the Titanic in 1985. Ballard discovered the German battleship Bismarck last year. He also is host of the PBS's National Geographic ``Explorer'' TV series. ``Woods Hole tends to support high-risk people more than a public institution would,'' said Ballard. ``It's very comparable to private industry versus the government. There's a greater risk if you fail, but it lets you try.''

DOC.HEAD: Salmonella Outbreak in Raw Tomatoes Hard to Trace
DOC.TEXT: An outbreak of salmonella in raw tomatoes in the Midwest points up the need to take precautions to clean all food properly. In the last two months, more than 100 people have been reported stricken with salmonella javiana in Illinois, Minnesota, Wisconsin and Michigan. It was the numbers that got officials' attention. Normally in Illinois, for example, officials would expect 20 cases of this strain of salmonella among 2,000 to 3,000 cases of salmonella a year. The exact source of the tomato contamination has yet to be solved, but it appears the problem stemmed from one distributor, said Minnesota state epidemiologist Mike Osterholm. The contamination, he said, could have occurred anywhere from the fields to the trucking operation. ``We have no evidence of anything intentional happening or of any breaks in good harvesting practices,'' he said. ``And it occurred at a time when millions of tomatoes were coming into the Midwest. We really are looking at a needle in a haystack.'' Osterholm estimated that thousands of people were made ill by the contaminated tomatoes. Only a small percentage of cases of such outbreaks generally get reported to state authorities, he said. Though people commonly think of salmonella in relation to animal products, strains of it have turned up and caused large outbreaks traced to lettuce and parsley, cantalopes and other plant foods. The symptoms _ vomiting, diarrhea and stomach cramps _ are the same for salmonella javiana and the better-known salmonella enteritidis, said Dr. David Swerdlow, a medical epidemiologist with the Centers for Disease Control. ``There are hundreds of salmonella strains. Some are more common than others, but most cause similar disease,'' he said. ``Javiana is fairly rare, so when there was increase in these states, everybody took notice.'' Recent outbreaks of food poisoning, Osterholm said, are a result of changes in food distribution _ large quantities of food moving over a widespread area. ``I have great concern about the safety of the food suyppy today,'' he said. ``It is a lot less safe today than 10 to 15 years ago.'' Some precautions that can be taken at home: _ Wash fruit and vegetables. ``I think it was impressive to us how few people knew'' they should wash produce, Osterholm said. _ For tomatoes and other fruit, cut off the stem area and then cut out any bruises or bad spots. Wash the knife between each cut to prevent any bacteria from spreading into the tomato flesh. The salmonella outbreak traced to cantalopes occurred because the bacteria on the rind was carried by knives to the fruit. _ After the fruit has been cut, don't leave it for long at room temperature. _ Thoroughly wash any cutting boards used for meat before putting produce on them. Better yet, use separate boards.
DOC.NOTE: End advance for Sept. 10

DOC.TEXT: Sales of North American-made cars and light trucks by the nation's Big Three automakers plunged 26.1 percent in late August compared with last year, the automakers said. General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. said Wednesday they sold an average of 32,046 cars and trucks a day during the Aug. 21-31 period, compared with a rate of 43,390 daily during the same time last year. Car sales were down 27 percent and truck sales were off 24.8 percent. Officials for the automakers attributed the decline more to a weak economy than higher gasoline prices stemming from Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.

Oil shortages from the embargo against Iraq and Kuwait may develop late this year, Bush administration officials said. Assistant Energy Secretary John J. Easton Jr. told the House Government Operations Committee on Wednesday that `we see the potential for greater uncertainty as winter develops.'' Despite record high inventories and commitments by OPEC producers to make up much of the Iraqi-Kuwaiti production, both government and private analysts said they expect a world shortage to develop by late November or early December.

Oil prices rose to nearly $30 per barrel as traders began buying in response to Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein's televised call for an Arab holy war against the West. Light sweet crude for October delivery rose 65 cents to close Wednesday at $29.77 per barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The price rose as high as $29.89 before falling back.

IBM unveiled a new generation of mainframe computers it said would double the power of its most profitable machines and cement their position at the center of office computing. The announcement, made Wednesday at the company's U.S. mainframe factory, was billed as the most important rollout for International Business Machines Corp. in 25 years. The success of the new machines is crucial to the world's largest computer company because it derives about half its income from mainframes and associated equipment and software.

The chairman of the House Banking Committee proposed limiting the number of accounts that can be insured by the government and perhaps reducing maximum coverage below $100,000. Rep. Henry Gonzalez, D-Texas, said Wednesday that in the wake of the failure of the fund that insured deposits in savings and loan institutions, the bank insurance fund is facing a fifth straight year of multibillion-dollar losses.

Xerox Corp. began offering a ``Total Satisfaction Guarantee'' that promises a free replacement to customers dissatisfied with any of the company's products. The guarantee, announced Wednesday, covers all Xerox products delivered from now on for three years, or for the full term of financing through Xerox, whichever is longer.

Alaska Airlines and Federal Express will be allowed to begin new air services to the Soviet Union, the Transportation Department said. The department also said Wednesday it will hold hearings to award passenger routes to three other carriers. Alaska Airlines had announced tentative approval of its application to fly three times a week to the Soviet Far East cities of Magadan and Khabarovsk. No other airline had applied for the route. Federal Express would provide all-cargo service between New York and Moscow or Leningrad.

The airline industry said it is concerned about a rash of retirements among key Federal Aviation Administration personnel, including air traffic controllers. The Air Transport Association, which represents major carriers, said Wednesday that the agency's loss of 341 people last month jeopardizes the FAA's critical air traffic control and airways operations.

Regional dairy groups feuded as the Bush administration began looking into whether the decades-old U.S. milk pricing system should be changed. The U.S. Agriculture Department on Wednesday returned to the city where dairy prices are determined as it opened the first of several hearings into recommendations to change the federal milk market order system. The complicated formula partially pays farmers based on how far they live from Eau Claire, a city of about 50,000 located 120 miles east of Minneapolis in the heart of Wisconsin's dairy land.

Energy issues led the way as the stock market posted a moderate gain Wednesday in a quiet session. The Dow Jones industrial average, which had dipped 0.99 on Tuesday, rose 14.85 to 2,628.22. The dollar sank against all major foreign currencies. Bond prices posted moderate gains in light trading. Wheat futures prices rebounded strongly; other grain and soybean futures closed mostly higher; precious metal futures advanced; and livestock and meat futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Crate&Barrel Blossoms With Innovative Display of Housewares
Also in Thursday AMs report.
LaserPhoto CX3 of Sept. 5
DOC.TEXT: It began in a renovated elevator factory where customers were drawn by dishes and utensils stacked devil-may-care in the crates and barrels they came in. That rustic presentation gave the first Crate&Barrel store a formula for success: Showing off mundane household products with the flair and imagination many stores reserve for designer garments. The notion has brought the company from that single store in 1962 to more than 30 in six states, with a new flagship showroom to open Thursday on Chicago's glitzy Magnificent Mile. ``Crate&Barrel does for its housewares what most apparel stores do for their clothing lines. They dress up their products so that a customer can look at a set of tableware and envision what their table at home could look like _ just like they would with an outfit of clothing,'' said George Rosenbaum, president of the retail research firm Leo J. Shapiro & Associates in Chicago. The flagship store is another expression of Crate&Barrel's trademark showmanship, offering display cases with dressers and chairs along Chicago's ritziest retail strip. It all began when Gordon and Carole Segal, then both 23, were washing the dishes one day in 1962. Mr. Segal wondered why he couldn't get the couple's favorite dishware in Chicago, and they decided there was a gap in the local market. They quit their jobs _ his in real estate, hers in teaching _ raised $17,000 and set out to fill the gap with the first Crate&Barrel. ``It was all created out of a desire to be different,'' said Mr. Segal, president and owner of the store chain. It operates under the corporate name Euromarket Designs Inc., based in the Chicago suburb of Northbrook. Mrs. Segal pulled away to start her own catering business and has since retired. When they started, the usual places to stock one's kitchen and dining room were department stores, where the goods often were warehoused in unobtrusive places, Mr. Segal said. ``It was really a dreadful part of the store,'' he said. ``It was always hidden away on the top floor.'' Retail analysts and experts say Crate&Barrel brought a new strategy to the housewares business by giving as much attention to the overall look of the store as to the types of goods it sells. ``Crate&Barrel has always been considered innovative in terms of color and style of their housewares, and especially in the way they display them,'' said Kimberly Rawn, spokeswoman for the Chicago-based National Housewares Manufacturers Association. Mr. Segal describes his company as a ``blend of artists and businessmen.'' ``It's a fine line,'' he said. ``We don't want to be an art gallery, but at the same time we don't want to just look at the bottom line.'' The privately owned company declines to release details of its finances or operations, except to say its staff has grown from three to about 1,000 employees. It has reported sales of about $15 million from its catalog business alone, and Mr. Segal said it taps the lucrative wedding market with a bridal registry listing an average 18,000 brides at any given time. Crate&Barrel stores are found in Illinois, California, Texas, Maine, Massachusetts, Minnesota and Washington, D.C. About 75 percent of the housewares sold in the stores are imported, and the stores' purchasers aren't bound by the consumer preference studies many department stores rely on, Mr. Segal said. ``If we don't like it, if we think it's ugly, we're not going to buy it,'' he said. ``Just because Bloomingdale's sold 2,000 of these lamps doesn't mean we're going to rush to sell them, too.'' He acknowledges not having stockholders allows him more freedom to veer from the norm and take risks instead of relying on market tests. ``He's not under pressure to increase business or cut corners in order to keep earnings up,'' Rosenbaum said. ``So he has the luxury of moving slowly and trying new things.''

DOC.HEAD: T. Boone Pickens Heats Up Rhetoric Against Koito, Japan
DOC.TEXT: Texas oilman T. Boone Pickens turns up the rhetoric in his personal trade war with Japan's Koito Manufacturing Co. today with full-page advertisements in New York and Washington. Pickens lambastes trade policies in Japan, which he said ``is even refusing to fully support America's military efforts in the Middle East. . . .'' Pickens, known for his often hostile raids on U.S. companies, has been battling with the management of Koito for 18 months to gain representation on its board of directors. Pickens claims his battle with Koito, an automobile parts manufacturer, is an example of Japan's closed corporate system, which the ads claim is unfair to competition. The ads, slated to appear in The New York Times and the Washington Post, said: ``The Japanese refuse to play on a level playing field, causing the loss of American jobs and a growing U.S. trade imbalance. Now Japan is even refusing to fully support America's military efforts in the Middle East where Japan gets all of its oil to fuel its economic machine.'' Koito issued a statement that branded Pickens' tactics ``outrageous and irresponsible.'' Pickens has maintained that Koito is really a subsidiary in an alleged cartel headed by Toyota Motor Corp., the Japanese carmaker, which is Koito's largest customer. Pickens, whose Boone Co. owns 26 percent of Koito's stock, claims Toyota has three seats on the Koito board while controlling only 19 percent of the car parts maker's stock. But Ruth Pachman, a Koito spokeswoman in New York, said Toyota has no representatives on the board, although three former Toyota employees are board members. Koito, in turn, has maintained Pickens is really fronting for a Japanese investor, Kitaro Wantanabe, who is allegedly seeking to mount a ``greenmail'' campaign, in which a corporate raider buys a company's stock, forcing it to buy the shares back at above-market prices. Pickens has denied the allegation but also refuses to disclose the source of his financing to obtain his stake in Koito. The Texan was again denied a seat on Koito's board at a raucous company's shareholders' March meeting in Tokyo. Koito said Pickens was ``trying to manipulate public opinion for his own personal gain. He continues to wrap his greenmailing schemes in the mantle of U.S.-Japan trade relations. These tactics are outrageous and irresponsible.'' Japan, which consumes 4.9 millions barrels of oil per day _ 3.4 million barrels of it from the Persian Gulf _ has pledged $1 billion in aid for the multi-national force opposing Iraqi troops that invaded Kuwait last month. But Kuwait and the United States have urged Japan to do more. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu has ruled out any direct role for Japan's military, citing the constitutional ban against using force in settling international disputes. A Japanese foreign ministry spokesman said Wednesday that corporations there will be asked to divert exisiting stock to the aid package and sell their products to the government at cost. Mark Helmke, a Pickens spokesman in Washington said the ads, which urge readers to complain to the White House, Congress and the Japanese embassy about Japanese trade policies, will run in other newspapers around the country at a later date.

DOC.HEAD: Late-August Sales Skid Against Strong Period
DOC.TEXT: Sales of North American-made cars and trucks skidded 21 percent in late August compared with a strong period last year when customers were lured by attractive incentives. Automakers said they saw no signs that spiraling gasoline prices had sent consumers to more fuel-efficient cars. The 10 major car and truck makers in the United States said Wednesday they sold vehicles at an average daily rate of 38,943 during the Aug. 21-31 period this year. That compared with a 49,276 vehicle-a-day rate during the same time last year, when incentives lured buyers to showrooms. Car sales during the Aug. 21-31 period dropped 18.8 percent and truck sales were off 24.9 percent. Sales of cars made by General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. were down 27 percent during the period while sales of cars made by Japanese companies in North America rose 26.5 percent. ``Thus far, consumers seem to be taking a wait-and-see attitude and the automobile market has been much more stable than might have been expected under the circumstances,'' Ford's North American sales executive Robert Rewey said of effects of Persian Gulf crisis. ``With few exceptions, these numbers are terrible,'' said Tom Webb, a senior economist with the National Automobile Dealers Association in McLean, Va. ``Sales typically spurt ahead in the final 10-day period. There was no oomph at the end of August.'' For the entire month, with import sales included, combined car and truck sales in the United States fell 17 percent from last August. Car sales were down 17.6 percent and truck sales fell 15.7 percent. Webb, Rewey, Chrysler spokesman Tom Jakowboski and GM marketing Vice President J.B. Fitzpatrick agreed that a general softening of the economy was more of a reason for the declining vehicle sales rate. ``While present business conditions have created some uncertainty in the marketplace, we are optimistic that the environment will continue to stabilize in the weeks ahead,'' Fitzpatrick said. Through the first eight months of this year, car and truck sales from domestic and overseas automakers were 6 percent behind last year's pace. Car sales were down 6.4 percent and truck sales were off 5 percent. Sales of domestic cars for the year were down 5.9 percent and import car sales were off 7.8 percent. Sales of trucks made in North America were down 2.7 percent and import truck sales were down 18.5 percent. Ford's car and truck sales rate dropped 28.7 percent in late August compared with a year ago. For the year, Ford's combined car and truck sales were 9.3 percent behind last year's pace. Chrysler said its combined car and truck sales for late August were 31 percent lower than last year, and down 14.9 percent for the first eight months of the year. GM said its late-August vehicle sales rate fell 22.5 percent. Through August of this year, the automaker's combined car and truck sales were running 4.7 percent behind last year.

DOC.HEAD: Brady Fund-Raising Effort Faces Challenge in Asia
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Recasts lead, restores dropped word in 2nd graf, picks up 3rd graf, The Bush...; should stand for PMS. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady, on a globe-trotting search for billions of dollars to support the campaign against Iraq's Saddam Hussein, arrived in Asia today for what promises to be the toughest selling job of the whole trip. Brady is scheduled to meet Friday with South Korean President Roh Tae-woo. Later the same day, he flies to Tokyo for talks with Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu. The Bush administration also dispatched Secretary of State James A. Baker III to oil-rich nations of the Middle East to look for economic support. Officials in the delegation traveling with Brady said the stops in South Korea and Japan were likely to be the most difficult, in part because Americans were looking for substantial contributions from both countries to defray the cost of the U.S. military buildup and to help ease the economic hardships on Jordan and other nations resulting from the trade embargo on Iraq. Critics in the United States have complained that both Japan and South Korea should be doing more, given the fact that their economies are heavily dependent on oil from the Middle East. A working dinner at the U.S. ambassador's residence was the only event on Brady's schedule before his meeting Friday morning with the South Korean president. These discussions were to follow on the heels of Brady's talks Tuesday and Wednesday with French officials and British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. But in those cases, the meetings involved countries which already have a sizable military presence in the Persian Gulf and have indicated a willingness to provide at least some aid to alleviate the economic suffering on Egypt, Jordan and Turkey from enforcement of the trade embargo against Iraq. Japan and South Korea have been less forthcoming in the eyes of the administration, and for that reason Brady's delegation was braced for tougher negotiations. During Brady's 17-hour flight from Europe to the Far East, senior administration officials said a $1 billion military support package offered by Japan represented a good first step. But they left the clear impression that Tokyo would be called on to do more. The officials, who briefed reporters on condition of anonymity, said there was no thought of asking South Korea to supply military troops in the Middle East. But they suggested Seoul would be asked to make in-kind contributions to support the American buildup. The administration officials also supplied some of the first specific figures on what President Bush had in mind when he called on America's allies to pay their fair share of the economic and military campaign being waged to force Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. The officials said the United States is looking for its allies to pick up the entire cost of the American military buildup in the Persian Gulf, which they estimated would cost $1 billion a month over the next year. ``I think it is not unreasonable to ask the allies to pick up all of it,'' one official said. ``After all, they couldn't buy this (military) capability anywhere else in the world.'' Japan's $1 billion has been earmarked to support the military exercise in such ways as sending medical personnel to the gulf. The officials indicated that this type of in-kind contributions of such things as oil, transportation and housing would be the preferred donation rather than direct cash, which raises questions among critics over whether the U.S. military is fielding a mercenary force in the Mideast. Secretary of State Baker, meanwhile, flew to the Middle East overnight in his search for economic support. The administration is hoping to get significant amounts from Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and the exiled government of Kuwait, which still has significant financial resources at its disposal. In addition to looking for support for the U.S. military effort, Brady and Baker were searching for a $10.5 billion pool of resources to assist Egypt, Jordan and Turkey, three countries severely hurt by the trade embargo against Iraq. Senior officials traveling on Brady's plane put the relief need for the three countries at $3.5 billion for the last three months of this year and $7 billion more next year. In his meetings in Europe, Brady has stressed how critical it is for the allies to put together an economic assistance package to insure that the embargo against Iraq doesn't begin to unravel. The conversations with Mrs. Thatcher and the French centered primarily on this issue of support for so-called frontline states in the Mideast. In addition to this aid, the administration wants to raise an unspecified amount to be used to alleviate adverse economic effects from rising oil prices on countries such as the Philippines, Brazil and the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe. The officials would not discuss an overall price tag, but the various elements could well add up to more than $25 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Trader Pleads Guilty to Fraud Charges
DOC.TEXT: Another soybean trader at the Chicago Board of Trade has pleaded guilty to charges stemming from an FBI probe of alleged corruption at the world's two largest commodities exchanges. The guilty plea Wednesday by Bruce Mittelstadt of Elmhurst was the eighth from a soybean trader charged in the FBI sting operation. Mittelstadt pleaded guilty before U.S. District Judge George Marovich to one count of mail fraud and one count of violating the Commodities Exchange Act, said Assistant U.S. Attorney Dan Gillogly. Federal prosecutors will drop the remainder of the 57 charges filed against Mittelstadt in exchange for his cooperation, Gillogly said. In all, 48 people have been indicted in the probe. FBI agents posed as traders and secretly tape recorded conversations that prosecutors said revealed fraud among traders at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade. A sentencing date was not set for Mittelstadt, but Gillogly said the trader could face a maximum sentence of six years in prison and a $350,000 fine. Mittelstadt's attorneys did not return telephone calls to their offices late Wednesday. Meanwhile Wednesday, jury selection for the trial of 14 Japanese yen futures traders charged in the probe began Wednesday in U.S. District Court in Chicago. Those defendants face 393 counts of illegal trading practices at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

DOC.HEAD: Report Says Milken Prosecutors Hope to Press Full Case at Sentencing Hearing
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors will attempt to bring their full case against Michael Milken before a federal judge next month when the former junk bond pioneer is sentenced for his guilty pleas on unlawful trading charges, a newspaper report said today. The Wall Street Journal said the government plans to urge U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood to consider additional allegations against Milken when she sentences him. Sentencing is set for Oct. 1. Milken, the former head of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s junk bond department, and the government reached a plea bargain in April under which Milken pleaded guilty to six felony counts related to unlawful trading. But the government didn't agree to recommend any specific sentence. The newspaper story said the government hopes that evidence of additional crimes _ presented in a sentencing memo and in live testimony _ will induce Judge Wood to give Milken a stiff sentence for the crimes to which he has pleaded guilty. Milken faces a maximum sentence on those charges of 28 years. The report said the witnesses could include Ivan Boesky, the convicted former stock trader. The story said the judge isn't obligated to take the government's additional allegations into consideration when deciding an appropriate sentence. But if she does, the story said Milken will be entitled to defend himself at a hearing. The story said prosecutors have held lengthy discussions with attorneys for Milken in recent months detailing what they plan to say in their sentencing memo to the judge, who is scheduled to receive it on Monday. In addition, the story said witnesses who aided the government in its case against Milken have confirmed that they were told by prosecutors that the government will seek to present the full force of its case against Milken at any such hearing. Prosecutors have told these attorneys that such a hearing could last for more than three months, the story said.

DOC.HEAD: Newthaler Will Lead Publishing Group
DOC.TEXT: Bertelsmann AG, the West German media conglomerate, has ended an eight-month search for a new boss of Bantam Doubleday Dell on by naming Paul D. Neuthaler as chairman and chief executive. The publishing group had been without a permanent leader since Alberto Vitale left to take over Random House at the start of the year. Officials of the parent company said Wednesday that the search was prolonged by the difficulty of finding an executive with credentials in both books and finance, the New York Times reported Thursday. The choice of Neuthaler, a relative unknown, appeared to be connected with Bertelsmann's desire to push into scientific, technical and professional publishing in the United States. Neuthaler, 47, had directed a fruitless effort by the company in the middle 1980s to develop a technical publishing arm in this country. He then left to become a partner of JPT Publishing Group, financial, scientific and market research publishers. Bantam Doubleday Dell is a general-interest, or trade, publishing group for which Bertelsmann paid $475 million three years ago. Bernhard von Minckwitz, a Bertelsmann board member who had been acting chief executive during the search for a new chairman, will remain with the group with the new title of executive chairman and Neuthaler will report to him, Bertelsmann said.

DOC.HEAD: Bombs Explode At Stock Exchange, Other Public Buildings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with threat in Paris, six injured in Madrid, warning by leftist group, background on GRAPO. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Mail bombs exploded at the Madrid Stock Exchange, the Economy Ministry and the Constitutional Court today, slightly injuring six people, police said. A shadowy leftist group claimed responsibility. In France, the Paris Stock Exchange was evacuated in mid-session today after a bomb threat, officials at the exchange said. Police conducted a 20-minute search of the building, then lifted the bomb alert and allowed employees to return. No details were released about the Paris threat, which came shortly after the Madrid blasts. The first two explosions in Madrid came at about 11:30 a.m. local time off the exchange's trading floor and on the 11th floor of the Economy Ministry, a police spokesman said. Minutes later, the third bomb exploded at the Constitutional Court on Madrid's western edge, Spanish National Radio reported. The six injured, all at the stock exchange, were treated for cuts and bruises at a hospital and later released. No one was injured at the Economy Ministry or the court, police and the national radio said. Callers claiming to represent the far-left group GRAPO warned Madrid municipal police and Economy Ministry officials minutes before the blasts, the police said. Earlier, police had said the attacks bore the hallmark of the Basque separatist group ETA. Witnesses told police they saw women carrying suspicious-looking packages entering the Madrid buildings just before the explosions, police said. Women have taken part in several GRAPO-claimed killings and bombings. All three buildings were evacuated and police bomb squads searched for other bombs. The stock market and ministry are located blocks apart on Castellana Boulevard, Madrid's main north-south thoroughfare. The national radio's stock market reporter Juan Antonio Polo said the explosion at the exchange caused part of the ground floor ceiling to collapse and sent people rushing from the building. The blast occurred near an elevator off the trading floor and shattered many windows, Polo said. GRAPO, a shadowy Maoist organization, has claimed responsibility for 30 killings since it surfaced in 1975. The last attack for which GRAPO claimed responsibility was June 15, when two gunmen shot to death an Army colonel outside his house in the northern city of Valladolid. GRAPO takes its name from the Spanish initials for the First of October Anti-Fascist Revolutionary Group, an organization that began its violent attacks on that date in 1975 with the murder of four Madrid policemen.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Denies Government's Bid to Delay Giving Up Control of Franklin
Repeating f0061 to incluide pickup reference
DOC.NOTE: Eds: TOPS with 10 new grafs to reflect judge's refusal to stay order. Picks up 7th graf pvs, Harris Weinstein . . .
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge today denied the government's request for a stay of his order requiring the Office of Thrift Supervision to return control of Franklin Savings Association to its former officers. The denial by Judge Dale E. Saffels sent government attorneys to the 10th U.S. Circuit Court in Denver seeking to override Saffels and get an order that would keep Franklin under federal management. The government was fighting a deadline Saffels set Wednesday for turning Franklin over to its former managers. Franklin's chief counsel, Roger Stanton, said the savings association had its attorneys ready in Denver to file a response opposing a similar motion there. He said 10th Circuit rules do not provide for a hearing on such a motion. OTS seized control of Franklin, based in Ottawa, Kan., and the state's largest thrift, last February in a dispute over whether it was being managed prudently. It placed Franklin under management of the Resolution Trust Corp. as conservator. Franklin's officers sued to regain control of the thrift, and Saffels held in a 93-page opinion made public Wednesday that the government seizure was arbitrary and capricious. He ordered the government to remove the RTC as conservator of Franklin and to turn over management reins today to the thrift's chairman, Ernest W. Fleischer. However, OTS attorneys filed a motion Wednesday night for a stay of judgment, seeking to keep Franklin in the hands of the RTC while the government appeals Saffels' decision. Saffels said the OTS ``has not demonstrated either a strong likelihood of success on the merits on appeal, or that it would suffer irreparable harm if a stay were not issued.'' The judge, ruling on the stay motion without a hearing, said a stay would be ``contrary to the public interest.'' Harris Weinstein, chief OTS counsel in Washington, said late Wednesday the federal agency would appeal to the 10th Circuit seeking a stay if Saffels denied its motion. In his order, Saffels found that the OTS decision to take control of Franklin ``lacked any basis in fact.'' Weinstein disagreed strongly. ``We firmly believe the government acted in a timely and proper manner in taking over Franklin, an institution that was being operated with insufficient capital and in an unsafe and unsound manner,'' Weinstein said in a statement issued in Washington. ``OTS continues to believe that prior to the conservatorship order, Franklin was placing excessive reliance on high-risk assets financed by high-cost and mobile brokered deposits, and that at the same time Franklin used improper accounting methods under which it recognized gains and deferred losses while distributing more than $45 million of the institution's funds in dividends to the shareholders.'' Saffels also retained jurisdiction in the case for the next 90 days, meaning that the OTS cannot appoint another conservator or attempt to place Franklin in receivership during that time without his approval. Saffels told reporters that after 90 days, the OTS could move against Franklin again. That could mean more court hearings, he said, ``and we'd probably start over again.'' The ruling was not expected to have any direct impact on other savings and loan litigation. At issue in this case was whether OTS was justified in seizing control of the $11 billion thrift on Feb. 16 for allegedly losing millions in the futures market but deferring those losses for bookkeeping purposes by using a controversial hedging accounting system. Franklin officials, headed by Fleischer, sued the government on March 12, contending the government had insufficient evidence of losses, management problems or improper accounting procedures to take over the thrift. Saffels declared in his lengthy opinion that ``no statutory ground for the imposition of a conservatorship existed.'' ``This was not a case of improper or retroactive rule-making, but one of erroneous application of existing regulatory rules,'' he wrote. ``The facts of this case clearly show that the regulator acted wrongly in imposing the conservatorship. This court must correct that wrongful action.'' The judge went out of his way to distinguish the Franklin case from others being prosecuted around the country by OTS. ``This is not a case involving an infamous or notorious savings and loan association, the likes of which the public has recently become more than familiar,'' Saffels wrote. ``This is not a case involving fraud, corruption or self-dealing by the management or directors of Franklin. There has been no allegation or even hint of illegal or unethical conduct by Franklin's management or directors. ``Essentially, this case boils down to a dispute over accounting practices,'' he wrote. Fleischer, who was in Saffels' courtroom when the ruling was released, said he was ``very pleased with the decision and the care with which the decision was written.''

DOC.HEAD: Prices Continue Rising
DOC.TEXT: Crude oil futures prices soared above $30 a barrel in early trading today on continued fears of supply disruptions because of the Persian Gulf crisis. The price of the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil was up $1.17 at $30.94 per 42-gallon a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Light, sweet crude for October delivery rose 65 cents to $29.77 per barrel on Wednesday. Traders said today's sharp rise extended Wednesday's gains, which came on harsh talk by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein and fears of shortages and signs of hoarding by U.S. consumers and distributors. Also, news overnight that an American had been shot by an Iraqi soldier trying to avoid capture increased fears of war in the region. The American later was reported in a hospital after he was shot in the hand. Oil prices have shot up since Iraq occupied Kuwait Aug. 2 on fears that the world's supply could be sharply reduced by fighting in the Middle East. Andrew Lebow, senior broker and analyst for E. D. & F. Man International Futures Inc., said traders are anticipating disruptions in oil supplies in the next couple weeks, as well as shortages as demand increases in the winter. Refined products traded on the Merc also shot up this morning. Home heating oil for October delivery was up 3.83 cents to 87.20 cents per gallon, after rising 0.98 cent on Wednesday. Unleaded gasoline was 2.98 cents higher to 95.25 cents per gallon, erasing Wednesday's drop of 2.25 cents.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 379.55 down 2.89 from the previous day's close.

The stock market headed lower today in another session of sluggish activity. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 24.75 to 2,603.47 by 11 a.m. on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers by nearly 2 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 415 up, 811 down and 432 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 42.21 million shares at midmorning. Analysts said buyers were holding back awaiting the Labor Department's report Friday morning on the employment situation for August. The figures are expected to show continued weakness in the economy. Speculation has begun to spread on Wall Street that the data might encourage the Federal Reserve to adopt a more stimulative credit policy in an effort to ease strains on the economy and the banking system. But Wall Streeters are not entirely convinced that long-term interest rates would automatically fall in response to such a move. In fact, some say, rates could rise in that setting if fears increased that the Fed was softening its stand against inflation. That, in turn, would stand to leave the central bank in an even worse policy bind than it faces now. Losers among the blue chips included Boeing, down 1 at 47}; General Electric, down [ at 60[; American Telephone & Telegraph, down ] at 31}, and Pepsico, down { at 24}. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks lost 1.42 to 176.51. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was off .05 at 325.36.

DOC.BYLINE: Lincoln Savings Memo: The Weak, Meek And Ignorant Are Good Targets
DOC.TEXT: SHERMAN OAKS, Calif. _ ``Capitalize on this,'' the memo began, and went on to list a dozen selling points for bond salesmen at Lincoln Savings & Loan's branches. It ended with this: ``And always remember the weak, meek and ignorant are always good targets.'' Slug BC-S&Ls-Lincoln Victims. By Scott McCartney. Moved Tuesday on FFF-level news wires for Sunday, Sept. 9. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.BYLINE: Part II: S&L Crisis Hits John And Jane Doe Where They Live _ Literally
DOC.TEXT: COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo. _ In many places, the savings and loan crisis seems a far-off fury: unknown people swindling faceless institutions in complicated ways with vague consequences. But in Colorado Springs, as in many cities across the country, the consequences have shaken everyday life. Some people can't get out of their homes. Some can't get into homes. Sellers have to swallow bigger losses because prices are depressed by the huge inventory of government-owned homes hanging over the market. The S&L crisis, says National Association of Home Builders economist Dean Crist, is ``hitting Main Street now.'' Slug BC-S&Ls on Main Street II. By Special Correspondent Tad Bartimus. Moved Tuesday on FFF-level news wires for Monday, Sept. 10. With LaserPhoto. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.BYLINE: Welcome To The Phoenician. Your Host? Why, The Federal Government
DOC.TEXT: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. _ English tea is served under ceilings decorated with gold leaf, and a pool is lined with mother-of-pearl tile. To some, the Phoenician resort is the epitome of excellence. To others, it is a monument to excess paid for by now-insolvent Lincoln Savings and Loan. But for anyone, it's hard to believe this $275 million desert oasis actually is a government-owned and operated property. Slug BC-S&Ls-Club Fed. By Scott McCartney. Moved Tuesday on FFF-level news wires for Monday, Sept. 10. With LaserPhoto. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.BYLINE: Part III: Anger in the Heartland: Tab for S&L Bailout Comes Due
DOC.TEXT: MILWAUKEE _ Donald Janke has worked for 40 years in savings and loans, taking in government-guaranteed deposits and lending them to homeowners as mortgages. His Marquette Savings and Loan still makes a profit with these non-glamorous transactions. But although Janke and others in America's heartland had nothing to do with the freewheeling deals behind the S&L fiasco, they're still paying for the bailout. There are millions of people like Janke _ people who do not work for a troubled savings and loan, and do not have accounts or loans with one; people who do not live in towns where real estate values have plunged because of S&L problems; people whose businesses have been unmolested by the crisis. They're all paying. Slug BC-S&Ls on Main Street III. By National Writer Robert Dvorchak. Moved Tuesday on FFF-level news wires for Tuesday, Sept. 11. With LaserPhoto.
DOC.BYLINE: Billions and Billions Filched: Where Did It Go?
DOC.TEXT: MESA, Ariz. _ A bronze sculpture at the base of a neon-outlined 16-story office tower here honors real estate developer Conley Wolfswinkel's parents, ``without whose love and guidance this building never would have been possible.'' Not exactly. Western Savings & Loan Association, and ultimately the U.S. taxpayer, helped, too. Slug BC-S&Ls-Where It Went. By Robert Dvorchak and Scott McCartney. Moved Tuesday on FFF-level news wires for Tuesday, Sept. 11. With LaserPhoto.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Subsidiary Makes New Oil, Gas Discovery in Malaysia
DOC.TEXT: A subsidiary of Exxon Corp. has made a new oil and gas discovery in a Malaysian offshore field, its exploration manager said Thursday. In production tests, oil flowed at more than 3,000 barrels a day, Dennis Francis, exploration manager of Esso Production Malaysia Ltd., said. Francis said the discovery was made from a well begun on July 5 in the Larut Field, in the South China Sea about 150 miles from the Malaysian town of Kuala Trengganu. The well is in a production-sharing contract block in which Esso is the operator and 50 percent equity holder, together with Petronas Carigali, a subsidiary of Petronas, the government-owned National Petroleum Corp. Francis said the results were encouraging, but plans to develop the Larut Field would depend on results from follow-up wells. Esso now produces 335,000 barrels of oil a day in Malaysia, up 5,000 since Malaysia increased its overall production to help meet oil requests from other countries amid the crisis resulting from Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Malaysia now produces 605,000 barrels a day, consumes 75,000 barrels a day, and exports the rest to Japan, South Korea, Thailand, the Philippines, India and other countries.

DOC.HEAD: Auto Production Down From Last Week
DOC.TEXT: Domestic automakers were scheduled to produce 178,382 cars and light trucks this week, down from last week's 199,924, Ward's Automotive Reports said Thursday. But this week's production is higher than the same week a year ago, in which 173,020 cars and light trucks were produced, the trade journal said. U.S. automakers were scheduled to make 111,612 cars this week, compared with 125,586 a week ago and 108,175 in the same week in 1988. Light truck production for the week was scheduled at 66,770, compared with last week's 74,338 and last year's 64,845. Canadian automakers were to build 21,177 cars this week, down from 21,475 a week ago and up from last year's 15,047. Canadian light truck production was scheduled at 14,142, compared with 16,941 a week ago and 17,045 in the same week last year.

DOC.HEAD: Mitsubishi Acquires Part of Italian Clothier
DOC.TEXT: Mitsubishi Corp. has acquired 30 percent of the Italian men's clothier F.G. Reporter in a move the two hope will more than double sales in four years. F.G. Reporter President Tino Girombelli said Thursday the alliance will increase the company's production capacity, strengthen its presence in the world market and facilitate development. Based in Ancona, Reporter had consolidated sales of 85 billion lire, or about $73 million, in 1989. With the help of Japan's leading industrial and trading conglomerate, Girombelli hopes to bring sales to more than 220 billion lire, or $189 million, by 1994. Girombelli said about 30 billion lire ($26 million) would be invested in the next two years to launch a line of women's clothing by 1992.

DOC.HEAD: Mexico Maintains Increased Crude Oil Exports For Three More Months
DOC.TEXT: Mexico announced it will continue exporting 100,000 barrels of crude oil more than normal every day until the end of this year to take advantage of rising world market prices caused by the Persian Gulf crisis. A news release by the state petroleum monopoly Petroleos Mexicanos S.A. _ popularly known by its Spanish acronym of Pemex _ said Wednesday the increased exports will not diminish liquid fuel supplies for domestic consumption. When the gulf crisis began with with Iraq's invasion of Kuwait Aug. 2, Pemex raised the volume of its exports by 100,000 barrels a day for August and September to help stabilize the market. It said at the time it could not go beyond that because it was behind in the development of its oilfields. But in Wednesday's news release, Pemex said it ``was able to increase its operating margins ... without sacrificing any domestic supplies, permitting it to take advantage of rising prices in the international market.'' Pemex exported an average of 1.2 million barrels a day in July, and an average of 1.3 million barrels daily in August. About half of Mexico's crude exports go to the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Brazil Pays $3.7 Billion But Foreign Debt Rises
DOC.TEXT: Brazil paid its creditors $3.7 billion in the first quarter but the country's foreign debt rose by $2.2 billion, the Central Bank said Thursday. The Brazilian debt rose to $116.9 billion in March from $114.7 in December 1989, according to a quarterly report from the bank. The report said Brazil's short-term debt rose to $19.5 billion, or 23.4 percent of the total. The medium- and long-term debt dropped slightly to $97.4 billion. Preliminary figures showed Brazil paid its creditors $3.7 billion between January and March. Brazil has the largest foreign debt in the developing world. The government stopped interest payments to private creditors in mid-1989 but has continued to pay the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and the Interamerican Development Bank. Arrears are estimated at $6 billion to commercial banks and $2 billion to government lenders of the so-called Paris Club.

DOC.HEAD: Rockefeller Family Takes Stake in New Spanish Investment Firm
DOC.TEXT: An investment arm of the Rockefeller family is joining Banco Hispano Americano of Spain and Britain's Dillon Read Ltd. to form a $60 million company to invest in Spanish stocks, spokesmen for Dillon Read and the bank said Thursday. Rockefeller and Co. Inc. plans to take a 30 percent stake in the new company with another undisclosed non-Spanish investor, said the spokesmen, who asked not to be identified. Hispano Americano will take a 50 percent share along with two Spanish companies, while Dillon Read is to share a 20 percent stake with an undisclosed non-Spanish partner. The Dillon Read spokesman said the as-yet unnamed investment company plans to make three-to-five-year investments in Spanish companies seen as undervalued. He said the company is to begin operations in the next few weeks and eventually would be listed on the Madrid Stock Exchange. The bank spokesman confirmed a report published Thursday in the business daily Expansion that said Hispano Americano will share its stake with construction company Ferrovial SA and Seville-based Abengoa SA, an engineering and electrical equipment maker. Ferrovial owns a large stake in Banco Hispano Americano, one of Spain's six major private banks and an experienced manager of foreign funds invested in Spain. Stock prices have dropped about 20 percent on the Madrid Stock Exchange since the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait roiled world stock markets. But the Dillon Read spokesman said the drop ihas created ``an opportune moment to start making investments'' because there was no longer concern about dealing with ``an overheated market.''

DOC.HEAD: Benetton Buys Most of U.S. Sports Equipment Maker
DOC.TEXT: The holding company for the Benetton family clothing group announced Thursday it has purchased 80 percent of Prince Holdings Inc., a U.S. manufacturer of tennis and squash equipment. Terms of the sale weren't disclosed by Edizione Holding SpA. Edizione, which owns 80 percent of Gruppo Benetton SpA and and ski boot maker Nordica SpA, bought the stake from Prince's management group, which itself had acquired the company from Unilever PLC in 1987. Prince Holdings, based in Lawrenceville, N.J., employs 600 people and produces several lines of rackets, balls, strings, shoes and other accessories for squash and tennis. It also produces golf clubs.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Rise on Export Hopes, Dry Delta Weather
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed mostly higher Thursday on the Chicago Board of Trade amid expectations of more sales of U.S. grain to the Soviet Union. The soybean market drew further support from reports that hot, dry weather has begun to stress soybeans in Nebraska as well as in the Mississippi Delta region, which has been unusually dry all summer, analysts said. Speculation continued to mount that the United States will grant credit to the Soviet Union for purchases of agricultural commodities, said William Biedermann, director of research with Allendale Inc., a futures brokerage in Crystal Lake, Ill. ``It could be as soon as Monday or Tuesday,'' Biedermann said. ``But I don't think the important thing is when _ the important thing is that they are going to get it.'' He said there were also signs that Soviet grain production this year will fall below market expectations. At the close, wheat futures were 1\ cents to 3\ cents higher with the contract for delivery in September at $2.66\ a bushel; corn was { cent lower to 1} cents higher with September at $2.42} a bushel; oats were 1{ cents to 2{ cents higher with September at $1.11\ a bushel; soybeans were \ cent lower to 5} cents higher with September at $6.17{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Airline Survey Reveals Travelers' Chief Gripe: Delays
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Frequent fliers want to get where they're going cheaply and on time. Nothing bugs them like delays. And in general they're pretty unhappy with airline service. So says the 1990 Zagat Airline Survey, which reflects the opinions of 4,462 upscale business travelers who spend nearly one night a week on the road. Results were released at a New York news conference Thursday. ``Many view the airlines and airports as akin to the buses and bus terminals of 20 years ago: deteriorating, overcrowded, disappearing and depressing,'' said survey analyst Nicholas Tortorello. The survey was a first for Tim and Nina Zagat, the husband and wife team known for their annual assessment of hotels and restaurants. They said they took on the airline industry ``to explore the public's feelings'' about air travel. Questionnaires were sent to 25,000 people this spring asking them to rate 1,400 U.S. hotels, restaurants, spas, car rental companies and airlines. Respondents were asked to rate 27 top international and domestic carriers in terms of comfort, service, timeliness, food and ``bang for buck,'' which rated cost and value. Scores were then averaged together for an overall rating. The top 10 spots went to international carriers, with Singapore Airlines heading the list with an overall rating of 25.14, followed by Swissair, Japan Air lines, Scandinavian Airlines System and Qantas. American Airlines ranked 11th with an 18.62 rating. Delta Air Lines, the next domestic airline on the list, was 14th at 18.12. Aeroflot Soviet Airline came in last, scoring a dismal 7.31. According to the 30-point scale, 26 to 30 signifies a rating of extraordinary to perfection; 20 to 25, very good to excellent; 10 to 19, good to very good; and zero to nine, poor to fair. Tortorello, whose firm Research & Forecasts analyzed the survey results, said foreign carriers scored better overall than domestics because airlines use bigger, more comfortable planes on longer flights and the crew has more time to pamper passengers. Domestic airlines fared better when respondents listed their favorite airlines, capturing six of the top 10 spots. American topped that list with 22.9 percent choosing it as their favorite. The other top domestics were United, Delta, Trans World, Continental and Pan American World Airways. The survey also separated the airlines into domestic and international categories. American, Delta and United Airlines respectively captured the top three domestic spots while troubled Eastern Airlines ranked last in 11th. Karen Cerensak, a spokeswoman for Eastern, defended the carrier's recent performance, saying: ``Some of these people obviously have not flown Eastern recently. In the last 18 months, we've been on top in the industry for on time performance. We've received food awards for our in-flight meals and our fares are among the lowest in the industry. So the perception that's out there does not match reality.'' Internationally, Singapore, Swissair and Japan Air Lines headed the list while El Al Israel Airlines, Olympic Airways and Aeroflot were listed at the bottom in 14th, 15th and 16th places. In a section that included comments, travelers generally had good and bad things to say about each carrier _ with the exception of Aeroflot. That airline was called ``a flying slum'' by one flyer and included this warning from another: ``Don't do it.'' The survey also found that of eight features travelers consider in choosing an airline, the most important were routes offered (46 percent), price (42 percent) and timeliness and reliability (41 percent). Quality of food, 12 percent, was least important. Tortorello says he believes the low figure reflects passengers' resignation that ``nothing can be done about the taste or selection of the food.'' Travelers' biggest gripe were delays (49.6 percent) followed by comfort (16.5 percent) and service (9.5 percent). Surprisingly, safety was at the bottom of the list (1.6 percent) and oft-heard complaints about baggage were cited by only 3.3 percent of the respondents. Tortorello said safety ranked so low because a majority of the travelers apparently believe ``every airline is trying to do its best.'' He said women rated safety as a concern more often than men, and women were also more concerned about price. ``Men basically seemed more concerned about the plane being on time and comfort,'' Tortorello said. The collective profile of those who responded to the questionnaire showed they were mostly upscale professionals between the ages of 30 and 59 who spend an average of nearly one night a week on the road. Fifty-nine percent of the respondents were men and 37 percent women. Four percent did not identify themselves by sex. The margin of error could not be scientifically calculated because the survey was not a random sampling. Cornish Hitchcock, of the non-profit watchdog group Aviation Consumer Action Project, said the Zagat survey will be a useful tool in helping consumers choose airlines and hopefully will ``serve as another goad to those (airlines) who are not doing such a good job to improve their performance.''
