DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Invasion of Kuwait Puts Sale of Resort in Limbo
DOC.TEXT: The Iraqi invasion of Kuwait last month has put on hold efforts by the Resolution Trust Corp. to sell the Phoenician Resort in Scottsdale to a branch of the Kuwait government. For months the RTC, the federal agency established to oversee the sale of failed savings and loan associations, had been negotiating with the Kuwait Investment Office in London on the sale of the $260 million-dollar Phoenician resort. ``That's all on hold until the Middle East situation clears up,'' said Kevin Shields, RTC spokesman in Denver. The Kuwaiti office has the right of first refusal for purchasing the Phoenician because it owns 45 percent of it and the Crescent, another hotel in Phoenix. The RTC obtained the remaining 55 percent interest in the hotels in 1989 when federal regulators seized the failing Lincoln Savings & Loan Association, which operated the hotels as subsidiaries. Lincoln was a unit of American Continental Corp. of Phoenix of which financier Charles H. Keating Jr. was chairman. He resigned Aug. 24. Selling the hotels already had been delayed because of the litigation surrounding Keating, as well as an $18.5 million lawsuit filed by McCarthy Western Constructors, prime contractor for the Phoenician. McCarthy says it is owed that much for work it did at the hotel but was not paid. That lawsuit was close to being settled, but Mark Nadeau, a Phoenix attorney representing the hotels for the RTC, said the Persian Gulf crisis complicates the situation because some Kuwaiti money would be needed to pay for the settlement. After Iraq seized Kuwait, several governments, including those of the United States, England and France, froze Kuwaiti investments and assets in their countries to protect them from the Iraqis. The Kuwaiti office is one of several Kuwaiti institutions set up to invest the massive oil profits Kuwait had earned since 1973, when the first Arab oil embargo sent prices soaring. The country now is believed to have about $100 billion in foreign assets and investments around the world, including the Phoenix-area hotels.

DOC.HEAD: Money Funds Rose-Fell $x.xx Billion in Latest Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Interest rate figures reported by Donoghue's Money Fund Report are for week ended Tuesday. All other figures are for the week ended Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: Assets of the nation's 520 money market mutual funds fell $770 million in the latest week, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday. The decline, to $406.55 billion in the seven-day period ended Wednesday, followed a $679.3 million drop in the funds' assets the previous week, according to the Washington-based mutual fund trade group. Fund assets hit an all time high of $408.0 billion in the week ended Aug. 22. The Investment Company Institute said that in the latest week, assets of 255 general purpose funds rose $422.6 million to $143.69 billion, assets of 105 broker-dealer funds dropped $410.9 million to $164.96 billion, and assets of 160 institutional funds fell $781.7 million to $97.90 billion. The seven-day average yield on money market mutual funds fell in the week ended Tuesday to 7.47 percent from 7.48 percent the previous week, according to Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a trade journal based in Holliston, Mass. The 30-day average yield fell to 7.49 percent from 7.50 percent, Donoghue's said. The average maturity of the portfolios held by money funds was 46 days, up from 45 days, Donoghue's said. Separately, the newsletter Bank Rate Monitor said its survey of 100 leading commercial banks, savings and loan associations and savings banks in the nation's 10 largest markets showed the effective annual yield available on money market accounts was unchanged from the previous week at 6.06 percent as of Wednesday. The North Palm Beach, Fla.-based newsletter said the effective annual yield available on special savings accounts, called Super NOW accounts, was unchanged at 5.03 percent. Bank Rate Monitor said the effective annual yield was 7.71 percent on six-month certificates of deposit, down from 7.73 the previous week. Yields were 7.85 percent on 1-year CDs, down from 7.87 percent; 7.92 percent on 2{-year CDs, down from 7.94 percent; and 8.05 percent on 5-year CDs, down from 8.06 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Arco Introduces Second Lower-Polluting Fuel
LaserPhoto and Graphic planned
DOC.TEXT: Atlantic Richfield Co. introduced its second less-polluting gasoline Thursday, a premium unleaded it said would burn cleaner and cost less than any competitor's. Arco Chairman Lodwrick M. Cook said the fuel also will help prove his contention that cleaner gasolines, not fuels such as methanol or natural gas, are the best way to meet increasingly tough smog-control laws in Southern California and other areas of heavy air pollution. He said Arco would absorb the extra costs of making the new gas, known as EC (for emission control) Premium, rather than passing them along to dealers in higher wholesale prices. Making the gas will cost a few cents more per gallon. ``What we'd like to think is we'll sell more of it, making up the lower margin in increased market share,'' Cook said. Arco currently has about 15 percent of the market for high-test gas in the five Western states in which it sells gas, he said. The new gasoline, with an octane rating 92, will be sold only in Southern California for the time being. It replaces Arco's old high-test gasoline, the 91 octane Super Unleaded. Arco became the first oil company with a low-emission gasoline in August 1989, when it introduced EC-1, a substitute for the leaded regular used in old cars and trucks. Since then, several other companies have begun selling fuels reformulated to evaporate less easily and burn cleaner. Many of those gasolines, like Arco's EC-Premium, are intended for newer cars that run on unleaded fuel. Examples include Shell SU 2000E, Chevron Supreme Unleaded and Exxon Plus. Arco said tests it conducted with state and regional air-quality officials showed the new fuel would reduce emissions by 86,000 pounds per day. Its EC-1 already has reduced vehicle air pollution by 73 million pounds, Arco said. Cook said it would cost Arco about four cents a gallon more to make the new premium. Arco had raised wholesale prices for the old premium by ``a couple of cents a gallon'' before the Persian Gulf crisis, and believes it can absorb the additional cost without undue damage to profits, he said. The key ingredient in the gas, as in EC-1, is the octane-booster methyl tertiary butyl ether, or MTBE. The oxygen-rich MTBE is used to replace higher polluting octane-enhancers such as lead, benzene or toluene. It's produced at Arco's Carson, Calif., refinery and by Arco's chemical affiliate, assuring Arco a regular supply. A shortage of MTBE, coupled with instability in energy markets, caused Chevron recently to postpone the introduction of its reformulated gas in Houston, Baltimore and Washington. Chevron already had begun selling the fuel in Southern California. Cook said Arco's new gas contains 1.5 percent MTBE, compared to competitors' 1 percent, while polluting components have been reduced. For example, it contains just 1 percent benzene, compared to 2.7 percent benzene in competitors' fuels, he said. Arco, the nation's eighth-largest oil company, sells gas in California, Oregon, Washington, Arizona and Nevada. Its strategy has been to offer the lowest pump prices, something it's accomplished by doing away with credit cards and nearly all full-service pumps. Huge reserves of Alaska crude have also helped that strategy, and came in handy in assuring crude supply when President Bush appealed to oil companies to restrain price increases after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Arco froze its wholesale gas prices for two weeks, longer than any other company. The move reaped goodwill from the public and politicians, a bonanza the company clearly hopes to augment with its new fuels. That response was clear at the news conference Thursday, as Los Angeles Mayor Tom Bradley and regional smog-control officials praised Cook as a farsighted smog-fighter. No oil company has yet introduced a less-polluting substitute for regular unleaded gasoline, by far the most commonly used grade and also the grade in which consumers are most cost-conscious. In an interview Thursday, Cook acknowledged that such a gas would inevitably mean higher pump prices. He said Arco won't market such a fuel until Congress finalizes clean-air standards nationwide and all oil companies will have to market the gasolines. ``It will be four or five years and a $2 billion investment before we can get close,'' Cook said. That investment will have to be borne by the whole industry, he said. While Arco was willing to shoulder ``several millions of dollars'' in development costs on a fuel like EC-Premium, ``we can't take a $2 billion hit all by ourselves.''

DOC.TEXT: The stock market staged a broad retreat Thursday under renewed pressure from rising oil prices and intensified recession worries. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 31.93 to 2,596.29. Declining issues outnumbered advances by more than 9 to 5 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 511 up, 960 down and 490 unchanged. The price of oil climbed as pessimism spread about chances for any early resolution of the crisis in the Persian Gulf. Crude oil futures for October delivery jumped $1.66 a barrel, to $31.43 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. In addition, analysts said buyers were holding back awaiting the Labor Department's report Friday morning on the employment situation for August. The figures are expected to show continued weakness in the economy. Speculation has begun to spread on Wall Street that the data might encourage the Federal Reserve to adopt a more stimulative credit policy in an effort to ease strains on the economy and the banking system. But Wall Streeters are not entirely convinced that long-term interest rates would automatically fall in response to such a move. In fact, some say, rates could rise in that setting if fears increased that the Fed was softening its stand against inflation. That, in turn, would stand to leave the central bank in an even worse policy bind than it has to contend with now. Sluggish August sales figures from leading retailing companies, meanwhile, helped to fan recession fears and induced selling of several retail stocks. The Limited fell 1[ to 15|; Wal-Mart Stores ~ to 27{; Toys R Us } to 23}; Petrie Stores | to 19], and J.C. Penney 1 to 45~. DOC.HEAD: Plans Specialized Satellite TV Network for Security Gaurds
DOC.TEXT: Westcott Communications, an operator of specialized satellite television networks, announced plans Thursday to start up a satellite programming service for security guards. The Professional Security Television Network would be the third offering from the Westcott, which also operates the Automotive Satellite Television Network and the Law Enforcement Television Network. PSTN will broadcast on Tuesdays and Thursdays and will offer about 400 hours of programming per year, chairman Carl Westcott said. Programming will include news briefs and informational and training programs and is expected to begin in the first quarter of 1991, Westcott said. The service would cost $688 a month. ``Our target market is the 2,000 largest companies in America that have a security department, that are interested in their employees' security in internal security and external security,'' Westcott said. Westcott said no satellite has been picked to transmit the the programming and there are no subscribers as yet to the service, which will be introduced to the industry at a security officers' convention in San Francisco Sept. 10. ASTN serves 5,000 subscribers in the automotive industry. LETN, begun in 1989, has 1,800 subscribers in law enforcement agencies across the country.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed in Thin Trading
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: The dollar finished mostly lower in thin trading on the world's currency markets Thursday as speculation mounted over whether the Federal Reserve is poised to nudge interest rates lower. The U.S. currency took its biggest hit against the Japanese yen, falling to an 11-month low, and gave up significant ground against the British pound. Analysts said the market's attention is tuned to the Labor Department's release Friday of unemployment statistics for August on the assumption that the Federal Reserve will respond by pushing interest rates lower to give the economy a boost. The market consensus contends the report will show a gain of between 50,000 to 65,000 jobs on non-farm payrolls. But it is unclear whether a figure within that range would prompt the Fed to take action. The nation's central bank is under considerable pressure to notch rates lower to avert a recession. At the same time, though, lower interest rates could fan inflation as oil price continue to rise. Some speculate the Fed will opt against easing, because of the sagging dollar. ``The dollar is too weak to ease now,'' said Earl Johnson, a vice president at Chicago-based Harris Trust and Savings Bank. The weaker the dollar, the less incentive for foreigners to invest in dollar-denominated securities. Foreign capital is critical to the financing of the nation's budget deficit. The United States has attracted foreign capital in the past by offering higher yields on government securities than those available elsewhere in the industrialized world. But the interest-rate advantage has been narrowed as yields in Europe and Japan have advanced recently. Analysts note that returns on short-term instruments, like three-month Treasury bills, are simply not as alluring as they once were. The pound, meanwhile, was bolstered by anticipation that Britain will join the European exchange rate mechanism at a meeting of European finance ministers in Rome this weekend. The mechanism establishes currency rates for a basket of European Community countries. Despite week-long weakness in the Japanese stock market, the yen has continued to gain ground _ at the expense of the dollar and a number of continental currencies. In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 141.65 Japanese yen from 142.30 yen at Wednesday's close. Later in London, it fell further to 141.05 yen. In New York, the dollar closed at 140.65 yen, down from 141.65 yen on Wednesday. In London, the British pound rose to $1.9075 from $1.8990 late Wednesday. In New York it cost $1.9125 to buy one pound, more expensive than Wednesday's $1.9055. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates included: 1.5560 German marks, down from 1.5580; 1.2975 Swiss francs, up from 1.2940; 5.2135 French francs, down from 5.2180; 1,161.50 Italian lire, down from 1,162.00, and 1.1563 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1525. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Wednesday's rates included: 1.5590 German marks, down from 1.5630; 1.2985 Swiss francs, up from 1.2963; 5.2168 French francs, down from 5.2375; 1.7545 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7607; 1,162.50 Italian lire, down from 1,166.00, and 1.1575 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1532. Gold prices rose worldwide. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, a troy ounce of gold for September delivery added $3.60 a to settle at $389.70. Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $389.85 for a ounce of gold, up $2.65 from Wednesday's 4 p.m. EDT bid. In London, gold traded at a late bid price of $389.50 a troy ounce, up from $387.75 bid late Wednesday. In Zurich, the metal rose to a closing bid of $388.80 from $385.75. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold rose $3.57 to close at a bid $387.59 an ounce. Silver prices also advanced. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.770 a troy ounce, up from $4.735 on Wednesday. In London the metal rose to a late bid price of $4.80 a troy ounce from $4.78.

DOC.HEAD: Franklin Managers Return to Offices after Judge's Ruling
DOC.TEXT: Managers of Franklin Savings Association returned to their offices for the first time in six months Thursday, one day after a federal judge said regulators improperly seized the state's largest thrift. Franklin Chairman Ernest Fleischer and other board members met with officials from the Resolution Trust Corp. at 11 a.m. EDT, the deadline U.S. District Judge Dale E. Saffels had given regulators to return the thrift. ``We waited for a couple minutes and then the order came in from (Office of Thrift Supervision director) Timothy Ryan to return the thrift to us, and that's what they did,'' said John Scowcroft, president of Franklin's holding company. But court action continued. Government attorneys filed a motion shortly after 11 a.m. with the 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Denver, asking for a stay in the judge's order while the government appeals the ruling. Earlier Thursday morning, Saffels had denied a similar request for a stay. The appeals court had taken no action by afternoon. Roger Stanton, the lead attorney for Franklin, said he would be surprised if the appeals court granted a stay. Franklin considered the government's request moot because it was filed after 11 a.m., he said. Scowcroft and Fleische when he was befriended by Perlasca. Ronai says he feels guilty that he never searched for Perlasca after the war to thank him for the phony ``letters of protection'' he issued to Jewish families, or the scraps of food Perlasca delivered to the starving inhabitants of Jewish safe houses that flew the Spanish flag. ``At least he is alive and at last, we are able to talk to each other,'' Ronai said. From October 1944 until January 1945, when Budapest was liberated by Soviet troops, Perlasca masqueraded as a Spanish diplomat and provided sanctuary for an estimated 5,200 Jews facing wholesale slaughter by Hungarian Nazi thugs. He saw a Jewish boy's skull crushed by Nazi rifle butts. He rescued a naked girl from a massacre of hundreds of screaming Jews who were marched out of the Budapest ghetto, shot to death and dumped into the Danube River. He confronted Adolf Eichmann during a train station tug-of-war over young Jewish twins _ and won their release. Stared down by an indignant and unyielding Perlasca, Eichmann told his underlings: ``Let them go. Their time will come, too.'' Eichmann, who engineered Nazi Germany's wartime extermination of 6 million European Jews, was seized by Israeli agents in 1960, convicted by a Jerusalem court of crimes against humanity, and hanged in 1962. ``His time came, too,'' Perlasca said. Incredibly, two former Gestapo officers knocked on Perlasca's door in Padua before Eichmann went on trial, beseeching him to testify as a character witness for the defendant. Perlasca brusquely refused. Unlike Wallenberg, the celebrated Swedish diplomat who saved tens of thousands of Jews in Budapest before he disappeared, Perlasca's exploits were virtually unknown in the United States until very recently. His name appeared occasionally in the Italian and Israeli press. Two years ago, the Yad V'Shem Holocaust Memorial in Jerusalem hailed him as ``Righteous Among the Nations of the World.'' His story was discovered by Miles Lerman, an executive of the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Council, during a visit to Budapest last fall. The council is a federal agency overseeing construction of a privately financed, $147 million Holocaust museum near the National Mall. When it opens in April 1993, Lerman said, its exhibits will include the story of Perlasca's extraordinary acts of courage. ``In this sea of darkness, there were flickers of light from a few people,'' Lerman said. ``There weren't many who cared to step forward while other good people stood idly by and did nothing. But their choices made the difference between life and death. ``In the total darkness of cruelty and indifference, they found that goodness has a power of its own, and they became beacons of light who redeemed mankind,'' he said. Perlasca speaks more modestly of his perilous feats 45 years ago, when he was the Hungarian representative of a Rome-based company that supplied meat to the Italian army. ``I always say, the opportunity makes a thief,'' Perlasca said, speaking through an interpreter. ``My opportunity was there, and I took it. Maybe those who remained silent didn't have the opportunity.''

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Back Above $30 Per Barrel
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices soared over $30 a barrel Thursday, reaching that plateau for the second time since the Persian Gulf crisis as traders bet that supply shortages will develop. Light sweet crude rose throughout a hectic day of trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, closing up $1.66 at $31.43 per barrel for October contracts. At its peak Thursday, oil traded at $31.58. ``The U.S. Energy Department testified yesterday to Congress that they thought there'd be a shortage of oil this winter,'' said Philip L. Dodge, an analyst with Nomura Securities International Inc. ``That was enough to move the markets. Also, there's no sign of peace breaking out in the gulf.'' Oil futures had last traded above $30 per barrel on Aug. 22-24, at one point matching the all-time Merc high of $32.35. Before that surge, the Merc had not seen $30 crude since November 1985. The stock market took a sharp dive Thursday in the face of rising oil prices, with the Dow Jones industrial average falling 31.93 points to 2,596.29. Unleaded gasoline futures also traded higher, up 2.8 cents to 95.07 cents per gallon for October delivery. Analysts partially attributed the increase to a realization that increased crude output by Saudi Arabia and Venezuela will not accommodate most U.S. refineries because it is a more difficult oil to refine. Even though those nations are exceeding temporarily their OPEC production limits to make up for the shortfall caused by the boycott of Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil, petroleum experts fear that refinery capacity in Kuwait cannot be replaced quickly. ``Gasoline is the item to worry about,'' Dodge said. ``It was in relatively short supply going into the crisis. Also, the oil that replaces the Iraqi crude has a lower yield of gasoline. The excess oil that's being made up by the Saudis and the Venezuelans is sour, heavy crude, which is not something the U.S. refineries like to run through their systems.'' Domestic refinery operators prefer light sweet crude, which has less sulfur and costs less to refine. The petroleum markets opened strong on news that an American citizen had been shot in the hand by an Iraqi police officer in Kuwait. The continued tensions in the Middle East kept oil high all day. Prices were also bolstered by bullish markets in Europe, where tight supplies might cut U.S. imports of heating oil, said Brendan Dolan, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ``That's helping (to) fuel the buying for crude right now,'' Dolan said. Home heating oil was up 4.87 cents to 88.24 cents for October delivery. Natural gas for October closed at $1.530 per 1,000 cubic feet, up from $1.514 a day earlier. Later contract months for the petroleum futures were all higher, with oil above $30 per barrel for November and December delivery. Although oil's initial rise above $30 per barrel last month caught futures traders by surprise, one expert said Thursday there was no particular significance to the number. ``Thirty dollars is just a magical number, as $25 was,'' said Thomas C. Lewis, a vice president with Duff & Phelps Inc. in Chicago. ``The next one will be $35.''

DOC.HEAD: Posts Rise in Third-Qtr Profit, Still Looks for Buyout Possibilities
DOC.TEXT: Paramount Communications Inc. is in the market for a merger or acquisition, but has already passed on specific chances to invest in the theme park, recorded music and publishing fields, its chairman said Thursday. Martin S. Davis, who is also chief executive, made the comments as Paramount reported that earnings for its third quarter rose 10.3 percent from a year ago. Improvement in Paramount's publishing operations more than offset a decline in operating income from its entertainment business. Davis has indicated on several occasions that Paramount is interested in making a purchase or arranging a merger in entertainment or publishing. The company made a failed bid for Time Inc. last year but subsequently raised a considerable amount of cash by selling its financial services arm, Associates Corp. of North America, for $3.35 billion last year. Nonetheless, most analysts say they expect Paramount is probably exploring relatively small strategic deals rather than large ones, especially given the depressed condition of the stock market recently. Davis was quoted in a report Thursday by Dow Jones News Service as saying Paramount continues to hold talks with a number of companies he declined to identify regarding a possible merger or acquisition. ``We have looked at specific opportunities to invest in the theme park and recorded music businesses, but we ultimately concluded that the opportunities presented could not achieve an acceptable return on our investment given the acquisition process and growth potential of the companies,'' he was quoted. But he said the company would explore other opportunities in these areas. He also said acquisition candidates in publishing and information services were abandoned because the prices were too high. Jerry Sherman, a spokesman for Paramount, said Davis was in meetings and unavailable for comment, but said the account of Davis' remarks was accurate. For the three months ended July 31, Paramount earned $106.2 million, or 88 cents a share, compared with $96.3 million, or 80 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue for the quarter rose 8.8 percent to $1.04 billion from $951 million a year earlier. The latest results include net interest income of $10.6 million, mainly due to investment of proceeds from the Associates sale. The 1989 results included net interest expense of $32.1 million, a charge of $48.3 million related to Paramount's unsuccessful bid for Time Inc. and $77.8 million in earnings from The Associates. Operating income from publishing rose 11 percent in the quarter to $115.2 million as gains in educational and international publishing sales more than offset lower results from consumer publishing and a flat performance in professional information. But the company said operating income from entertainment dropped 4 percent in the quarter to $55.1 million as gains in television operations were more than offset by declines in motion picture and theater operations and costs associated with the renovation of Madison Square Garden. It noted that the bulk of the profits from domestic distribution of its summer blockbuster ``Ghosts'' will be recorded in the fourth quarter. For the first nine months of its fiscal year, Paramount said it earned $148.6 million, or $1.23 a share, down 36 percent from $231.1 million, or $1.93 a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the nine months rose 11.2 percent to $2.69 billion from $2.42 billion a year earlier. Davis was also quoted as saying the company now expected to be ``at the lower end'' of its earlier forecast of full year earnings of $2.10 to $2.60 a share. Paramount earned $12.21 a share in fiscal 1989 including a onetime gain of $10.05 on the sale of The Associates.

DOC.HEAD: Money Supply Measures Mixed
DOC.TEXT: One measure of the nation's money supply rose and another fell in the week ended Aug. 27, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the measure known as M2 declined to to a seasonally adjusted $3,304.7 billion from $3,305.4 billion the previous week. An even broader measure, M3, rose to a seasonally adjusted $4,091.3 billion from $4,087.4 billion. The narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, fell to a seasonally adjusted $815.4 billion from $817.6 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The annual growth rate in M2 so far this year is 4.2 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The annual growth rate in M3 was 1.9 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 1 percent to 5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3,286.7 billion, a 1.6 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4,075.5 billion, up 0.6 percent, while M1 rose 2.7 percent to an average of $811.1 billion. In other reports: _ The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported commercial and industrial loans at major New York City banks fell $709 million. _ The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $762 million a day in the week ended Wednesday, up from $500 million the previous week. _ The Federal Reserve said net free reserves averaged $217 million in the two weeks ended Wednesday, up from a revised net borrowed reserves of $182 million in the previous two-week period. _ The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $313.3 billion in the two-week period ended Wednesday, down from $313.7 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Goodyear Foresees Layoffs, Economic Downturn
DOC.TEXT: The Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co. said Thursday it will eliminate 1,180 jobs in Europe by mid-1992 in an ongoing restructuring effort that has cut jobs in the United States and Canada. The company also announced it expects to incur an estimated $51 million in after-tax charges in the third quarter to cover restructuring and environmental cleanup costs linked to production sites closed in 1986. In a statement, Goodyear Chairman Tom H. Barrett predicted that competitive forces within the tire industry and higher costs tied to instability in the Middle East create an atmosphere for a general economic downturn the rest of this year and in 1991. Barrett said Goodyear will focus on containing costs while improving the efficiency of North American and European operations. ``These measures are designed to strengthen our core businesses as we continue our focus on improving production efficiencies and the development of high quality products which meet the needs of our customers,'' Barrett said. Company spokesman Walt McClenny said the company has a European workforce of about 20,000. In July, Goodyear reported a loss of $9.4 million in the second quarter due to charges resulting from the restructuring of tire operations and the closing of a roofing systems plant. The loss amounted to 16 cents per share for the quarter ended June 30 compared with a profit of $27.1 million, or 47 cents per share, a year ago. Sales in the quarter rose slightly to $2.87 billion from $2.81 billion. Those results included a charge of $21.4 million, or 37 cents a share, due to restructuring. In the first half, Goodyear earned $11.5 million, or 20 cents per share, on sales of $5.56 billion. That compared with $121.6 million, or $2.11 per share, on sales of $5.45 billion in the first half of 1989. Citing sluggishness in the auto industry and concerns about inventory, Goodyear announced last week its plans to lay off 800 employees at manufacturing plants in Tennessee and Quebec. Goodyear said Aug. 30 that the duration of the layoffs would depend on ``the economy and market demand.'' Valleyfield, Quebec, has Goodyear's largest Canadian plant. The temporary layoffs of 530 workers follow Goodyear's recent announcement of plans to lay off 360 workers there by year's end because the plant is discontinuing production of medium- and heavy-duty truck tires. In June, Goodyear revealed a plan to eliminate 1,100 jobs and take a $35 million charge in the second quarter as part of a restructuring of its U.S. tire sales and support staff. Those job cuts were to be phased in through layoffs and early retirements.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Nears $390 As Rebound Continues
DOC.TEXT: Gold neared $390 an ounce Thursday, the third straight day of rising prices as the market continued its recovery from last week's collapse. But unlike last month's explosive rally, analysts said gold's current strength appeared to reflect investor concerns about the economy rather than knee-jerk reactions to Persian Gulf developments. On other markets, oil prices soared following reports that Iraqi police shot an American civilian in the hand in occupied Kuwait; grains and soybeans advanced; and livestock and meat futures were mostly higher. Gold futures settled $3.20 to $3.60 higher on New York's Commodity Exchange with the contract for spot delivery up $3.60 at $389.70 a troy ounce. The heavily traded December contract settled at $396.20. Silver futures settled 3.3 cents to 3.7 cents higher with September at $4.77 a troy ounce. Spot gold has climbed $7.40 an ounce this week after plunging $32.70 last week amid perceptions that the U.S.-Iraq confrontation was cooling down. Heightened tensions in the Gulf this week have provided support for gold but investors seem to be responding more to economic news, especially inflation signals, said Stephen W. Platt, an analyst who follows the precious metal and oil markets for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Gold is often considered an investment hedge against inflation. Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan told the Senate banking committee Wednesday it could take several years to reduce the U.S. inflation rate. Platt said that remark apparently sparked some of the demand for gold. ``It appears that in this point in time, the monetary authorities have given up on trying to contain inflationary pressures in the U.S. economy and appear to be focusing on how to limit any kind of recessionary tendency that might be popping up,'' he said. Oil prices rose sharply for the fifth straight day on the New York Mercantile Exchange as traders responded to the Middle East developments and to Wednesday's weekly American Petroleum Institute inventory report, which showed a larger-than-expected drop last week in U.S. supplies of crude oil. Light sweet crude oil futures settled 64 cents to $1.66 higher with October at $31.43 a barrel; heating oil was 1.85 cents to 4.87 cents higher with October at 88.24 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 2.75 cents to 3.38 cents higher with October at 95.07 cents a gallon. Grain and soybean futures settled mostly higher on the Chicago Board of Trade amid expectations of more sales of U.S. grain to the Soviet Union. The soybean market drew further support from reports that hot, dry weather has begun to stress soybeans in Nebraska as well as in the Mississippi Delta region, which has been unusually dry all summer, analysts said. Speculation continued to mount that the United States will grant credit to the Soviet Union for purchases of agricultural commodities, said William Biedermann, director of research with Allendale Inc., a futures brokerage in Crystal Lake, Ill. Wheat futures settled 1} cents to 2} cents higher with September at $2.65} a bushel; corn was \ cent lower to 1} cents higher with September at $2.43 a bushel; oats were 1{ cents to 2{ cents higher with September at $1.11\ a bushel; soybeans were { cent lower to 5{ cents higher with September at $6.17\ a bushel. On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, cattle futures were boosted by higher cash steer prices and active retail beef movement. Near-term hog futures also advanced but the deferred contracts settled lower amid expectations that hog marketings will increase next week when cooler weather is expected in the Midwest. Live cattle futures settled .03 cent to .55 cent higher with October at 77.82 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .02 cent lower to .30 cent higher with September at 87 cents a pound; live hogs were .22 cent lower to .08 cent higher with October at 49.35 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .82 cent to 1 cent higher with February at 52.05 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Extends Asbestos Trust Payment Freeze
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Thursday extended a freeze on payments to asbestos victims by the Manville trust for one month to complete a restructuring plan for the fund. U.S. District Judge Jack B. Weinstein said more time was needed to ``work out the details'' of a court order to rehabilitate the finances of the trust, which has run out of money to pay tens of thousands of new asbestos health claims. It was the second month-long extension by Weinstein. The freeze applies to paying all claims or court judgments made since the first order in August or until the new Oct. 6 expiration date. The trust was created in 1988 as part of Manville Corp.'s bankruptcy court reorganization, which was forced by mounting liability for lung cancer and other serious and fatal diseases caused by asbestos. Leon Silverman, a New York attorney appointed by Weinstein as a special adviser to restructure the trust, said negotiations were continuing on completing a reorganization plan. Under the freeze, the trust is permitted to make payments for hardship claims and emergency health needs, as well as operating expenses, legal fees of trust attorneys and Silverman's fees. The trust to date has settled close to 24,000 claims for more than $1 billion from people made sick inhaling asbestos fibers, mostly during shipbuilding and other construction. About a third of that money has gone toward lawyers' fees. The trust faces 130,000 more claims it can't meet. The reorganization order came after the trust said it was out of money to pay new claims it said would not be met until well into the 21st century. The reorganization is designed to speed payments and alter the compensation scheme to process claims based on victims' health and financial need rather than when they file a claim. The trust effectively owns 80 percent of Denver-based Manville, which must make annual payments to the trust beginning next year and is shielded from further legal liability for asbestos claims. The cash shortage at the trust had been anticipated, but made worse by more cases, larger payouts and quicker settlements than expected. Victims had received an average of $43,000 per claim, compared with estimates of $25,000.

DOC.HEAD: Contributions Few for Mideast Effort, Except From Saudis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates in top 7 grafs with Saudi action, picking up in 7th graf pvs, Neither the. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: While Saddam Hussein has given new urgency to an old debate over whether America's friends should bear more of the burden for defending democracy, the response from most allies in the current crisis has been far from overwhelming. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady is on an 18,500-mile odyssey that has taken him from Europe to Asia in search of economic assistance, while Secretary of State James A. Baker III launched his own Middle East fund-raising mission Thursday in the Saudi Arabian capital of Jiddah. The two Cabinet members are seeking aid to defray the high cost of keeping a protective U.S. military shield on the Saudi-Kuwaiti border. Back at home, a third Cabinet officer, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, was keeping the verbal pressure on, declaring in a speech, ``We need to have some of our friends step up to the counter and contribute more than some of them have indicated that they are prepared to contribute.'' Shortly after Baker arrived, Saudi Arabia said it would commit several billion dollars toward the cost of defending the kingdom's oil fields. And, following meetings earlier this week in Paris and London, Brady insisted he was getting strong words of encouragement, especially from British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. But while the words have been effusive, the flow of money from most countries has not. Neither the French nor the British committed to specific dollar amounts and officials of the 12-nation European Community were scheduled to take up the question of increased assistance at a meeting Friday. While one official traveling with Brady on the flight from London to Seoul said it would not be unreasonable for the allies to pick up the entire $1 billion monthly cost of the U.S. troop buildup, that statement was viewed more as a negotiating ploy than a reasonable expectation of the outcome. For one thing, the Brady delegation faced an even harder sell in meetings Friday with South Korean President Roh Tae-woo and Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu. The administration is turning to the two economic powerhouses in Asia for support since both nations depend heavily on Middle Eastern oil. Japan has pledged $1 billion to support the troop buildup, but did so only after Bush made a personal call to Kaifu. The administration says privately what critics in Congress are saying openly _ that Japan should do much more, given the size of its economy. The current debate has echoes that reach back to the height of the Cold War, when critics contended that America's huge military burden was diverting resources from critical areas such as making the investments needed to boost productivity. Japan and other countries without large military obligations were getting a free ride, the argument went, allowing them to make the enormous investments needed to complete effectively in the world marketplace. In dispatching Brady and Bush on their money missions, President Bush declared that the ``shape of the post-Cold War world'' was at stake in the Persian Gulf crisis. What he left unsaid was that America, hobbled by a sluggish economy and a huge mountain of debt, can no longer afford to go it alone. But officials traveling with Brady insist that the fund-raising effort would make sense even if the administration weren't bedeviled by the mammoth budget deficit. They note that when the European Community dismantles its economic barriers in 1992, the combined economies of its dozen members will equal America's $5 trillion annual gross national product. Meanwhile, Japan's exploding GNP could well surpass that of the United States by the end of this decade. ``We live in a changing world, whether there is a budget deficit or not,'' said one senior official traveling with Brady who spoke on condition that he not be named. ``In that changed world, we Americans have a right to expect that the burdens will be shared more appropriately.'' Despite the lukewarm public response from countries being targeted for aid, other forces could prod the allies to do more. For one thing, Japan risks triggering an avalanche of resentment in its biggest foreign market unless it pays a bigger share. In addition, there is a belief that the allies cannot afford to waver in this effort, given the threat posed by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. Both the Brady and Baker missions were designed as highly visible campaigns to demonstrate that the allies are a united force, thus raising the stakes considerably if there is a perceived failure. ``One of the most important audiences for this whole thing is Saddam Hussein,'' said another official on Brady's plane who spoke on background. ``We need to let him see that this is not one country or a couple of countries, but it really is the whole world.''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Martin Crutsinger has covered economic issues for The Associated Press in Washington since 1984.

DOC.HEAD: Blanchard Satisfied with HOST Rating
DOC.TEXT: Top Michigan officials expressed satisfaction Thursday with the credit ratings given a new program designed to help young couples save for the down payments for their first homes. Gov. James Blanchard said Michigan got the highest credit rating possible for short-term bonds to be sold under the Home Ownership Savings Trust. The ratings for long-term bonds in the HOST program parallel Michigan's overall bond rating and are just one notch below the highest, said state Treasurer Robert Bowman. Both said the interest rates reflect the evaluation of Michigan's financial strength, especially when compared to other areas of the nation, which are slumping. The HOST program guarantees money invested in it will grow at least as fast as housing inflation in Michigan. Moody's Investors Service rated the short-term bonds MIG-1 and Standard & Poor's Corp. gave them a SP-1 rating, officials said. Long-term features of the HOST program _ for investments lasting more than about a year _ will carry an AA rating from Standard & Poor's, A-1 from Moody's and AA from Fitch Investors Service. Acquiring a credit rating was needed to market the HOST bonds, which will go on sale shortly, officials said. Under the program, investors can buy the general obligation bonds with monthly payments, a lump sum, or a combination of both for up to five years. The investors estimate how much they'll need for a down payment and a payment schedule is set based on that. The minimum savings plan would require payments of $50 a month, Bowman said. About 6,000 people have expressed interest in the tax-free HOST investments so far, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Polaroid Announces Joint Chinese Venture
DOC.TEXT: Polaroid Corp. said Thursday it would form a joint venture to produce instant cameras, package film and market imaging products in the People's Republic of China. A Polaroid division, Polaroid of Shanghai Ltd., will initially employ 130 people in the joint venture with SMPIC, formerly the Shanghai Motion Picture Co., Polaroid said. SMPIC is a corporation of the Shanghai Light Industry bureau, a branch of the Chinese Ministry of Light Industry. The venture is part of Polaroid's long-term growth strategy to expand the market for instant photography, said I. MacAllister Booth, Polaroid's president and chief executive officer. During this past year, Polaroid opened manufacturing facilities and a retail store in Moscow, founded Polaroid India Inc. and activated Polaroid Oy in Finland, Booth said. ``Now, with the establishment of Polaroid in Shanghai, Polaroid is continuing to develop new market potential,'' he said in a statement. The venture comes slightly more than a year after the Tiananmen Square massacre and the subsequent pullout of some U.S. business interests from the country. Harry Johnson, a Polaroid spokesman, said the project's implementation was slowed in the wake of the crackdown on the student democracy movement in 1989. It was continued after discussions with the U.S. government ``to determine whether the action was appropriate,'' he said. ``A good many questions have been asked.'' Initially, Polaroid of Shanghai will assemble Polaroid Supercolor 635CL instant cameras, the company said. Used extensively in business applications, the camera will retail for about $100. Cameras and film will be marketed to business and industrial markets as well as to China's more than 2,500 street photographers, Polaroid said. Cameras will be assembled beginning later this year at the Shanghai Xian Feng Factory. For the past two years, the factory has been assembling the camera's printed circuit boards for export to Polaroid plants overseas. As part of its effort to introduce instant photography to China, Polaroid will be a sponsor of the 1990 Asian Games beginning in Beijing Sept. 22.

DOC.HEAD: Mack Signs Merger Plan with Renault
DOC.TEXT: Financially troubled Mack Trucks Inc. announced Thursday it has approved an $81 million buyout by Renault Vehicules Industriels SA. Mack said the agreement, which calls for the Paris-based Renault to pay $6.25 a share, was reached earlier in the week. Renault started the week with 44.5 percent of Mack's 29 million shares. On Wednesday, the French firm purchased 4.5 percent more. The French firm hopes to buy the rest of the stock by Sept. 20, said Renault spokesman Bill Catacosinos. The car company has been trying to buy out the Allentown-based firm for several months, saying it was making the offer ``because of the continuing deterioration of the financial condition of Mack'' and the need to restructure the company's debt. Mack lost a record $185.4 million last year and lost $97.2 million in the six months ending June 30. Net sales for the first half of 1990 were $793.9 million, a 22 percent decrease from the $1 billion in sales in the 1989 period. The company's five-year financial plan in July projected a net loss of about $130 million for this year. At the time, Mack officials said they did not expect the company to show a profit before 1992. In the past year, Mack has tried to reduce business costs and conserve cash amid a slowing market for heavy trucks. Mack's financial advisor, BT Securities Corp., called the $6.25 per share offer fair. Mack spokesman James A. Santanasto said Thursday the merger would have no immediate effect on the truck company's employees. ``This just reflects a corporate change,'' he said. Catacosinos said it was too early to predict any changes. ``This is still in the preliminary stages,'' he said. Mack is one of North America's largest producers of heavy-duty diesel trucks. Mack also markets a line of medium-duty diesel trucks throughout North America and parts of Central America, Australia and New Zealand.

DOC.HEAD: Made in America Ad Campaign Gets Tougher
DOC.TEXT: American textile and fiber makers are talking tougher. They have dumped the celebrities who grinned as they flashed the ``Made in U.S.A.'' labels for the cameras in those old buy-American commercials. In a new round of ads that debut this weekend on NBC's telecast of the Miss America Pageant, they show shoppers making excuses for buying imports while workers cart their belongings outside a plant closing for good. In another commercial, a mother explains to her bewildered young son that they are moving because his father's plant shut down. Why did the plant close, the boy asks. ``Because a lot of people are buying clothes made in other countries, not ours,'' Mom replies. Welcome to the sober new world as seen by the Crafted With Pride in U.S.A. Council, a non-profit organization set up in 1984 to encourage sales of U.S.-made clothes and home furnishings, and its ad agency, Warwick Baker & Fiore. Robert E. Swift, executive director of the council, said the group decided on the new approach in reponse to surveys that indicate consumers are growing more concerned about their reduced standard of living. Imported clothing, for instance, accounts for nearly 60 percent of all clothing sales in the United States, he said. But when Americans are asked about imports, he said they usually cite the car market, where foreigners have captured only a one-third share. Swift said he hopes the ads get American consumers to think about what impact imports are having in apparel and furnishings as well. The council estimates that nearly 500,000 jobs have been lost in the U.S. apparel and textile industries since 1980. Swift said the new ads should make consumers aware that job losses and plant shutdowns not only hurt American workers, but hurt the community tax base and their own standard of living. Swift declined to say how much the council would spend over the next year to run the ads on television. But he said the new campaign will start off with more support than the council has spent in launching any earlier campaign. The celebrity campaign that kicked off the council's ``Made in U.S.A.'' campaign in 1985 was useful in calling attention to the quality and value of American-made products, Swift said. While imports' share of the clothes market rose to 59 percent last year from 47 percent in 1985, he said the pace at which the imports' share was rising has slowed considerably.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Worldwide Economic Growth Sluggish
DOC.TEXT: Worldwide economic growth continues to be sluggish, according to a report released Thursday by a business research group. The Conference Board said its composite leading index for 11 of the major industrialized nations is growing at an annual rate of 2 percent, the same rate as three months ago. The latest figure, which projects future economic conditions, predates the Persian Gulf crisis, it noted. ``The recent curtailment of oil supplies and rise in the cost of oil will likely add a depressing influence to the slow growth prospects already shown by the leading indexes for most countries,'' said Geoffrey Moore, director of Columbia University's Center for Business Cycle Research, which compiles the Conference Board's monthly index. The Conference Board, a business-funded research organization, studied the economies of the United States, Canada, West Germany, France, Britain, Italy, Japan, Australia, Taiwan, South Korea and New Zealand. The West German economy grew at the fastest annual pace, 4 percent, while Australia had the worst performance, with a 3 percent annual rate of decline.

DOC.HEAD: Oldsmobile to Offer Warranty on Used Cars
DOC.TEXT: Oldsmobile dealers will offer a warranty and roadside assistance program on used cars by the end of the year, General Motors Corp. officials said Thursday. The program is expected to help Oldsmobile dealers resell cars originally purchased by large fleet buyers, such as rental-car companies. Mercedes-Benz is the only other automaker to offer a special used-car warranty. The Oldsmobile program is an extension of the ``Oldsmobile Edge'' program offered on all new cars sold by the GM division. That program included provisions for return of a new Oldsmobile for credit toward a new one and a roadside assistance program. Oldsmobile General Manager Michael Losh said that during the last year, about 1.2 percent of new Oldsmobiles bought were returned under the ``Oldsmobile Edge'' program. He estimated a 1 percent rate when he announced the program last year. About half of the cars were returned because customers changed their minds about a feature of the vehicle and the other half were returned because of problems with the vehicle, he said. The used-car program _ called ``value rated'' _ covers qualifying 1984-89 cars on Oldsmobile dealer lots, no matter what make, with less than 50,000 miles. Cars qualifying for the warranty must pass a check list similar to one used for every used car on an Oldsmobile dealer's used-car lot. The program should help dealers by offering shoppers lower-priced cars at Oldsmobile dealerships, Losh said. ``It's a way for our dealers to extend our product line,'' he said. The company also will offer a ``value rated plus'' program for Oldsmobiles from the 1990 or 1991 model years. That program is aimed at directly helping dealers sell cars that were owned by fleet purchasers, said Roy Pikus, Oldsmobile's direct marketing manager. A cost hasn't been fixed, but Pikus estimated it would be between $200 and $300 and probably would be passed on to the customer through the price of the used car. The Mercedes-Benz program covers only cars made since 1980 by the West German company which have less than 100,000 miles on them. The Mercedes program is also geared toward dealers. Mercedes spokesman A.B. Schuman said Thursday that company research shows that about 62 percent of the 4,000 people who bought used cars under warranty last year were first-time Mercedes buyers, 72 percent said they would buy another Mercedes and 25 percent said they would buy a new Mercedes.

DOC.HEAD: Argentina Supreme Court to Consider Airline Sale to Iberia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with four grafs to UPDATE with Supreme Court taking case; PICK UP third graf pvs, A consortium . . .
DOC.TEXT: The Argentina Supreme Court decided Thursday evening to review the latest legal challenge to the controversial sale of the state-owned carrier Aerolineas Argentinas. Hours earlier, administrative law judge Oscar Garzon Funes ordered the sale suspended because the proposed buyers made the down payment by letter of credit instead of cash. Garzon Funes gave the Public Works Ministry eight days to explain why it accepted the letter of credit, after which he said he would decide whether to annul the sale. The Supreme Court took the case out of Judge Garzon Funes' hands on the grounds that it would be speedier to issue a single, final ruling rather than have the case drag out in appeals courts. Six of the nine justices voted in favor, including all five nominated by President Carlos Menem. A consortium led by Spain's state airline Iberia agreed last July to buy 85 percent of Aerolineas for $260 million and the retirement of $2 billion of Argentina's foreign debt. The down payment of $130 million, due Aug. 21, was paid by letter of credit to the Banco Hispanamericano in New York. Iberia spokesman Margarita Blanco said from Madrid last week that the consortium did not feel obliged to tie up $130 million in cash because the Argentine government had not fulfilled its obligation to obtain a waiver, or approval, from creditor banks. The underlying issue for Argentina, however, is the consortium's financial stability and its intentions for the second largest commercial fleet in Latin America. Opponents of the sale _ including Aerolineas labor unions and nationalist elements of the ruling Peronist Party _ claim the consortium is trying to sell or lease planes to come up with the down payment, and may not intend to invest in the airline as pledged. The vice president of the privatization committee of the lower house of congress, Alberto Natale, last week urged the government of President Carlos Menem to set aside the sale because the consortium did not comply with its agreement. Menem wants to sell Aerolineas and virtually every other company operated by the state as a way to reduce the fiscal deficit and reorient Argentina toward a free market economy. However, even the president indicated he is irritated with how the sale now appears to be stalled. Asked to comment on a Thursday report in the newspaper Clarin that the consortium has requested the government's permission to sell some Aerolineas planes to come up with the down payment, Menem said, ``A maneuver of that kind ... would not be acceptable to the government.''

DOC.HEAD: Greenspan Believes Treasury Proposal Would Have Small Effect
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board told a Senate committee Thursday he believed mortgage interest rates would rise only slightly if the government-backed mortgage-buying corporations were forced to maintain the highest private credit ratings. However, in his letter to Sen. Donald Riegle, D-Mich., chairman of the Banking Committee, Chairman Alan Greenspan did not give a numerical estimate of the likely increase, saying only that studies suggested it would be ``relatively small.'' In follow-up questions to recent Greenspan testimony, Riegle had noted the Treasury's proposal that the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. and the Federal National Mortgage Association be required to win and maintain the best private credit ratings, triple-A ratings, from the private credit rating agencies. Riegle asked for Greenspan's estimate of how much mortgage interest rates would rise if the proposal were adopted. Rates would be expected to rise because the corporations would be required to raise more shareholder capital to win the highest rating. They can operate with less capital now because the credit and capital markets assume the government would not let the corporations fail. In his response, Greenspan said it was unclear how much of the subsidy represented by the implicit government guarantee gets passed along to people who take out mortgages and how much is retained by shareholders of the corporations. But Greenspan noted that prices of shares in the corporations had declined following the Treasury proposal, ``suggesting a sizeable proportion of the subsidy has gone to shareholders.'' Studies suggest the subsidy going to mortgage holders _ which would be lost under the Treasury proposal _ is ``relatively small,'' Greenspan wrote.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Reserve Board Voids Delaware's Bank-Insurance Law
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Reserve Board's order voiding a Delaware law that allows banks to sell insurance nationwide was the result of a turf battle between the central bank and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., banking officials said Thursday. The insurance industry, however, which sought the order by filing a complaint against Citicorp's insurance operation, scored the decision as a major victory. The Delaware law, enacted in May, allows banks incorporated in the state to write insurance policies nationwide through a subsidiary. The Fed on Wednesday said Delaware's law violated federal regulations and ordered Citicorp to close its insurance business in Dover. ``What they're really trying to do is take the authority away from the states and the FDIC in hopes Congress will put them (the Fed) in charge of the banking system. It's all about turf,'' said Philip S. Corwin, director of retail banking for the American Bankers Association in Washington. The Fed's order targeted Family Guardian Life Insurance Co., a company controlled by Citicorp's wholly-owned Citibank of Delaware. The company opened June 1 with plans to hire 500 people. Richard T. Collins, Citibank Delaware vice president, said bank officials were reviewing the order, but the Dover operation had not been closed. When the law was being drafted, the FDIC asked that it include safeguards to protect the banks' capital and deposits. The reserve board said those safeguards were so restrictive they, in effect, barred the banks from the insurance business. Therefore the board ruled the Delaware law violated a federal law that bars a subsidiary or division from engaging in a business which the parent company is barred from engaging in. James B. Watt, president of the Conference of State Bank Supervisors in Washington, said the reserve board was using ``a technical interpretation to prevent something they don't want to happen.'' Corwin and Ellis both said they believed the state was caught in a turf war between the reserve board and the FDIC. ``They put us in a Catch-22 to do all the FDIC wants and basically the federal reserve said because you did such a good job, we're not going to let you do it. That's untenable. Everyone is in amazement,'' Ellis said. He said state officials will meet to determine what Delaware will do next. Gov. Michael N. Castle had no comment. The Fed's order was the result of a petition from a coalition of insurance trade groups to bar Citicorp's insurance business, claiming the law would create unfair competition in the industry. Since 1981, Delaware has enacted several laws aimed at financial services. For instance, in 1981, the state enacted a law offering tax breaks for credit card operations and eliminating interest rate ceilings on credit cards. The purpose was to convince out-of-state banks to move their credit card operations to Delaware. The banking-insurance law was aimed at banks that relocated or opened subsidiaries under the 1981 law.

DOC.HEAD: Fox Network To Be Shown Via Cable TV
DOC.TEXT: Fox Broadcasting Co. announced Thursday it will begin distributing its shows via cable television in markets where it has not been able to sign affiliates. Fox reached an agreement with Denver, Colo.-based TeleCommunications Inc. that could allow it to reach up to 6 million new households, said Jamie Kellner, Fox Broadcasting Co. president. ``It's the beginning of a relationship that will become our delivery system in areas where there are no Fox affiliates,'' he said. Fox is about to expand its three-night prime time programming to five nights in prime time and has scheduled its popular cartoon ``The Simpsons'' against NBC-TV's highly-rated ``The Cosby Show.'' Kellner said Fox had received letters from officials in cities including Dubuque, Iowa requesting Fox programming. ``By . . . extending our programs on a direct cable feed to areas that cannot support another broadcast station we can best satisfy the growing viewer demand for Fox,'' Kellner said.
